There are so, so many things I could say.But I'll never say enough for this book, so here's what I can tell you: I read it in a day. I laughed. I grew furious. Grew happy again. Curled on a small, painful couch and read for hours and hours and hours until my eyes wanted to blur but I wouldn't let them, because I had to finish, I had to. And then they did blur, despite it all, and I cried. Just for a moment.And a few pages later, the book was done.

This book crushed me in the best way possible. At first, I didn't understand what was going on. I just knew that I liked the writing style and the characters, and that I liked the sort of painful feeling that came through the story, haunting but beautifully translated into writing. This story is both dark and joyful. It made me cry and smile, sometimes even laugh. It's a beautiful story of friendship, love, and grief that doesn't spare the readers but still manages to instill in them the desire to live, and to belong. I'm forever grateful that I picked this book up.

LOVED IT! Such a good book. So much emotion, family discovery, friendships, and romance. This book covers everything. I could not put it down. "In my room I lie on my bed, sick to the stomach and I want to cry because my mind is working too much. All I know is that there is something not right. It's in my dreams, it's inside my heart, and without Hannah here, it's an all-consuming feeling of doom"(Marchetta 130). This is an example of beautiful writing Marchetta used throughout the book.
My favorite book in the whole entire world. Have read it more times than I can count and it will never get old.

I keep saying I don’t like contemporary YA but apparently I just haven’t been reading the right YA authors. This was such a unique story. Taylor is a teenager abandoned by her mother and who now lives at a boarding school. The woman who she is most attached to disappears one day and Taylor is desperate to find out where she went. In the meantime, the school is entrenched in territory wars with students from other organizations, including one led by a boy with whom Taylor has a lot of history. Entwined in this narrative are portions of a story written by the missing woman which offer hints of Taylor’s past. I thought the teenagers were written exceptionally well. Sometimes I just don’t feel like YA authors are writing recognizable teenagers. I love teenagers and teach high schoolers and the conversations and humor that Marchetta has created were so authentic. I love the relationships that were built and the realistic portrayal of their emotions. I have already put a library hold on Marchetta’s other books and look forward to picking them up!
Just perfect

A tough slog in the beginning, with talks of territory wars, and a sideline story which felt very disconnected. Eventually, the characters developed, the intrigue built and I was hooked. A real page turner for the second half. Recommend.
it was perfect
This book took a bit of time to get into but then was a real joy ride that I enjoyed a lot. More of 4 and a half for me.

Jellicoe Road is dark and tragic in a hauntingly beautiful way. It is imaginative, poetic, emotional, and masterfully written. It is young adult fiction with very mature themes (e.g. childhood trauma, drug addiction, suicide, and death). The characters are broken down to the core, and from the depths of their vulnerability and resiliency, they find themselves. The first 100 pages of this book is confusing. It feels like fragments of a dream that you can’t quite piece together. Then at about 1/3 of the way through, it suddenly clicks, things start to make sense; you feel the haze lifting, and the dream is actually a nightmare that is as devastating as it is uplifting. I love this book for its mystery, powerful themes, and multi-layered storytelling.
I may have been too young to grasp it when I read it, or perhaps I just had too high expectations for it

i don't remember a lot beyond the general plot but i do remember it was set in Australia, it helped me get some ideas about boarding school internal hierarchies (which was the point of reading it), and every time I see the title I get this song stuck in my head that goes "on the jericho road / there's room for just two / no more and no less / just Jesus and you" only my brain goes "on the jellicoe road" idk why am I like this

This book was comprised of two very different reading experiences for me. The first half was unenjoyable. I was utterly lost and had to continually scan the beginning pages to figure out what Melina was referring to. It took alot of self control not to stop reading and go onto something else. Then the second half of the book happened. Finally I understood what was going on and began to enjoy the novel. I just wish things were a bit clearer in the beginning.
I had a bit of trouble getting into this book at first but once I dived in!! Let me tell you I could not stop falling in love with the characters, especially Griggs!
holy shit I read this in one sitting on a plane,,,,holy shit

I don’t recommend this book especially if you have a hard time following along. There were too many characters and while in the end it all came together it was not worth my time especially because all the events seemed insignificant, almost like page fillers. It was also quite confusing at times, dark and stressed me out a lot. I would compare it to a mixture of Riverdale, Legacies, The Bride to Teribithia, and the Outsiders. I felt like I was reading a book forced upon me by an English teacher. Lastly I don’t feel that I took much away from this book other than anger because I could have read a way better book. And what was with ALL THE WEIRD CHARACTER NAMES???
My god I'm so glad I held out on this one. The first half was so slow, but then it all started to make sense and ended up being more profound than I thought it would be.

I have read this book about 5 times and each time I finish it in one sitting. I love the interweaving of the story of Taylor with Narni's story and how the history of the Jelicoe road is formed by the writings. This also makes re-reading the book very rewarding since you pick up nuances and small points that you didn't that first time you read it.

This story has layers and complexity and is just like a puzzle. Melina Marchetta wrote this book wonderfully—the way the book ended in full circle is brilliant and absolutely beautiful. The characters have depth and their voices are unique. I read this book once and immediately re-read it the day after, as, although the layers and complexity of this book make it captivating, it also makes it a bit difficult to piece things together and remember everything. Reading it again makes me appreciate everything this book has to offer so much more. The first section of the book is a bit difficult to swallow, even for the second time reading it, with confusing details that barely make sense, but they got better, and the confusing-ness really reflects the thought process of Taylor Markham, the main character. That being said, I don't love the plot as much as I loved the writing. Things got confusing or weird or dramatic at times, but I enjoyed this book for the puzzle it is and for its characters and the way things are set up. Overall, I spent one month reading and reflecting on and fully comprehending this book, and I'm glad I did.

I'm not usually the kind of reader who will press on even when I'm incredibly confused, but Jellicoe Road is special for some reason. I had no idea what was happening for at least the first third, and I loved it to bits anyway. And once things do become clear...well, it's a masterwork.

This book was heart wrenching. It also tried way too hard to throw plot twists at you, so it made everything vague and hard to follow so that it could surprise you. It was beautifully written and was very compelling, clearly because I couldn't put it down.

This book was a hard read. It took me about 200 pages to get into, and I barely understood what was going on plot wise until then. There's so little description of scenery and even characters, that at times it felt like I was reading a script for a film. However, I did like the characters, found the story interesting enough, and I cried at the end. I'm also cutting it some slack as I started a new job almost at the time I started reading it, and I was so exhausted for the first few weeks, that I barely had the energy to read, let alone understand a kind of complicated narrative. So that's why I'm giving it three stars instead of two.

I didn't think I would love this book this much, but I do. Can't wait to buy a physical copy and read it again I love each and every character and I already miss them 🥺Definitely a book everyone should read! In the beginning it might be really confusing but hang on that everything will make sense
This is the best book I have ever read. By far my absolute favourite.
I gave it a good try and read more than half of it. I just couldn’t get into it. I listened on audible and it just didn’t seem to go anywhere so I gave up and returned it.

I feel very left out for not enjoying this book… The first 200 pages are about these territory wars between kids that make little to no sense. This isn’t really the main plotline so I have no idea why this was such a huge part of the novel. The last two hundred pages get better in that you get some answers about Taylor’s past and family, but you figure it out on your own and then you still have another 100+ pages to get through. Like this book won the Printz award in 2009? Maybe I would have enjoyed it more if I read it back then/when I was younger.

After reading so many positive reviews, I bought this for my teenaged granddaughter and only then read it. I should have read it first. The first half of the book was so hard to follow, I would have set it aside had I not been determined to see if it lived up to the glowing reviews. The story has real potential, but the execution is rambling. The story is nearly unrelentingly dark, but a dark novel with a compelling, well-told story is worth the journey. This one left me with a bad taste and a sense of wasted reading hours. What I like about it is that the book attracts avid fans. So one day I will look forward to a conversation with my granddaughter about it. Her perspective may make me decide to re-read it, with new eyes.

Heartbreaking, beautiful written , would read more of this author’s work Taylor was insufferable for a good chunk of the book, and it’s nice that even her potiential(spoiler eventual love interest/boyfriend ?) called her out on it , but it was actually albeit just as irritating to read, but sometimes more justified than ALL CAPS Harry in the order of the phoniex book(this coming from a life long/ forever hp fan of fandom as a positive and life changing thing for millions ).

This is one of the most incredible books written by anyone, ever. I have been reading since I was three. I own thousands of books and have read thousands more in every genre imaginable and there is nothing like this one, anywhere. I wish I could buy a copy for everyone in the world so we could all have our hearts strengthened by these characters and the love and grit and sheer stubborn life of the words on these pages. I will be rereading this book for the rest of my life.I now have the kindle and the audiobook, and huge shoutout for the narrator, Rebecca Macaulay, I’m so glad she has an Australian accent and manages to tell this story so well.
A book in which a serial killer and five arsonists are just mentioned casually is pretty hardcore.Wonderfully written, expertly woven.
broke my heart
marchetta really went for the jugular on this onealso jonah griggs please date me challenge

This book destroyed me in the best way possible. I loved the characters and the character development, as well as the overall plot. The twists with the older generation of characters (Jude, Fitz, Narnie, Webb, and Tate) had me flying through this book to see what happened next. Absolutely beautiful.
FUCK YEAH!!!!!

I did NOT expect to love this book so much. I bought it on a whim and based off one quote I had seen from it. But boy was I not disappointed, this book had me crying at the end. Such a heartfelt story with past and present views that make you ache to read more and more. Taylor and Jonah>>> and then the story of the 5 that created the territory wars was such a unique twist. I do admit that the beginning was so confusing and it does not give you a lot to work with, just put straight in the middle of Taylors life. But keep reading, it gets so much better!!!!
If you want the biggest book hangover of your life, read this.

Just kinda meh. Confusing introduction where I wasn’t sure what was real and what was a dream she had. I didn’t feel a strong connection to anyone either, unfortunately. The terf war was also confusing. A lot of it didn’t make sense set up wise until over 100 pages in. Would have enjoyed a better, clear picture of the setting and characters to like it more.
*4.5/5 stars*

It took me a little while to get into this one, but I kept going because I adore Melina Marchetta and she's an author I trust. I'm glad I stuck with it. This novella was tragic most of the way through and my heart just broke and broke and broke for poor Taylor and the characters around her. I found the mysteries compelling (although I solved them faster than some of the characters did, I think) and the characters seemed realistic and interesting throughout. It's a bit of a classic coming-of-age type of novel but I don't mind that. There's a cute romance. Overall it is lacking in diversity. But generally speaking, I enjoyed this novel. Not one of Marchetta's best but in the end I still think she's a genius author who can do no wrong.
Fast-paced read that is a little adult themed and very sad. A little unbelievable but not enough to ruin it. Overall, fun to read.

Wow, this book was all kinds of confusing! Too many plot lines going on, so I was really lost in the beginning. Things came together in the end, but I literally had to write down who was related to who, just to keep my head from spinning. Sad, depressing, heartbreaking…it was ok, but just wasn’t my cup of tea. (Also, why do such terrible things always happen at/near boarding schools?? Sending my kids to one would be a big NOPE. 😂)
Get through the first quarter of the book and the rest is quite good.
I think I would give this a 3.5 maybe a 4
this book drained my tear ducts
5/5this book was perfect from start to finish.it's literally perfect.

This book took me by surprise. First, it’s been on my TBR for ~6 years. I’m glad I finally read it but damn... that hurt. Glad it lived up to the hype from people I know!The blurb doesn’t really give away much so I felt like I went in blind. I’d sell this as a young adult coming-of-age story overall. There’s a bit of romance but I found the mystery aspect the best part along with the stories of the two generations. This is a sad and beautiful story that will stay with me for a while.Gave it 4 stars instead of 5 since I initially had issues with the writing. The first 1/3 of the book felt like a slow set-up I could do away with but it got so much better after as things started unraveling. A few things also didn’t age well in this book haha (it was first published in 2006!)

Can't recommend this book more. Just read it again for the 6/7/8th time and I still tear up every time. The way she writes broken people with emotions and wonder just kills me. One of my favourite books, from my favourite author!
This is one of my favourite books. Great characters, great story, beautifully written, it is joyful and heartbreaking yet life-affirming. Everyone should read this book.
bel you’re sick. i am not fine
bels going to hell

I can see why people love this book BUT it wasn’t for me- I didn’t click with any characters, and it seemed to drag on for a LONG time.I will say that once the twists and story lines start to make sense to the reader, it becomes a lot better to read - but would I read it again? Probably not.ALSO, it did make me cry for the last couple of pages, so there’s that.I generally just didn’t enjoy the writing style- I feel like the plot is good, and if it was written differently with the same plot and twists, I would like it a lot better.

These kids have gone through way serious shit that have been swept under the rug. One admittedly goes to a counsellor which is a good thing, but for the love of all things sacred, let the other characters have therapy too. The amount of trauma that they have endured should not be so easily solved by Love and Friendship anymore. Brownie points for shedding light on teen trauma, minus points for the cheesy execution.This thing isnt going to fly if it was published in the 2020s.

i absolutely love it when the main character is a raging cunt whos just a bitch to everyone so of course taylor my ride or die <3333 like i genuinely enjoy reading this kinda dynamic but only when it done on purpose not them just annoying af u know :) loved hers and griggs relationship 😻 although i do wish it was more of a slow burn like the tension at the beginning !!! when he pinned her to the wall 😦 but i think with the way the story went it made sense tho i would kill for a similar story but instead of all the mummy drama it just about the whole territory war like listen to this leaders of rival teams who once ran away together 3 years before and the girl thinks he betrayed her but he never did, she saved his life without even knowing and he called and wrote to her for a whole year and they know all the bad parts of each other so the tension is high because they know how to get to each other😝😝like they had it all!! i really liked how the book was written but i was hella confused at the start like u kinda just get thrown in and r expected to know what going on like i deadass thought they were in a real war for sec and then this side-story just pops up and ur like who the fuck r these randos hello?? but once u get it and it all starts adding up you appreciate it so much more. one thing that really pissed me off tho was the pacing of the book and how it would just cut to something else like like there was this part where griggs was like that day at the train station when i met u i lied i wasn’t going to visit my mum i went there kill myself and then chapter ended and then next chapter was back to the war negotiating like wait a minute go back GO BACK!! i would like to know what happened next u can’t just leave it at that 😕 again would kill for a book with this kinda of group dynamic because i love them but it was so sudden like hey we besties now after being you know at war with one another i think the whole mum and hannah business overshadowed this whole part of the story so it felt rushed so a similar book focused on the development of the group and their friendship is a need 😄🤲
I will be thinking about this for the next 3 days or so.

I really enjoyed this book, though I did find it harder to get myself into than Looking for Alibrandi or Saving Francesca, however from the halfway point I was unable to put it down. Another thoroughly enjoyable book from Melina Marchetta.
Great.
If I would have read this in high school or early college, it would have absolutely blown me away. Just beautiful.
I’m a sobby mess right now. I wish I’d read this sooner!

i figured out most everything at 50% but then proceeded to cry all the way through the last 20% lmao i miss the christine who was so adamant about never cryingsept 20th - LOL I bought a copy of this book from thriftbooks bc I literally couldn't find it elsewhere and this whole thing was annotated IN BLUE INK I am DYING on one hand this is so cool on the other, What

This was everything I hoped it would be! I was looking for something heartbreaking and full of love and friendship and also uplifting and this was exactly what I needed. There's nothing like a story about teenagers (and also some people in their thirties like me) to make you feel all the feels. Precious.
was very confused at the beginning of this book but ended up crying my guts out.

“Who are they?” the Cadet sitting next to him asked.Jude looked at Webb’s face, the grin stretching from ear to ear.“They’re my best friends. I’m going to know them until the day I die.”this book is my religion and has been since i was 13.----------rereading my absolute favourite classics (i'm on my fitzgerald and austen binge reread because they were the only ones who made me feel anything when i was young) and books that destroyed 14 year old me seems to be the theme of july and i am not giving up!!i don't understand folks who love summer more than anything. the only thing i feel these months is crippling nostalgia and sadness at 4pm.
i've read it twice in one week, i think that sums it up

I’ve read this book first in 2010, and have since reread it many times whenever I’m looking for comfort. It always manages to make me cry. Exquisite young adult fiction. My only gripe is that the narrative of the five kids (Hannah’s manuscript) is difficult to piece together and not as easy to connect with as Taylor’s voice. Still, one of my favourite reads.

I haven’t read a book this quickly in a while. Fantastic book with a chaotic, yet interesting plot. I cried all the way through. I’m only giving it two stars rather than five, because of the constant racist remarks throughout the book. They made me extremely uncomfortable, and quite frankly they were just unnecessary. This book was written in the early 2000’s…so we definitely can’t blame it on the time and place in history. Perhaps the author is a racist?

I had no idea what was happening for the first 150 pages so I'm not sure if I enjoyed it.But I'm dedicated to Melina Marchetta so I ended up crying in the last few chapters. Not sure if it's better than Saving Francesca/The Piper's Son/Dalhousie.Probably need a few days to process.

I appreciate the opportunity to explore older Australian YA, which has a very different tone and focus than what we anticipate in YA lit today. This novel, however, did not work for present-me - though I'll admit it probably would have been my jam if I had read it when it came out in 2006. The timeline/narrative shifts were confusing and even when these stories converged, I found my interest waning. I always appreciate the discussion that comes with book club but not my favorite pick.

When the secrets slowly gets unravelled and the intricate puzzle pieces start to fall together, you realise in the heart of it all, this is a love story with so many layers and so many surprises- exactly the kind of YA contemporary I have been looking forever to be so fond of, the kind with a certain air of mystery, tragedy and emotion without being so overly dramatic.

Interesting story, I honestly was confused as a book reader for part of it. Prob because I feel asleep while listening to audiobook and got lost on friend groups. Character development created an interesting story.
my favourite book ever. can read and reread endlessly. the characters and the unravelling of the storyline is effortless and beautiful.

Yes, I was severely confused for half of the book and then I started figuring things out and it was kind of worth the insanity I had to go through. I do love when there are switching storylines and the added suspense that came with it in this novel, especially as things began to make more sense. I felt like the mysteries were easy for me to figure out and that made me feel smart and proud of myself. However, it also made me frustrated at the main character for not piecing it together yet. I definitely became more interested in Taylor’s story but I also needed to know how the other storyline would end. I really liked the sense of deja vu I kept feeling within this book and all the connections that I wasn’t sure about. Even with all the links I made, I feel like I missed so many more and would need to read this multiple more times to really understand what all the author is doing with the different narrative devices she uses. There is a lot of trauma in this book and I’m still confused as to how much fictionalized trauma is a ridiculous amount for me, in context.
will i ever recover from this book? no

3.5 stars. I thought the characters were interesting, and the coming-of-age / mystery / romance / family drama mashup worked for me, but I just found it hard to get into this book. I’d say by the second half / last third I was fully engrossed but until then it was slow going.

I can’t really describe it but this book just has this “Australia-atmosphere“ to it. Ever since I lived in Australia for a while I’ve had this longing for a childhood living there and reading this book now made me a little sad because of that.The beginning was a little confusing to me and I didn’t really get what was going on for the first three or four chapters.Overall it was a good read but I didn’t enjoy it as much as I enjoyed “Looking for Alibrandi“.
A dreamlike, amazing, adventurous ya I've read in a while.
need this in every edition tenks
It was believable, kept me interested, and left me wanting more.

The first 30-50% is just hard to follow until more information is revealed. It’s got a lot of melodrama and definitely feels targeted towards teens, so I rolled my eyes a lot as an adult. I don’t know, maybe the author hit the sweet spot for brain development, but I found it a little insipid.

To be honest, I think I read this book to quickly. I felt like I was always missing something while reading this text, and I'm not sure I necessarily want to re-read it to find out what I missed because it seemed just sad.
I have no idea what is it about this book, but this sticks with me.
3.5 stars
i accidentally deleted all my reread dates & my old reviews :'( but hey i adore this book so much - the characters, the story, the writing - they all mean a whole big lot to me

My Australian stop in the #readtheworld challenge and a beautiful multigenerational love story and bildungsroman.I love the atmosphere, the kids and the development of the story and the mystery and phrases like these: It’s funny how you can forget everything except people loving you. Maybe that’s why humans find it so hard getting over love affairs. It’s not the pain they’re getting over, it’s the love.I laughed and cried and I recommend it fully more for the story than for the setting.

I read the entire book mostly in one sitting except for the last few pages which is a real testament to the quality of the writing and the interest of the plot. I will say that things that you’re supposed to wonder were definitely predictable but I don’t see this as a mystery novel so that doesn’t really matter. Read this if you’re a hopeless romantic and you want to get emotional

There are some books that stay with you for awhile, and this is definitely one of them. This sat on my shelf for years and this year I was finally ready to read it as it was recommended by an editor to learn about good writing and characterisation.It's so wonderfully constructed-- it's like with each chapter, you carefully peel back the layers of the story and something beautiful is revealed underneath. I live for books where you turn the final page and you're like "Wow. That was something." Some readers might begin this story and feel a little confused, but if you persist through that confusion, eventually everything becomes clear and it's VERY worth it.As soon as I was finished, I wanted to read it again! Highly recommend.
One of my favorite YA stories, ever. Have reread this once or twice before, but each time I can feel the characters' emotions so strongly it hurts my heart. Highly highly recommend!

This is a strong character driven YA novel. As many reviewers have mentioned, the beginning is confusing. The story jumps around introducing a developing characters without a clear link between them. If you don’t enjoy character development then the first third of this book will be a slog. However that’s my fiction happy-place, so this held my interest. For those who recognize the real places in the book, the references are evocative. The plot felt over embellished but stayed just shy of farcical. A worthwhile YA read for sure.
I love this book with all my heart and have read it several times.

Marchetta is the master of writing a single line that will cut you in half without warning. She is like a prose ninja. Four stars because the genre isn't my cup of tea, but that is a me problem. The book is fantastic.

Believe me, I tried to like this book, but the lackluster and predictable story made it so difficult. I actually only finished this because I already DNFed two books. It had its good moments, I particularly loved the narrative about the five kids and would've liked it better if the book was actually about them instead lol (it was one of the very few things that pushed me to keep reading this book). I appreciate the good writing and the development of the characters (especially the female MC whose name I already forgot and don't even wanna bother to look up). Also, why do a lot of people like Jonah Griggs so much? Did I miss something?
This book started out so confusing and stupid I decided to not put myself thru it. Didn’t realize it was young adult but thought maybe I’d enjoy it anyway. Nope.
Even though I really enjoyed this book, I’m docking a star because of all the unnecessary secret keeping that goes on throughout. Other than that, just an absolutely lovely book.
forwarding melina marchetta my therapy bills
WHAT THE HELL IS GOING ON???

Everything about this books is perfection. I laughed, cried, yearned. Melina Marchetta’s ability to build friendships and write dialogue if flawless. I put this book off for years not realizing what a disservice I was doing to myself. The idea of found family within her books is golden.
Beautiful painful love story tangled in life.
I loved how Marchetta ties everything together. It's a book that'll make you cry, but ends on a note of hope.
Re-read this 8 years later and mY HEART STILL HURTS
This is one you still think about have you have finished reading...

Bit of a slow burn, and some stuff I struggled to follow (who are these people?), but when it all comes together, wow. The characters are somehow mysterious and familiar. Complex and not. The end is just a beautiful gut punch.
I wish I could give this book a sixth star.

This is a reread from my childhood, and although I normally hate rereading, this had to be done. It didn’t affect me in the same way as it did when I was 13, but it moved me all the same. It talks so beautifully about childhood and growing up and the bonds we form during that time, as well as how easy it is for those same bonds to break during the years due to life’s tragic events. This is a book I’ll want my kids to read when they’re growing up.

This book has everything a coming of age book should have. Heartbreak , romance, love, friendship, self discovery and so much more. I fell in love with this book on every single page and I already want to read it again.
This book was everything to my high school best friends and I. This is god-tier YA fiction!! I remember loving this with all my heart back when I was a teenager.
oh god now that i'm done my friend will finally stop nagging me to read this book i have been liberated as for the book itself melina marchetta you write very well aha <3
I could not get into this story.If you enjoyed it, I am glad. Please continue to support his authors' works.

SO GOOD. I was rlly invested from the beggining...ish,,, so I didnt rlly know what genre it was so the beggining was confusing. I thought these were witches and from the get-go but turns out they're just teens in Australia. Yeah I definitely recommend continuing to read it bc it clears this and other things so well. And the plot points transition smoothly and nothing is forced. Have a good read 😂
Not entirely sure how I feel about this book...Probably happy and sad. It's so very Australian which I love, and a tiny bit mysterious which I also love. I think it gave me book hangover...

Wow. I flew through this book so quickly that I feel like I need to go back and savour it all again. While the beginning of OTJCR is definitely confusing and seems (almost) dystopian, PERSEVERE! After a hundred or so pages it all becomes clear, and you begin to go deeper with the characters & connect with them. It's one of the best YA novels I think I've ever read; it's real and gritty, with flawed characters that don't make all the right choices, but you at least understand why they do what they do.I'm a sucker for good character development, and I do feel like Taylor - and some of the supporting characters to a lesser extent (Jude! Jonah!)- go through quite a bit of change; I love watching as characters learn to open up and let people in. I really liked the 2 timelines, and trying to put together the pieces of the puzzle and figure it out. The more I think about it, the more parallels I can see between the 2 friend groups and their stories. (I love way the 2nd group is kind of a redemption of the 1st, and they come out even stronger). The friendships that are formed are my favourite part, I loved Chaz, Raffy, Jonah!!, and Taylor. Around 60% I did figure out the biggest "reveal", but I was still eager to see how the characters would find out. It's a beautifully written book about broken, hurting people and the friendships that save them. (I'm a sucker for cool friend groups, they made me think of the Marauders in a way).

First, I listened to the Audible version. I don't recommend it. From reading other reviews, I'm not alone in this thinking. This story is SUPER confusing and requires your undivided attention. I had to start it over after reading reviews that told me there were TWO stories being told at the same time. I totally didn't get that in the audiobook.I think I like the premise, but there are things about it that I just thought were pointless-like the territory wars. I still don't understand how that had any bearing on the actual story. It seemed kind of pointless and added to the confusion. The first half of the book is incredibly confusing. When the big reveals comes out half way through, your head starts to get unmuffled, but why do you have to go through half a book of confusion to get there?Not my favorite book.
five stars every time. I will forever love this book and I recommend it to everyone :)

DNF. I tried hard but just couldn’t get past the eaudiobook readers voice and the way she delivered the story. The whole thing was confusing, I had no idea what was going on majority of the time, was definitely not a good one for eaudio. Maybe I’ll give it another go once I can land my hands on the actual book.Dymocks Reading Challenge- a book by an Australian author.

THIS. IS. MY. FAVORITE. BOOK. OF. THE. YEAR.I can't say exactly why this book became a favorite but wow! It's hard to write much of a review because a) I'm crying and b) I don't want to give spoilers. I loved the audiobook so much. It's dreamy.This book jumps back & forth between the present and 15-20 years ago so the audiobook was a bit confusing at the beginning but, as with all good things, it comes together in the end. Again, I don't want to say too much because of spoilers but this book made me laugh, cry, cringe, squeal with excitement - remembering that first love. There are a few mentions of suicide, drug use, sexual abuse but they are all addressed with care and it does add to the story.

This beautiful book is an ode to friendship and longing for a place to call home. Written in a semi-dark atmosphere, the author combines the past, the present and the future, revealing teenagers that only want to belong, to live for one another. Even if it doesn’t make sense in the beginning, the story develops more emotionally towards the end. However, you don’t feel the need to give up reading on it, the story grabs you in a way that you can’t let go. In the end, you are only left with that human emotion through which life goes on. Beautiful book, definitely worth reading!

I am glad this book was recommended to me. I absolutely adore it. The narration was absolutely perfect and I will say that matters a lot in this context. It felt a bit hard to get into at first but it gets way more interesting. The book maintained the intrigue and the Revelation was executed perfectly. The characters are written very well and the concept is executed well, though it took me time to understand everything in the beginning phase but later it turns into an absolute gem. The book balances the different arcs and emotions well. It starts a bit slow but takes on pace when more things are explained and revealed. I don't know how to express how much I love this book. if you feel bored or confused, go back, it's worth the read and the ending makes up for everything. There's foreshadowing that was very well and kept me excited. This one definitely belongs in my most favorite books list.

in honor of today marking a year since I finished reading jellicoe road for the first time I just wanna say USJ😭😭SKS..;@*@*.JH*(HJKK😭 AJ&@*@AJK!AKW. ....!!*.WIA thank you. Jellicoe Road is really a book full of laughter, tears, and a lot of "oh my god's". I don't think i'm ever gonna get tired of this book because it's full of everything I love (small towns, unresolved tension(?), TERRITORY WARS). I'm positive I was part of the majority who were puzzled in the first few chapters and having doubts but everything was making sense once you keep reading on and I couldn't put it down and I thought I was going insane. Rereading jellicoe road made me twice as insane because everything made so much more sense, everything fell into place and the indirect words of fondness between the characters knowing who they were finally directed to made my brain go haywire and made me cheer so hard. This is so messy but please read this book thank you marchetta for your service.Chaz Santangelo i am still in love with you please call me

3.5 stars - Fine, this book was pretty great. It was so hard at first getting into (probably cause I read it for school with a due date in my head) Had some pretty cute romance, but in the end I’d say It was just another one that was just not it for me!
This story broke my heart, made me cry, made me laugh. It also made me fall in love with the characters, especially Jonah. Thank you, Melina Marchetta, for this wonderful story.

And life goes on, which seems kind of strange and cruel when you're watching someone dieThere’s this heavy feeling in my chest. Melina Marchetta did it again, she wrenched my heart. This book was really… something. It started off very confusing, not going to lie, therefore hard to stick to it. Kids talking about House leaders and territory wars and what faction owns what and Taylor’s very difficult personality and my attention span was not having it. It was also hard to differentiate what was a POV, what was a flashback and a dream, it took me until chapter 9, where our protagonist mentions one of the original 5’s name as part of a story she is reading that I realized what was what from whom. And then, Taylor grew on me just like her house girls grew on her and I understood her and where she was coming from and I just could not stop reading. I just needed to know what happened to these 5 kids and I just needed Taylor to get her answers and I needed to know how all their lives were connected. Marchetta has a talent for that, knotting people’s lives in her stories in such a beautiful way. I have so much love for Taylor and Jonah and Raffaela and Chaz and Ben and Jessa even Anson Choi and the Mullet Brothers. It was beautiful to see their friendship bloom. I had the strong need to protect every single one of these characters throughout the whole book.I am in love with the way Marchetta writes emotions, and how strongly you can feel her characters feel them. She also has a talent for presenting you a character who you might not see in a good light at the beginning and instead of giving them this miraculous redemption arc, she explains their reasons and you, without noticing, accept this character, root for them. Fucked up characters doing their best to survive. My kind of book.
i hope one day i find a place where i can belong or long to be like jellicoe road

3.5 StarsThis was a cute little read, albeit a little too middle-grades for me. The writing and plot are both pretty simplistic, which is what keeps this from being 4 or 5 stars. But it’s a good found-family story with a bittersweet ending. I could see my daughter falling in love with this book, maybe when she’s 9 or 10 years old.

  Trigger warnings may include but not limited to: character death, man slaughter, suicide, emotional trauma, physical violence, substance abuse
(hide spoiler)]Oh, how do I even talk about this book? I don't know how to review this because it's that kind of book that you just need to read to know what it's really about. This book put me in a reading slump because I just needed a lot of time to process everything that happened in this book. I can't even decide if this is a quick and easy read or a heavy and hard-to-get-through read. I feel like it's both. It's a quick and easy read because it's so easy to get hooked to the story, and it's also heartwarming to read about the friendship and family dynamics shown in it. Stopped at 29% This was beyond confusing and I wasn’t invested enough in any part of it to try and figure out what was going on. May try again another time, but probably not.
So, so good.

4/5 - I was blown away by the build-up of the storyline and the ending of this book. It was intense and gripped me so much that I almost couldn't believe it was YA fiction. It's a book centred on teenaged characters, but it feels very mature, and a lot of the subject matter is heavy and dark - I don't think I could imagine myself reading this as a teenager. I thought the way the author connected the characters and tied up all the storylines was very elegant. Half the story is written from the main character, Taylor Markham's perspective, while the other half is written in italics. At first it was really difficult to keep the two storylines and numerous characters separate, but at the end, it becomes very clear and every character is significant and has a clear connection to each storyline. I took 1 star away because I thought the "territory war" between the Townies and the Cadets seemed juvenile and out of place. I felt that it wasn't as realistic as it could have been, because the characters seemed so mature, and at the same time they were participating in some odd war game. I wish the plot didn't centre so much on the territory war since it was pretty insignificant near the end. Anyway - if you are a fan of YA fiction and are looking for something that is well-written and mature, I would recommend this one. (CW: (view spoiler)[ drug addiction, suicide, mentions of pedophilia  (hide spoiler)])

Taylor Markham, a teen going to school at the Jellicoe School is chosen to lead the new section of a game between the neighboring groups containing the townies, and the cadets. As she tries to learn and understand her new role as a leader and fight off those intending to vote her out, her past begins to catch up with her. She knows that her friend Hannah knows more about her past than she has let on, but when Hannah goes missing Taylor is left wondering just how much she knows. The leader of the cadets is Jonah, another reminder of her past that she is forced to reconcile. Trying to juggle a pretend war, school, her past, and the sudden vanishment of Hannah leaves Taylor struggling to understand herself and what's important. I found myself relating to Taylor a lot more than I thought I would. Her struggle with her mental health because of her past is relatable and heartwarming. Hannah's story is also being told during the novel, and while I enjoyed it sometimes it took me out of the story that I typically found myself right in the middle of. I was rooting for the main characters the entire time and appreciated how unique tone of voice the author had. ◦ Sexual Abuse◦ Child Neglect◦ Drug Abuse◦ Themes of Suicide

I love Melina Marchetta’s books they fill me with so much emotions and I always yearn to be with the characters or to meet characters like them one day. I just want to to fly away to these characters on Jellicoe Street. Hopefully when I visit Australia one day I will have these characters in mind, with spirit.
