(Looking at other reviews, I don't seem to be alone in this.) The ending is definitely worth the wait.

Taylor is the head of her house at the Jellicoe boarding school and she’s the head of the school in the territory wars between the school, the Townies, and the Cadets. Taylor ran away from school 3 years ago when she was 14 (with one of the Cadets – Jonah Griggs) to try and find her mother who abandoned her at a 7-11 when she was just a little girl. Taylor’s been wondering about her family and her past for as long as she can remember, and this year things come to a head when her guardian, Hannah, disappears for several weeks to take care of some “personal” business, and leaves Taylor alone and frustrated. Taylor and the leaders of the Cadets and Townies become close friends, as the leaders once were back when the territory wars started. And it’s Jonah, again, who accompanies Taylor when she sets off – this time to track down Hannah – in search of the truth.This is really two stories woven together - Hannah’s story about her past, and Taylor’s story about her present. They’re remarkably similar – with young people who come to be friends and then more than friends, who invent and play a game just so they can spend more time together, and who have a shared history. In Hannah’s story, however, there’s a terrible tragedy that affects the lives of all the others and continues to have effects years later. It’s what makes Taylor’s mom turn to drugs so she can forget, what makes her abandon Taylor, what makes Hannah keep a distance from the people she loves, and what eventually brings the survivors back together again. This is all about the friendships forged and the unraveling mystery of Taylor’s and Hannah’s past. I really like Melina Marchetta’s writing, she creates realistic characters and situations and stories with depth.
Okay, so maybe there was another book from 2008 better than Frankie Landau-Banks. To superficially simplify things, that one delighted my head while this one hit me in the gut.
I have been reading a lot of good YA this year, it seems, probably due to Navah's influence. I was hooked from the very first line.

Marchetta captures the complexity of human relationships in a way that is compelling and and memorable.Due to the language and subject matter, this book would be best for mature teens or adults--preferrably to read and discuss together.

An intensely emotional rollercoaster ride of a book.One that starts out a little on the confusing side. There are so many things going on in this book it was hard to keep them straight. There is Taylor Markham, abandoned by her mother when she was 11, her father has never been around and she doesn't know why, her guardian Hannah has left town without telling her, a boy from her past is back in town and getting under her skin. Then there are the territory wars between the townies, the cadets and the students of the Jellico school, a boarding school of which she is their reluctant leader.And then there is the back story which pops up intermitently throughout the book about 5 kids who lived on the Jellicoe Road over 20 years ago, 3 of whom were involved in a terrible accident that killed 5 people. This part confused me at first because I could not figure out how the story of those 5 kids had any relevance at all to the present situation and I kept feeling like I was missing some crucial plot element, but when the pieces start to fall together like pieces in a puzzle it is so worth the wait. Each detail of this story has some relevance and each piece that falls into place is like a revelation. Once things start to come together I had a hard time putting it down and am still thinking about even now.Ultimately this is a book about a girl who is desperate to put together the pieces of her past and find where she belongs. It is a heartbreaking story and yet it is also one of hope and love.There are definitely undertones of some mature subject matter; death, drug addiction, abuse, suicide, and a brief sex scene so I would not recommend it to younger readers or anyone really who would be bothered by that, but definitely a story that made an impression on me.
I loved this one. Completely and totally.
Wonderful, wonderful! I was lying in bed sobbing after I finished this book; partly because of the story, and partly because I was sad it was finished.
I did not want this book to end! I felt like I knew the characters personally and was rooting for each one--even the ones from the past--to find happiness.

Yep everyone right, this one was slightly confusing for the first hundred pages or so. I kept wondering if that was the authors way of creating some mystery because, while I really liked the book, it was pretty obvious what was going on and who was who. I loved the relationships, and since that's primarily what the book was about, I enjoyed it.

A few months ago I predicted on my blog that Paper Towns (2008) would be receiving a nod from the Printz committee at the 2009 awards ceremony. Failing that, I was certain that after nabbing a National Book Award, What I Saw and How I Lied (2008) would take a Printz award/honor.You can therefore imagine my surprise when it was neither of my predicted titles but Melina Marchetta's Jellicoe Road* (2008**) that won the 2009 Printz Award for excellence in young adult literature. Being a fan of Marchetta's previous novels Looking for Alibrandi (1992) and especially Saving Francesca (2005) you can also imagine my embarrassment upon realizing one of my favorite authors had published a new book without my realizing it.The only solution, of course, was to immediately procure a copy from the library and read it as soon as possible.Jellicoe Road is not a novel with one protagonist. Rather, it has many. The story starts on the Jellicoe Road with a tragic accident that will have far reaching repercussions for each character in the novel. Then, abruptly, the story starts again twenty-two years later at the Jellicoe School--the boarding school located farther down the same road--when Taylor Markham is chosen to lead the school's faction in a secret territory war that has spanned a generation between the school boarders, the Townies, and the Cadets.The Jellicoe School is the only real home Taylor has ever known. She has been at the school since she was eleven, when her mother abandoned her on Jellicoe Road and Hannah drove by to pick Taylor up and take her to the school. Now seventeen, Taylor is in many ways still a young girl afraid of being abandoned by those she loves. Which is why, at the start of the story, Taylor balks at the authority thrust upon her and the relationships it will necessitate. Leading the Jellicoe School through the territory wars is bad enough, but being in charge of an entire dorm of students seems truly unbearable. Taylor's resolve to live a life apart is tested, and in many ways broken, with the efforts of well-meaning friends and the appearance of Jonah Griggs--the one person Taylor never expected to see, or need, ever again.As the territory wars escalate, Taylor's life is thrown into disarray with the sudden disappearance of Hannah--the only adult Taylor would come close to calling family. With Hannah gone, Taylor begins reading Hannah's unfinished novel for lack of anything else to cling to. Marchetta weaves Taylor's story and the events of Hannah's novel and even the histories of other characters together to create one haunting narrative where, the more Taylor reads, the more it feels like she is looking not at fictitious characters but at people she has known her entire life.While trying to understand Hannah's sudden absence, Taylor also starts to understand herself. Eventually she realizes that living life at a distance offers no protection from abandonment and provides even fewer options to heal scars from past betrayals.The novel starts with rapid fire narration as Taylor throws out events and names at the reader without any frame of reference. Later in the story the importance of the Cadet, the Hermit, and the Brigadier becomes painfully obvious. But in the first pages the narrative comes closer to painfully confusing and unwieldy. By the end of my reading I had a marker at almost every page to indicated important points and favorite passages. However, if you can roll with the uncertainty, you will be rewarded. At a little over four hundred pages, Marchetta still creates a page-turner that moves quickly and weaves together every single narrative thread by the final page.Because Taylor is not forthcoming with explanations, the novel reads like a mystery (fitting since my two Printz Award predictions were also mysteries of sorts). However a good portion of the story is also simply about friendship and love. Taylor expects neither from her time on the Jellicoe Road even though they might be exactly what she was supposed to find there all along. Marchetta blends moments of humor and gravitas in her unique prose style to create another really great read.* Jellicoe Road was actually originally published, I assume in Marchetta's native Australia, with the title On the Jellicoe Road. For various reasons, upon finishing the novel, I feel that this title is superior to the American edition's shortened version.** The book was originally published, again I assume in Australia, in 2006.*** In addition to the original title being superior, in terms of relevance to the story, the original cover art is also much more apt. (Although I just realized the US cover has a Poppy on it which I will grudgingly admit is actually pretty relevant to the story. It also makes it impossible to pick a cover to feature here so, readers, you get both.)
Had a hard time getting through this. Actually, I didn't. Got about 1/3 of the way. But I'll go back to this one again. I think I just was reading it at a bad time -- very tired.

Somewhere around halfway through Jellicoe Road Aaron asked me what my book was about and I responded, "...I'm still not really sure, actually."I spent the first 3/4 of the book totally puzzled and the last 1/4 bawling because: the love! the tragedy! the bittersweetness of it all!I was really annoyed for the first 150 pages because I don't like books that are all intentionally convoluted only to pull together at the last minute in an attempt to make you say, "Ah yes! Of course. How clever!" But this one pulled together so beautifully that I forgave it and declared my love for it and am now sorrowing that I must return it to the library. But that structure might make it difficult for readers who don't have the patience to wade through the (very long) confusing bits to get to the wonderful bits at the end. If you can make it, though, it's worth it!

Summary: At a boarding school in the Australian bush country, Taylor Markham has been selected as the reluctant leader to represent the school in negotiations with their rivals, the Townies and the Cadets. But when the only adult in her life disappears and Taylor finds out the Cadet leader knows her better than she’d like, will she be able to hold it together and protect her kids from retaliation?Review: When I finished Jellicoe Road, I smiled and set it down on my nightstand. Not 30 seconds later, I picked it back up and started reading it again from the beginning. The last time I did that was with the fourth Harry Potter. Actually, that might be the only other time I’ve ever done that.So yeah, I loved it.This is just from page 2, and there’s more where that came from, I promise. The narrator is talking about having survived a car crash where her parents were driving.Someone asked us later, “Didn’t you wonder why no one came across you sooner?”Did I wonder?When you see your parents zipped up in black body bags on the Jellicoe Road like they’re some kind of garbage, don’t you know?Wonder dies.But don’t take that one snippet to mean this book is all depressing. It’s not at all. It’s heartbreaking, yes, but also hopeful. And funny.This is one of my all-time YA favorites.
Through the use of more tragedy and conflict than any one person is likely to experience in their lives, this book perfectly captures the intensity of being young and in love.
For the first forty pages I was really confused about what was going on. Then it was okay

I found the beginning of this book confusing and hard to get into, but after the first seventy pages or so, it sucked me in and it haunted me for a couple days after I finished. You know a book's written well, when it stays with you like that after you put it down. I just wish the beginning was easier to wade through.
By the end of this book I was really engrossed, but it took awhile. The interaction between the two stories was intriguing.

I can see why this won the Printz award this year. I really really liked this book. I was advised (not by people I know, but by bloggers) to stick with this one, even if the beginning frustrates you beyond all reason. And I was never really frustrated with the book, but I was confused. Especially at the beginning. The book starts out very much like a puzzle and I enjoyed putting the pieces together. There were a few things I had issues with : one, Taylor is hinted at being an unreliable narrator a few times, but it didn't really become an issue in the telling of the story - it wasn't a Catcher in the Rye kind of unreliable narrator sort of situation, but there were a few discrepancies between her story and the stories put forth by other characters. Might have just been me getting my panties in a bunch over nothing. The other thing (and this might be a big thing for some readers) is that I put the pieces together too soon. Before the narrator. In some cases many many pages before the narrator. While I do pride myself on being an expert reader, this bugs me. I feel like I shouldn't know something WAY before the main character does. I should maybe think...could that be? nah, there would have been more hints....not Oh I get it now. Wait....she doesn't? Seriously? So yeah. Other than those two points, I really liked this book. I liked that it was set in Australia, but there wasn't too much crazy slang that threw me off. And I liked the characters and the premise. Intriguing and new. Something different, but yet that dealt with contemporary issues. Two thumbs up.

It's a good read and nicely constructed, but the amount of barely contained emotion in this book made me tired after about 200 pages. The narrative voice is very cool and restrained, so it didn't quite veer off into melodrama, but sometimes I wished there had been more quiet and ordinary things going on in between the characters' intense revelations of family and personal history. And I got skeptical sometimes about all the caring being directed at Taylor. All the right people care about each other and seem much too emotionally fluent for people who have supposedly suffered so much damage throughout their lives. But it's a sweet story, if you're willing to suspend your disbelief a little. And the second to last page did give me chills, a bit.

Had to move on. I kept putting it down and picking it up again because it won the Printz this year, and the reviewers said it comes together really well. I love complex stories, generally, and want to see how Hannah's story comes together with Taylors. I love the Australian authors, and I loved Marchetta's Saving Francesca. So, this has a lot going for it, but I think I'm just not in the mood right now. Recommended for high school.

Although I really liked the last 1/4 of the book, it took me a long time to get into this book. I am sure I missed a lot of stuff at the beginning because I was confused. Perhaps if I read the book again I would like it more. I don't know many teens who would stick with this book...I think many would start it and never finish it. I'll have to read more reviews to figure out why it won the Printz!

Taylor Markham is a leader in a dorm in rural Australia where she plots little wars against the military cadets and townies who all share common territory around their schools. A simple teen story about growing up, family, friendships and first love runs parallel to the real tragedy and mystery that pervade Taylor’s world. We care and worry about her as she seeks to find answers about her mother, father and other family members whose lives were shattered on one sunny day many years before on Jellicoe Road. This is a complex and riveting tale recommended for mature teens and deserving of the Printz award even though I loved The Hunger Games!

The only reason I started reading this book is because it won the Printz Award for young adult literature. I had never even heard of the book when it won, but I moved it to the top of my "to read" list. I only finished the book because a fellow librarian told me "keep going, it's worth it." Most books that have a hook like this one, "My father took 132 minutes to die. I counted," keep you hooked, but the marvel of this book is in my ever changing experience as a reader. One page one I was hooked (if not a little disturbed by the subject matter). By page fifty I was bored and confused. By page 100 I was ready to put it down. Thank goodness I didn't. By page 150 I was reeling through it enraptured and excited as I connected the dots and the puzzle pieces slowly came into place. This book is a moving depiction of two generations as their lives run in near parallel. Taylor Markham discovers the truths she either never knew or didn't remember and comes to realizations about love and relationships. It sounds cheesy and cliche when I put it that way, but really the book is anything but cheesy and cliched. It's a bit hard to put your finger on and I don't want to give anything away so that the puzzle can come together for you, too. I can tell you that you'll find a teenage girl frantically grappling with the past, a relationship fueled as much by dislike as it is by a sense of connectedness and longing, a territory war among three factions and a patch of poppies along the side of the most beautiful road you'll ever see, Jellicoe Road.

Before reading this book I was told to stick with it past the first 200 pages and that it helps to go back and reread parts. I was afraid I would feel somewhat let down after high expectations. I was impressed by the way two stories 18 years apart intersected and had similarities and differences. I actually enjoyed going back and rereading parts after I had finished. It added to the experience of the book. Most of all, this book reminds us that great tragedies, great friendships, great loves, great joy can come from average, everyday situations and people.

Ick, puke. Just what I love to read. . . a book about more self-absorbed, overly introspective, egocentric overdramatic teenaged girls. My social worker and counselor friends almost universally had the same reaction. This art does not resemble real life. Give me some honest portrayals.

The beginning of this book was confusing, because you don't know who the people are and I personally didn't realize we were looking at 2 different time periods etc. Once I started piecing the puzzle together, I had a hard time putting it down. So...for those of you who are having a hard time with this one - just give it a little more time!

For the first several chapters, I was confused about just what was going on in this book. It took some work on my part, like looking back to previous chapters, before I eventually "got it." But the work was worth it, and I couldn't put it down! These characters are so well-drawn. They are real. They are.

This book was nothing like I expected, right from page one.First off, the whole concept of the territory wars made it seem like the book should be some sort of post-apocalyptic tale, but then with all the modern-day cultural references (sparingly) sprinkled in, I realized that it was actually a present-day story.The first half of the book was just a tangle of plot and unexplained relationships, both past and present, and it was very disconcerting to not have much of a clue what was going on. The second half really picked up, and the story started to make a bit of sense and finally at the end, the reward was well worth the wait.If I could rate the book in parts, I'd give the first half about three stars, the next quarter four stars, and the end four and a half to five. I guess that with all the confusion at the beginning, I wasn't AS caught up in the story as I could have been so the payoff at the end wasn't a solid five even though I did really enjoy it.I love stories that weave themselves together, making unrelated strands all have a clear place in the tale by the end. Holes is another really enjoyable example.I'd definitely read more of Melina Marchetta. One side note: I did find it interesting that the US version of this book is just called "Jellicoe Road" instead of "On the Jellicoe Road." I wonder why they bothered to change it? It's like changing Northern Lights to The Golden Compass - whyyy? If anyone is going to understand the Northern Lights reference it would be people in this hemisphere, right? Oh well.Read this if you can have some patience for a giant question-mark beginning, knowing that it will all be worth it. :)

This book took some time to get into (although it has one of the most intriguingly engaging first chapters I've ever encountered which made me keep reading.) Once the book started to pick up steam (I found the early chapters on the battle between the Townies, Cadets, and Jellicoe students kind of tedious) I was thoroughly hooked into the story and just started weeping when I reached the end, partly because the last 100 pages are truly beautiful, and partly because I was really sad to see the story end.

5Q 3P S“Jellicoe Road” was the surprise winner of the 2009 Michael L. Printz Award. Taylor Markham is the main character in this novel filled with mystery, emotion, tragedy, and love. Taylor must solve the puzzle of her past, and make the necessary connections to the present, in order to ensure her future. All the while she is coping with being head of her boarding school dorm, and finds herself representing her school in the territorial war with the Townies and the Cadets. Further complications ensue when she discovers that the Cadets are lead by Jonah Griggs, another part of her past she can’t seem to leave behind. The truth all comes to light on the Jellicoe Road, “the prettiest road I’ve ever seen…”. Developmentally the book delves into teenage peer relationships, the importance of family and one’s past, and the ultimate need for love and to belong (versus abandonment, etc.). The book is full of mystery, adventure, and surprising twists and turns that have definite young adult appeal. The only problem is that the novel is quite confusing in the beginning, going between Taylor in the present and Hannah’s manuscript of the past. I must admit that it is difficult to get into the novel initially, and I’m not sure if young adults will read far enough into the story to get hooked. I would promote the book with other award winners, taking the opportunity to educate teens on the various awards and honors available to young adult literature.

This book is going to haunt me. So exquisitely painful. And beautifully hopeful. And achingly sad. I couldn't put it down. And now I'll need to read something absolutely mindless and fluffy and stupid in an attempt to get certain images out of my head long enough for me to sleep. But even if that doesn't work, it was worth it!

I have had this book for a week and I am only on Chapter 3. It's sort of painful right now and I am considering ditching it. Someone, tell me if I should keep going.Ok so now I'm done and although I can't say anything negative about it (interesting characters, exciting and surprising plot, original setting) I just wasn't wowed personally. I think it was all the territory wars, which I tried really hard to care about since it made sense to me why territory was so important to these kids, but I just couldn't care enough. It's akin to how I feel about the game Risk. I appreciate the game and understand why it's so popular, but do I want to play? Not really.I will be recommending this book a lot, though. I think it will rock a lot of folks' socks.
Although slow to begin, I found myself invested in the lives of Taylor and her 'family'.

I'm a sucker for books with links to the past, strong bonds of family and friendship, and hope intermingled with tragedy. Jellicoe Road has it all- I cried, I laughed, I cried some more. The satisfaction I had at the end reminded me how I felt when reading Harry Potter and all the pieces about his parents, Syrius, and the Marauders Map came together... I love that!
Eh

Todos los personajes tienen una construcción similar, pues se encuentran en una misma situación. No he logrado empatizar con ninguno de ellos.La autora escribe bonito y con delicadeza, logrando que el lector avance en su lectura con fluidez. Además, alternar entre pasado y presente aporta un ritmo más ágil.No recurre a excesivas descripciones, pero sí aporta datos de la trama que poco a poco irán conectando. Además, consigue adentrarte en el mundo de Taylor y en su mente, a pesar de no lograr conectar con ella. La historia se me ha hecho bastante aburrida, pues tardó mucho en despertar un interés en mí que se volvería a ir rápidamente. Esperaba una historia profunda y ha resultado ser bastante plana para mi gusto.

Esta historia ha sido una decepción.En primer lugar la historia tarda muchísimo en arrancar, tanto que durante los primeros capítulos ni siquiera se sabe muy bien de que te está hablando. Pasas completamente descontextualizada hasta casi la mitad del libro.A la mitad la trama empieza a coger ritmo pero se desvela una historia dramática que para mí no ha tenido mucho interés. He sentido que daba vueltas sobre la misma idea una y otra vez.El final ha sido simple, rápido y nada satisfactorio. Los personajes me han resultado en general bastante irritantes.No me ha gustado, aunque se puede salvar un poco que algunos capítulos de la segunda mitad sí enganchan algo y un pequeño romance que no está mal del todo.

DNF 36%I have really, really great news. I can remove about four books from my TBR. This is the third time I've tried, and the third time I could not give a damn for this author's book. I've said before that outside of romance, I don't need to love/identify with/like my characters. It's really true. I enjoy books where I am completely, utterly separate. I can enjoy author's art without enjoying anything else about the book. And I was detached from this protagonist. She was unlikable. She was detached. And sometimes I even love those characters. But Marchetta's words don't make me care about what's happening, they don't have the clarity and the direction for me to invest in the story. And hold on your hats, unpopular opinion, I don't like her writing.*Ducks/deflects things being thrown*Definitely don't take my word on it, and from what I understand the back half of this book is like...magic. But it's too late friends, I don't care, and I don't think an author should get away with writing such a weird, confusing foundation without it being...the point? If it is the point...I should still care? Does this make sense? Probably not. You might want to check other reviews. I just called it because I'm sitting over here with a bored look on my face, actively disliking this book. And yep, after 3 experiences that left me like...oh....kay? I'm won't be reading her again.

An unnecessarily hard to follow, fragmented story tells about a pointless and tedious summerschool wargame - where the one and only "plot twist"(if you can call it such) is amongst the first things you connect early on.It supposed to be a children's/teen's read, but I don't know... If you want to make them to hate reading, there is your perfect pick.

There is definitely something wrong with me because 9 people I follow gave this a 5 star rating, and I've NEVER had that before. I found it confusing and hard to follow- it wasn't that I didn't LIKE the plot, I didnt even fucking understand it. I defo defo defo need to come back to this some day.
DNF this at page 136. No more. I was going to stop at 100 but there’s so many good reviews on it that I tried again today, but I can’t. I have no clue what’s even going on
I gave up on this after 100 pages... Given all the accolades, maybe I can be persuaded to pick it up again in the future when I’m in a different psychological place.
I shouldn't check this as "read" because I couldn't make heads or tails of it and by page 85 I gave up. I was really annoyed that I'd spent that much time on it as it was.
I tried three times to get through this novel, and every time I just could not push through it. I could see it's potential but the characters just don't grab at me enough for me to care. DNF at 50%.

A sickly sweet and totally unrealistic book about what it's like to grow up without parents. We follow 'the lucky' protagonist and peer from a safe distance at the 'sorry' troubled ones that are left behind.

first I thought that it's just a very boring book with weird structure where the events, dreams and pieces of a book-within-the-book are all mixed up. the "territory wars" plot is just a snooze fest, and the MC does now grow as a person at all, she is just overly dramatic and absolutely unrelatable. so, nothing happens in the book except pointless conversations and whining but then the MC kills a cat! WHAT DA FUCK? that was it for me, i'm not even gonna hide it under "spoiler" cut because I think people should know. nobody mentioned it in their reviews, and i'd actually never started it if i knew. an animal's death as a plot device infuriates me beyond imaginable

I spent 60% of this book confused by the characters and the world building. When it finally started to all come together I was so disinterested that the conclusion was just a big “merp”. It’s been on my TBR for ever so I’m glad I finally read it but I didn’t like it.

I'm calling this a DNF, I just don't see what the big deal was. I didn't feel that there was much of a plot, or that I got to know the main character. It was just a bunch of teenage boarding school kids with too much time on their hands apparently. I was left with so many questions: what was the deal with the school? What was so special about this Jellicoe Road? Maybe I didn't real carefully enough, or far enough, but also what was the deal with Hannah? So there's this lady who lives on the edge of the school property and apparently not associated with the school but helps out with the younger kids. I don't know why this book was awarded the Printz award for "excellence in young adult literature." I didn't feel like it was well written either.

What's going on?This book made absolutely no sense to me at all.Did I miss something?I didn't know what was going on like, half of the book, and the other half bored me to death. I struggled 

A LOT

 to finish it, and I wasn't even planning to do it.
Didn't finish it... I've gotten over finishing books I don't like... I just don't have that kind of time.

This book was not for me. I am not sure why so many rated it so highly. I really feel if the people in the story actually talked honestly with one another the whole book would not have had to happen. They were all so cryptic and could have solved all their problems by not keeping unnecessary secrets. Maybe I just didn't understand the need for the drama of the whole thing.

If you're looking for painfully overwrought, convoluted, dull-as-dirt, or a sure-fire cure for insomnia, this is it. A House leader, Taylor Markham, who can't seem to figure out anything, including where her mom is, how to order white toast and marmalade, or how to spell "Holy Bible." She has a love/hate relationship with Cadet Griggs. There's a "war" going on between the Jellicoe school where Taylor attends, the Cadets, and the Townies. Girl wonder Raffy, Taylor's sidekick, is in a snit. So is Jonah Griggs' sidekick, boy wonder Santangelo. Throw in"To Kill a Mockingbird" with Jem and Mrs. Dubose. Kenny Rogers and "Coward of the Country." (Oh, please.) A boy in a tree who visits Taylor in her dreams. An idiot who shoots at tin cans from a tree. Add a "Prayer Tree" with "messages" in its trunk. Poor pacing. A ridiculous, rambling plot and enough teen angst and adolescent whining to choke a camel. It goes downhill from there. Fast.If "Drama Queen" was an Olympic sport, Taylor Markham would bring home gold for Australia.What a load of crap.

Tried to read this book because it won an award, but I just couldn't get into it. I didn't care about the characters, didn't understand why I should care about what was happening, and it felt like the story was going nowhere. So, I didn't bother finishing it. Reading other reviews of this book, it seems like a lot of people say it takes about 100 pages to get into the story. I ask, why would I want to read 100 pages of a story I'm not enjoying to supposedly get to the heart of the story? Lame. What is it with award winning books sometimes being unreadable???

I have no idea what I just read.and I listened to most reviews that were on here... "to stick it thru til the end."but I'm telling you, that if you are as lost and confused as I was by pg 100, then stop reading it. it's not worth it.
Tried for a long time but never finished it. I think it fits into my personal category of Prize Winners I Do Not Like.

I couldn't get into this book. I had a VERY hard time understanding the storyline and where the story was going. I was lost from the start. Maybe I'll go back to this one day and try again, but for now I am going to say I did not like it.

I didn't care for this Young Adult novel. I thought the language was really rough and the two intertwined story lines were hard to follow. She had some very well-devloped characters. The author is a very talented, Australian author, however I didn't love this book.
It's not often I can't finish a book, but I couldn't get past the first chapter of this one, and I tried twice. It wasn't holding my interest and I actually found it a bit confusing.
I read 78 pages of this book, and then the ending to see if I should keep pushing on. Blaugh. I couldn't get behind the protagonist. The plot is strained and confusing. And this won the Printz?
Too many characters, too many stories, too much going on without any indication of the connection between any of it! Frustrating!

I loved Looking for Alibrandi and expected a novel of equal stature with Jellicoe Road. It was like reading a tossed word salad, waaaay too confusing for this little black duck. Couldn't get very far with it at all. Disappointing.

I'm missing something here - I tried three times and couldn't get past the first three chapters. I believe everyone who said it was a fantastic book - but with Townies and Cadets and Wars - my eyes just glazed over and I put it aside again - until the final time.Hmm, having read all these reviews, I guess I have to try again and stick with it.
I read almost half of this (160 pages) and gave up. I really tried to get into it, but I just found it so confusing. I still don't really know what it was about/where it was heading.

really REALLY struggling to keep reading this one. I have heard such fabulous things, but the first part of this book is SO not my type of book... turf wars, multiple stories being told at the same time... someone give me a reason to continue!

OK so I kind-of read this one. I skimmed through most of it. It was really confusing. I probably would have understood it more had I been more aware of the school system in australia. It had some bad language which was a turn off and it was a depressing storyline. Not my kind of book.
Depressing story line (young adult fiction); not sure why everyone loves this book.
DNF unfortunately at page 108

I never finsihed this book because I just couldn't get into it or follow it really. It was pretty confusing and I just didn't get invested in it so I quit reading in about the 5th or 6th chapter. Oh well...

specifics to this book: I figured out all the supposed mystery very close to the beginning, and figured out who the corresponding characters in the story were and how they related to Taylor by 1/4 of the way through the book.
I can't get into this book. Not for me.

I am finally done with this blasted book! If I could I would of rated it a 0. I just did not enjoy it. I think my main problem was because I never really got into it I would find myself reading solely on short 15 minute breaks at work and that's it. This is a book that you need to read in large chunks in a short amount of time so that the story doesn't lose you.Be warned that this book starts off confusing. There are a couple stories that the author is having you read and for the fist 150-200 pages or so you will have no clue how they relate. She does tie them together and it ends up making sense in the end.Some surprising bad language makes its way into the end of the book and I just didn't feel like it was needed. Especially since nothing was used earlier. There is also a "love" scene at the end of the book that I felt was not needed either.If you really feel the pull to read this book do not buy it. Check it out from the library or borrow it from me.

having a h-u-g-e problem with this book - one that seems to have plagued everyone else. i'm at my 100 page cutoff and it's mostly boring me. i love a good mystery and don't need everything spelled out for me (major Lost and BSG geek here), by any means, but there's a fine line between disparate plot points that are intriguing and captivating and those that are irritating and piss me right the hell off. and that fine line is an entirely personal thing.however, since such a massive amount of the reviewers rated it so highly while at the same time admitting that it takes 100 pages to get into it (although many say it takes another 30-50 *groan*) and have the pieces start falling together, i'll continue on for a bit . . . only a bit though, because it's not just the pieces that need to fall together, i gotta start liking at least one or more of these characters (besides the musically artistic Ben) stat!yeah, so . . . read another 100 and disliked it just as much if not more. so i did something i almost never do and literally flipped the pages, looking for anything to stick out. can i just say that one thing that did was another 90 pages later - still talking about the frakking territory wars and the clubhouse!! honestly?! then i went online and dug up the details of the story to fill in my skimming antics. interesting enough how they all collided and overlapped, IF the pace had been quickened, for me at least. thought the overdone mysteriousness of who those original kids were/are now was pretentious. now knowing what happened - it just seems melodramaticwhy the drama about the territory wars, making it sound post-apocalyptic or other-worldly? oh, that's right. so, people will be so enthralled by the unknown that they'll keep reading. not so much.and really, we've all been through struggles, but this girl Taylor was too much of an emotional wreck for me - get a grip, girlfriend. haven't been this irritated by a book in a long time. gonna have to grab something good from the library tomorrow to get the taste out of my mouth.

As I said in one of my status updates, I was very upset by the fact that they lived in Australia. I wasn't expecting that and frankly I kind of hate books that are based in Australia. Like, Stolen. I don't know why it bothered me but it did and I did not enjoy it. Plus, I'm kinda over the whole boarding school thing. After reading The Disreputable History of Frankie... and The Mockingbirds , I became kind of disenchanted with the whole thing. Which is sad because some books like Looking for Alaska do it pretty well. The dozen pages or so that I actually read of this book kinda sucked if I'm to be honest. I didn't understand what they were talking about. It seemed, at first, that they girl's mother died on this notorious "Jellicoe Road" but then she talks about her like she's alive or something and I didn't understand. And then she was elected to be some kind of leader for some darn secret society and I started gagging because it reminded me of the darn books I mentioned above(the Frankie and mockingbirds one). I just didn't like it and when I read those dozen pages or whatever and sat it down, I knew that I wouldn't be picking it up again. I think a lot of people like this book and I'm not exactly sure why. This is one of those books that I didn't finish and that I have no regret doing so.
hated it. had to force myself to finish it. Her books seem to be getting worse with each one. this is a far cry from Looking for Alibrandi.
only made it 78 pages in and gave up...bad me.

This book has gotten quite a bit of buzz and I thought I would check it out. After reading 50 pages I am giving it up. I find myself very confused, not sure what is going on with the school versus the car accident things. They don't seem like they connect at all. I find Taylor to be very apathetic and hard to like. This one just isn't for me.
Not very well written. A bit dramatic for a pretty basic story of a girl searching for her real family. I didn't hate it, but I'm happy to be finished with it so I can move on to something better.

I feel terrible about this rating, but I can't give it any higher. I've had this book on my "to-read" list for a long time so when I was looking at the library for something different to read, this jumped out at me. I tried very hard to get into this book and just couldn't. In my opinion, it was a confused mess -- however, I only read the first 50 or so pages. This book is getting terrific reviews, so others must see something in it that I couldn't. Take my review with a grain of salt -- maybe it's just not my thing.
I couldn't. :/ This just didn't snag my attention at all, and I found the flashbacks really awkward and confusing.
Got the book and it didn't look that good, read the first couple of pages and it made absolutly no sense. GAVE UP!

OK- maybe I'm just over dystopian YA books (read a few over the last few months). Maybe it's the fact that from the start the book is extremely confusing and it takes over 100 pages just to get to some kind of connection between the characters. I just could not get into this book. I didn't care for the characters and if you have to read 100 pages just to make sense in a book I say it's not worth it. Perhaps the fact that I kept putting it down and reading other books instead should have given me the clue that it was not my taste. I just saw it won all these awards so I wanted to give it a try- not worth it.....

"Someone asked us later, “Didn’t you wonder why no one came across you sooner?” Did I wonder? When you see your parents zipped up in black body bags on the Jellicoe Road like they’re some kind of garbage, don’t you know? ‘Wonder dies.’""According to Dickens, the first rule of human nature is self-preservation and when I forgive him for writing a character as pathetic as Oliver Twist, I'll thank him for the advice.""I remember love. It's what I have to keep on reminding myself. It's funny how you can forget everything except people loving you. Maybe that's why humans find it so hard getting over love affairs. It's not he pain they're getting over, it's the love."I thought this was a very confusing book. It just sort of plops you down right in the middle of things that don't get explained until the middle of the book. (and I'm not talking about the secrets. I am talking about details that make the basic plot.) I also thought that some of the author's sentences were poorly developed which left the reader wondering who the sentence was even about. I did love how parts of a manuscript one of the characters was intertwined throughout the book. I wasn't left wanting more from this book. It ended when it did and I didn't miss the experience of reading it and I will not read this book again.

I actually didn't finish it so maybe it got better after I stopped. I just couldn't get through it. I like books that I am really looking forward to reading when I get some time in the day. For this book, I was dreading that time just because I didn't have anything else to read.

I started it and tried to get in to it, but it felt contrived, confusing and I lost interest quickly. I scanned through the rest quickly and decided it wouldn't be worth the time. I read about 50 pages.
I couldn't get through this one. It's too bizarre for my taste.
I just couldn't get into this book. I tried so hard, but I didn't GET it. I gave up about 50 pages in.
I tried reading this book but it was too confusing... I don't even understand the plot summary! What is going on??? A boarding school? A war for territory?? What?!?!?
I just could NOT get into this book! It just started, with nary an introduction, and it felt confusing. I gave up around page 30.

Most disappointing book I read this year so far. I had high expectations based on the rave reviews and the blurb. It's a good concept for a good story but for me this is just written RAW. It starts out really confusing, and I mean in a bad way and not the type of confusion that engages the reader. The worst part is it continues that way until more than half of the book. For a place that is supposed to be so wonderful, so beautiful, and so central to the lives of these kids, Jellicoe is sadly just not described well enough to make you actually believe. I was also not totally convinced and could not empathize properly with the characters in the story. I forgive the unbelievable amount of tragedies and coincidences, and there were some good pages in it when Marchetta rewards your patience and confusion with some fluid chapters, but I, seriously, did not like this.

I have no inclination to read this further. I actually completely forgot it's existence until I logged back onto GR and despite my worry of loosing friends with this review I refuse to torture myself further. I don't have enough time to read good books let alone boring ones.

This is a young adult book and probably should not be reviewed by a reader who does not appreciate young adult reads. It is likely that I would have enjoyed this at the age of 12 or 13, but not today. This is a coming of age story that recycles much exploited elements: orphans, boarding school with largely absent adults, strong, exclusive peer bonding in an insulated group, first love and the discovery of the truth of one’s past. I found the writing mediocre, the characters unrealistic, the plot predictable.
hated it. read as much as I could take.

This book was incredibly dull, and I wish I had given up after the first one hundred pages instead of continuing to read like the reviews on goodreads told me to.First of all, one hundred pages is about fifty too many to keep your audience in the dark. Honestly, if you can't make the plot interesting enough to hook people by then, you just need to stop writing.I never felt any connection with the characters--no one really had any special personality that made me really like them or even really dislike them--they were just there, with me feeling completely neutral about them.The plot was practically non-existent and what little there was could be figured out halfway through the book.The territory war was honestly the most pointless thing I have ever read about. Definitely the only reason it was added was so Taylor could fall in love with one of her enemies.Speaking of falling in love, I did not feel any kind of love between Taylor and Jonah. Maybe there was just too much else going on in the book, but in any case, if it's a big enough plot point to put on the summary on the back cover, it's a big enough plot point to actually make seem realistic.I regret buying this book. Does anyone want to take it from me so I don't have to deal with it in my house anymore?
I could not get into this book....100 pages in, I give up!

I would like to know who was on the Printz committee the year this book was selected as the winner, because SERIOUSLY, it was all over the place, and not in a good way. I listened to this book on audio, so I would like to think that it might have made more sense if I had read it, but probably not.Like many other reviewers, I found the first third of the book to be extremely confusing. There are "border wars" between the kids from the Jellicoe school, the townies, and the cadets. For the longest time I couldn't decipher if these wars were serious and spoke to the setting, or if they were just child's play. When it became evident that the adults in the story didn't know about the border wars, I stopped caring because the border wars were obviously just some added element that didn't really serve a purpose or move the plot forward. Next was the "manuscript" that the chapters alternate back and forth between. This did not translate well into the audio book at all and for the record, THERE WERE TOO MANY DAMN CHARACTERS. I couldn't keep track of all the kids in the manuscript and all the kids in present tense. It seemed to me that the manuscript gave Taylor (MC) an omniscient advantage, but then at the same time, how could she not realize that the kids from the manuscript were related to her, especially when she seemed to know so much about them. Learning about these characters via their pasts just didn't work well--there was too much of a disconnect.And the hermit. Once we find out who he is, there's still no explanation as to why he shot himself (with a shotgun--is that possible?) right in front of Taylor. Again, this element was just a sensational idea that served no purpose.I think the take away from this book is that connections are important, family or otherwise, but the message was overshadowed with so many other frivolous happenings and dead end ideas. I did not enjoy this book at all and couldn't wait for it to be over. I'm sure there were many other more deserving novels for the Printz award that year.

I'm just not a fan of this book - I can't get into it at all and I'm already on page 150. Nothing about the story is drawing me in. I'm not sure if it's just the writing style, story line or maybe just the distractions of life going on around me right now but I cannot connect with it. I can't even finish it... Maybe I'll try again another time.
Disgusting, boring read. Probably one of the worst books I've read.
My finish date is the day I admitted I was never getting past 40% complete. This one just never grabbed me.
gosto do enredo mas a forma como esse ele livro é construído é estranhissima

Por fin acabé este libro y no me ha gustado.He llevado una gran decepción porque todo el mundo lo ponía por las nubes y era el libro favorito de muchos booktubers y sin embargo a mi me ha dejado con una cara un poco extraña al llegar a la última página.Para empezar, no entendía nada de lo que estaba sucediendo en la historia hasta prácticamente más de la mitad del libro. Entonces...¿Qué sentido tiene que todos contaran que su final era increíble si la primera mitad, que son unas 200 páginas, no te enteras ni de quién es la protagonista, quienes son los demás personajes y dónde se encuentran?.Se me hacía tan tedioso leer un libro que no comprendía nada de lo que estaba pasando...Pienso que está mal escrito y que eso hace que no me enterase de nada, además hay millones de personajes y al cuando aparece el nombre de uno, me quedaba tipo "¿y este quién era?".También, la historia de amor pasó de ser de un te odio a un te quiero en un día... Osea nada creíble.Y el final, pues tampoco fue para tanto si el libro no lo estaba entendiendo. Si hubiera estado mejor escrito y me hubiera ubicado mejor en la historia, ese final hubiese estado mejor y me hubiera encantado el libro.Además, no podría hablar de la trama con un hilo argumental y decir "primero pasa esto, luego lo otro y por último aquello" ¡Es imposible! Es todo demasiado confuso.Lo único bueno, fueron las frases bonitas y que el final de algún capítulo me dejaba impactada. Pero sin más. Me hubiera impresionado muchísimo más si estuviera mejor narrado.

فکر می کنم وقتشه که بپذیرم برای این سبک کتاب ها زیادی بزرگ شدم. این کتاب قرار بود استراحت بین کتاب های سنگینم باشه، ولی بیشتر باعث عذابم شدتیلور دختریه که در یک مدرسه شبانه روزی زندگی می کنه و چیز زیادی از گذشته و پدر و مادرش نمی دونه. سال هاست که جنگ های مرزی بین این مدرسه، پسران دانشکده افسری و بچه های شهر در حال انجامه و امسال تیلور نماینده مدرسه خودشه. در طول این جنگ که در واقع یک جور بازی خشنه و با غیبت ناگهانی یکی از مهم ترین افراد زندگیش همزمان شده، تیلور کم کم گذشته اش رو کشف می کنه و تکه های پازل رو کنار هم می چینهریویوهای این کتاب از کسانی که سال هاست نظراتشون رو می خونم، اونقدر خوب بودن که این کتاب چند سال توی لیستم بود و تقریبا مطمئن بودم با یک داستان خیلی جالب مواجه می شم. یک سوم اول کتاب رو هم نخونده بودم که فهمیدم سخت در اشتباهم. داستان برای من به شدت کند پیش می رفت، هیچکدام از وقایع جذاب در واقع هیجان انگیز نبود و راستش... هیچ اهمیتی به تیلور و تلاشش برای کشف گذشته اش نمی دادمدر واقع ستاره دوم فقط به خاطر اینه که در انتها به نظرم اومد واقعا داستانی وجود داشت که البته برای من جالب نبود. ریویو نوشتن برای کتاب های دو و سه ستاره خیلی سخته، نه اونقدر ازشون متنفرم که یک ریویو پرشور منفی بنویسم، نه اونقدر دوسشون دارم که بررسیشون کنمخلاصه که "در جاده جلیکو"، ممنونم که برای ریویو نوشتن هم رفتی رو اعصابم٩٩.١١.٢٨

Reseña completa: https://www.lectorfisgon.com/resena-c...RESUMENLa verdad es que tengo sentimientos encontrados con esta novela, con cosas que sí me han gustado y otras tantas que me han parecido demasiado incoherentes o poco desarrolladas. Hasta las 100 primeras páginas, todo es muy confuso. Hay muchísimos interrogantes y hechos que no sabes por qué están sucediendo. La verdad que todo me parecía caótico y desordenado, e incluso me aburría avanzar en la historia porque sentía que no iba a ningún sitio. Sin embargo, a partir de la mitad del libro conseguí engancharme bastante gracias a que hay más acción y se desarrolla el arco romántico. Aunque «En el camino de Jellicoe» parece contener muchas tramas por donde tirar: guerras territoriales, una desaparición, hechos que ocurrieron en el pasado, etc. La verdad es que finalmente la acción se centra casi por completo en nuestra protagonista Taylor y su pasado.Las guerras territoriales, que se van anunciado a lo bombo y platillo por todo el libro, brillan su ausencia (y lógica). Sinceramente, da la impresión que nadie tiene un motivo serio para nada. Los personajes atacan los otros bandos porque sí y se perdonan con una celeridad pasmante🤦‍♀️🤦‍♀️.En cuanto los hechos del pasado, vale la pena mencionar que son complejos y tristes, además de contarnos sobre nuevas esperanzas y otras rotas♥. Sin duda, esta línea argumental es la que más interesante me ha parecido de toda la novela y descubrir cómo se conectaría con la historia del presente.Sobre los personajes, reconozco que no he acabado de conectar con Taylor, nuestra protagonista. Al inicio de la novela me pareció que tenía potencial, pero varias cosas de ella las encontré demasiado inmaduras y, en general, me pareció un personaje plano. Por el contrario, me he dado cuenta de que el resto de personajes de En el camino de Jellicoe sí que me gustado bastante. «En el camino de Jellicoe» es una novela que descubre pasados rotos y complejos, pero con una protagonista que, en mi opinión, no consigue estar a la altura. Además, aunque a partir de la mitad del libro disfruté la historia, el final se me quedó algo flojo.

Es un young adult de una historia contada a dos tiempos sobre vínculos familiares con un transfondo bonito y emotivo. Pero a mí me ha faltado algo... No entendía nada hasta la página 300 aprox, qué hacían realmente esos personajes, quiénes eran, por qué eran así... Me sentí muy perdida durante demasiado tiempo con muchas piezas sueltas pendientes de encajar. Hay mucha intriga y eso es un aspecto guay de esta lectura.Luego todo empieza a encajar. Todo. Y es como que empieza a molar porque por fin vas entendiendo todo. Pero a pesar de esto y a pesar de que la última parte gana muchos puntos, no conseguí conectar con la historia. Ya digo, no me caló. Y creo que es por haberme tenido perdida durante demasiadas páginas para mi gusto, y por la protagonista... Esa protagonista es que no. No. Hubiera agradecido un poco más de guía al lector, algun dato en ciertas partes del texto... y una prota con más carisma.Pero oye, la historia, original, es. Yo sé que este libro ha gustado a mucha gente así que si teníais pensado leerlo seguid con la idea. Esta es mi opinión y es algo muy personal, es decir, que no tiene por qué ser ninguna verdad universal ni tiene que ser lo que os pase a vosotros si leéis este libro. Peeeero es mi experiencia con él...

En historia om en flicka på ett internat som övergavs av sin mammans hon var elva, och nu söker svar på existensiella frågor om trygghet, tilltro och identitet. Parallellt handlar det om fem vänner, i en annan tid, och hur deras liv vävs in i Taylors.Konstig på många vis. Hade först svårt att komma in i röran, men plötsligt ville jag bara läsa vidare. Men kunde aldrig släppa att det är en konstig historia och hade svårt att bestämma om jag tyckte om den eller inte.

Voiam mai mult, mai multa chimie, mai mult mister. Am primit doar nisip în ochi. Chestii pe care nu le-am inteles nici la sfarsit. Ce era cu războiul ala?? Inteleg luptele de liceu între diverse bisericuțe, dar asta s-a vrut a fi dus la extrem și a iesit un kkt amestecat.M-a amenințat cu traume și n-am simțit nimic. Relatia mamă-fiică, fiasco total. Da. Te-a abandonat. Da. O urasti. Da. O cauti ca un câine turbat. Si ce?? "Și viața merge mai departe", dar niciodata nu e asa usor.Prost fragmentată, prost aranjată. Ar fi trebuit să-mi curgă mucii suroaie, dar n-am simțit nimic. Poate un pic de mila din loc în loc.A avut o parte bună. Unde a existat și chimie. Jude și Hannah. Atât. In rest, s-a încercat mult și nu a iesit nimic. Păcat de idee.Si care-i treaba cu Fitz ăsta??? Cred ca mi-a scăpat ceva totuși!

I'm sorry, but I don't understand the sobbing 5-star reviews. First of all: The beginning. I mean, like, the first 150 pages. What even was that? I didn't understand a single thing that was going on and I couldn't keep up with any of the characters. The first time I picked this up I spent about a week getting to page 156 and then couldn't drag myself through it any longer. This time I went in hard and powered through the entire book in two days (even though I very much didn't understand why the entire first half). It does get noticeably better in the second half. But not as much as I hoped. Second of all: The characters weren't that well developed. At least I didn't feel I got to know Raffy or Jessa or what-was-that-person's-name? at all. Third of all: Unnecessary relationship between plain YA-protagonist and boring love interest. Don't come for me please.Forth of all: I still don't completely understand how Taylor figured everything out. (view spoiler)[Like how did she know Hannah was Narnie, and how did she find out that Fitz shot Webb? (hide spoiler)] This was probably explained and I just didn't read closely enough. So yeah. Great that y'all loved it but this was not for me.

This book was told in a fragmented way that I felt was not necessary to the story. Nor was Hannah and Jude keeping Taylor’s past a secret from her. A lot of unnecessary mystery and secret keeping that was not believable to me. I also just didn’t connect with the characters like it appears many readers did. 🤷‍♀️
Confusing. Not relatable. Disjointed- “What do you want from me?" he asks. What I want from every person in my life, I want to tell him. More.”
very slow start and took a long time to get into. the 2nd half of the book was much better.
DNF
I'm sure this is a great book, but it just wasn't for me. I couldn't connect with the characters well or understood what was going in the story at all. I ended up not finishing the book.

My criticisms of this book are definitely a mixture of Me problems and Book problems — things I personally didn't like and things that I think are genuinely not good about the book. I was going to try to split them out but I'm not sure how helpful that would be, so I'll just run through them all here.-The book doesn't give you a lot of clues to orient yourself, so it's hard to follow at first. I don't necessarily mind this in a book — sometimes it's fun to try to piece things together — but it's a solid third of the way through the book before you have any kind of clue WTF is going on. That was far too long for me and kept me from feeling connected to the main character because I couldn't understand her motives for a lot of what she did, much of which was being terrible to other people.-Once the pieces did start falling into place, I found it to be disappointingly predictable. I figured out who the Brigadier was chapters before Taylor did. If it was supposed to be a mystery, it didn't play out like one — it was more like everything was a confusing jumble, so I didn't even know what I was looking at, and then suddenly it all came into focus and I was just waiting for Taylor to catch up.-The writing felt much more like telling than showing. It was very choppy, a lot of "This happened and then this happened and then this person said this." This meant that the romance felt underdeveloped and I had no real reason to root for them to get together or stay together, and the fact that they were either jumping each other or screaming at each other felt disconnected to any actual passion.-Also, Jonah is kind of a terrible person at the opening of the book, and he never really redeems himself. It's more like a combination of Taylor remembering him at his most vulnerable + he behaves like a halfway-decent person for a while. The characters are constantly throwing one-liners at each other, so we don't see who they are as individuals. At one point we're told something like, "Jonah said some witty things to the girls," which just felt like lazy writing to me — tell us what the witty things were, and maybe we'll get some sense of his personality?-The underdeveloped writing also extended to plotting. One example: Taylor's bike gets stolen. Then there's a chapter where she's riding her bike into enemy territory. Then later her bike turns up again. We get no explanation — Was this a flashback? Did she borrow someone else's bike? No idea. Another example: The kids all get in the car together and they're driving and driving and Taylor is settling into the back seat and watching the colors go by the window, until she sees something and makes them all stop. When they get back in the car, the driver says, "Where should we go?" and they have a whole discussion about it and then start driving again. There's no reason that conversation couldn't have happened before they started driving initially, and it's unclear where exactly they were planning to drive to in the first place before they screeched to a halt and then had a conversation about it. This contributed to the feeling of being lost while reading, and it didn't feel intentional, just sloppy.-I am not a fan of magical realism, so all the pieces with the boy in the tree in Taylor's dream and how she named herself before she was born were a little eye-roll-y to me.I actually really liked the idea behind the book and I think I would have genuinely liked the book a lot had it been executed better. There's a sweet message about found family and laying aside differences and how we can come to terms with the past and move forward. And the interweaving of Hannah's book, as Taylor's reading it out of order, was a clever device. It was just unfortunate that we're told at the very beginning that Taylor's story opens "twenty-two years later" than the start of Hannah's story, because otherwise we, like Taylor, might think it was fictional until the coincidences with real life start happening.So, on the whole, I didn't hate the book, and I can understand why people like it (I was even tearing up a little bit at the end), but in general it was hard to get through and not enjoyable for me personally.
This was just way too confusing.
Confusing.I don't even know what to say.

It seems that I am in the minority for not loving this book. There was a poetic and haunting quality to it, but I could not relate to the characters or their pain as written and I was utterly confused for the first half of the book. The story is full of darkness and dysfunction, powerful in its way. Not my cup of tea, though.

Wow. I must have really missed something here. I found it boring, convoluted and neither relatable or believable. I thought it was quite an unrealistic portrayal of trauma and it did nothing for me emotionally. For example, her mother is a “drug addict” who abandoned her daughter. There’s no nuance- I gather we’re supposed to believe all drug addicts are the same so there’s no need to go into any detail of her mother’s addiction or personality, because “Addict due to past trauma” is her whole identity. All the interesting emotions were brushed over in a shallow way and there was little depth or complexity.
Me costó adentrarme en la historia porque al principio todo era muy confuso.Toma un matiz un poco interesante a medida pasan las páginas pero no lo suficiente para que me pareciera una buena lectura.

It’s taken me a long time to write this review. I love many things about this book but am overwhelmed by discomfort. Anger even. One of the important failings is the head space of a child without parents. It wasn’t realistic to me. I know this is a hugely unpopular view and the majority of readers love this book but I found the soppiness upsetting. Unrealistic. Dismissive of the true experiences of voiceless children. It was a book about some kids without parents that is opaque and unrealistic in its approach and I feel that it’s unfair and let’s down and is a disservice to the true to life experiences of such kids - books are written about this world so rarely. What a missed opportunity! At least show SOME aspects of reality. We were allowed to feel sorry for rejected characters (druggies on the street) but no real engagement was achieved. Instead the message was to reject and give up on them. The lucky and loved remained the entitled. So... In the end I found this book offensive. I know it’s safe and easily consumable but it’s not real. It’s fiction to the true sense and probably easier for conservative readers. A safer read than reality might serve up.

Actually abandoned this one after 100 pages or so. It was good -- had some mystery to it that kept me going for a while to see if I could figure out what was happening -- but ultimately, since my discretionary reading time is precious these days, it didn't seem worth it.

I found this book underwhelming after all the praise I read about it. The book goes on and on for ages with nothing in particular happening. It has two storylines running side by side. That of Taylor Markham who is abandoned by her mother Tate at a 7/11 after Tate phoned her paternal aunt, Hannah to pick her up. And another one running about 22 years earlier which through the course of the book we realise is about Hannah and Taylor’s parents and their friends. I had a problem with this book on the issue of the territory wars. I found it hard to imagine these “wars” and even harder to imagine any teenagers to refer to an ages old notebook containing the regulations on which these wars were said to be waged without wanting to make any amendments themselves. In the end the wars were practically inconsequential to the storyline anyway so the author could have left them out. Ridiculous also is how Hannah never tells Taylor that she is her aunt and her father’s sister, and also that she always kept Taylor at arm’s length. The pathetic explanation that Tate told her not to mother her because she already had a mother really ruins it. I mean what would you do, respect the wishes of a junkie who can’t even respect her own child or show some love to a poor abandoned eleven-year-old? Actually it seems that whilst Taylor longed to find out about her past, all the adults around seemed to conspire to keep her in the dark.
very confusing

This was painful to read. I didn’t care about any of the characters, even at the “big reveals” in the plot. The last 100 pages were better than the first confusing 300 pages, but I really had to force myself to finish. This won the Printz award instead of “Hunger Games”????
The story was confusing and all over the place. it went from depressing to even more depressing. I had everything figured out long before the main character and found the story quite predicable.

I thought I'd get into this right away, it being set in a boarding school. But the thing is, is that it starts with a flashback, and then starts again with different characters in the middle of gearing up for the annual territory wars at their school. I'm pretty much the least competitive person I know, so things like war games don't really hook me the way they would other readers. But I trust the Printz committee, so I stuck with it, and I did end up wanting to know what would happen. Although I saw how things fit together before they were revealed, and that made it a little less fun for me. I liked that the book had a bunch of emotionally damaged characters but they weren't melodramatically emotionally damaged (the manuscript flashbacks were written too dramatically, but I think that's a separate issue).

I absolutely did NOT like this book...until the last 100 pages when it all came together and FINALLY made since. The only reason I read the novel was because it is part of a workshop I'm taking this summer.Two story lines are going on at the same time. You know they must be connected in some way, but you have to get to the end of the book to truly know how they are connected.The characters are believable and likeable, and the setting is in the bush of Australia. A pretend "war" is going on between the students of Jellicoe School, the Cadets, and the "Townies". However, the real story revolves around Taylor, who is the student in charge of the Jellicoe School side of the "war" and her coming to terms with the loss of her mother, the loss of her very good friend Hannah, and her feelings for the leader of the Cadets, Jonah Griggs, with whom she has a slight past.I believe the story is told in such a confusing way because Taylor's emotions are so confused and heated. The more Taylor begins to learn about her past, the more the two stories begin to meld.For those who aspire to be writers, this book is worthy of study; otherwise, I wouldn't recommend it.
I finished this one because it won the Printz award.

user_name: Julia via Stylish in the Stacks

text: I didn't love this book. I thought the concept in the last 50 pages was good, but poorly executed as a whole book. There were too many characters who were doing things that I couldn't find a reason to care about. Finally, I definitely don't know how an actual young adult would get through this or understand it. I give it 2.25 stars.
Hated it. I was so confused by what was going on, I quickly lost interest. By the time I did figure it out, I could've cared less.

I did not get this book. I mean, eventually I figured out what was happening, but it lacked certain details that I guess my brain needs in order to become absorbed. A startling dearth of physical details, both of settings and people.
Language, language, language. I won't be reading any more by this author.

Had a hard time getting into this book. I started it several times and was about to return it to the library when I decided to give it one more shot. I think the story was interesting but it had a bit of bad language and one part I skipped due to it's content.

Ummm, I'm not sure how I felt about this book. Heck, I couldn't even understand what was going on for the entire first half. It seemed like a bad dream I couldn't quite wake up from - there were occasional welcome scenes of lightheartedness and then it was back to the weird, disturbing stuff. Shudder.
I tried getting through this book twice, and never made it past page 170. I just don't know why it didn't click with me because it got great reviews. I just found it odd and hated the writing style.

I'm largely a big fan of any Printz award book winners, but the last few years have been real doozies. It's an interesting book about warring kids and territories in Australia. The writing tries too hard to make the reader want to solve all of the mysteries and figure out the characters motives, but I was just invested enough to read it, not really to understand all of its intricacies.
didnt really enjoy it

While I found Jellicoe Road a very quick and engaging read, it frustrated me a lot. It's one of those stories where, if one or two characters would just tell the main character a few little snippets of information, all the angst and drama could be prevented. But no, the story has to take the hard emo route of, "Who am I? Who are my parents? Where are they? Why do I have these weird memories? What do they mean?" Getting to the answer keeps the pages turning like lightening, and once it comes, it's very satisfying for the main character, but I felt a little like I'd been put through the wringer for nothing.

The first half of the book is very confusing. Hard to tell what parts are from the past or the present. This book would be good for high school students due to the confusing past and present characters and plot. The book is set in the Australian countryside, which the author describes in a beautiful way. The conflict of the book is the “turf” war between Townies, Cadets, and Jellicoe school students. The present day character, Taylor Markham, is a 17-year-old orphan who is trying to figure out the secrets of her past to find out who she truly is. Taylor falls in love with Jonah, a cadet leader and a forbidden love interest. Will she ever discover the truth of her past? This will all unravel, if you can understand it, through a series of flashbacks and charismatic characters. This book includes heartbreak, happiness, and sadness, but was hard for me to truly connect with.
This probably would've been a good story but it just never quite came together. A coming of age young teen with a history she only begins to learn of.

I think she was trying to get into some deep characters, and failed miserably. The main character had little interesting or redeeming qualities and there was no one else to make up for it. It just wasn't as twisty/turny as it wanted to be.

This book took way too long to make any sense. It also wasn't good enough in the first 150 pages to make me want to keep reading to find out what was actually going on. If I didn't have to read it for book club, I never would have finished it. I liked the Jonah Griggs character, but the rest of the characters I couldn't care less about.
i really liked this story. it got a little confusing at times, but overall i would recommend this.

Took me all semester to get through this book. I only stuck with it because it won the Printz and wanted to see why. Still don't know. The struggle wasn't worth the good part, and I fail to see the audience for this book.

Some points about this book:- author overused some words in sections of a book- lots of Australian slang I didn't understand- I didn't know why Jonah was able to suddenly kiss and fall in love with her if they hadn't seen each other in so long- didn't understand why they called everyone by their last names- basically, I spent the whole time while I was reading trying to figure out what the hell was going on instead of actually enjoying the story. A bit too confusing, especially in the beginning I had no idea what anything meant. I couldn't get into it as much and wasn't that relatable so no tears were even close to being shed. Also, I was very confused at first because I wasn't sure if she was a Townie or Cadet...turns out she's neither.**update: too confusing and weird to actually make an impact on me.

I really enjoyed Marchetta's first two books, but this one just didn't work for me.Taylor was so angsty and frustrated -- the romance between her and Griggs was well done, but the whole "idyllic friendship of the past ruined by tragedy even though it was tragedy that brought them together" thing didn't hold my interest. Maybe I just wasn't in a sentimental mood.It felt like the author was being too mysterious about the territory wars (although I did think the source of Hannah's manuscript was obvious). I didn't realize there were three groups -- and that Taylor's was a sort of boarding school -- until way into the book and that was confusing. Maybe if I had understood that in the beginning I would've been more invested in the characters.

Simply put: I read this book before using Goodreads and I hardly remember this book at all. I do remember checking it out from the library more than once because I couldn't get myself to finish it the first time but others seem to really like it. Should have listened to my instincts. meh.

I don't know how this book ended up on my list because it is more of a teen novel and not the 'Hunger Games' kind of teen novelIt is a very confusing story I think. Lots of stuff in there from different times. There is the abandoned kid, the hermit, a serial killer, and so onI didn't care too much for the story, but the writing was fine.

I got it. I understood why the story seemed so disjointed because it reflected Taylor's state of mind. And I didn't mind that the dream boy really didn't interfere that much on the story.But the end annoyed the hell out of me. And the crying too. Suddenly everyone seemed to be crying when it did not seem congruent with their character. I also didn't like the Taylor thought she was so cold and unfeeling and kickass when her actions just made her seem angsty and whiny. I still am not entirely clear on why Hannah unnecessarily kept all those things secret. I know there are couples that meet each other when they are babies and end up being together forever, but I don't why Marchetta makes it seem like all the love that happens on Jellicoe Road is eternal.And I'm not entirely sure how Webb, Narnie, and Tate happened to go to Jellicoe school even though they were orphaned. Who took them in? Did they have no extended families? uncles? aunts? Grandparents?

I really loved Saving Francesca so I expected quite a bit from this one but it was not as good. I have read that this book is different from most of Marchetta's writing. It's one of those that I need to reread because some parts were confusing due to the mixing of two story lines (the main story, and the story Taylor is reading), but I really don't know if it's good enough for me to want to reread so I probably won't.
I didn't care for the rhythm of the book or the plot.

This book is definitely written with a sophisticated reader in mind. Several stories happen at the same time which can be confusing. I started reading this book at the end of March but put it aside for a couple of books from the public library. I was confused when I got back to it which seldom happens with young adult literature.Two very similar sets of characters in two different time periods add to the mix yet they are not distinct enough to stand on their own.I really liked the way the book ended but getting to the good part was a challenge.
