Most of my students would not hang with the text long enough to get to the good part.The book contains elements of mystery AND it is written by an Australian. I would recommend it to strong girl readers who like mystery.

it was an ok book. i never even finsihed it because it couldnt hold my attention. it wasnt a book that i felt like i had to get straight back to every free min i had. when i did read i couldnt read it for very long didnt hold my attention.

I was seriously confused for the first 150+ pages. I felt like I started reading in the middle of a book instead of page 1. When I actually got to the middle of the book, I really enjoyed it and was interested in the characters. By the end, it all just kind of fizzled and I ended up disappointed. I figured out the 'twist' very early on and the ending just seemed too neat and clean for how messy and confusing the rest of the book was. Very interesting, good idea - it just wasn't carried out very well. Advisory: occasional strong language throughout
Kind of weird. Definitely not by favorite by her

An atypical coming-of-age tale where the protagonist discovers the secrets of her past. I didn't like or hate this book. Even days after I've finished, I remain ambivalent about this. Now that I think about it, I got this from the library after a review at Dear Author and the buzz after numerous rewards. I wish I could say more, but it just doesn't inspire that many words.

This book made me bristle and I couldn't wait for it to be over with. As I was reading it, I couldn't figure out why. I finished it last night and slept on it. When I woke up this morning, I realized what the problem was. I simply did not like some of the "younger generation" main characters ... especially Taylor and Griggs. Both of them seemed very fake and contrived. I especially didn't like Taylor's voice, and she's the narrator! (This books is told in first person from her view.) So, no matter what was going on, I couldn't get away from Taylor. Blech.Except! There are these passages in italics, which you'll soon find out, are in fact excerpts from Hannah's book that she has been writing. Ahh, there I could get some escape from Taylor! I enjoyed Hannah's narration and storytelling. If the entire story had been told in Hannah's voice, with her style of narration, I'm sure I would have enjoyed it much more. Hannah's passages had sort of a mystical quality to them, and the characters in her book were much more likable than the characters in the "real life" world of Taylor and Griggs.Blech! I'm glad the book is over. Taylor became more tolerable toward the end ... but for the first 80% of the book, she was just so terribly annoying. As I would read this book, it was a real effort for me to turn the page. I had no interest in the main characters, in fact I didn't even like them, so ... there were times when I'd ask myself, "Why am I turning the page?" And then I would say, "Ah yes. It's for the book club. OK, I'll keep reading." It was just that pointless. I'm glad I finished, only because that means it's all behind me now. I could give it 1 star, but somehow 2 stars for "it was okay" feels better. I did kind of like the story of the older generation.
From the revies I expected better, tangle story.
The synopsis was really good but that was about it.....only started getting marginally better halfway through.

Some children/young adult literature transcends its genre and can appeal to adults as well (Harry Potter being an obvious example; The Book Thief another less famous one). Unfortunately this book did not do that for me. I found it full of stereotypical teenage melodrama and maudlin observations. Best to leave this one to the kids.

Personally, I felt that this book was just okay. There were quite a few things I liked about it, but the overall story was slow for me, and I coudn't really get into it. However, that is just my opinion, so I am not making any recommendations on this book, positive or negative. I will only list a few personal pros and cons:Pros:- the way that the story of the past and present blend together as the story progresses- the depth of the characters, particulary Jonah Griggs and Taylor Markham. The author alerts you to elements of their past without flat out saying it - letting the reader use more inferencing, which I like.Cons:- the first 100 pages of the book are super confusing, and I almost put the book down. I don't usually give up on books, especially after an investment of 100 pages, but I was that confused at first.- the story didn't hold my interest for a lot of the book, and I felt that I was finishing it just to finish it. The last 100 pages were the best, to me.

I read this book thinking what the double fudge, for the first few chapters that is, but then little bits of information tunnelled their way to me, thank god for that!!This quote really does epitomise the book 'When you see your parents zipped up in black body bags on the Jellicoe Road like they’re some kind of garbage, don’t you know'? I loved the novel finding it unputdownable, mainly because of the relatable characters. I think Jonah, Santangelo, Raffie and the 'killer' were all great, I didn't really conect with the main character but thisdidnt stop it from being a great read!! I think this is more 4 and a half than four! A must read!
Teen angst - didn't hold my attention enough to even finish it.

I picked this book up due to the glowing reviews that I've read, but I was ultimately disappointed.This book is disjointed - the first and second halves of the novel could be separated and the storytelling would not have been affected. The "mystery" is ever so predictable, and the romance absurd/awkward.

This book was okay, but I don't see what the big deal is. It is a boarding school story with a bunch of screwed up kids. Nothing unique there. There were some good parts but most of it was tedious and predictable.
Didn't care for the animosity and violence between the groups.

I actually have anxiety about writing this review because I am the only person who wasn't bowled over by this. I've been putting this off all day long. I'm not sure why this missed the mark for me when so many others adored it, and I do adore her style, but this just...didn't work. I spent a lot of time being confused and trying to keep the 5 separate in my mind and who was who, and who did what, and why it should matter so much, but it was tiresome. I thought that it was choppy and I wasn't satisfied with the information I was given about anyone. I spent the majority of the book just seeing the words on the page, but there were a couple times I did tear up. I just wanted more of the way she wrote Finnikin of the Rock and Froi of the Exiles so that I could be so immersed in the story that I forgot everything else. I don't know what to say about this really. I'm too tired to put any real effort into it, and since there are nothing but glowing reviews I'm sure it was just me. I plan on reading it again sometime to see if it makes better sense, and maybe I'll be able to connect much stronger to Taylor and Jonah than I did this time around.
All you reviewers keep saying... "hold on keep going, it will mean something!"......WHEN, where

This book was painfully slow through the first half. I'm not sure how I didn't give up on it, because I wanted to. Several times. It picked up a bit by the end, but not enough to warrant more than two stars.

I was thoroughly confused until the last few chapters, and while I did eventually come to care a little bit about what happened to the characters, that wasn't the case for the vast majority of the book. I finished the book because of perseverance, not interest.
I wish I could rave about this book! I this for some this would be a top choice, but I just couldn't get in to it. May pick it up again down the road! The writing style was just not for me.
3.5?griggs å taylors relationship😗🤌

Jag läser Jellicoe Road 9 år efter att den kom ut och blev oerhört hypad. Jag är tyvärr inte lika tagen. Första halvan är rörig med hopp i tid och mellan dröm och verklighet. Det tar sig och jag förstår alltmer av pusslet, vilket är både förfärande och rörande. Min samlade känsla är ändå att jag aldrig kommer karaktärerna in på livet. När jag börjar om med första kapitlet förstår jag dock saker på ett helt annat vis (såklart) och jag tror att det kanske är nyckeln: läs Jellicoe Road flera gånger!
Que enredo, Chica problemática y caos por donde no lo había.

”Jag minns kärlek. Det är det jag hela tiden måste komma ihåg. Det är konstigt hur man kan glömma allting utom att det fanns personer som älskade en. Kanske är det därför människor har så svårt att komma över sina kärlekshistorier. Det är inte smärtan de ska lägga bakom sig, det är kärleken.”
hehehehe.... hihihihi.... joonaaaah 😘😘😘
2,75Es un libro bastante random la verdad. Entretenido pero sin más.

“So why would I want someone to be my everything when one day that might not be around? What will be left of me then?”“¿Para qué querría que alguien fuera mi “todo” si un día tal vez ya no estará a mi lado? ¿Qué quedaría de mi entonces?”Me tiré a la piscina con esta lectura porque era el primer libro elegido por el grupo creado por @natinbooks para el reto #unlibroeninglesalmes que organiza este año. No tenía ni idea de qué iba la historia y lo cierto es que me pasé las primeras casi 100 páginas más perdida que un pulpo en un garaje, porque la narración alterna dos líneas temporales (el presente y el pasado en forma de un relato inconexo y desordenado que ha escrito una de los personajes) y cuesta un montón entender lo que pasó/está pasando.Básicamente tenemos un cóctel conformado por un grupo de adolescentes y niños que viven en una especie de internado, los chicos del pueblo cercano y un grupo de “cadetes juveniles” que pasan el verano en un campamento “¿pseudomilitar?” en los terrenos anexos al internado. Hay un juego como de bandas, en el que pelean entre ellos por el territorio. Desaparece una persona. Reaparecen viejos conocidos de los protagonistas… en fin, una historia de adolescentes extraña.Me obligué a proseguir con la lectura y acabarlo y la verdad es que al final va mejorando un poco, porque empiezas a entender cosas, la narración se ordena, se hace más ligera y los protagonistas interactúan más entre ellos. Y conseguí engancharme en las últimas 100 páginas, en las que me eché unas risas y la historia se hizo más interesante, aunque muy previsible.¿Lo recomendaría? Mmmmm, creo que no, salvo que no tengáis nada más que leer alrededor o que necesitéis una lectura ligera de las de no pensar.

No sé ni como empezar a escribir mi opinión sobre este libro. Me ha dejado muy reflexiva. Empezaré diciendo que desde el principio he ido con unas expectativas altísimas y eso ha sido un problema. Me ha costado entender la historia, ya que es muy dispersa. Me he liado mucho con los personajes, no sabía si los nombres eran de chicos o de chicas, quien era el narrador... en fin, me he hecho un lío hasta más o menos las últimas 100 páginas, que ha sido cuando he empezado a entender cosas relevantes de la trama y me ha empezado a interesar. Hay escenas realmente fuertes, emocionantes, sentimentales y que me han conmovido, pero en general, me he quedado con un sabor de boca algo insípido. Es como si me hubieran faltado cosas por entender. Necesito más tiempo para digerirlo todo o una relectura en un futuro próximo. En resumen: gran parte del libro ha sido un poco meh pero la parte final me ha gustado y engamchado muchísimo. 3/5⭐
Al principio de me enganchaba nada, pero conforme vas leyendo todo va cobrando sentido y tiene un final muy bonito

3,5 ⭐Esta historia me ha mantenido súper enganchada todo el rato y me ha encantado desde el principio, como vas descubriendo detalles de ella poco a poco hasta que todo se desvela. Es una historia desgarradora que me tenía todo en rato una sensación de tristeza que no se si me gusta o no. Pero en general muy muy bonita.
Secretos, drama y amor.Me encanta que la historia se desarrolle en Australia.
Demasiado drama al final, creo que con un poquito menos me hubiera gustado más la historia, al final se unen todos los cabos, igual me gustó
interesting mystery.
why did this win?

I really hated this book at the beginning but kept going since Kate had liked it. And I ended up enjoying it quite a bit. The author is Australian which is funny because the book reminded me a bit of a Markus Zusak book and he is the only other YA Australian author that I know. Maybe they are all the same over there...

This year's Printz Award winner for young adults. What a wonderful, complex book! A little slow to begin with, but worth the effort. This is an amazing book that is set in Australia. From the beginning, you are introduced to five friends, who stick by each other through trials and terrible tragedies. Interwoven into the five characters (they are from the past), you also learn about a group of young friends, present time period, who are going through their own set of troubles. As the story progresses, the author does an amazing job of bringing past with present for a terrific ending.

I thought this book was a bit strange. I know it is intended for young readers, but I can't recommend it because of the violence, language, and values. Once I got into the story it was OK, but I was taken aback everytime I got to one of those "spots" in the story. I am not offended easily and I know the book won an award, but this is not for kids. It is an OK read for adults though and the writing is well done.

There's something that resonates with me in this story. The hopes and fears that Taylor feels toward the people in her life are things I think most people can identify with and understand. Plus, on a less serious note anything that makes me cry my own tears has to get at least 3-stars. And not to be a Debbie Downer, but sometimes the unnecessarily "inscrutable, secretive, reticent, evasive, furtive" characters masquerading around under the pretense of something mysterioso wasn't impressive.
this book was okay, kind of confusing at first though....
You must be willing to read 200 pages of "whatever" before the story gets rolling. Liked it a lot BUT, it was disjointed.

I ripped right through this book and really did like it, but I found the organization really confusing in the first half of the book and way too predictable in the second half. I figured out all of the "subtle" connections between the characters quite a bit before the main character realized them and so was a bit bored while she fumbled along for another 100 pages. That said, the general plot and characters are really interesting and, for the most part, make up for the book's weaknesses.

Beware spoilers ahead.Well, hmm. There were parts of this book I found just wonderful -- in particular, Melina Marchetta does teenagers shooting the breeze and falling in love, the multiple layers of that dialogue and how it can be both understatedly casual and completely overwhelmingly meaningful and intense at the same time, better than anyone I know. I loved Taylor's relationship with Griggs, I loved the territory wars (once I figured out they were just a game and not some postapocalyptic serious thing), all the school stuff was great. But the family piece felt willfully obscure to me, and also sort of willfully irrational or melodramatic. Like, WHY wouldn't Hannah tell Taylor she was her aunt? She could do that without undermining her relationship with her mother, it seemed to me -- indeed, it might even clarify the Hannah-Taylor relationship by better defining the roles. Or why wouldn't she tell Taylor about her dad, her beloved brother? Did Taylor not know her mom's first name was Tate? The Hermit was Fitz, and he shot himself because he felt guilty about shooting Webb, right? And he did it in front of Taylor because she reminded him so much of Webb?Everyone says this is better the second time through, and I can believe that, and I guess I should go back and reread it. But the first read left me so nonplussed about all this that I don't really want to spend the eye time on the second read. It was okay, but I didn't love it.

VOYA Book Review Code: S, A/YA; 2P; 3QI thought Jellicoe Road by Melina Marchetta was a pretty intense story. I did not really know what to expect from this book and at times I found it difficult to read, but as I continued I got more and more into it. Jellicoe Road is a book for females, but I’m glad I had an opportunity to read it.
Well done - can definitely see why this was an award winner. Really enjoyed the narrative structure!
Really hard to get into, but worth plowing through the first 150 pages

Maybe a 3.5?I did enjoy this book and for once all the teens in the book actually had reasons to be dramatic. In the end I really did love the story, though it was very sad and tragic in parts. The reason this book wasn't a 4 or 5 star book for me was in the way the plot is set up. At the beginning I found it very confusing. A story told in italics, a bitchy, hateful teenager, and a weird Skulls-esque secret society who are fighting a turf war with no purpose. It took a while for the plot to sort itself out and to get me to care about all the characters, though I did by the end. I also thought there was too much foreshadowing, so by the time Taylor makes her revelations, it's not shocking, it's something that I've figured out chapters before. At the beginning it seemed like that was the point: that Taylor really know the truth but doesn't want to say it aloud, and won't admit she knows until it's completely obvious. I'm not sure if that's what the author intended though.I didn't like the climax. It seemed over the top like the author wanted a big gesture to get her point across, but it made me skeptical (like of course that would happen) especially when the real cause came out. Disappointing, but once all that was over I loved the actual ending. So by the end it all came together and made sense. However, it took too long to get there, and I can understand people giving up on the book before they finish. Definitely don't think it should have won the Printz (I think Hunger Games was better) but it did deal with some tough issues really well. I would still definitely recommend it, but a little editing would have made it better.
I think I'm just not a YA person. Not much of one, anyway.
It was okay. REALLY confusing for the first 100-150 pages but once you get it you're pretty hooked. And the end tied everything together in a fun way. Very tricky.

Taylor Markham was eleven when her mother left her at a 7-11 in the Australian countryside. She's spent the last six years at a school, keeping her distance from everyone except Hannah, a woman who has a house off the school's property.When Hannah disappears at the same time as a couple of local children, rumors begin to circulate that the area serial killer has re-emerged. To add to her problems, Taylor finds herself leading a team of students in the annual territory wars between the school, Cadets and Townies.A coming-of-age story with a twist, Jellicoe Road explores the idea of finding yourself by learning about your past and your family's history --however horrific and tragic it may be.
I liked this book.

This book was utterly confusing for the first 100-150 pages. If I hadn't been reading it for book club I probably would have stopped. But then I would have missed a beautiful ending.On a side note, there wasn't much bad language and sex, but for a "teen" book I would prefer there wan't any.

Cons: the distracting language. Pros: great character development and fascinating mystery.Like many other reviewers, I had a hard time figuring out what was going on for the first half of the book. However, it comes together well in the end. I loved the mystery and I think I'll have to read it again. I'll probably like it more without all the opening confusion.

When I first picked this book up I had the hardest time getting into it so I jumped onto goodreads to check the reviews. Everyone that really enjoyed it said to just power through the first 150 pages and then it'll start to make sense. That was really hard for me cause I hate reading something and wondering if I'm missing the important parts. This was a really interestingly crafted story that provides history of the characters and flashback dreams and chaos all at the same time. The end was a little anti climatic for me after so much work to get to it, but I bet if you have time to read it a second time you'll appreciate it more.
A coming of age novel ripe with an everpresent war between the various teenagers along the Jellicoe Road that was set up by past events. Wonderful descriptions.

This is an American Library Assoc. Printz Award for Excellence in Young Adult Lit, so you have to respect that. It was a little slow at first, but it did get better. It's pretty cool how all these mysterious pieces of the plot fit together in the end.

I know this is an award winner. But that award was given by adult who are librarians and are going to read it all the way through. Few teens are going to have the patience to do that. Note all the comments here about "it took a while for me to get into this...the first half is slow....not enough happens at first...." etc? Do you really think that the average reader of crap like "Twilight" is going to have the same patience as a bright young Childrens/YA librarian--or a cranky older one? :DThere is too much going on here. There's the war between the schools story, there's Taylor's back story, there's the Narnie story. It's confusing and jerky. Eventually, they all come together and the ending will satisfy by making (nearly) everything come out happily ever after--a bit of a stretch for me, but great for those teens, if they get there.And I don't think that they will.
Once I got past the confusing part, it was completely predictable. Still, it was an interesting story and I liked the characters.Click here for my full review.

Told from the perspective of a 17-year old Australian young woman at a boarding school, this book offers another story within it about a special group of friends who are brought together due to a horrific car accident. A good, fast coming-of-age story.

I enjoy stories woven together - multiple threads that seem unrelated tied back into a lovely pattern. This book is more like a Rauschenberg painting - at first there is a sense of chaos, of story lines that you know MUST be related (they are in the same book after all) but its not tidy, like a tapestry where the picture starts to become clearer as its woven. The longer you look at a Rauschenberg painting, though, the more you can see pattern and even a cohesive theme. There are themes of abandonment, mixed with love and hope, of learning about the frailties of one's parents (who are human and have a past that does not include you), of discovering a history you belong to. My favorite idea what put into two statements: "Belong. Longing to be."

This book is quite interesting, and definitely a mystery. It was fun to try to figure out who was who. I love when characters form good friendships, and especially when there's a special connection. That happens between the two main characters, and a little with a few others. I wouldn't recommend it for 7th and 8th graders.

i liked this best and was in 5-star love mode when the territory wars drove the narrative and the past/present/taylor/hannah/5 kids stuff seethed right below the surface. when the past/present/taylor/hannah/5 kids stuff was the sole focus though... it was just too... schmaltzy.

The first half of this book was very boring and typical, in my opinion. I would only give that section about one or two stars, as I was forcing myself to read it (it was the only book I brought on a plane). The second half was incredibly good. I would rank that part about 4 or 5 stars for its characterization, interest level, and suspense. Therefore, I averaged the two, and gave it 3 stars.

Taylor Markham was abandoned on the Jellicoe Road when she was eleven. At seventeen she attends the Jellicoe School, where 10% of the students are also wards of the state, like her. It's convenient for Taylor, whose caretaker, Hannah, lives right outside school property. At the beginning of her senior year, she finds herself elected not only leader of her dorm, but leader of all the Jellicoe dorms in the Territory Wars in which her school, the Townies and the Cadets (who camp in the local bushland every year) participate. The rules have been passed down year after year in a purple notebook, and Taylor is under pressure to make sure things go smoothly for Jellicoe. However, just as things are getting underway, Hannah leaves without notice, and Taylor's life is in turmoil. She discovers that the manuscript of Hannah's that she's been reading over the years might be more than just a story, and she discovers that the Cadet she claims to have no history with might be more than just a one-time acquaintance. As the leaders of the various groups get closer through the War, they find that there is more to their game than they ever thought, and Taylor discovers that her family history is more complicated and bittersweet than she'd ever imagined.Marchetta's book is beautiful, but stricken with slow pacing that may not catch the attention of many readers. While the snippets of Hannah's manuscript and the peeks at romance certainly make things interesting, the plot doesn't pick up until at least half way through the book, and the Territory Wars are confusing at best until the very end. This is a book that I would certainly recommend to teen readers, but not without the caveat that they really need to stick with it to get to the good parts.
A good book, no real surprises and not very thought provoking.

This Australian young adult title won the Printz Award which is given to the best YA book published in the U.S. in a given year. So, of course, I had to read it to see what the fuss was about. I know from reading other librarians' blogs that this winner came out of left field. And I have to agree with them. To me, this title is a lot like The Book Thief. It's a mature book, but not because it's full of "adult" topics. It's written like an adult book--flashbacks, lots of secondary characters, and winding plots and innuendos.[return][return]I had to force myself to finish it. I didn't get sucked into the book until the last third of it, when I had to stay up until 1 am to finish. However, I don't think my teenagers will enjoy it. It's another boarding school book and the mystery doesn't grab the reader like it should. The italicized flashbacks are confusing until the readers gets to the last third of the book. I never really liked the main character, either, although she does seem witty. I didn't want to feel sorry for her because she isn't nice to her housemates. And when she finally was a good friend, I thought her actions seemed forced.

When I first started this book, I was tempted to put it down. The beginning was confusing and not very interesting. But, I read the reviews on Goodreads - plus, it won the Printz award, so I felt sort of obliged to read it - and many of them said the same thing: keep reading, the end is worth it. And it is. The problem is, I don't think many teens are willing to wade through 100+ pages of a book before the story starts to make sense or gets really interesting. Like many other award winners, this story has orphans (why are there always orphans?), and similar to some other Printz award and honor books(Frankie Landau-Banks, Looking for Alaska), this story takes place at a boarding school (I wonder how many teens can relate to living at a boarding school?). At any rate, if you've got a teen who is a very mature and patient reader, you might recommend this to them. There are two sex scenes (very mild, not graphic), and a good amount of cursing, so you might want to consider that when making recommendations. For high school and up.
I feel badly, bc I really wanted to like this book, but I just couldn't relate to the main character at all... she just seemed too sullen and put-upon...

About halfway through, I still wasn't quite sure why this won all the awards and accolades. But I stuck with it. It was a bit painful at times to try and piece together all the past and present characters, none of whom really came to life for me.
Liked it for the language and emotional tug, not the plot.

Interesting story, started slow but kind of clicked about a third of the of the way in. Was a page turner after that. I enjoyed it but had trouble forgiving the characters for their lack of communication, and had trouble forgiving the author for using the confusion of characters not communicating as the suspense in the novel. That might be a little harsh.

I don't know why so many people think this is so confusing to start. I thought the direction was kind of obvious. It's an ok book. Sorry, I suck at review writing. LoL It's a good character... who you can't help but feel for. The only thing that kind of didn't fit for me was the age of the characters. They are engaging in territory wars with eachother... something eleven year olds might do. And they often conduct themselves as such. The importance with which they treat the "war" really conveys that they should be small kids. However, they are in fact seventeen years old! (not all of them, but the main characters)... Maybe I'm jaded... but that seemed stupid.

Tortured souls at their best:"I remember love. It's what I have to keep myself. It's funny how you can forget everything except people loving you. Maybe that's why humans find it so hard getting love affairs. It's not the pain they're getting over, It's the love."You have to invest in this book to really get something out of it. The author tries a bit too hard to weave two stories together. I almost stopped reading it, but the ending was redemptive and beautiful and tragic. The best kind of story.

Sigh... I really liked the writing style of this author, and I really liked so much of this story, I really liked this book, and I really wanted to use this for book club ----but---- it had a dark tone (a lot of horrible experiences and some graphic detail about accidents/suicide) and there was a lot of profanity (F-word filled up more than one hand) and all this in a book written for teens?! I would not let my daughters read this until they were much older(18). I am so torn because I liked this story SO much, yet the few things that I didn't like make it difficult to recommend to those who have my same standards, that said. it was a really good story.
Rating: 2.5

This book was rather hard to finish. I think that it was because of the flashback dialogue that kept popping up intermitently. It begins like this:"What do you want from me?" he asks. What I want from every person in my life, I want to tell him. More. Abandoned by her mother on Jellicoe Road when she was eleven, Taylor Markham, now seventeen, is finally being confronted with her past. But as the reluctant leader of her boarding school dorm, there isn't a lot of time for introspection. And while Hannah, the closest adult Taylor has to family, has disappeared, Jonah Griggs is back in town, moody stares and all. In this absorbing story by Melina Marchetta, nothing is as it seems and every clue leads to more questions as Taylor tries to work out the connection between her mother dumping her, Hannah finding her then and her sudden departure now, a mysterious stranger who once whispered something in her ear, a boy in her dreams, five kids who lived on Jellicoe Road eighteen years ago, and the maddening and magnetic Jonah Griggs, who knows her better than she thinks he does. If Taylor can put together the pieces of her past, she might just be able to change her future. Some students might enjoy the book as it deals with initiations and cliques. I don't think that I could get through it again although I am sure that it help me garner more understanding of what was going on.
Last comment was: I'm on page 106 of Jellicoe Road. not what I expected; definitely interesting; still wondering where it's going...... and I never got back to it! Didn't hate it, didn't love it...

This book was VERY slow to get started but once it got going it was pretty good. You really have to read it in one sitting or you get confused about what's going on. I kind of want to read it again to see what I missed, but I don't have a lot of free time and it wasn't good enough for me to make time to read it again. Would someone please tell me how she figured out that he was shot out of a tree by his friend?
Frustratingly unsatisfying until at least midway through, this book eventually offers a reward, but only after an exasperating journey.

Taylor was abandoned by her mother when she was eleven at a 7-11. She remembers being loved once and that is what keeps her going. Now, seventeen she has been given the job of leading her school against the Townies and the Cadets from Sydney (that make camp every year near their school). The war has been going on so long that nobody knew why it ever started. The purple book of the rules is all they have to go by and a rumor of a hidden tunnel that leads from Jellicoe School to the town. Taylor, now leader of the Jellicoe School students, is questioned by each leader of the other houses. Her past has come back to haunt her, just as the one person who has been constant in her life, Hannah, disappears. The Cadet she ran away with when she was younger (who later turned her in) has come back to town to lead the Cadets. Taylor’s life is difficult but she must find a way to protect and expand her schools territory, find her mother and Hannah, discover the truth about how the war really started and where she really comes from, and finally find herself and where she belongs.I’m more of a fantasy person, but I really enjoyed this. I tend to love her books when I read them.

I had to read it for class, and it was the second school book that I ever enjoyed. Yeah, it was dull and depressing, but compared to the other stuff they make me read it was a breath of fresh, tropical air. The characters are interesting, if a little too mysterious and obnoxious for my liking. The plot was well structured and I liked how the story came full circle. It had the odd effect of being encouraging despite all the death and sadness. I suppose I would recommend it.
What started out as a bizarre little book actually turned out to be pretty cool .

3.5 starsI know this is a book that everyone gives 5 stars. And it's hard for me to know that, and know that it's a Printz winner, and not give it 5 stars myself. But I just couldn't connect with this book. I actually gave up on it, and only picked it up again at the urging of a few friends. The writing is absolutely amazing. I would definitely pick up something else by the author because her writing is wonderful. But the long slog to get to the plot in the beginning, and then the ultimate pay-off, was just too confusing and not worth it. I thought many of the plot points didn't seem to match character motivations, and I wasn't sure why characters were acting that way. I also guessed a few of the issues that were supposed to be surprises. That being said, a lot of the story was compelling and drew me in. I liked how the relationship between the two main characters played out, and I thought Taylor's growth was wonderful. Ultimately, though, I didn't LOVE the book.

This book was kind of confusing in the beginning since it wasn't in chronological order and followed different characters, but when it all came together towards the end, I couldn't stop reading it! It had to deal with friendship, love, and all the craziness that deals with our fallen nature.
Well written story of growing up and friendships.A few things I don't agree with as presented, but a good read.

(4.132/5) huh mb i should stop trying to re-read all the books i liked in high school.. the first time i read this i was so shocked by the turn of events and i knew i would have to re-read it again to fully grasp how everything was connected and i definitely was able to see how everything was connected this time around. i think this book is jus the epitome of what i loved abt reading YA books in hs, the wattpad-style romance, the page-turning momentum, the click at the end when everything slides into place. i wish i liked this book as much as i did the first time but it was hard not to notice the subtle flaws now tht im older. the diversity in the book is admirable but u can definitely tell its written by a yt and some parts of the book were underdeveloped or jus seemed rushed. overall it’s definitely a quick read i would recommend if ur nostalgic for YA mystery/thriller/romance books
pura pena

Este libro se puede definir como una auténtica sorpresa. La verdad es que el principio me costó mucho, entre que el inglés me pareció un poco complicado y que la historia no me tenía mucho sentido yo estaba perdida.Pero una vez fui avanzando en la historia me vi de lleno en ella, intentando entenderlo todo y sin estar preparada para cada giro de los acontecimientos.Lo mejor: los personajes, sin ninguna duda. Son personas con un trasfondo tan profundo que se merecen toda tu atención. Mi favorito es Griggs, por supuesto, es mi tipo de chico. Me alegro muchísimo de haberme animado a leer este libro, va a ser de esos que recordare siempre
Jamás imaginé que este libro me haría llorar

La recomendaré muchísimo. Una historia muy adolescente, llena de energía y belleza. Misteriosa, dolorosa, pero con un final positivo y realista.Me divertí mucho con sus aventuras en medio de la naturaleza, disfruté mucho su amistad, entendí sus miedos y me involucré con ellos. Discutimos, hicimos muchas cosas. Un par de escenas que pasar rápido, pero estuvo bien. Mi personaje favorito será Raffy, tiene todo lo que quiero.Le gustó al hijo de psiquiatra porque las personalidades están de acuerdo a las vivencias, familias y problemas de los personajes. Me gustó a mí, porque todos, juntos, con mucho cariño y paciencia, sanaron. Formaron una familia, se perdonaron, ¡grandioso!
4.5 🌟 Ohhh fue muy muy lindo

Misterio, romance, ficción general.He llegado años tarde al hype de este libro y entiendo el porqué hace mucho tiempo fue bastante amado. Sin embargo, creo que a día de hoy, alguien que lee mucho juvenil, no le maravillaría leer este libro. Y esa soy yo.Me habría encantado saber antes de empezarlo que tendría que tener paciencia, que no me engancharía a la primera y que solo disfrutara de la pluma de la autora. Me habría encantado que nadie me dijera que terminaría con el corazón adolorido para así no esperarlo. Esta novela se centra más en el misterio que envuelve la vida de Taylor, nuestra protagonista, además de encontrar un romance en enemies to lovers y slow burn.No ha sido sino hasta la página 150 cuando por fin me enganché a la historia y a encariñarme con los personajes. Dejarlos ha sido de hecho un pequeño vacío. Creo que este libro es de esos qué hay que leer una y otra vez en tu vida para regresar a ese sentimiento de nostalgia y volver a fijarte en aquellos detalles que te perdiste. La pluma de la autora me ha gustado mucho: no ha sido repetitiva, ha sido dulce y a la vez feroz, queriendo que aquellas frases importantes realmente lleguen a tocarte el corazón. Por supuesto que lo recomiendo, pero solo a quien quiere leer algo un poco pesado al inicio, alguien que busca no una lectura fácil ni rápida, sino que solo quiere adentrarse a una historia nostálgica.
Listening on audio.

A disorienting, multilayered puzzle of a coming-of-age story. The Plot:I'm . . . um . . . not even going to bother. It's too complicated, involving flashbacks, repressed memories, secret journals, a bizarre turf war between private school, military school, and townie kids, a thick coating of slang, and a double-barreled storyline. Marchetta doesn't bother giving a lot of context to what is going on, trusting her readers to have the patience to figure it out themselves. Thus, the first half of the book is darn confusing.However, the SECOND half of the book is impossible to put down. While I feel that the plot relied heavily on coincidences, the characters' ideas and actions so perfectly depicted adolesence -- where a childhood game could concievably be heightened into a overdramatic imitation of adult life, where anything is a good excuse for DRAMA -- that I can understand why the Printz committee chose to give it the big gold sticker this year.

This was really complicated and good. For the first half of the book, I was confused, and really couldn't tell what was going on. The story-within-a-story motif sometimes made it hard for me to keep track of all the characters. Marchetta did a great job of tying it all together, though, and though I figured out the "twists" ahead of time, it was a redemptive, complex and moving story of the main character figuring out her history and family.

I was really confused with everything in the beginning with it going back and forth between what seems like two different hardly related sotries- But it eventually came together and I really liked it. You got to stick with it-it's well worth it! Very beautifully written. It had a lot of heart. Some of it was super sad, and I cried a lot!(What's new-LOL).

Jellicoe Road is a very complex, well written book. The characters are believable and throughout the book I was trying to guess how the characters in the prologue connected with the characters in the story. This kind of drove me a little crazy... wondering and waiting yet the story worked and was very interesting.

I wanted to love it. I liked it A LOT. I think I'm going to like it more on a reread because this is a complicated story of two tales woven together. (I jumped online as soon as I was done and hammered Akilah with questions!) It is worth immersing yourself though; the revelations and rewards are extraordinary.

An amazing read, especially when you get about halfway through. I generally try not to give away spoilers, but I'm going to clue you in on part of a spoiler here, because otherwise the first part of the book would be nearly impossible to follow. There are large sections of italics in the first half of the book. This is another story, written by another character in the book (not saying who, although the reader will figure it out quickly). The first half is a bit disjointed at times, which makes sense because the main character, Taylor Markham, isn't sure where she fits in. She finds herself the reluctant leader of a private school dorm, thrust into planning the annual schemes the school puts up against the Cadets and Townies. Taylor's life is shaken further when Hannah, an adult counselor of sorts who lives on the school grounds, vanishes overnight. Taylor's mother abandoned her near the school when she was 11, and the teen always saw Hannah as a mother figure. She is especially worried because of additional reports of young girls going missing. In addition, it seems like Taylor's closest peers and adults know more about her past than she does -- are are reluctant to give her any details. As I said -- the first half of the book is a bit disjointed, but it's not too bad. Things finally get rolling with the confrontations between the teens at the school, the Townies and the Cadets, and the story finds its stride when the students go on vacation. At that point is when the book becomes purely exhilerating, and the wrap-ups end on many unexpected twists. Some language, but fairly clean overall; good for 8th/9th grade and up.

(Printz Award)It took me quite a few pages to get into this story. At first I was more interested in the side story, which appears in italics, than the main story of Taylor. However, once more of Taylor’s past is revealed and Jonah appears, I was hooked. As more of Taylor is revealed, you begin to understand why so many people try to protect her, even when she is not being nice in return. You cannot help but want to protect her. She just wants to have a mother, to have someone who will love her and not leave her in the middle of nowhere and never look back. As the side story and Taylor’s begin to interconnect, you understand why Taylor was left with Hannah.Teens can relate to Taylor and her school life. So many times high school can feel like a war between the different caste systems. At Taylor’s school, it actually is war. Her need to find Hannah, her reliance on Jonah, who should be her enemy in this war, and her friends are all relatable. In addition, the side story, of how a tragic event can break apart a group of friends and wreak havoc on their future, can also appeal to teens. Friends share so much at this age that most teens are bound to have dealt with situations that solidified friendships for years to come. While Taylor seems one-dimensional at first, she grows into a solid, three-dimensional character by the end. I would have to talk about this book to promote it. Just looking at the cover or reading the jacket flap is not enough to know this book is worth reading. I would tease the two connecting stories and give a hint of Taylor’s emotional conflicts that relate directly to the side story.4Q, 4P, J/S

It took me a bit to get into it but once I listened to CD #1 again, I was hooked. The book tells the story of Taylor Markham, a girl in her last year at the Jellicoe School somewhere in the middle of nowhere, out in the Australian bush. Taylor is prickly and jumpy and angry, and slowly as the story unfolds you learn about her and her background. And as she lets you into her heart, you (= I) learn to like her.At times it's heartwrenching, awful and sad but there's transformation and light at the end of the tunnel (or story). I think I'd like to read it again, and this time actually read the book (though the audio version was very well narrated - can just get a bit hard to keep up with all the different characters. And there are lots.).

I loved this book--the story is excellent and intriguing, the characters are complex and haunting, their relationships are profound. I would have given it 5 stars if it weren't for the very confusing nature of the first 1/4 of the book. I worry that the intended audience (teens) might not power through to get to the beauty and heart of the book. Who am I kidding, I almost thought about putting it down. But then suddenly everything clicks and the story sails through until the powerful ending. I hope not too many readers missed out because of its start.

I was totally confused for the first several chapters of this book, which must have been how Taylor feels until everything starts coming together and she begins to figure out who she is and her story connects with the five kids from that tragic day on the Jellicoe Road. Everything connects just perfectly in the end, even though it's not a happy story, it is just the sort of bittersweet that doesn't leave you feeling depressed.
I listened to the audiobook. It was hard to keep track of where things were heading, but at the end I loved the book.
loved it loads and loads and loads and loads. very poignant
Definitely teen. The first few chapters are confusing, but if you can stick with it, she develops the characters wonderfully and you really feel for Taylor as she tries to uncover her past.

The only thing keeping me from giving this book 5 stars is the first half of it. Although I understand the book now, I just could not get into it and almost gave up on it numerous times. I had to force myself to just sit down and read it, figuring that it won the Printz award for a reason. This book was one of the more confusing ones that I have read in a long time, but I am so glad that I stuck it through.The end of this book makes trudging through the first half worthwhile. Marchetta has done a wonderful job crafting a believable world with unique characters. A mystery at its heart, this story is one that I would recommend to anyone who has the tenacity to see it through to the very end.
A complex, compelling, sweet and tragic story. Yup, I wept through the last few chapters. I read this in one sitting. There are some words a US reader has to translate (singlet, jumper).

this is the sort of story where from the first sentence you are both drawn in and repelled. and, from the first page you know are starting a journey that mirrors the plot.it's organized in a way that reflects the protagonist's sense of time and memories, which leads the reader to be confused - particularly in the beginning. finish the book, it's worth the confusion though! i have to admit, i was lump-in-the-throat crying by the end. it was that good!

Whatever you think about this story, you have to admit that there's nothing simple or obvious about it, unlike other teen fiction offerings today. The story is unusual and complicated, and the two narratives are confusing for a very long time -- distractingly so. In fact, I suspect it will lose a lot of its targeted teen audience because it's "hard".The italicized narrative is, in my opinion, the weak part of the book, and I wish that part of the story had been told in a different way. There are several things about it that bothered me. For instance, the writing is grandiose and overly dramatic to the point of being kind of ridiculous and annoying (Did she really count 132 minutes? Was that before or after Tate crawled over and held their hands? Did they all sit in the same spot for 2 hours and 12 minutes, counting the time? Before Fitz arrived? And then the cars blew up? After 132 + 10 or so minutes? Or was the dad still alive when Fitz dragged him out? Hmmm... ) Also, there is too much omniscient narration for a story told from one person's point of view. Definitely the weak part of the story.However, the part of the book that deals with the day to day life of Taylor and her friends is fascinating and entertaining. I would have enjoyed more tales of the war between the different factions. The Australian setting is neat but negligible -- the story could have taken place in any remote place in any country. I also didn't think it was necessary to tie up every single loose end. Who cares who the serial killer is? Why state what happened to Webb when it's already heavily implied? Why make neat a story that is all about complicated messes?Overall, an enjoyable, fresh read. I think adults who enjoy reading young adult fiction will like this more than teens.

There's a lot going on in this book and at times it feels like a little too much. But overall the book is moving, haunting, wonderfully complex, and definitely different from most other young adult fiction. The first page should grab teens in, but the action unfolds a bit slowly from there. However, especially for teens who like books with a lot of emotion, this one should keep their attention.
Slow start but eventually engaging. I liked the twists and turns, and the abandonment theme.

I read the reviews for this book and could not agree more that the book begins rather confusing but that everything is pieced together in the end.Taylor Markham is a teenager who was abandoned years ago by her mother. When her surrogate mother, Hannah, disappears, Taylor finds Hannah's manuscript about a tragic car accident on Jellicoe Road that happened 20 years ago. What Taylor soon discovers is that the manuscript is the key to unlocking the secret identity of her mother.

I wasn't really looking forward to reading this book. I kind of assume that Printz winners are books that adults think are good but teens won't really like. I still think that might be true of this book. I also wish I hadn't read the jacket, because it made me confused about what was going on for a brief time. However, I also feel like once I realized what was going on, all of the Dickensian coincidences/relationships were very obvious and when they were revealed I wasn't surprised at all. It didn't decrease my enjoyment of the book because the author may not have intended them to be huge shocker moments and I also felt that the story was really meaningful. I don't know that teens would enjoy it because it is kind of heavy and even though the protagonist is a teen, I'm not totally sure a teen would appreciate this book. Worth reading though, without a doubt.
I finished this just before I left for Europe and loved it. I need to go back and think about it some more and will post more on it later.

Like most of the other reviewers, it took me a good 150 pages or so to really start to make sense of how the story was structured and what was going on. And yet, I felt totally okay with that. The story was compelling enough from the opening chapter for me to be willing to sit in that state of tension and confusion as a reader. In fact, it almost seemed appropriate that I should be in that state. I appreciated that the author and setting are Australian as well. :)

I didn't really understand what was happening in the first four chapters of this book, and struggled to catch up the rest of the way. Still, I have to admit, when I finally realized what was going on (that the story a character has been attached to throughout the book is telling the past of her own story), I began to realize how clever and ingenious the book really is. On the surface, there's a lot happening with the regional wars between different factions of a boarding school, and on another layer there's what's happening with a mysterious serial killer and a missing guardian, and on yet another level there's the supposedly fictional narrative that becomes more and more real as the story goes along. Very creative and interesting, and once it finally gets going, hard to put down.

Ok, this book has been on my "to-read" list for years and has sat on my bedside table many times but I just never got around to reading it. I finally got it again and after hearing my sister rave about it, decided to really tackle it.I read it down in Lake Powell and let's just say, I don't think I saw anyone else for hours. Poor Ricky just hung out with the kids in the water while boring Mom read her books. After about page 50 I couldn't put this one down. Did not expect it to turn out the way it did. From the beginning I thought it was going to be a fun loving, camp warfare, pranks and lighthearted comedic young adult. It definitely took a turn away from that. I ended up being a beautiful book about family, friendship, redemption, how the past influences the future, and fears. I thoroughly enjoyed the characters, the story of the Fab Five, and Taylor's search for herself. There were brave moments, funny moments, romantic moments, and sad moments. All in all, a great book. A good book for Young Adults that is well written, finely crafted, and entertaining. Really liked it.*Just a head's up. This does have some foul language.
Fabulous...just as good, if not better than Saving Francesca. Am looking up this author's other works and placing them on hold as well.
I loved listening to this book because the Australian accent helped accentuate the mood. The story was confusing in the beginning as the narration kept shifting.

One brief comment: audiobook is not the way to go with this one, if you're listening on your iPod and keep making stupid mistakes when trying to go back a sentence or two which result in your losing your place altogether. TOO MANY chapters begin essentially the same way!That said, I liked the narrator. Not sure exactly why I liked this one so much, as there were a lot of things I thought inadequately reasoned (like why Hannah didn't just tell Taylor what was going on, or why Taylor didn't recognise a character she'd no reason to forget) and I slightly resented coming to love a character who had deliberately stomped on another character's fingers (with all his considerable body weight *and* heavy boots). Things like that. And the seeming lack of necessity for there to have been QUITE so much tragedy and misfortune in everyone's lives, except to leave things where they needed to be. But then sometimes that's the way it goes with a book and reading pleasure is reading pleasure, even if you do have more doubts about the book than you might.

Part mystery, love story, coming of age, this novel is a page turner. Marchetta successfully develops two generations of characters who grab you and become individuals you can relate to. Her insights into teens' thought processes are revealing.Taylor Markham boards at an Australian school. Her mother abandoned her when she was 11 years old. She wants to find her mother but must also deal with the disappearance of her close friend while also seeing to her duties as house leader of her dorm.
i totally did NOT get this book until the end.then i still didn't fully get it. maybe cause it's an australian story? but touching.

I was really into this book as I was reading it and definitely enjoyed it. It's a teen book, so the many strands of the story were not completely developed, but the writing was good and the story is compelling. I will recommend this one.
Beautiful and strange story set in contemporary Australia. The beginning is a little difficult to follow but it is worth pressing forward.

An excellently crafted story, Jellicoe Road jolts the reader through mysteries of the past and present. The unique storyline kept me reading--first, to find out what was going on and finally to find out the happenings of the past. The characters are teenagers with attitude, but they manage to have attitude in a likable way. My one big complaint (and a warning to those who read it) there is one case of teenage sex--very disappointing and unnecessary. The scene isn't explicit, but the fact that it isn't discouraged and no consequences occur is disappointing. As a result, I don't feel comfortable recommending the book to any teenagers, in spite of the great story.

I have never read one of Melina Marchettas books and not love it, of course on the Jellicoe road was no exception. I found the book rather confusing at the beginning because of the two strand narrative used. By the time I was a quarter into the book I was hooked and this technique only had me hooked deeper as I began to understand how the two stories were connected. This book is going to be one that will stay with me long after i finish reading it and though it is a young adult book, I would recommend it for adults as well.

This book won the Printz Award this year, and I've noticed that I tend to love these award winners, except for when I really, really DON'T (White Darkness.) Anyway, On the Jellicoe Road was a very beautiful, intricate story of memory, drama, and friendship told by a compelling young woman living at a boarding school in Australia. The telling of the story included snippets of dreams, a novel being written by one of the characters, and even writing on an old tree at the school. It moved slowly but eventually the world pulled me in and I can tell it is one of those stories whose landscape is going to remain vivid in my mind.

2009 printz honor - Very nice story of Taylor who is left at a 7 -11 by her mother at age 11. Now 17, she has been attending the boarding school on Jellicoe Road. She has dreams and Hannah's story for her to put together Hannah's past and make sense of her dreams. Complicated and thoughtful, it takes a careful read, I should read it again. She does have sex with her boyfriend, but it is more of an aside than a plot point. I should read it again. I think I'll get more out of it. I read it in chunks and not continuously.

In this historical fiction book a group of scouts goes camping on the Hawaiian islands. While camping, an earthquake erupts and causes a massive tidal wave. This is a story of survival. Dylan and Louie must put aside their differences and work together to lead their troop to safety.
Probably would have liked it better without liberal use of the f-word and the scene where having teenage sex seems to "complete" and "liberate" a character

This is really an amazing book. It was recommended to me by my sister Amy, and it was only on this recommendation that I didn't abandon it in the first 100 or so pages. But today I am completely blurry eyed because I stayed up all night unable to put this book down. The story is lovely, heart breaking, surprising and completely satisfying. And if that doesn't tell you anything about the actual story, that is OK. I think that you need to have this book unfold for you to really get the full impact. I know I need time to let it all settle before I start a new book, and I am completely happy for that.
Sensational YA fiction.

Eu tô me acabando de chorar aqui, pelo amor de Deus nunca ia imaginar que esse livro ia mexer tanto comigo e ia me apaixonar tanto por ele. Definitivamente uma das melhores leituras de 2021. A história da Taylor e como vai se desenvolvendo o passado dela e o presente, e todos os personagens do livro, toda a ambientação da jellicoe road é apaixonante, APAIXONANTE MESMO. Eu só quero esquecer o que eu li pra poder ler tudo de novo e me apaixonar tudo de novo.Eu não consigo nem descrever o quanto eu amei esse livro. Sério mesmo, sem palavras pra descrever o quanto eu amei ele.

"rasa" yang beda dari Melina Marchetta. Kalau udah baca Saving Francesca dan Looking for Alibrandi, jangan berharap menemukan jenis cerita dan masalah-masalah yang ditemukan di kedua buku tersebut di buku ini. Bagus banget! Bagus banget!
Brilliant book. No words.

DNF @ 21%What's going??!?Ok. Clearly this book won an award which meant it was supposed to be better than average or even amazing. Unfortunately, I didn't connect well with this book and was terribly confused. That said, I belonged to the minority for this read. So take my review with a pinch of salt. The epilogue was ok fine but moving on the chapters, I could not grasp the plot. Townies... cadets... so thing was these terms were coined by the author and was not explained before plunging into it. Besides, there were random flashbacks which oh dear me could not get how it was related. In all, I guess it's hit or miss for this. It's a miss for me...

"Read" and "finished" don't really apply, as I am opting to free myself from the shackles of this book at page 36, but if I can save one person from beginning it, this review serves its purpose. Plus, I wouldn't want to forget that I attempted it once and try a second time in my more senile years!Plot (as far as I can tell): Taylor goes to a weird military-seeming boarding school after being abandoned by her parents and is placed in charge of basically a fraternity/sorority of "underground" kids that think way too highly of themselves and put too much faith into speaking in code. There's a woman she's close to in the school and she dreams of being in love. I'm kind of in shock as to why I couldn't force myself to read it. I read rave reviews from revered Goodreads personalities and got the title from a list of "must reads" somewhere in the social media abyss, but unlike some of the reviewers, I found the prose heavy, murky, and droll. The flashbacks/internal thoughts mixed with the actions didn't flow, and I don't need over 300 pages of suffering to sift through it. Taylor didn't compel me to enjoy her character in any way, as she is a brat with a chip on her shoulder despite the advantages normal orphans wouldn't be offered. The worst aspect of all, however, had to be the jargon. I couldn't stand the mention of many artifacts that held no significance to me or any of the characters, like the "little purple book," and I didn't care to read anymore to learn! Instead of intriguing, it was just off-putting, much like how the narration didn't help the reader understand the weird townie vs. boarding school war. It was almost like an idea meant for an elementary audience, but "beefed up" to try to make it YA.I don't quit books often. In fact, I only remember quitting two others in the past five years, but I just couldn't go on, and this is someone who is completing a doctorate, has an M.A. in English, reads YA often, and teaches high school.

DNF at pg 106So... I gave Melina Marchetta another try to woo me... and guys... I REALLY wanted her to woo me. Wow me. Whoa me. Wake me. Anything (that preferably begins with a "w" and doesn't involve putting me to sleep. jk... but only on the "w" part.) besides another DNF. Welp. I really wanted to hop aboard the Melina Marchetta train, because it seems like everyone has, but then again... I remind myself that I am my own person, and there's no point in standing with a crowd you don't belong in. So, while I can see why many people adore her writing, I guess it just simply is not for me. The humor is a little too dry (like the desert) for my taste, her prose has a nice simplicity that makes it an easy read but I lean more to literary fiction (BUT I allot many exceptions), and what I think really gets me is the pace. I got to page 50 and was still wondering when something, ANYTHING, would happen. Where is the introduction of conflict? Action? Excitement? Maybe I missed it when my eyes glazed over somewhere between the flipping of said pages, but I earnestly tried to invest myself in this book, and when you have to work hard to do that... well it's not a promising sign. Even at page 100, I was still oblivious as to what the plot of this book was. Well, I'm sure many people will read 
Jellicoe Road
 and be instant converts. But overall, my feelings are sort of "meh" and "time for a nap".

Could not get past preview. I like to get about 25% in before I decide I'm not going to continue on with a book. I didn't get that far with this one. The voice was hard to grasp and hold onto for me personally. As a writer I have learned there are three ways to disorient the reader straight off the bat. 1. A Dream- This book starts with a prologue (but begins chapter one by talking about a dream.)2. Prologue- Background info that is usually better told inside the story. A lot of people skip over prologues 3. Italics- The prologue itself was in italics. Not terrible but made me a little crazy. All three of these things together disoriented me about the beginning of the story, the character, and what was actually happening. The language was beautiful and I enjoyed the description of thought but without something to grab onto I was just floating through pretty sky without a destination.

Ugh. Broke my own rule and ended up with another YA book which I said I wouldn't do. Reason being the blurb on the back didn't give me an insight to it being set at a school. I DON'T WANT TO READ ABOUT BROKEN TEEENAGERS WITH ISSUES. Sorry for shouty capitals but this format has been flogged to death. There is another plot that's trying to run through this story about Taylor's mother and the story behind why she was abandoned, but got to 40 % and it wasn't developed enough to keep me interested and I just couldn't read any more about the stupid turf wars between school kids.

Ugh. I HATED this book, and I rarely say that. The book was depressing, full of flat, unlikeable characters that don't have individual voices, and it's so peppered with profanity (including the "f-word" multiple times) that at times I just wanted to put it down. I didn't put it down because I kept reading with the hope that something would change and the book would become a better book, but it never did.I honestly don't see how it won an award for excellence. I've read TONS of YA books that I like better than this one.

I barely read this (I know, I know, I'm sorry) and I'm definitely in the minority but even just the first 20 ages were such hard work to read. I don't know if it's just the book or maybe the author's style but I don't think I'm ever going to be able to finish this one.
I started out confused and then when I figured out what was going on, I didn't care.

On the Jellicoe Road is a melodramatic and wearisome YA novel about a girl searching for her family. It’s a joyless and jarring book, with all kinds of ill-fitting elements rammed in together. The first half is mostly about school kids playing a trite game of “territory wars” in a small Australian town. The author treats the game with extreme seriousness and weight, but in reality it’s a mere trifle. The “war” only lasts for 6 weeks each year, there are no real consequences for breaching territory, there’s nothing at stake either externally or personally, the teens could easily seek help from their teachers at any time, and the main character, Taylor Markham, isn’t even all that invested in the banal “war.” Taylor’s got other, more important things to worry about like having been abandoned by her drug addict mother as a child, and having witnessed a man kill himself via a rifle to the head (described with brain chunks and all. Ew!). As a result, the so-called war is little more than a bunch of pathetic, foolish children having hammy, soap opera-style confrontations and saying “You can’t go there, or else…!” for over a hundred pages. Oh, there’s an occasional punch, but it’s nothing to get worked up about. To make matters worse, eventually even the characters realise how pointless the “war” is and abandon the entire thing in an anticlimactic whimper. When even the characters think the central plot is boring and meaningless, that’s a sure sign to the author that her book needs to go back to rewrite. Apart from the so-called war, the book also features flashbacks to a group of teens 20 years ago, and explores Taylor’s search for identity and family. The flashbacks aren’t all that successful, chiefly because the past characters experience some serious, serious trauma that makes the present-day story seem even more lightweight and meaningless. For example, one repeated flashback depicts a girl surviving an horrific car crash and watching her mother getting decapitated right before her eyes. (Again, ew! Such exceedingly grotesque images are tonally jarring). How on earth are we supposed to care one iota about Taylor Markham’s schoolyard rivalries after reading that?Taylor Markham’s search for identity is not particularly involving either. Taylor is obviously hurting from the separation from her mother and yearning for some sort of connection – that’s fine. But Taylor is a histrionic drama queen who reacts to every minor problem in her life by screaming. Emotion-wise, there’s no perceptible difference between Taylor being abandoned by her mother as a child and Taylor having a petty argument with her sorta, kinda boyfriend. Apart from making Taylor unlikeable, this strips all the impact from the actually serious, life-changing events in the book. Moreover, because so much of the book is taken up by the tiresome non-war, everything else is left rushed and underdeveloped. This book is unrealistically over-stuffed with some truly HEAVY topics. Apart from the traumatic car crash and suicide scenes, there’s also paedophilia, child prostitution, homelessness, drug addiction, cancer, mental illness, attempted suicide, accidental death, a fire... But these big events aren't explored with much in the way of depth or subtlety. There simply isn't space in the book for that. Some of these events come across as exploitative, as though they were included simply to shock the reader. Others come across as excessively sentimental melodrama.Not to mention, it’s all incredibly predictable. Like, golly gosh, do you suppose there might be some sort of link between the present and past stories?! Golly gosh, could Taylor Markham’s search for family possibly lead her to the group of teens featured in the flashbacks?! Every time a link is “revealed,” I literally groaned in frustration because it was SO BLOODY OBVIOUS. I wouldn’t usually complain about this, except that the author uses such flimsy, bald-faced plot devices to artificially extend Taylor’s search for her family. Like, Taylor has been cared for by a woman who knows the whole story, but chosen not to say anything for positively no discernible reason. And Taylor discovers a manuscript depicting the events on the teens 20 years ago – but it is conveniently unfinished and then stolen before she can read it all. Not to mention that Taylor has conveniently forgotten or repressed the memory of every significant event in her life – until the opportune moment when her memory suddenly returns(!). And isn’t it a tad unbelievable that 
all
 the characters were known by completely different names as teenagers? These contrivances had me rolling my eyes. I just couldn’t become engaged with the story because the way it unfolds was so nonsensical. Oh, and there’s also this totally random serial killer subplot that, unsurprisingly, goes nowhere. That sentence plainly has nothing to do with anything previously mentioned in this paragraph, but the serial killer subplot plainly has nothing to do with anything in this book.The bottom line is this book was an absolute chore to read. I will gladly admit that there are some fleeting, isolated scenes that were dramatically effective and for that reason I can kinda understand why some readers absolutely love this book. For example, there's what might be the perfect teen sex scene - a scene that manages to be both emotionally intense but also painfully realistic. But for me there was just too much padding in this book for me to give it anything other than a 1 out of 5. With absolute honesty, when I finished this book I was downright relieved I didn’t have to put up with any more of Taylor Markham’s crap.
I tried so hard to read this book, to like it, to "get it", but I couldn't. Stopped halfway, not a good book for me.
I generally don’t like quitting a book... but after 130 pages, I’m still so confused. Too much teenage angst for me.
this book made me feel like I missed the first book?? and there wasn't one

DNF at 30%. How does literally everyone love this book?? I wanted to give up at 12%, but I assume it HAD to get better, it just had to right? Well, if I'm 1/3 of the way through, and I still don't even know what is going on in this book, or what the point of it is, HOW can the author expect me to continue? Seriously, WHAT IS THE POINT of this book? It's flat characters running around complaining about territory wars at a school... Except none of it is interesting. I assume eventually something will happen, but if a THIRD of your book has gone by with noting happening... Maybe the book is  too freaking long??!!!??
I quit reading this book on page 100. The story line and the writing style did not work for me which is the reason for the one star rating.

I have no clue what's going on in this book to be honest.The very few pages I was so confused that I had to go back and reread it to make sure I didn't skip anything or something. After I reread the first few pages, I still had no clue what was going on.I only checked this book out from the library because the Goodreads summary intrigued me. The summary on the book that I got however said:Abandoned by her mother on Jellicoe Road when she was eleven, Taylor Markham, now seventeen, is finally being confronted with her past. But as the reluctant leader of her boarding school dorm, there isn't a lot of time for introspection. And while Hannah, the closest adult Taylor has to family, had disappeared, Jonah Griggs is back in town, moody stares and all.It doesn't seem like it's that interesting, to me anyway. It doesn't mention anything about the freaking territory wars or the manuscripts that Hannah writes.It just plops us down in the middle of the action. Taylor is being led to a... different building? She's being made a leader? How does that happen? There's different people that elect her as a leader? Do the dorm-mates elect?Why are the adults so fucking useless that they don't know about this cult thing?Why is Taylor such a bitch?She makes me want to roll my eyes at this stuff. There's no reason on why she wants to run away. She just does.I can't like this book. I just can't like it.

I just did not warm to this book. It was, as many reviewers confirmed, very confusing to start with. This story is really in a nutshell about a 17 year old girl wanting family. Taylor was abandoned by her drug addicted mother at a petrol station when she was 11. She is being raised by her guardian Hannah and all the while Taylor pines for her mum and then goes on a journey to find her. If that was all the book was about, it would've been great. But no, the story oscillates between Taylor's life at school, the territory wars, backflashes to before Taylor was born, Taylor's life at home, Taylor's blossoming romance, blahdee blahdee blah. Too many threads, too many nicknames for characters, too confusing.

I can not wrap my head around how this book received so much praise. I only fought my way through to the end based on other reviewers saying that the book gets better. It doesn't. It is confusing, no background is given and it's as if the author couldn't decide if the story was supposed to be a dystopian novel, a murder/kidnapping type suspense or just a drama. The characters aren't fleshed out until the very end and by then I was so over this book. It tried too hard to be enigmatic and was just plain confusing. I was never able to picture the world she tried to build in this book. I much preferred Finnikin of the Rock.

Horrible! I really don't understand 'why' so many people give it 4 and 5 stars. The plot is so confusing, there are too many people in it all the time is difficult to keep track of who is who. I think that the quality of a good book is when the story line flows, and there's some harmony or good transition throughout. You find none of that here. I am very disappointed on this book. I kept reading all the time hoping the story would get better but it never did. The only reason I read to the end is because our book club suggested it & I hate attending a book discussion and have nothing to say about it, but I wouldn't recommend it to anyone. A total waste of time!

Trudging through 100+ pages of pandemonium was not only frustrating but also wearisome, and then to read through the next half of the book to make sense of the first half was in the end emotionally draining.This book is just not for me. I also don't like Marchetta's seeming fondness for her characters to be verbally and intentionally hurtful to conceal what they really feel. And Jonah Griggs? I am concerned he is showing signs of being physically abusive -- like his dad -- and yet the readers swoon over his dark, brooding self. That may be part of Marchetta's readership's appeal to her work, but not for me.

Despite the raving reviews I've heard, this book didn't do it for me. I found the plot extremely confusing; I didn't understand what was going on for the first 200 pages, and while toward the end I started understanding some parts, I still didn't understand much by the end of the book. The romance was weird and didn't make much sense for me, and the whole Townies, Cadets, and Houses aspect of the plot was completely lost on me. The protagonist Taylor seemed apathetic and somewhat unpleasant, so overall I couldn't find much to enjoy.

I felt like beating my head against a wall trying to read this. I finally stopped around page 50. I felt lost in regards to plot. The story kept referring to things but never explaining them and everything felt vague and confusing. I never got a strong sense of the MC, and therefore, didn't care for her at all. It astonished me that so many people loved this book to death. Maybe if I had kept reading I would have ended up liking it? A book needs to make me care, and all this book did was make me want to throw it across the room. It made no sense.
