Esperaba emocionarme, encontrar un final más impactante, no sé... En definitiva, una histora bonita, escrita de forma muy cuidada, pero que no ha terminado de convencerme.

I finished it and I’m still not sure about the rating. I liked it but not as much as other people? I hate feeling confused and this book has AT LEAST 150 where I didn’t know what the hell was happening. When we FINALLY understand everything, I was kind of expecting more. I would love to re read it now that I know everything. I think I would enjoy it more then.

At first I wasn't sure what was going on in this book (with the territory wars and the dialogue on the 'fab five'), but the story unravelled after a while and even though I could predict some outcomes it was an enjoyable enough read.

3.5* for this audiobook editionI found the plot of this Australian young adult book predictable. However, the characters were mostly well written & Taylor, the 17-year-old girl from whose perspective the narrative is primarily told, is particularly interesting as she (& the reader) begin to understand the roots of some of her instincts and behaviors in her early years (view spoiler)[living with a drug-addicted mother & what happened to make her mother that way (hide spoiler)].Rebecca Macauley does a fine narration in this audiobook.

Everyone seems to adore this but I just didn't really gel with it. Hannah has disappeared but we don't really know why or what her role is. And then there are Cadets and Townies and a boarding school with houses and what appears to be not many lessons? And flashbacks that only really make sense in the last 50 pages.
*3.5 stars
O poveste surprinzătoare, perfectă pentru a fi citită acasă sau în tren, pe timp de vară, cu o băutură răcoritoare alături :)

3.5 overall. Honestly, I want to give the first half of the book 2 stars and the second half 4 stars. When the novel begins, Taylor is whiny and angsty and I wanted to punch her in the face, and the whole "territory war" made no sense me. Where are the adults?? What is even happening?? And then halfway through, things begin to shift, and the book turns into something sad and beautiful and I began to love it. Not sure if I would recommend, but I'm glad I read it.

I was reading this book for a week, something that I normally don't do because I’m a very fast reader. And before I started I did something different as well; I’ve read a lot of reviews, most of them were pointing out to have patience because the beginning is dizzy, disjointed and with too many characters which are categorised into boarders, townies and cadets.But I didn't have that big of a problem with the beginning although I was slightly annoyed because I am very ''cautious'' with YA books – especially those that have high ratings, which this one definitely has.Because I so often switch from genre to genre I give myself a right to be a sheriff and a judge in my own bookhood. I like to swoon over something and instead of being infatuated I end up being disoriented in my disbelief. I became very harsh with books – because just reading something to read, that cannot be applied to my mouth watering yearn and long lasting love affair that I will have with books till.the.end.of.my.time.la.la.la.la. So it’s not the plot that slowed my reading down, but the sentences of this book were to blame. I instantly started liking Marchetta's way of expressing herself and there was this ironical attitude that Taylor had which attracted me further. I admire people with integrity who have an opinion. Without your opinion what are you left with that it counts? She writes in a way where you can see the end. Meaning, she tells a lot of things in one subject-verb-object-fullstop. Especially when he said: ''Go to hell.'' And she replied, ''Been there. Trust me, it's overrated.'' I can tell you it’s overrated as well, but I never thought of it in this simple way. That’s the reason why I loved this book. It was full of these short written gems that you heard before but you didn’t recognise them as life savers. But this book didn’t impress me how I wanted it. It had very strong moments and toward the end, I cried but what I’ve learned in my life is that tears are not the expression of sadness; complete retreat into yourself and blessed numbness are. Tears will help you a great deal, they wash you over and nurture you, but no, they will not tell you how one person feels. Taylor didn't cry that much, but it was heartbreaking to read how stoical she had to be, if not, she would shatter. So while I liked Taylor and her development, not just with Jonah Griggs but dealing with overwhelmingly sad beginning of her childhood – see, this is where this book lost me completely - history and present were just too separated. Her life, but just her current life was great to read about because it was senselessly sad but I was getting annoyed because everything was tied up in the end, and I wished that the whole book was like the last 50 pages. I didn’t like how clumsy antagonism between townies, cadets and boarders was described, and I sure didn’t like the entire mumble jumble that happened on the Jellicoe road twenty years ago. Not the result of it, or how people dealt with that excruciating story but how Memento and Irreversible (movies) it was written. I am not talking about how confused I felt, but how it wasn’t emotionally engaging as the present story was, which is a tough cookie because it could have been just it was entangled too much. On a higher scale, this book really deals with a lot of bad things – traumas of loss and abusiveness. And that makes me somehow indecisive because there are so many things that made me lull, that I found startling and touching, and then there were these whirls of shallowness, laziness and lightness, which I can't forgive this book.What I want to say is that Marchetta’s books are difficult to review. Yeah, I’ve written so much, but these are just words. Basic message is – read this book, in the end it will not disappoint you. Whoever you are, I guarantee you that you will find something that will be just yours because reading about happy people, where’s fun in that. Reading about broken people who found a way out, mmmmm, yes please.

3.5It's hard to get into, specially because in my country there aren't any schooling systems like the ones in the book. I liked the flawed characters, the mysterious backstory and how both of them come together. It was very dramatic, sad and beautiful. I don't think this story was too memorable for me, but I really enjoyed it once I got into it.

Rating: 3,5 stars.I'm having a hard time rating/reviewing this book. I can’t make up my mind about it. Despite it being pitched it as a mystery and many users tagging it as a romance, it felt like neither to me. Imo this was a coming of age story about friendship and bonds that are forged at a young age and last forever.One thing’s for sure: Melina Marchetta’s writing is lyrical and beautiful and captivating. “I live on the Jellicoe Road. Where trees make canopies over-head and where you can sit at the top of them and see forever.” Now, as for the story … there are actually 2 stories being told: the ‘present’ story and the ‘past’ story, which elicited opposite reactions from me. (The connection between them was obvious to me as a reader from almost the beginning, but for the heroine from the present it takes a journey that lasts the whole book to figure out how her life is connected to those from the past.)- I wasn't much invested in the ‘present’ story, mostly because I had trouble connecting with its heroine, Taylor. Her story was sad and I felt bad for her but I didn't really feel her pain as I would have for someone I knew and cared about. I never figured out what made her tick: what was going through her head when she acted the way she acted? And what was up with her weird dreams? The love interest, Jonah, was kind of “in the shadows” and for most of the book their relationship was almost non-existing. I frankly didn't feel the Taylor/Jonah love. I liked the secondary characters Raff, Chaz, Ben and Jessa a lot more than I did the MCs, but once again, they seemed barely fleshed out. I guess what I want to say is that I felt like an outsider looking into their lives but not really being a part of it. - I also didn't buy the part of the plot about the territorial wars between Townies, Cadets and Jellicoe kids. There were a lot of threats and little action. They weren't doing anything other than saying “we are at war, don’t enter our turf” and it seemed like they didn't accomplish much. (But I must admit that the literal “shit fight” made me laugh.)+ The ‘past’ story on the other hand... WOW. Narnie, Webb, Tate, Fitz and Jude carved a path right into my heart and took permanent residence there. They made my heart ache with tremendous joy and unspeakable sadness.I cried my heart out and then cried some more. I was left feeling raw. I wanted to pull them all into a group hug and never let them go. Every tragedy they experienced I experienced as if it were my own. Their friendship, their mutual love, their bond, was all incredibly beautiful and heat-breaking. Nostalgic. Bittersweet. Melancholic. Everlasting. Memorable. And that ending! In a nutshell: two stories were told and interwoven in this book. One I was rather indifferent to; the other I was totally invested in and loved. I wish the people from the ‘past’ story had had more page time, or even had the book all to themselves and then I would surely had rated Jellicoe Road with 5 stars.Australian slang I picked up:*Gaol=jail*Pash= heavy duty kissing between teenagers/snog.

This was the perfect example of a ‘slow’ story that isn’t boring. The pacing is pretty slow, but it builds on itself and reveals information and history about the characters, their relationships, and the world. The story grows and develops and blooms. It’s a weird one - I wouldn’t think much about it when I wasn’t reading, but when I was reading it had my full attention. 
Things I Liked
:I really liked the writing style. It was very much a stream of consciousness style that I found easy to read. It was easy to connect with Taylor because we get so much of her emotions and thoughts from the writing. I liked how we were discovering information alongside her. The story pulls you with it and keeps you engaged.I really loved the flashback scenes to Narnie, Tate, Jude, Fitz, and Webb. I found the characters endearing and very lively. They had such an earnest friendship and it was great to see. (view spoiler)[I also loved that Hannah’s book was about these flashback characters we meet and that the story was her story. The story of her and her friends, it paralleled Taylor, Griggs, Santangelo and the other characters beautifully (hide spoiler)] We get so much history from them. I loved seeing how their relationship changed the townies, the cadets, and the Jellicoe school kids.I also really loved the dynamic that developed between Griggs, Taylor, and Santangelo. As the chosen leaders of the cadets, the Jellicoe school houses, and the townies respectively, it was nice to see their interactions change and evolve over the course of the story. The learn more about each other and their history and they evolve naturally. I really loved the bonding at the Prayer tree, it felt so genuine that I became completely invested in these three characters.
Things I Didn’t Like
:I didn’t really care about Raffaela at all. She felt pretty useless as a character to me. I know she has some kind of history with Santangelo that was supposed to cause drama or at least bring her into the core group, but we don’t get any information to actually make me care. The side characters in general all receive virtually no information, but that’s really ok because the story is more about the core group and their history and the history of Jellicoe road. But Raffaela is integrated as part of the core group, but I don’t think we get enough of her to establish her on her own.The serial killer side plot fell completely flat to me. There wasn’t enough information to establish is and it didn’t have much closure either. It never went anywhere, it was just brought up now and again with no history or development. It was really just unnecessary and didn’t add anything at all to the story.This was an enjoyable and engaging read, that builds and creates this hazy world of nostalgia and mystery. I really liked how the answers revealed themselves naturally and organically. The characters and the world are ethereal, while still being incredible grounded in emotion and humility.

"—Estoy aquí por ti, tú eres mi prioridad. Tu felicidad, de alguna manera jodida, está unida a la mía. A ver si se te mete en la cabezota. ¿Te gustaría que fuera de otra manera? Demonios, sí, pero no creo que pase mientras yo viva."
Empecé este libro por Melina, porque amé Finnikin of the Rock y porque quería leer algo más suyo… y no pensé, ni por un segundo, que me produciría tantas emociones al mismo tiempo y me haría sentir tan bien y tan mal simultáneamente. Me ha gustado mucho, pero también lo he odiado. Es un sentimiento difícil de explicar, pero lo intentaré.
"…la gente con tanta personalidad me asusta terriblemente. Hacen que quiera ser mejor persona, sabiendo que no me es posible."
Más de la mitad del libro me desconcertó, no entendía muy bien lo que leía y no por qué fuera un lenguaje complicado sino porque no me enteraba del porqué de nada. Necesitaba saber por qué las cosas eran como las leía pero no lo conseguía, no le encontraba sentido y me frustraba. El personaje principal me molestaba porque siempre tenía una actitud de todo me vale una mierda y constantemente estaba buscando una “razón” para alejarse de los que la querían y se preocupaban por ella porque sentía que no podía depender de nadie, la habían abandonado ya dos veces y no se creía capaz de soportar eso de nuevo. Creó una barrera entre ella y los demás, siempre aparentemente impenetrable. Me frustraba porque quería que abriera los ojos, que se diera cuenta que no estaba sola y que aunque había sufrido no todo podría ser tan malo… pero todo fue una ilusión, y más o menos cuando le quedaban unas cien páginas al libro, todo cambió. Y la entendí, sufrí por ella y con ella y me abrumó todo lo que se descubre en estas páginas. Entonces me agradó, pero no me podía olvidar de lo tedioso que fue soportarla anteriormente. "Si quiero más, tengo que ir a buscarlo, exigirlo, abrazarlo con todas mis fuerzas y tratarlo de la mejor manera de la que soy capaz."Me gustó porque Melina escribe precioso y me hizo sentir lo que leía, me hizo sufrir y me hizo lamentar que a veces la vida de unas personas tan buenas no vaya tan bien como se podría esperar. Fue tan abrumador que en ocasiones no quería continuar leyendo, porque sabía que se descubriría un hecho que me dolería saber. Todos mis no tiene sentido, es incoherente, parece más un juego que otra cosa… y demás dudas y críticas se vieron opacadas por tanto sentimiento. Mientras leía pase de pensar que se merecía una estrella por hacerme perder el tiempo a que se las merecía todas. Yo no le doy cinco por lo que dije, porque también lo odié y me hizo muy mal aunque sea una novela espectacularCreo que se merece una oportunidad porque pasa de ser absurdo e ilógico a ser bonito y esperanzador. Me molestaron muchas cosas, pero al final creo que fueron más los pros que los contras.
I liked it, but the confusing parts of the story made me less reluctant to keep continuing on. At least it wrapped up in a sweet ending.And Jonah Briggs, though.

3.5 starsThis is a tricky book to review. I haven't actually read a Melina Marchetta since Looking for Alibrandi in Highschool. I loved Looking for Alibrandi. It got me through many difficult, angsty 16 year old times. Had I read Jellicoe Road in High School, I feel I would have loved it just as much.Because the thing is - Taylor is a really great main character. She's a rough around the edges, but damaged, needy girl who is able to pull out her strength when she needs it. All she realls wants is to love and be loved. The story is centred around Taylor's search for her mentor, Hannah, who has disappeared in the middle of the night to "care for a friend". Taylor has reason to believe that isn't true and is concerned for Hannah's safety.In the middle of the search for Hannah is the "war" - the school is divided up into various factions, and they have battled for years, distributing various areas of the school to the diffrent factions based on the outcomes of strategy and negotiation. People from other factions aren't really supposed to be friends, but there is definitely some emotion going on between Taylor and Jonah Griggs (who may I add, is a bit yummy.)As well as all of these concepts, the chapters are interspersed with the manuscript that Hannah is writing about 5 friends on the Jellicoe Road. And these 5 friends are starting to feel awfully familiar to Taylor.Right so - Marchetta certainly knows how to write a believeable love story. I loved Josie & Jacob in looking for Alibrandi, and I certainly loved Taylor Markham and Jonah Griggs. There is something so raw and real about them. It isn't all sunshine and lollipops - they are both seriously flawed characters who manage to bring out the best in each other.I read the book fairly quickly, because it was certainly very readable. There were a few times when I scratched my head and flicked back a few pages because I felt I had missed something, but it all came together in the end. As far as the story goes, it was pretty good. Not amazing, but I would certainly prefer to see teenagers reading this over something like Twilight.

When I first started reading Jellicoe road, the first chapters or so I was very confused. I did not get anything, I did not like how it was written, I did not like the characters, I did not know where the characters were, who was named what and why certain things happened. But it was still quite capturing. It was a mystery. And the more you read the more you found out. I kept finding it flurry until I had read about half of the book. There I got more answers and I now knew the characters better and I understood them and that made me like them. The book still contained a whole lot of mystery and secrets. The other half of the book is the most exiting I think. You get a lot more clues, things get solved and romance becomes on of the big topics. And there I found myself totally captivated and unable to put the book down. I found the story both really lovely and sad.The romance in the book is so beautiful that it almost beats romance in other romance novels. The main character Taylor Markham is a 17 year old girl who lives at the Jellicoe boarding school. On the outside she seems very tough but underneath it all she is very fragile. She was abounded by her mother at fourteen and do not have an idea where her mother is now. The book is about looking for something you been missing and feeling empty and lost but then finding these things that makes you whole. I did not know if I really liked the book when I stated reading it cause it was just so unclear. But when I had finished it and everything made sense and I got a closure of the story I found myself loving everything about it. I recommend this book to anyone who would like a good, touching, can not put down kind of book.

Jellicoe Road Review	Jellicoe Road is a boarding school where social aspects are taken seriously and adults are not allowed to know details. Taylor Markham was abandoned at a gas station by her drug-addicted mother at age eleven. She is 17, lives in Jellicoe School, with many state wards and troubled children. She is in charge of her House of younger girls and is expected to lead an ongoing 'territory war' between the Jellicoe School kids. She battles with the 'Townies' and the Cadets. Her main source of parental guidance (Hannah) goes missing and she becomes emotionally distraught. The genre is mystery; however, the story line is more about the intense journey instead of solving unanswered questions. Within Jellicoe Road relationships are formed between the most different of people. Taylor’s house has been burnt down and in the ruins she finds the most love from the people she didn’t appreciate as much as she should have. After talking to her house mate Raffy, Taylor internally decides “to vow to keep Raffy around for the rest of (her) life.” This quote magnifies the love between friends and the safety net everyone forms with each other.Jellicoe road can be seen in many different ways, from the inside it is a competitive confusing place where trust is always at question. Although the houses negotiate for territory they know inside what is right and what belongs to whom. Often threatening each other, “Whatever is now covered up will be uncovered and every secret will be made known.” Within the Jellicoe system are people that know everything about each other yet now are in competition.

Perhaps part of my problem with this book is that I was constantly comparing it to Looking for Alibrandi, which dominated my teen years. That and the fact that I went to high school in an area where lots of the boys' schools have cadet corps, and I know what total asshats cadets can be. Really, it was only the fact that it had so many positive reviews from people I trust that kept me reading. The first hundred-odd pages was enormously confusing. I had no idea who the protagonist was, other than that her name was Taylor and that she attended a boarding school somewhere in rural New South Wales. Based on the fact that it's seven hours from Sydney, you go through Yass to get there and it's somewhere near the Murrumbidgee based on various names that crop up in the story, I'm going with somewhere around Hay, but that's just because I like to have some kind of sense of where things are set when I read Australian books. ANYWAY. It took a LONG time for the story to get going. Like, a third of the book kind of long time. Prior to that, there were ideas flying around everywhere, and overlapping stories, and I generally felt like my copy of the book was missing at least 50 pages of story and that I'd just been dumped in the middle. But I persevered, and it did get better. The overlapping stories came together beautifully, and I loved Taylor slowly discovering that not everything is the way she thinks it is. Some of the scenes were absolutely beautiful. I think it would have been a 4 star book for me if it hadn't taken so long for me to feel involved in the story. Perhaps it's one that will grow on me with rereads in the future...

The beginning of this book is so confusing, I almost abandoned it, but I'm nine chapters in now and totally hooked on the mystery of who everyone is and how they are connected...so, the mystery doesn't last too long, but by the time you've figured out who's who, the characters have become interesting, and you want to see what will happen. It's a little bit hard to characterize this book as "realistic," since it has a feeling of unreality both because the setting seems a bit implausible and the dreams are mystical, but it isn't a fantasy either. The setting is a rural boarding school (in Australia) apparently largely for troubled kids and orphans, where there is an annual battle for territory between the students of the school, the townies and the cadets from a military school that spend time camping nearby. Taylor Markham, who was abandoned by her mother years earlier, becomes the leader of the students in her last year at the school, and also is in charge of the care of all of the students in her house. Hannah, a woman who lives in an unfinished house by the river, has provided a refuge and support to Taylor since picking her up from the store where she was abandoned. But Hannah mysteriously disappears, leaving behind a sad and mysterious manuscript, just when Taylor feels she needs her most. When the cadets come, Jonah Griggs is their leader, and he and Taylor have an uncomfortable and confusing history. To further complicate the normal territorial wars, the townies' leader Santangelo, is a lifelong friend of Taylor's best friend at school, Rafaela. Everything is tied together in a tangle that is revealed gradually.

I cringe as I give this book three stars. Most of my friends who have read it loved it. Which goes to show what we all know, books don't affect all people the same. I can understand why people liked the book, but for me it was really slow in the beginning and I just wasn't getting it. I got the general idea that Taylor had been abandoned by her mother on Jellicoe Road. Hannah, the woman who found her and who has given her a home has now disappeared. Perhaps it is me but I had trouble figuring out the boarding school that Taylor is attending and just what this "war" these kids are conducting between "Townies", "Cadets" and the "Houses" was all about. I still don't really understand it. I made one error in reading this book, and this is advice for anyone who is going to read it. I did not pay enough attention to the story that Hannah had written and Taylor is reading a page or two at a time. I think I was too concerned with trying to figure out this world Taylor is living in and missed some details that later play a major part in the story. There is romance in this book between Taylor and Jonah and that part was nicely done. There is also a touch of the supernatural in Taylor's dreams when she loses consciousness. It's a mystery of sorts as this girl tries to figure out who everyone is and what part they played in her early life. It is not a bad book and I was never tempted to not finish it, but I kind of had to make myself pick it up and keep reading at times. I just never was really in it.

I glanced over the other glowing 5 star reviews and somehow I feel guilty for rating this an honest 3 stars, meaning, I did like it... but not to point of "really" liking it.Like other reviewers, I felt completely lost in the first 100 pages and wanted to give up at several points, but other reader's assertions that it would all click into place pushed me to finish the book. Yes, it does get better.The main problem is I couldn't picture what the setting and some characters looked like. It's my personal thing that I often struggle with, but some aspects never clicked. For example, the fact that there would be territory wars between the Cadets/Townies/Jellicoe students seemed unbelievable to me. And that all this would go unnoticed by the adults. It was easy to lose track of the characters like Anson Choi, Ben Cassidy, Mullet Brothers.... it seemed the only thing that defined them was their name and I found myself having to flip back and re-read pages multiple times just to be able to get a gist of what was going on. This jumbled-ness really irritated me in the beginning, especially with the pages of Hannah's story. Again, I emphasise my experience of the novel is shaped by my personal reading style - perhaps a difficulty in fully immersing myself into the story.Gripes over, I really did like the story. Very clever, well written and with strong endearing main characters that bind you to them. Examples of this are Taylor and Griggs. Perhaps this is one of those novels I have to read more than once to fully appreciate that. Will update review then.

Sigh. When a book wins an award and the majority of reviewers gush about it, I feel like I should pay attention.The last half of the book almost redeems the first half. Almost. But the first half was so confusing that the payoffs in the second half fell flat. I wanted to go back to the early part and reread it (hard to do on a kindle) and decided not to. I shouldn't have to work that hard to figure things out.The tone is realistic; I like that. The first person narration seems right. But the setting was... odd to say the least. They're in a boarding school but there's no actual school going on. Where are the teachers? Why are there territory wars with cadets and townies? (The turf wars had little or nothing to do with the meat of the story - why Taylor, the narrator, was abandoned as a child.) And why was every single main character broken? And why did the few adults in the book - all connected to the narrator by blood or by history - have to keep the secrets about the narrator's parents? I'm equivocating with a two star review. Frankly I'm growing weary of the star system. I would like to dispense with these stars because they say nothing really. Was it a quality book? Maybe. So many reviewers say it is the BEST book they EVER read. Okay, I believe them. It didn't do much for me, and if it hadn't been for their urging to read it to the very end, I might have stopped after 100 pages.

Jellicoe Road, written by Melina Marchetta, has a very captivating plot that will have your eyes glued to the book for hours, but the book does have its confusing areas. I did not really adore the main character, Taylor Markham, because I noticed throughout the book that she is not a very nice and joyful person to be around. This is because there were spots in the book where she was cruel to kids and through her actions, you could tell that she is a depressed and anxiety - prone girl. For example, Taylor was rudely sarcastic to Hannah, her mentor and guardian, "I don't have wings, Hannah" (Marchetta 21). It is not her fault that she is that way because her mom ditched her when she was only 11, and she only has one recollection of her father due to him dying when she was really young. I also feel that the author should have put more thought into the character development of Taylor so that readers can see how Taylor progresses throughout the book, since she was a major part of the book. I did especially like the territory war between the Townies and the Cadets. I thought this war brought a lot of captivation to the readers, since it is a subject that we have never experienced in other books. One thing that happened during the territory war: "On the other side of the room of the Darling girls are surrounded by Cadets while the girls from Hastings House look on in total envy" (Marchetta 294).

This is one of those books that you have to finish before you can form a complete opinion about it. In the beginning I found it very choppy and hard to follow. All of the characters felt disconnected, the narrator Taylor was a void for me - I couldn't figure out who she was and where she was coming from. As the story progresses the pieces start falling into place and everything starts making sense. While I can conceptually appreciate how the author structured the book to embody the experience and mindset of its narrator, I don't know if it is completely successful in practice. It definitely requires a measure of patience and perseverance on the part of the reader to stick with it long enough to be given sufficient information to start caring about the characters. I also found the "story" that is set in italic and interwoven with narrative a bit disorienting until it is made clear that is Hannah's story that Taylor is reading. While some of the mysteries took a while to completely untangle, I found that I was able to discern the true identities of most of the characters a long while before the revelations within the book. Even so, the way Taylor internalizes it manages to give it extra weight and intensity.By the end, I found that the story had exceeded my initial expectations. It is a transformative experience, both for the characters and the reader.

While there were some wonderful parts in Jellicoe Road,, in the end, it just fell short for me. I think if I had read this upon its release, I’d have enjoyed it more. Too many authors that have mimicked this format now, and it’s not as fresh as it once was. Griggs was the highlight of the book. I love a strong, steady hero, and he was he was solemn to boot. There was no reading between the lines with this guy; you knew what he wanted you to know. Unfortunately, I wasn’t a fan of Taylor. It was hard for me to tell what her motivations were, and there was a point where she crossed the line for me. She was never able to come back from that. The parallel story was much more interesting than the one being told in its entirety, and I thought that was detrimental to the overall book. The reason some of the secrets were kept from Taylor felt flimsy to me. It was predictable, and while there were some emotional parts, I was never able to fully connect with anyone in the book. I did, however, love Raffy and Santangelo’s cat and mouse game, and I wish we’d seen more of them. Simon also tugged at my heart strings, and I’d have loved there to be some sort of resolution there. I guess, overall, I was looking for more things to be tied up.This review was originally posted at Badass Book Reviews.

For me it was an OK read. Review: This story is one that tells 2 stories into one. It slowly unravels the mystery of a group of 5 friends who come together after a terrible accident on Jellicoe Road.It tells a tragic story of love and loss. I loved how strong Taylor was while she was trying to dig into her mother and fathers past. Even Griggs, who is the leader of the Cadet with his drill sergeant attitude, has a compassionate side that he shares with Taylor. That compassion is what helps Taylor as she goes in search to find her mother. Slowly you see how their love grows even at times when you think their relationship is over!At times I felt very confused on which characters story I was reading about. I feel that if I were to read it a second time I would understand in better detail the past of the characters more.Overall I thought that it was a good story. I don't think this would be a book I would buy from the bookstore though. I would have rather got it from the library or borrowed it from someone. I would still recommend this novel to anyone. It was a good story of friends, family, love, and loss.

First of all, this book is long. Like, really long. I listened to the audio book on 1.5x speed and I still feel like it took me just forever to finish it. I liked the flow of the story, and I appreciate any book where the author tries to make it more character than plot driven, because I'm sure that's very challenging. That being said, I found it to be relatively predictable for the most part (some aspects were surprising, but the majority of it went exactly as I expected), I didn't understand the point of the serial killer side plot, and the whole territory war thing seemed contrived. My biggest complaint though was the Jellicoe school. All of this crap is going on, kids actually getting kidnapped or physically injured in a fake war, and the teachers are conspicuously absent. Seriously, these are the WORST teachers in the world. The only person that even semi cares about these kids is Hannah, and she's gone for half the book. I just felt like this egregiously long book would have been half the length with some educator intervention. Not a bad read, but not my favorite.

I loved this unreservedly when I read it years ago, even in my extreme confusion. I didn't remember much of the story before rereading, but things came back to me and I worked out everything before it happened. I don't know if that was because I remembered it or if things were glaringly obvious. It felt a lot more like the latter.I was so disappointed that I didn't love it this time round. Mostly I was bored to sleep or rolling my eyes with incredulity. If Hannah was gone for six weeks, where were all the teachers or even lessons in this school for delinquents and derelicts. Was no-classes their all new method for teaching? Leaving the kids to play war games was how education happened these days?I totally regret rereading. I ruined my happy memories of how much I loved life and death on the Jellicoe Road."I'm very disturbed to find out the leader of the Townies has a soul."

Read for the 2015 Book Genre Challenge|Contemporary3.5 I wish i had enjoyed this book more, believe me, i do. And even though i could notice the sadness of it, i couldn't get too attached to the story or characters - I mean, i'm in love with Ben but.. -. I'm not sure what happened. The first fifty pages were too confusing -english not being my mother language probably didn't help- but then i got it and could read it smoothly - which hasn't been happening in a while so points for that- but as the story kept going i would still ask myself why everyone loved it so much. That being said, i still have high hopes for the rest of Melina Marchetta's books, it's not as if i didn't enjoy this book after all. It did make me feel, but i guess it's been such a weird year of reading that books are not affecting me as much.

hmmmm..... this is one of those books wherein you really really liked it or don't like it at all. its either you give it a 5 star rating or 1 star rating and not in between. reading this book i had a lot of expectations but sad to say that i only liked this book during the last few chapters of it. it was rather slow and boring 75% read for me and i'm having a hard time just getting into it. though i would say that the remaining 25% of it, i really like. and another thing i liked about it: griggs! i wouldnt say he's hot (though he is, in his own "i'm not aware i'm hot" way) but as taylor described him: he is one romantic guy having done what he has done for taylor and for her to come in terms with herself and her being. having said this, it's still worth the read if you want to be touched in a heart warming way.

This is purely a spoiler review. I was reading this and it had so many secrets that I had to look at snippets of other peoples reviews just to get some insight on what was going on, who the characters were and what was going on, so if you don't want to know the secrets look away CharactersTaylor Lily Markmen Jonah Griggs - her love interest, cadet leaderRaffeala/Raffy - her bffChaz Santangelo - Townie LeaderJessa -(view spoiler)[Fitz daughter (hide spoiler)]Tate - (view spoiler)[Tate Markman, Taylors mother, is dying of cancer (hide spoiler)]Webb - (view spoiler)[Xavier Webster Schroeder, Taylors father (hide spoiler)]Narnie - Webbs sister (view spoiler)[is really Hannah. This one is hard for me to review. I'm very conflicted on what to rate this book. It took me about 150 pages before I even started to pull together what was happening. It almost felt like I had started reading the second book in a series without reading the first one to understand what in the world was going on. I was so lost for the first 150 pages I was very close to giving up on reading it.Another big thing I didn't like was the language. This book is classified as a Young Adult book, but I wouldn't recommend it to any of the young people I know who are currently reading this level of books. The f-word was used so many times I lost count. Also there is some sex in the book (although not overly graphic).I did, in the end, enjoy the story. It all finally makes sense, but the way it was written makes me rate it 3 stars.

This was an intriguing story, with the past and present wound together like the fibers in a rope. The characters were complex and sometimes unfathomable, the setting almost otherworldly.That being said, were I an editor, I would have mercilessly cut a hundred pages from this book. I was mostly bored until page 218, and it was only because this is my friend Wendy's favorite book that I slogged through. At that page, I suddenly figured out the entire story. The pace of the book picked up and held my attention, for the most part, until the end. I admit that I am not a fan of realistic fiction and I like Marchetta's fantasy books much more.

I would actually give this a 3.5, I think. The book is a bit hard to follow at first as a host of characters and plot points are introduced in series of somewhat cryptic context clues...which slowly gain more clarity over the course of the story. I did start to figure out some twists early on, so there were little surprises, here, but the book has a lot going for it. The story centers on Taylor Markham, who, over the course of the summer faces a series of crises and revelations that answer her questions about who she is, who she came from, and where she is going. I found the characters to be honest, the story to be interesting, emotional, and ultimately pretty satisfying.

The only reason I am not giving this book 5 stars is because I honestly felt like giving up in the beginning. I couldn't keep up with the story at first, and it seemed like it would never get interesting. I stuck it out because all the reviews said that if you feel like giving up, wait until at least a hundred pages in. After trudging through the beginning of the book, and reaching that hundred page mark, it all started coming together. I'm really glad I didn't give up on this book. It was wonderful. So, anyone who is just starting this book and wanting to give it up, don't do it. It's worth the read.

I hated this book at first. Too much information, new characters, confusing, disorienting information. I thought it was one of those dystopia novels at first and I kept thinking how misleading the blurb from the goodreads description was. I kept reading though and didn't enjoy it much until I got about halfway through and then I could see all the pieces falling together and it ended strong enough for me to raise my star-rating from a two to a three. Parts were really well-written and beautiful; while others just weren't. Some characters were more likeable than others. I could see teenagers liking this a lot.

It's most certainly me... because the ending of On the Jellicoe Road was totally magical and perfect, and yes, I would agree that the ending made the rest of the book worth it. That being said, the rest of the book - was so very serious and bleak and just, for that reason alone, not more than 3 stars for me. Also, the first 150+ pages of confusion made me impatient. The multiple storylines, the characters that I couldn't tell apart... it does all become clear at the end of it all, but that was a lot of bewildered time that I really think could have been made somewhat less bewildering.But, I can see why so many others loved it. I almost even had a tear or two happening.

I went in only knowing the title, so a lot of the first 25% was spent thinking "how serious is this situation?" "is this post-apocalyptic?" "is this supernatural?" "where even are they" and so on. Kind of nifty slowly discovering what the deal is via scattered context clues sans any preconception of what the book is about... What I do think I'd say the book is perhaps about is that feeling of lacking control over your life and the information you do or do not possess about yourself and others, and the strugs that result. That's something I personally identify with, at least!vague review is vague

This was a very interesting story and, while confusing in the beginning, comes together quite nicely in the end. I really liked some of the plot devices use to make these connections and drive the story, and I appreciated getting to gain a gradual understanding rather than having everything laid out for me in the beginning. The characters are well-fleshed out and engaging. What took this book from a 4-star to a 3-star review for me was the language and the few sexual situations - This is not a clean read, and that is something I look for. Just a heads up for others in the same boat.

I wanted to like this book more than I did, partly because I really liked the other two Melina Marchetta's books I'd read (Looking For Alibrandi and Saving Francesca) and partly because there are so many 5 star reviews on Goodreads for this one. Overall it was a good story but it was really mysterious and had two stories being told at once and to be honest, I was pretty confused through most of it trying to figure out who was who and how they were connected.It did all come together in the end (mostly), but all the guessing took away a lot of the enjoyment of the story for me.

Ok, so....mad props to the YA readers who could understand what the hell was even going on for the first 1/3 of the book. I was completely lost. Couldn't figure out the narration or the italics and holy cats there were a lot of similar names to try to get straight. I keep wondering if I'm missing something major since all the reviews I've ever seen of this book are just glowing. My mind has been elsewhere this week, so maybe if deserves a second chance. Maybe. I shouldn't have to TRY to enjoy a book though right? Ugh.

The first half of this book is super confusing. I had no idea wtf was going on most of the time and I almost gave up on it. Only the fact that everyone loved it kept me reading. I loved Jonah and the trip to the city. I loved that the tunnel was real. And I loved the maniacal way the story was told, once I understood where it was going. There's just something about it that I didn't love, something that everyone else found in the story that I didn't. Maybe after I think about it and digest, I'll change my rating.

The journey through this book was a long and twisted road. Beginning with confusion and frustration. I had heard that this book was so amazing, and for the first 100 pages or so, I was completely and utterly confused. However, after persisting through the book, slowly I began to get more and more invested in the story and understood the beautifully written characters. It wasn't until the end, after all the pieces fell into place that I could fully appreciate this amazing book.

I think that my main problem with this book is that it took 200 pages for the story to start coming together. For the first half, it was just confusing. You didn't have enough information yet, & therefore the story dragged. Other than that, it was an interesting story. Nothing too exciting, but with an ending that really tied up all loose ends.

This book was a challenge, but worth a read.Surreal, and yet sometimes all too close.A well-drawn cast of characters who are all linked to one another in ways they never could have imagined and whose lives must invariably touch.There are many, many excellent reviews already out there on this book, so I am not going to try for a synopsis here.

This book has interesting characters and a nicely grim moodiness but much of the story was frustrating. The ending ties it up and redeems it but patience through the first half may be required by many readers.
It's a 3.5 actually. :D
Actual rating=3.5
Al fin lo terminé!!!
It was good but very confusing specially at first
Feb 22, 2016Such a slow burn. I thought I'd give up on this book but I don't normally DNF book and thank goodness I didn't! B.E.A.U.T.I.F.U.L.!
I felt like it tried to do too much. Almost magical realism, almost a romance, almost a mother daughter story, almost a mystery. Almost a good book.
Kinda confusing in the beginning but as things unravel, it gets so much better.
something different for me. It was a good mystery

This was a very poignant book that would be a perfect Book Club choice because it delves into lots of deep issues and there would be so much to talk about. A few things I liked: - Exceptionally well written. The writing style was intriguing. There were many connections and symbols. Fabulously well written.- The story delved into sobering societal issues. Not only drugs, homelessness, abandonment, and death, but also the cycle of abuse and addiction, how people handle trauma and grief and guilt, etc. - I like how the characters relied on each other and supported each other. They absolutely LOVED each other and trusted each other, like family.- I felt so deeply. I cried. I hurt. I ached. - I liked how the story unravels - revealing this connection and then that connection. With little twists and turns along the way. It was captivating.A few things that were hard for me: - If I had to use one word to describe this book it would be TURMOIL. There was so much emotional agony, chaos, damage, and trauma. It was tragic. There was still hope in the end, but if they were weighed against each other, the anguish/tragedy would outweigh the hope/joy in the book. That was hard for me. Yes, it had a happy ending but, ugh, it was so sad...- I'm not a huge fan of prickly, harsh heroines like Taylor. (Regardless of what made them that way, although that knowledge definitely helps me have patience for them.)- A few aspects of the book, although they were necessary for the plot, were unrealistic. Would Hannah really abide by (view spoiler)[Tate's request that she (Hannah) never treat Taylor like a mother would?  (hide spoiler)] That was just stupid that Hannah always kept Taylor at an arm's distance, never filling her need to be loved and nurtured, just to comply with a (view spoiler)[ drug addict's selfish request.  (hide spoiler)] True love dictates that she would raise Taylor differently. It just doesn't jive with what we know about Hannah. Also, why would Hannah keep Taylor's heritage a secret? Not tell Taylor that (view spoiler)[ she was her aunt  (hide spoiler)], that she loved Taylor and would always be there for her? Taylor was so lost and confused, and dealt with major abandonment issues. How could Hannah, who is supposed to love her so deeply, keep her in the dark and watch her flounder that way? Taylor was a tormented girl because she had NO CLUE what her story was. Sad, so sad! It was so wrong of Hannah. I don't care (view spoiler)[ what Taylor's messed up mom wanted. Tate relinquished the right to be the only mother figure for Taylor when she made the life choices she made.  (hide spoiler)] Why make Taylor suffer so? Just allow the girl to know that someone loves her for heaven's sake!- It was so sad that (view spoiler)[ Tate could not stay strong and live for her daughter.  (hide spoiler)] She dealt with her grief in such a tragic, destructive way. - I was disappointed that (view spoiler)[ Tate and Jude  (hide spoiler)] had sex when they were overcome with grief, sadness, and loneliness and were seeking relief. That is not what sex is about. It's not a way to forget. It's a way to draw closer and express love to a committed partner. That's not how it felt, though. And it was even worse when (view spoiler)[ Taylor and Jonah  (hide spoiler)] had sex. They were emotionally and physically exhausted, processing post-traumatic stress, and seeking acceptance and relief in each other. Before that, they were just starting to experiment with being with each other on friendly terms. They were just teenagers and only starting on the journey of knowing who they were and growing into themselves. They weren't mature enough for a sexual relationship. They had had a rocky, raw, harsh relationship that was just starting to have a tiny hint of sweetness, but it was still frail and suddenly having sex out of a response to emotional strain was not cool. There was just something so wrong about it. Their relationship needed to be based on mutual attraction, affection, trust, and support, and yet sometimes I felt like they were drawn together because of mutual anguish and dependency. (As an aside, I can't help but compare this to the similar situation in A Different Blue by Amy Harmon, which was handled SO MUCH better because the characters showed restraint when they knew they were under emotional strain. It was a great book, by the way.) I did not like the scene when she yells at him saying in essence, she hopes she never sees him again, and he gets in her face, livid, and says "I'm about this close to telling you to get the @#$% out of my life" (chapter 17, page 252). It was scary and it made me realize that they aren't really in love as much as they have a dependency on each other (this sentence doesn't even address the fact that they were teenagers, and were clearly not mature enough to know what true love looks like). Again, later on, he made a very telling remark about why he was drawn to her; I don't recall it exactly- he might have said it in frustration- but it was disturbing because it wasn't what love should be. It was the instance when she answered sarcastically, "How romantic," and I think that night they had sex. Yuck. The "romance" in this book wasn't romantic as much as it was raw. - There were a bunch of f-words. Maybe like 10 or so? And two instances of teen sex as I mentioned above. Although I liked the story, it was a heavier book than I usually read.

The only reason I found myself on The Jellicoe Road was because of my love for Melina Marchetta's outstanding Finnikin of the Rock trilogy. There's no denying she has a superb command of language, endless creativity, and the ability to rip your heart out and stomp it to pieces. When I read glowing reviews for OTJR by some of my favorite bloggers, I knew I had to read it. One click on Audible and I was suddenly whisked away to the Australian outback.  So what exactly is this book about?? ~shrugs~ No review really gave much of a synopsis. A lot of posts read "You just have to experience the plot for yourself!" Strike one. Apparently the story is about young Taylor Markham, abandoned by her mother in a gas station when she was 11, and how she has found herself plunked down at the Jellicoe boarding school. There's also something about territory wars between her school and a couple other groups of kids, and then at one point her caretaker goes missing and Taylor tries to find her. But knowing Marchetta, there's a lot more going on to the story. There's also poignant stories of friendship, love, loss...ya know...typical YA standards. So why don't I love this story like I did Finnikin? Same themes, same drama and tragedy. For one, the book starts out insanely confusing, and then you get pieces of the puzzle in a stylish attempt to create mystery and intrigue in the story. Strike two. I was too confused to enjoy the subtleties. For another, I just didn't love the characters the same way. Other than Taylor and Griggs, the characters seemed so flat and two dimensional. It was hard for me to really allow Marchetta to rip on my heartstrings when really I just didn't care. But that could be more of a reflection on my heartlessness than her writing. And finally, I just didn't like the protagonist. Strike three. She came off as selfish and whiny, and darn it if she wasn't crying every other chapter. She was uncaring to her friends, completely self-absorbed, and not always the brightest crayon in the box. And maybe some people like that kind of protagonist. She definitely came across as human, emotional, and genuinely teenager-ish. Full marks to Marchetta for nailing that characterization. I guess I just wanted someone to root for more. But dang. Marchetta is flawless with words. Her narratives read like poetry. Her stories are real and honest. I would definitely recommend reading this one before moving on to her trilogy. I think she has since become a much more polished writer. So while this wasn't my favorite read of the year, I'm glad I gave Jellicoe a chance (if nothing else I truly enjoyed the narrator's Australian accent).

"There is no place in my life for sentimentality," Taylor Markham thinks, near the start of Jellicoe Road. It seems true when she says it: she's 17 and has been at the Jellicoe School for years, and now she's "the one-in-charge" in the Territory Wars that happen for six weeks, in which students from her school face off against local kids (the Townies) and boys from a Sydney military school (the Cadets). The Jellicoe School is pretty much home for Taylor, though she also has lived in a nearby house that belongs to a woman in her early 30s named Hannah, who's been taking care of Taylor since her drug-addicted mom abandoned her in a 7-11 bathroom when Taylor was eleven. But Taylor's story isn't the only one we get: there's also a story from decades before that starts with a car crash on Jellicoe Road: we quickly learn that this other story is a book that Hannah's writing, but Taylor wonders if it's more than that, too. At the start of the book, I found the dual narratives somewhat off-putting, and had a hard time getting into the book generally: it felt like there was a lot going on and it didn't all flow together, and I wasn't really into some of the moments of magical realism. But by the end, I was sitting on my couch in tears, so I'd say Jellicoe Road won me over, magical realism and all. What makes the book work for me, mostly, is Taylor, and how she grows over the course of it. She's so closed-off when the book starts (understandably, given her childhood): she has a hard time trusting people and tells herself she isn't particularly interested in changing that. But of course that isn't totally true, and on some level she knows it. I like how we get to see Taylor becoming friends with other kids from her school, and becoming close to the leaders of the Townies and the Cadets as well (especially the leader of the Cadets, a kid named Jonah she knows from a few years back). And I like how we get to see her learning more about Hannah and her mom and the other kids who were part of their close-knit circle of friends, back when they were kids and teenagers, and how she starts to understand some things about why her mother has done the things she's done.

I've struggled with the rating, but I think this is more a 3.5 star book because while it did win me over by the end, it took a long time to do so. This book wasn't bad by any means, but I had a few issues with the book. Some were reasonably wrapped up by the end, but it fully took me half the book before I felt invested in the outcome and I still felt annoyed by some things:1. I expected more fun hijinks and pranks in the territory war, but instead I found myself genuinely fearing for the safety of these children.2. It kinda felt like I was reading a sequel or companion to some other novel, and that even if the story wasn't really dependent on this imagined other book, I was lacking an understanding of the world - not just the Australian references, but events and relationships and context for the school. Again, a lot did get filled in as the story unfolded, but so much of the book just felt like unconnected pieces floating around.3. I don't think any of the adults have a valid reason to justify hiding so much information from Taylor in the way that they did, and I think she should have been more angry with them. Obviously, she has some spotted memories due some really traumatic childhood experiences, and much of the story was her discovering the connection between the past and present...but there were some needlessly massive gaps in her history. And given that that knowledge affected a lot more than just her, it's very difficult for me to reconcile.Ultimately, I just don't think this the right book for me at this moment time. If I'd read this when it first came out (when I was a teenager who was slightly obsessed with boarding school novels), I probably would have been over the moon about it. But the subject matter, especially at this time of year, made it difficult for me.

Edging toward 2.5, which is a bummer. The writing in this was lovely, but I had no idea what was going on most of the time. The Territory Wars at first seemed Hunger Games level serious to me, given the bodily damage and very real consequences, but then they just...stopped? For no reason? They were never really explained. So much wasn't explained. What was the point of the Wars? What was the point of the three differently aligned groups? I also exactly predicted the identities/truth behind Hannah's story and who Tate, Narnie, Webb, Jude and Fitz were. That was frustrating. I struggled with likability of the characters as well. They were just too intense, and normally I love intensity. I couldn't stand Tate. THERE, I SAID IT.But again, the writing was beautiful. Just...Minus 1 star for the near total lack of world-building. This was a convoluted mess of solidity in terms of what was happening and why. So...you're telling me these kids lost their parents and just...drifted in the Australian outback? There were no adults or care services brought in to that situation? I couldn't suspend my disbelief enough to fully accept that. But, again, nothing was fleshed out in terms of building blocks of their realities, so who actually knows.Minus 0.5 star for the intensity of the romances (view spoiler)[ both present day with Griggs and Taylor, and in the past, with the other 5 (hide spoiler)] at such young ages. It felt cloying and unbelievable most of the time.Minus 0.5 star for edging on torture porn levels of dramatic things occurring in/around Taylor's life.Minus 0.5 star for predictability and closeness of ideas. These people NEVER wanted to leave this little nowheresville place?

There's something about Marchetta's prose that makes this story beautiful. It's subtle and soft, but the emotion is intense. My heart naturally goes out to each of these characters and Marchetta paints a very intricate, raw, and beautiful picture of life in its purity and ugliness. It is truly fascinating.The one problem I had with the novel (and this was a pretty big problem since it essentially resulted in the novel getting bumped down two stars) was that I was 75% confused for the first half of the novel and 25% confused until the end. Like honestly, the original 5 have the following names: Tate, Narnie, Webb, Jude, and Fitz. Now, guess which ones are girls? Maybe it's just me, but it was so hard for me to understand the relationship between the original 5 (I had to search it up on Schmoop to understand) and the short snippets of their stories in completely randomized order twisted my mind upside down in its head. (For my question, the first two, Tate and Narnie, are the girls and this didn't really make sense to me because I had just read a novel with a female lead named Jude and I only found this out after reading 30% of the novel.)But otherwise, the close bonds between characters as they find a family where they never had one is truly inspiring. I especially loved the gradual way in which Taylor becomes a true friend, and overall, it just seems so natural and realistic, like this is just the way the world is: ugly and terrifying but full of kind, supportive people to have your back.

Teenager Taylor Markham's life is a puzzle to her. It is full of pieces that don't fit together to explain what happened to her father and why her mother abandoned her at the 7-11 on Jellicoe Road six years earlier. She is now a boarder at Jellicoe School. Taylor's puzzle pieces include a serial killer, a hermit, a scary brigadier general and an unfinished manuscript of a novel by Hannah, the woman who found her at the 7-11.I listened to On the Jellicoe Road and also found Taylor's story to be a puzzle. Neither her life at school nor her family situation made sense to me. It seemed that the book was one disagreement after another between various factions at her school over territory. I was confused and bored by the story. I pushed myself to continue listening since others found Taylor's story to be brilliant. Finally, as the audio book reached its last hour, the puzzle pieces started to come together and I began to understand what had been happening all along.Author Melina Marchetta never satisfactorily explained to me why there was so much secrecy about the whereabouts of Taylor's parents.Apparently, the print version of On the Jellicoe Road is titled Jellicoe Road. It won a Michael L. Printz Award for Excellence in Young Adult Literature in 2009. I received an audio copy through the audio YA SYNC program in 2016 (www.audiosync.com).Rating: 3-

On the Jellicoe Road is a book about a girl named Taylor who goes to a boarding school that has an annual rivalry, called the territory wars, with another boarding school. Taylor is the leader of her school, the Townies, and she develops a romance with the leader of the other school, Jonah, called the Cadets. But, things take a turn after Taylor's guardian Hannah, who took her in after her mom abandoned her when she was eleven, disappears. Taylor finds out that her disappearance has to do with Taylor's mysterious past that her parents never told her about. Taylor reads Hannah's book in order to find clues about where she might be, and along the way she discovers secrets about her parents and the origin of the territory wars, and in the end she winds up finding much more than Hannah. I enjoyed this book, and I liked that as a reader I got to help discover Taylor's mystery alongside her, but I thought that the plot was a bit confusing because it jumped around so much, and some points were not as clear as they should have been. I would recommend this book to any teens who are dealing with absent parents or who have parents struggling with substance abuse.

3.5I was talking to a friend who has read both Melina Marchetta books yesterday and she said that she liked Saving Francesca more, and I do agree.It doesn't mean that Jellicoe Road is a bad book--compared to other YA novels, it is definitely a gem of the genre. The main character isn't ditzy and useless like some of her other contemporaries. There were just a lot of things that seemed so obvious to me that I couldn't understand how Taylor didn't pick up on them (view spoiler)[like the Brigadier being Jude (hide spoiler)] and how it took everything a while to become as clear and explained as I wanted it to be (view spoiler)[I was really confused with how Fitz died for the longest time, and there is so much I don't understand about how and why Tate did while raising Taylor (hide spoiler)].Overall, though, it was a great book that makes me want to read more Marchetta. She's a fine writer, her settings and characters are never what you're used to, and her romances never take center stage to the actual plot.

🤷🏻‍♀️-the entire beginning makes absolutely no sense and it’s so hard to get into because of it. maybe i’m just dumb, but the switching from hannah’s story to taylor’s life is not made clear at all about what is happening and even tho i realize that’s the point, it just really annoyed me -territory wars game thing aspect was horrible and i couldn’t give 2 shits about it. it was also super confusing -i’m not from australia, so the school system and lingo was just so foreign to me, also leading me to be very very confused-taylor was annoying. i hate the rude, stoic, tough girl trope with my entire heart -jonah griggs was not all that he was cracked up to be. i read the reviews of everyone being like “WOW my boyfriend!!! he’s so cute i’m obsessed!!! the feels!!!” and i just didn’t get that. he barely talked he had no personality other than being nice. maybe i missed something? -too many character names so much happening -when the ending comes together, it is really satisfying and i ended up enjoying a little bit

Man the amount of times I've picked up this book then dropped it after like 4 pages is insane. This book has been with me for two years and I was never able to get into it because the writing style was so fucking confusing. Anyways I'm fucking glad I finally finished it but at the same time I kinda wanted more. Idk but I just felt detached. Yes the writing was eventually deep and beautiful but idk man I felt that the story was so lackluster. I pretty much guessed all the so called "mysteries". I expected much more considering it's an award wining book. Truth be told it was deep and sad and fucking realistic and there were a few lines that literally had me on the verge of tears but I just wanted more idk. The parts about Hannah's manuscript at the end of book holy fuckkkk that was some sad shit. Overall it was an alright sad book read at a sad time of my life lol.

I’m glad I stayed with this one— and that was NOT easy, I gotta say! There’s a LOT of stuff Marchetta’s got going on, but unlike most other books I’ve criticized for this, “Road” manages to eventually pull all it’s business together and make it poignant. At the beginning, “Road” had me stumbling around to place all the plot points but ALSO because I almost felt like they were speaking a different language . . . Words off the page just weren’t making sense together in my mind and situations also seemed weird and out of place. I’ve chalked this up to a cultural divide of a magnitude that I just didn’t expect from Australia. All these roadblocks though are ultimately just further testament to how well written this thing is considering how deeply it eventually made me feel. If you enjoy “Looking For Alaska,” this is better. And they’re in Australia!

I loved the intertwining of the stories, the competition between the factions, and the unfolding mystery. There were some surprising and fun twists and turns which I enjoyed. But I also found it quite confusing at times. It was probably a good 100-150 pages in before I remotely understood what was happening and what was going on. And even after finishing it, I'm still not sure I got all the ends tied up. Some of it might have made more sense if I was from Australia - but there were quite a few situations that just didn't make sense to me. And that made reading it frustrating.And then the main story itself is hard - and just plain sad. It has a goodish ending. But lots of really sad experiences for young adults to go through. I think it was a cool story, but it was just frustrating and kinda not believable at times, thus the 3 star rating.

When I started reading this I wasn't enjoying it at all because I didn't understand anything that was going on and I get it was done on purpose so as to have a sense of a mystery about the events that followed. However, I don't know why the style of writing and what happened didn't just appeal to me and that probably set the tone for the whole book. I have read other thriller/mystery books where I didn't know what happened but I still managed to like them so I'm guessing the writing style and the weaving in and out of the past and present is just not my cup of coffee unfortunately. Although I have to mention the second half of the book was so much better as the writing was clear and there was resolution, so the 2.5 rating is mainly for that.

It took me a looong time to learn to love this book. I did love it by the end, but I was reading with my American high school students in mind, as it was chosen by another librarian for a book club in our district. I feel like the first part of the book would be quite a stretch for many of my students, who would be unfamiliar with the world of boarding schools and some of the vocabulary in the book. I found the story difficult to engage with for a good bit of the first half, but those who stick with it will be rewarded as the beautiful connections begin to emerge and as the characters and their relationships grow.

2.5....I know, I know...I'm going against the masses on this one. I just didn't like it that much. The ending redeemed it a little for me, but it took so long to get into. I remember being on page 150 and thinking, is anything gonna happen? And then I was on page 250, and still thinking the same thing. I was getting so bored with it. I didn't like the "territory wars" at all, and that comprised up a lot of the book. I also found it somewhat confusing, at times. As I mentioned earlier, it did get a little better near the end of the book, but I like books that hook me from the very beginning and never let go. I'm sorry to those that love this book, it just wasn't for me.

For most of the book I would have rated it a 2. By the end it had turned into a 3, but I still won't be recommending it to others. It was just so frustratingly confusing for so long, and then so many depressing topics. I was ready to give up in the middle, and I normally don't give up on books. But instead I did something I've never done and skipped to read the last two chapters. Once I knew the ending at least had some light in it, I could keep reading and finish it. Don't get me wrong, it's well written and an interesting story, it's just not my type. I don't have the emotional bandwidth to spend my reading time on depressing fiction books.

I read half of a review on this book and decided to end there and add it to my “want to read” shelf... my thoughts of what this book would be about were completely different than what it actually was. I was confused for most of the beginning of the book, not sure if it’s because I was so thrown off about what the book was actually about or because how it was written. It took me till page 204 ( 70% of the book ) to actually get engaged and excited to keep going. Once I hit that point I enjoyed it and didn’t want to stop reading, I just wish I hit that point sooner! It’s a cute story and once it all comes together it gives you that warm feeling in your heart.

3.5 stars. I am rather conflicted by this book. Firstly, it starts out glacially, but that is only because I can't think of something that moves slower. When the speed picks up, it doesn't let up, so the pacing of this book is never quite correct, it's either way too slow or way too fast. The story itself did build up brilliantly, and came together with a few expected and unexpected shocks. The climax was a little cliche in parts, but also rather lovely to read. I would have preferred slightly more of a resolution.

I read this book for the first time when I was in high school and LOVED it. I was kind of in a slump so I picked it up again and it was just as good as the first time! I loved the characters and Marchetta was really good at letting the reader figure everything out as Taylor, the main character, was. I loved how everything came together and I loved Taylor and Jonah together. The relationships between all the characters are really amazing actually. They are so complex and I love this book just like before.Cw: racial slurs

Set in Australia, this is the story of Taylor Markham. She was abandoned by her drug addicted mother when she was 11 and was raised by Hannah and attends school at Jellicoe Road. There is a long-standing feud between the students at Jellicoe Road, the Townies and the Cadets. Hannah disappears. And there is a story about 5 people that somehow ties all these disparate elements together.It's very literary - which I guess is why it won the Printz. But I never really grew to care for any of the characters and it took me a long time to get invested in the plot as well. Meh.

3.5(Review to come. Let me gather my thoughts first... not to mention extra time)Okay, I actually made a review of this, but this stupid GR box deleted it, so I kind of lost interest again. Tsk.Edit 12/8/13 Disclaimer: I'm doing this in between reading breaks so review might be a little sloppy but will try my best.To start with, let me just say that I'm a big Marchetta fan eversince Saving Francesca. That book I totally dig because it's one of those few YA books that reeks with realism while still avoiding sex (it was only referred, which is still good to me). And then Marchetta sealed the fangirl in me in The Piper's Son. Loved it beyond words.It is not the case with Jellicoe Road. Actually, while writing this, I am still struggling on how to rate this one. But seeing how there are books that I admittedly say few of the best that didn't even receive a 5-star from me, then my rating just suggests personal preference.On with the bad: Taylor Markham. Ugh. I can't believe I'm even considering this, but I think I hate her just as much as I hate Katniss Everdeen. Taylor got into my nerve several more times than I can count. The fact that I'm reading the book through her perspective makes it that much worse. I have never ever encountered a lead character with so much negativity in her body (okay, maybe I did, but right now Taylor outshines them all in the worst way possible) that it was a struggle to finish her POV. And everytime I finish a chapter, I feel like treating myself to a Thai massage parlor. She's the kind of girl I take pains to avoid in real life, as she is very, very toxic. She has this false self-entitlement of the worst kind, believing that she is worthy of all the happiness in the world and stomping her foot on everyone's feet when it isn't delivered to her on a silver platter. She constantly blames the people around her for her misery, is ungrateful to the friends who stick to her Just Because (I mean, I can't see why, as she is just a prickly nose-in-the-air), and has no regard for anybody else's comfort other than her own. You know those kind of people who treat people around them like crap? That's exactly what Taylor is. C'mon Taylor, get over yourself! The fact that people around Taylor stuck to her only meant that the world in Jellicoe Road is that small that they couldn't escape bumping into her so why bother, might as well try to develop a (false/forced?) friendship with her. And even though I love Jonah Griggs, I fail to see how someone like him would take up so much interest in her. I mean, Jonah, you a masochist?! There are better girls out there! Case in point: Raffy the best girl friend ever. I think it is totally unreasonable for someone to be attracted to an obvious broken douchebag. Why would anyone want to fall in love with Taylor? Unless, of course, Jonah also this false self-righteousness thingy going on about him which makes him think that he is a kind of Superman or something - but this is a totally different story so will not dwell on this. Thankfully of course, because Marchetta is a street magician who is able to pull a rabbit out of a sack cloth, she was able to straighten Taylor's repulsive character. By the last 30 pages or so, I was able to see the total change in her character, but by then, I didn't care anymore about her. I just want to see how the story would tie up. Taylor's annoying personality singlehandedly took the star out of what could potentially be a five.The less .5 star (see, I always start out a Marchetta with a full five) is for that stupid territory wars. I mean, my country lost hundreds and thousands of lives, sacrificed families and loved-ones, just to secure our independence from greedy colonizers for years, and then I find this little orange book taking it up as 'just a game.' The fact that the characters even take up the territory wars too seriously - negotiating to leaders like it was a matter of life and death for them - offends me even more. How privileged these little kids must have been that they can afford to start a war all on their own accord. Tsk. Why don't you just toss Taylor in the middle of a bomb drill while you're at it, so I can maybe find a bit of solace in this abominable insensitivity? Okaaay, enough of the bad. Moving on.I am still glad to inform Marchetta readers that Jellicoe Road has her trademark knife-in-the-gut. Even now, whenever I think of what happened to the friends, I feel this pain in my chest that traps my tears and keeps them from coming out so I won't ever find my peace ever again in my life. Even Taylor's existence wasn't enough to mask the wonder of how Marchetta was able to tie the stories together in the end. Honestly, after 130+ pages of Taylor's negativity and nothing happening aside from that stupid (I will not tire of saying this) territory wars, I kind of wanted to fly to the bookstore and demand a refund. Boy, was I glad to have stuck with it. That's Marchetta's magic, I think. That she's able to draw in you a kind of faith which will make you jump off a cliff and still believe that you will land on the realm of rainbows and marshmallows. And while I may have personal issues on the whole 'dependency' thingy, I still find the narrative punch-in-your-pained-soul.
