I won't post spoilers, but if you're into deep life-wrecking-life-changing friendships, Jellicoe Road is the book to read.Will recommend it? Definitely. But not for those who know the truth about the territory wars.

A very depressing read. Between suicide, homicide, pedophilia, killing of pets, drug abuse, insanity, abandonment and homelessness, there really isn’t a lot of room to enjoy the words that are written.The first 100 pages are extremely convoluted and the main mystery takes so long to unfold that it’s painful. And when it does, it really isn’t that shocking. Looking for Alibrandi was definitely a better read.

I was pretty lost when I start the book, my friend Melina (the one who insist I read it) have to make me a power point presentation to follow the book. So, if you're a noob and lost soul like me, here's two basic things you need to know.The book have to stories.One is Narnie's story (italics) and Taylor's seventeen old GIRL, who goes to the Jellicoe School, It's a love story, but sad parts, funny parts and full of friendship

I have to admit I speed-read this novel in a bad way, in part because I couldn't quite keep track of all the characters in either of the narratives. Somehow I still think Marchetta spun together very compelling mysteries and love stories, and I liked that the world of this novel so powerfully emphasized the youth who ran it. It reminded me of the the Marauders from Harry Potter and the movie Brick.

I'd give this 3.5 stars but rounded down, not up. I loved the main character but found there were too many other characters that didn't stand out from one another. I found myself having to go back and re-read bits to make sure I had the characters right in my head. It was different enough from other books to make me want to read to the end and I would recommend it to people, just not amaaaazing....

Un libro que trata varias historias y muestra la pérdida y la unión. Los personajes son muy humanos, son personas corrientes que nos acompañan a lo largo de esta misteriosa historia y nos desvelan las suyas. Es muy recomendable pero mejor leerlo sin saber casi nada. Es uno de esos libros que llega a tus manos en el momento que debe ser leído y que une la idea del destino a la expuesta en las páginas.

2.5 stars. The beginning is incredibly confusing. The unfolding of the story is immensely slow. The pieces DO ultimately come together in the end. But honestly, it wasn't earth-shattering. Overall somewhat intriguing in its own right - and I actually liked the MC, Taylor, and her developed boyfriend, Jonah Griggs. The ending just fell a bit flat for me - and it took me almost a month to get there because I wasn't captivated enough. Meh.

3.5 starsIt took me a while but I did end up liking this book. The first half of the book bounces back and forth between two story lines and I had a really hard time following what was going on, things started to fall into place by the second half of the book (I would have given it a 4 if the storylines came together sooner so I wasn't so confused for so long). The story is sad, but interesting. Glad I read it.

I think that the second time you read this book, it would be best ...but when I finished it I didn't really want to spend the time going back and reading it again. It's a little confusing and hard to get into but after I did I read the rest all the way trough fast. I thought there was a lot of melodramatic things thrown in that didn't need to be there. It gives you A LOT to think about. The friend relationships were my favorite part.

While I did enjoy this YA piece of fiction, I found it a tad confusing. The introduction to this book doesn't really "explain itself". It took me some time in the book to piece together the information I needed to organize time frames, characters, and settings. There is a dramatically dark side to this book that becomes even more exaggerated by the twists and turns the story takes.Overall, an enjoyable summer read with the back drop of Australia adding to it's ambiance.

This was a difficult book for me to get into, in fact I really didn’t get *into* it until the last quarter. Although surprisingly mature and violently graphic at times, I’m a little shocked I didn’t like it as much as I was expecting. Hazy and wayward, I spent the first three quarters of the book expecting to find a “…and the whole thing was all a dream!” line at the very end. That was not the case, but the Epilogue indeed had me teary eyed.

It was an exciting read. The story has a different setting, not an ordinary school tale in the least. The reader might get confused reading bits and pieces of inter woven stories and dreams. But in the end all the pieces fall into place to make perfect sense. The cause of Webb's death turned out to be a slight disappointment. A general reader would expect a little more valid end to such an energetic youth. Altogether this story is nicely written and a pleasure to read.

Wtf?En general, una protagonista fácil de detestar, trama diferente de los típicos YA pero que no llega a ser memorable, y una narrativa que es un triste intento de La ciudad y los perros (donde no sabes que esta pasando ni reconoces al narrador). A pesar de lo anterior, es entretenido. En resumen... Un buen libro para dominguiar

2.5★???La verdad no sé cómo sentirme al respecto a este libro.Algo que si debo de reconocer es que hay algunas oraciones bellísimas y se leen tan natural. No es pretencioso o explota los temas delicados que toca. Por otra parte algunas cosas me tenían muy confundida. No estoy muy segura porque pasaron algunas cosas. Sinceramente la mayoría del libro me pareció aburrido y agregando la confusión It was a burning crash.

I wanted to love this and the writing is beautiful, but I just couldn’t quite follow the various characters and story threads (partially my fault that I read the first half in patches over a fortnight!). I definitely enjoyed the second half and the moving ending. I suspect a second read would add a lot of meaning.

I found this book to be interesting, but also quite confusing. I was not able to follow the storyline and relationships between characters easily. I felt like I needed to go back and start over from the beginning and read it again once I finished, so I could understand exactly what happened from beginning to end.

petition for “pash” to become part of the American lexicon ! //Jellicoe Road is realistically complex but that was also frustrating. The territory wars still seem trite and I’m still not sure how everyone is related, but those are likely because this world was so unfamiliar. That being said, Marchetta did a fantastic job of making you care despite that.

More of a 3.5 The ending didn't quite compensate for the extremely confusing first 100 pages. I'm happy I was absolutely bored at school and forced myself to continue reading. Once I started to understand what was the connection between the five kids and Taylor, I couldn't put the book down. I read over half of it in one night because I needed to see how it would end.

I found this book super confusing at first and I didn't really understand the story but as it continued it all came together. I think it was a good story, but I didn't like how it was presented. The non-linear scenes with the five was super confusing , so that took away a lot of my enjoyment with the book. Also I just found it quite sad overall.

It took half way through the book before I became interested. The only reason I continued reading was because I was up north with no other books available. Plus I had to figure out why it won an award. I ended up reading the book twice - the second time after I read some character and plot summaries. I enjoyed it the second time. That is the only reason I rated it a three instead of a two.

This book was one of those books that you have no idea how to rate!The first third of it was so confusing, so boring and so make-no-sense, and I have no idea how I could make my way through it! But by the end of the second third, I begun to like it! It wasn't a great novel but it was worth reading!

3.5/4 - This one was really, really hard for me to get into and kind of confusing in the beginning. It took 2 full weeks to read it because I just didn't care at first and didn't know what was going on. But I hung in there and I'm so glad I did. Love these characters. Love the two friend groups (past and present). Beautiful.

I like how this book doesn't spit it all out for you but weaves in and out leaving threads for you to follow and work out for yourself. Interesting characters with dark backgrounds and strong voice. An enjoyable read.

If I could rate the second half of this book 5 stars and the first half 2, I totally would. I was so confused and bored, I almost gave up. And then almost exactly half way through it started to click and the end was so good. But seriously, why all the crypicness in first half? So unnecessary.

In spite of the length of time it took me to get through this book, it was an entertaining and interesting story of coming of age and learning the secrets of your parents and their friends - and how those secrets infiltrate every aspect of your life.

3.5 stars. It started off kinda slow and confusing. I had a hard time keeping all the characters straight. But it was a touching story about family, friends, and the emotional roller coaster years of being a teenager. I enjoyed it.

Kul att läsa något man inte är van vid och så roligt med lite tonårslitteratur! Förstod nästan inget till en början men precis som Marchetta har planerat faller alla bitar på plats när tillfället är rätt. Ändå väldigt trevlig läsning.
I’ve had this on my must read list for yearsSo I bit the bullet and bought it. It was ok. Lots of back and forth between the past, dreams, and the now. Kind of reminded me of A Separate Peace

Conflicted between giving this 3 .5 to 4 stars. Was enjoyable, however was slow to start and not sure i would of liked it so much without the main characters romance. Because as you all know I am a sucker for romance.

I wanted to like this book more than I actually liked it. Although I found it interesting, the writing was confusing and there was a major, glaring plot hole that made absolutely no sense in the wrapup of the story.
2.5 stars
Me gusto el desenlace de la historia. Pero siento que la mayor parte fue muy infantil. Creo que solo no fue para mí. El final no me encantó.
Pure teenage drama read. It is fantastic and pure nonsense. Perfect summer read and I'm adding it to my classroom library.
I really wanted to like this book but it just wasn't for me
3.9 stars
I'm not sure how I feel about this, I liked it but I didnt.
I don't know why I didn't fully understand the book. Though, I got confused in characters, I finished the book.
Decent book about a school and territorial gangs in Australia.
I love the story of this book, but it was incredibly hard to follow. It took me forever to get through because I had to keep stopping to figure out who Narnie, Tate, Fitz, and Webb were.
I think I liked this book? The first half was super confusing and it sometimes felt overdone or over the top.
No lo entendí!!! :(
The first half of this book felt very rambling and aimless. I thiught the second half was top notch.
Not As good as everyone made it out to be. I don't like books where dreams mean things.
2.5Overrated. Too much drama. Unnecessarily confusing, boring and sentimental. It looks for the easy crying.
Bien hecho y bien escrito pero entre el exceso de drama y la confusión intencional en las 100 primeras páginas me ha dado pereza leerlo bien. Hay elementos que me gustan mucho pero quedan ocultos.
Tror denna bok hade varit bättre för mig att läsa på engelska; översättningen var inte speciellt uppfyllande. Dessutom ångrar jag att jag drog ut på att läsa ut den.
Wish I'd read it when I was 15-16
It was a good one. Felt it was boring at the starting, but once I got into the story it was good
3.5 stars
*3,5 stars*
Listened to first few chapters on audio. Initially intriguing but teen fiction lost me after a while and gave up on it.
A decent read. Solid characters and plot. Don't recommend this as an audio book due to time jumps.
it was ok

It was so sweet sad. It was two stories in one. I guess I had to figure out the present one to enjoy the past one. I was 200 pages into the story before it started to make some sense in my head. It's about friends, family, and the things that bind us together even when we think we are alone.
Ok, yes, this was a riveting book. But am I the only person who had most of the "mystery" figured out early on? ...

It was good but also incredibly depressing, I was going to give it a 4 but right at the end when the mystery is solved I realized that the entire main plot could’ve been solved with one conversation and it made that part of the book seem pointless. I liked the relationships for the most part, I think it would’ve been better if all the kids would’ve just stayed friends . I think that would make the message of the book more powerful.
Excellent book of writing advice. I love Writer’s style. Highly recommend for other.

I was really excited to read this one. It’s my first experience with Marchetta, and I was hopeful to find another YA Australian author to add to my list of favorites. As a Printz winner and an often recommendation from several bloggers, I thought it stood a good chance of becoming a must read for me as well. Although I found this book hard to put down and I *liked* the story, I didn’t find it a homerun, I’m sorry to report.Taylor Markham has had a difficult life. As a child, she grew up in the home of a drug-addicted single mother who abandoned her at a gas station on Jellicoe Road. She was found by a woman named Hannah, with whom she has an often turbulent relationship, and ended up at the Jellicoe School. She finds it hard to relate to her fellow students and is taken by surprise when she is chosen to lead her classmates in a territory war with the Townies and Cadets that began so many years ago. Just as she is getting started in this new role, Hannah--the only family she’s ever really known--mysteriously disappears, leaving her anxious and questioning her whole existence. With her support system vanished, Taylor finds friendship in unlikely places, all the while piecing together an old story about a terrible accident which also resulted in unlikely friendships, ones that Taylor begins to suspect may have affected her life in ways that she can’t imagine.Marchetta is certainly a compelling writer, and I found myself very unable to put Jellicoe Road down. Let’s just say in the two days it took me to read this book, my toddler was watching a lot of Sesame Street and eating a lot of treats. If that alone could make a book for me, than Marchetta would have aced the test.I enjoyed the complexity of the stories, and the ways in which they converged. I think what Marchetta did best was to illustrate the need everyone has of family, of belonging, of knowing that someone somewhere loves you. That connection to the past, to your own origins, is so tantamount because it gives you a place to be rooted, and then you are free to grow, to change, to become what you want to. When terrible things happen, there must be an explanation, no matter how tragic or how hurtful, as to why. There is a certain peace and calm that comes with knowledge and understanding, especially of a person’s past. Without that, Taylor was just a wisp in the wind, unable to connect to anyone, to really care about life, to look past her own strange and concealed history.Marchetta’s characters do come off the page; they are very much alive and distinct. However, that they are realistic is not a compliment I can pay. I really tired of Taylor by the end. She is the type of character I rather dislike, in that she acts as if she can take care of herself but is completely unable, in every instance, to do so. Every bit of new truth set off either a health attack, a deep depression, or erratic and misdirected anger. Are these all normal emotions for someone who is faced with her kind of life? Perhaps, but it still bordered on a hysteria that gets old fast.I found Jonah to be equally as unbelieveable, but in the opposite way. He was the ever-stalwart caretaker, which I found to be a stretch for any normal person, certainly in the case of a teenage boy. Were there mitigating circumstances? Yes. But I think even taking those into consideration, it was just a little much. No relationship can stand when one person is always giving, the other always receiving. And Taylor needed all of what Jonah could give, and more. That all being said, I still felt both characters had depth. Although there was more than one instance of eye-rolling as I was reading their interactions, I’ve got to hand it to Marchetta. Notwithstanding, Taylor and Jonah and all the other inhabitants of Jellicoe were all memorable characters.Overall, an interesting and enjoyable story, but not one I feel devoted to. I don’t know that I would recommend this one. I think if it were to be made into a miniseries, “soap opera” would be the term to describe it. I simply didn’t feel the degree of reality and seriousness that I wish could have been there.www.makniks.blogspot.com

I need to reread this book because the author is talented AND so I know what is going on and not skip over details that turn out to be exteremely important later on. Here are my random thoughts in no particular order with minimal editing since I am on an iPad.-There was a lot going on, and some of it just seemed to be added for extra drama (the child porn and tunnel/fire storyline at the end of the book). -It seemed extreme that the cadets would stomp on a school kid's fingers, so for a while I was thinking that this was a dystopian book where there was an actual war going on. -The previous generation confused me until the very end and I could barely keep their identities and connections to the current generation straight. This sounds like a dumb problem, but I think that the names in this book added to my frustration. A character might be referred to as their last name for the majority of the book, and then be referred to by their first name every once in a while. This is fine in dialogue, but it just seemed weird that with Taylor would mentally observe Jonah as Griggs even after they become an item and she had been calling him Jonah. -speaking of Jonah, it is implied that he killed his dad then later confirmed. But what were the consequences? Was it self defense? Was he a cadet as a punishment? Was there ever an investigation?-The origins of the territory wars didn't seem to click with the modern day version. These five individuals created it because they are such great friends (but from what I noticed they barely spent any time with it), and then it somehow morphs into an intense 6 week long battle where much of the point is to not spend time with your friends on the other teams (even though they obviously do). More transitional history would have been helpful. I mean I guess I can see them having the time to do this, since apparently they had enough time to dig a secret tunnel too.-Taylor sees a photo of the previous gen characters, and from this she can identify everyone EXCEPT Jude? The guy she has seen the most recently? Also there is a lot of repression, which I admit I am probably not familiar with(who knows, I might have repressed a lot of my life and not know it). It seems weird that she could have told one of her housemates that she was left alone with a sex offender and then repress it so that the other girl is her secret keeper, even from herself. She also repressed her happy memories with Hannah and Jude which just seemed convenient. Also why is Jude breaking a window to Hannah's house to get the manuscript?-I know I am not the first person to not grasp that Fitz killed Webb until it is brought up at the very end about being able to forgive Fitz. I know I am not the only one to be confused because Google auto filled my search for me after I typed in "who killed Webb" to add in the book title. I admit I skimmed over the first clue because I have very little interest in target shooting, and even f I had paid more attention I would not have pieced that together with Fitz throwing himself into the river to realize that Fitz was reenact in the death. -I thought that she did a good job linking how the struggles of the first gen characters impacted the next generation. I thought that Taylor's processing of the relationship with her mother was pretty authentic and I enjoyed reading her insights on the different types of relationships that one can have. -Why would Hannah not refer to the fact that she was Taylor's aunt though? It just seemed weird that she had seemed to identify as an aunt before the abandonment, and then she pretty much was like a distant counselor once Taylor was a student. I know she wasn't supposed to be a "mom" per Tate's orders, but she seemed unnecessarily distant considering how much she was able to bond with Fitz's kid.-Maybe I have been overdosing on too much YA lately, but is was probably a bit too much "poor communication" drama mystery for me. I think that the author has an incredible way with words that made me like this book much more than if it had been done by someone else. I look forward to reading more of her work in the future, and maybe giving this book another crack.

initially I wasn't impressed. the audio was hard to follow and the jump between two story lines was confusing. my interest picked up around chapter 17. Prior to this I considered abandoning the book but felt as though I was too far in to give up now. the book earned a 3 star rating from me because it did pick up later; I would have liked this to happen earlier.

The thing about Jellicoe Road is that I can't remember why I liked it so much. Which wouldn't be so bad... if I didn't finish it three days ago.I've come to view media from two - and only two - perspectives. Entertainment. Enlightenment. When I read Wealth of Nations, I don't expect to be entertained, I expect to be enlightened. That is fair, I think. When I watch Avengers, I expect to be entertained but not enlightened. That, too, is fair. Perhaps what is less fair is that when I read a novel, I expect to be both entertained and enlightened. Fair or not, that is how I judge the value of fiction. I expect to learn something new and I expect to be entertained as I do. My criteria for new knowledge are not stringent: I will take concrete knowledge about a culture, or a place, or a scientific theory, or a time in history, but I will also accept more nebulous knowledge, like a new idea, a new perspective, or even a new way of wording things.Once, for example, I went to a poetry reading of a Russian poet whose name I cannot recall who read poems about stuff I cannot recall. There were some fancy schmancy metaphors, I believe. There usually are. But I can't recall any of them. Except for one: the poet compared love to a chemical bond. He said, "I cannot unlove you. You changed my chemical composition." What a fabulous way of looking at it! That's all I remember. But it was worth it.Jellicoe Road did not give me even that. I learned the plot of course, the characters, the basic vibe and feel and emotion of it. It was far from a boring read. Yet nothing managed to make its way from the pages and into ME. I grew in neither mind nor spirit.Now it is no fault of Jellicoe Road that I am well read, that I am knowledgeable, that I am no longer a teenager. But then neither can I be expected to review it from a perspective other than my own. I think that, for a non-trivial set of people, there is MUCH to learn here, for the writing is clean and good and far from bereft of memorable lines.Yet those two missing stars is not entirely subjective either. The characters behave oh so predictably until about 100 pages in. Taylor, our relatable-but-not-likable protaganist, angsts up a storm. The adults are woefully absent and predictably oblivious. And tough guy Jonah Griggs plays tough macho guy to a T. He's tough, yo. It's not until this scene in a jail, when Jonah actually shows some compassion, that the story starts, that the characters are actually allowed to become humans, instead of cardboard cut-outs. Now, I'm not the only one who's saying this. Read even those 5 star reviews in here and you'll see them mention how it has a slow start. Most attribute it to the "confusing" pseudo-split narrative (which I didn't find confusing at all - in fact the 'mystery' seemed blatantly obvious to me, but luckily I wasn't reading it as a mystery and so therefore did not mind), but I would argue it's a matter of bad characterization.In particular: Hannah, who has been Taylor's caretaker ever since Taylor was abandoned by her mother some six or seven years earlier. Much of Taylor's angst derives from Hannah's disappearance early on in the novel. Unfortunately, her disappearance occurs before Hannah's character is even established! So there's this immediate disconnect between the reader and Taylor, and her angst therefore takes awhile to settle in and feel organic.Which it does. The characters do gain depth and heft and humanity. The split narrative eventually melds together, even has a delightful parallelism to it. The story gains poignancy and emotion and life.Yet, perhaps because of these early flaws, what I said about a lack of enlightenment still holds true. I gained very little. This is a story, whose emotional beats I have already tread many a time. This is not a unique story, not a unique setting, not a unique voice.As such, for me, Jellicoe Road is three stars. Objectively, I would say it's four stars. And for some lucky individuals, it has everything a novel needs to be a full five stars. I begrudge them that not at all.

I've read On the Jellicoe Road by Melina Marchetta twice now, and while there's a lot to like about the story, there is something that keeps me from absolutely loving it.On the Jellicoe Road is set in a small town and boarding school in the Australian Outback. When she was 11 Taylor Markham was abandoned by her mother at a 7-11 gas station. A stranger named Hannah picks her up and takes her to the boarding school where Taylor spends the next six years feeling abandoned. There is one incidence when she is 14 when she tries to run away to find her mother, but the Cadet who is with her gets scared and calls his school. The Brigadier stops them before Taylor can see her mother. Everything changes when Taylor is in her last year of school and Hannah disappears without a note. Taylor feels abandoned all over again. In addition, the start of the territory wars between the Cadets, including the Cadet who ran away with her, townies, and the school. Taylor struggles with her depression and overwhelming sense of loneliness as she deals with her feelings towards that Cadet and discovers her family history. Throughout Taylor's narrative are stories by Hannah, which turn out to be her teenage history that is markedly linked to Taylor's. There are a lot of depressed people and secrets in the story, both of which bug me. The depressed people I get because all of them have suffered tragic events, but it isn't necessarily lighthearted to read about. One thing I wish Marchetta had done is include more descriptions of the characters. I have no idea what any person looks like, except for Taylor's mother and Santangelo. It was very confusing at first to get the characters straight, especially since the story starts with Hannah's story and then the next chapter abruptly jumps to Taylor's POV. I felt like I need to draw a character map to keep everyone straight. There could have been more character development and description to sort everyone out.(Spoilers in the next paragraph)My biggest problem with the story and what keeps me from absolutely loving this novel is the adults in the story. Where are they? And why do they feel the need to keep secrets? Hannah is Taylor's mother's childhood friend and her father's sister. She should have told Taylor about their family connection. There was no point in keeping it a secret. When Hannah took Taylor in she promised Taylor's mom that she would not act like Taylor's mom, but that didn't mean she couldn't be the aunt or tell Taylor stories about her mom. Instead, Hannah continues to make Taylor feel unloved and like she doesn't have a family. Also, Taylor's mom was a worthless drug addict whose wishes maybe weren't worth keeping. Taylor deserved a mom and Hannah could have filled that role because Taylor deserved to be loved even if it hurt Taylor's mom's feelings. I think Hannah probably still had mental problems (severe depression, etc.) leftover from her childhood, and that may be why she didn't always make the right decisions. The Brigadier also annoys me because he kept secrets about his past, and again, there was no point in leaving all the mysteries around him so that people thought he was a serial killer. Besides the fact that there were some unnecessary secrets kept by Hannah and the Brigadier, the story is good. It has a magical feel to it, like there's something about the setting and story that isn't quite real. I enjoyed Marchetta's writing style (except for some confusion at the beginning). I think some people will really like the story and others will kind of like it, but I don't think anyone will hate it. On the Jellicoe Road reminds me of a lot of the other recent YA Australian novels, and if you have enjoyed some of those (e.g. Jasper Jones, Graffiti Moon) then you should enjoy this one.

I wanted so badly to fall deeply in love with this book. Before purchasing, I always do a fair deal of Goodreads research on my selections and the ratings for this book were off the chart. Nearly all the reviewers I follow had read it at one point or another, and all of them had given it a final five star rating. But I just didn't fall like the rest of you, unfortunately.As forewarned in several reviews, Jellicoe Road was very difficult to break into. Marchetta wastes zero time on explanation or world-building, preferring instead to simply toss you in and let you figure it all out on your own. It was an interesting experience (and not one I can say I've had before in the Young Adult genre) but the more I think about it, the more I think that there's a reason authors tend to avoid revealing so little. With such minor exposition, I read through the first one hundred and fifty pages (at least) without a clue as to what was going on and without emotional attachment to any of the characters, which I find sad in retrospect because they truly were an amazing set of individuals.The second issue I had was that, once I finally read far enough to appreciate the story and feel included, I unraveled the mystery far too quickly. By the time I reached the climax at the end, the swell of emotion didn't overwhelm me; I'd already figured it all out and that unfortunately made the packaging of the big reveal feel gratuitously melodramatic.Most of all, I severely struggled with believability from about halfway into the novel until the end. (view spoiler)[Why on earth would Hannah not tell Taylor who her parents were? Why didn't The Brigadier explain it to her when Hannah disappeared and Taylor was so clearly looking for answers? I found the "true identity" secrecy ridiculous and necessary only because it was convenient to the plot. And I was left with so many questions: What are the odds that Fitz just happened to aim exactly where Webb was sitting in that tree? And if he had a clear enough vantage point to hit a can, how on earth did he miss seeing a teenage body falling into the river immediately after? Why would five people who enjoyed spending time together start a "war" about boundaries—Wouldn't they want to share their space equally because they liked each other? How did Taylor not know her own mother's first name? I could go on, but I think I've made my point. (hide spoiler)]But, looking past all of my negatives listed above, I did find Marchetta's writing style to be absolutely gorgeous, as promised. The pages were filled with lyrical, flowing prose that held all the right emotions. No complaint there at all. The Australian settings were gorgeous and unlike anything else I'd read in a book before. And by the end, I was undeniably attached to several of the characters (predictably, Jonah Griggs was my absolute favorite, closely followed by Ben (who was adorable)).I have read reviews that say this book truly turns golden when read for a second time and I can completely believe that being true. But, as of this moment, I'm just not sure I'm invested enough to double the effort. I currently have Book One of her fantasy series on my to-read list; I guess we'll see how I handle that.

3,5 de 5 puntosLas críticas tan buenas del libro me han hecho acelerar su lectura antes otros que ya tenía previstos. La historia es trágica. Una niña de 11 años es abandonada por su madre en el camino de Jellicoe y es recogida por Hannah, una mujer agradable que la escolariza en el campamento que en ese mismo camino hay y cuida de ella.Será en el verano que Taylor Markham, la niña en cuestión, cumpla los 17 cuando la historia sobre 5 amigos que vivieron veinte años atrás allí le pique la curiosidad y le haga investigar. Más aún, cuando Hannah desaparece y encuentra un borrador sobre la historia de esos 5 chavales en la casa de Hannah. Comienza a sospechar que los rumores podrían ser verdad y a partir de ahí, los 3 grupos en que se divide el campamento y los cuales luchan entre sí aunarán fuerzas para descubrir lo que de verdad ocurrió en aquel camino.En este libro se juntan muchos sentimientos aunque muy bien descritos a lo largo del libro: miedo por un asesino en serie que anda suelto; melancolía por la desaparición inesperada de Hannah; dudas ante el comportamiento de John Griggs, jefe de uno de los grupos del campamento, quien a veces parece sentir algo por ella y otras la ignora; temor ante el brigadier, quien es su principal sospechoso de ser el asesino en serie y quien parece saber más de lo que aparenta.Muchas claves se irán resolviendo a lo largo del libro e incluso la protagonista compartirá un viaje inesperado en busca de respuestas que solo se verán resueltas de boca de la persona menos esperada.En primer lugar, la historia me ha gustado porque vemos dos historias diferentes mezcladas entre sí con muchos puntos en común y es la protagonista la encargada de ir uniéndolos. Con la ayuda de los chicos del grupo Cadete irá avanzando en sus pesquisas pero solo los verdaderos protagonistas podrán ayudarle a dar color a la imagen y desvelar toda la trama.He disfrutado de la historia individual de Taylor con su grupo de chicas, su sentimiento de independencia y a la vez de ese amor hacia Hannah que descubre una vez se ha ido ésta. También la historia de amistad-amor entre Taylor-Jonah y Raffy-Chaz. Y, sobre todo, cómo los grupos del campamento intentan invadirse unos a otros y tratan de hacer pactos, como si fueran "pequeños guerreros", y cómo se descubre cómo se originó todo aquello.Por otro lado, el libro, para mi gusto, también tiene cosas negativas. Una es que, al igual que cada persona es un mundo tampoco hay dos libros iguales y aunque la historia es estupenda, el final parece imitar en su narrativa al de The Lovely Bones y es algo que para mí le quita puntos pues no tienen nada que ver y el libro de Alice Sebold es bastante más trágico y emotivo. Otro punto negativo, de la historia es la cantidad de personajes que hay entre sus páginas y cómo eso puede hacer que el lector pierda el hilo fácilmente. En conclusión, un libro ameno y con el que es fácil engancharse y pasar una tarde entretenida, pero sin grandes pretensiones.

I liked this book, however I felt like I was not sucked into this book in same manner as The Luxe, The Hunger Games, or Tyrell. I think I find it easier to engaged into a book when I am familiar with the setting, the rules, or the situations. Jellicoe Road does not take place in the US, it takes place in Australia. Although the novel takes place in a school, with traditions, I just feel like an outsider looking in. I like books that have a lot of unanswered questions, however, I felt like I didn't quite know where the book was doing. I didn't fully understand the plot. And I know for a fact that I will have to re-read the book to fully understand all parts of the book. So becaues I couldn't really find my comfort zone within the pages of the book, I couldn't give it a higher rating than 3 stars. I found the novel to be wonderfully written. I can understand why the novel won the Printz Award. The characters are full of depth and layers. I adore the character of Taylor for her rough exterior, her protective covering, yet having the softest heart and love for her House. I felt like Taylor, who was abandoned by her mom, knew how to be a mom to the younger girls in her house. She might have been tough, she might have yelled, she might have wanted her space but she really loved each and every girl. This novel needed a context by which Taylor could find out her history. I though the turf wars were a perfect way to set up this scavenger hunt. However, I felt like many of the situations that the students placed themselves into were unrealistic. Or maybe just unrealistic for the United States. I don't know how many boarding schools do not have a closer eye on their charges as they ran though the woods, having secret meetings on a nighly basis. The ending was emotional. I was happy that Taylor finally finds her family, the family that has been protecting her all her life. And it was very sad to see her mother die. I was not prepared for her mother actually coming back. As a reader, I was more prepared to hear that her mother had already passed. However, I was happy that Taylor got some sort of closure at the end. Although this novel is beautifully written, I would have to think it would be a hard sell for young adults. The language is rather high. The plot is set in a country they don't fully understand. However, Taylor's character is universal and can translate to the liking of the right student. What I liked most about this novel is that it talked about the feelings of those kids who are orpahned by their parents. Taylor was oraphned by her mother by choice. Where as a lot of the charges at the school were wards of the state for more tragic reasons. I think there may be some students who may relate to this feeling of being neglected or orphaned. I also think another question that can be explored using this novel is the idea of whether a drug addicted mother should give up custody of their child for the child's well being? So there is a lot of value and questions to be raised in this novel.

What a strange book. I don't really know what to think. Apparently everyone else is raving about it. I feel like maybe there's something I'm not quite getting about it.I mostly enjoyed it, and it was well written. But I also had problems with it. Like the whole 'war' set up seemed bizarre and inexplicable for much of the book. Maybe there were formatting issues with the ebook, but the switches between the present day narrative and what was eventually revealed to be Hannah's story were really abrupt and unsignalled. Not even a blank line between them. So I'd be reading about Taylor's day, and then I'd be half way through the next paragraph before I realised the narrative had switched to the other story line. The confusion never lasted long, but it was jarring and annoying.Speaking of confusion - I never got it straight in my head who all the kids in Hannah's story were. Every single one of them had a stupid non-gender-specific name. I knew who the characters were, but couldn't match the names to them, so never knew who was doing what. Even by the end of the book I couldn't tell you which one was Jude and which one was Webb :-/I didn't really like/buy/understand the supernaturally bits.And I never really understood the school set up. The kids seemed to have a ridiculous amount of freedom and responsibility. I get that part of the point must be that adults don't really feature cuz they're so irrelevant to the important bits of the kids lives, but it basically seemed like a load of teenagers lived in a house with no adult, and an arbitrarily chosen 17 year old (I only know she's 17 cuz all the other reviews say so. Maybe it said so on the back of the book - but I shouldn't have to rely on that for information. I don't recall it ever saying so in the actual story) is responsible for dozens of kids between the ages of 11 and 16. That seems... an unlikely set up.Then, having all been fun and hijinks (I guess*), it suddenly switches tone in the final quarter or so with some really unsavory revelations about Taylor's past.And finally, that zinger about 'the serial killer' was just a bit too much. It over-egged the pudding.Hmm, all I've done is complain about stuff, but honestly, I quite enjoyed the book despite all these grumbles! (I wouldn't have finished it otherwise). I'm sure everyone else has said what's good about it, so I'll leave my review here. * Personally I found it horrific that the musician had his fingers damaged (I assumed at first they were broken, but he seemed alright a bit later), but none of the characters seemed to think it was anything remotely important! I had a problem with Taylor falling for the guy who inflicted that damage.******** EDIT *********oh, actually having read some of the other reviews: No. No swooning. Not even a bit. What I liked about it was the authenticity of the teenage voice/experience. That's pretty much it.
I liked the writing, but didn't connect with it the way most people do. I was basically confused for the first 100 pages.

I wanted to love this book. I was so sure I would. I remember epicreads posting quotes and pictures on Instagram and I immediately bought the book. So what happened? The book began in a very confusing way. There was no introduction to the character. It went from a italicized prologue to a 22 years later heading and then straight into the narration of Taylor Markham. Her voice was not different from the italicized sections, so at first I thought my Kindle bugged out and I wasn’t reading the beginning because I was so confused. Who is narrating? Is this not the same person? Where are we? What is happening? What war? WHAT THE HECK IS GOING ON?! Why am I supposed to care? What is important? WTF?! I felt like that for about 30% of the book, which is quite a large section to be confused and irritated. I knew from other reviews that the book would pick up soon and make sense, but I promised myself I would not rate it 5 stars even if I loved it because I wouldn’t forget how irritated the beginning was. Yes, now that I’m done it makes sense. Yes, it was a good story. Yes, I even cried. But the execution of Jellicoe Road was horrible and it’s not okay. I don’t forgive the author for the beginning. It should have done what beginnings of stories are supposed to do and explain, build, and draw me in. Not confuse the hell out of everyone. It’s not brilliant that it all “comes to together in the end” and makes sense. It’s crap. I loved the actual plot. I eventually enjoyed Taylor’s narration, even if I never quite connected with her. I still don’t feel like I knew her at all, but at least the pieces of her life were put together. I loved the end result of Jellicoe Road. It could have been an unforgettable and amazing story. I cannot say whether anyone was believable because I felt so disconnected from everyone. I was so confused for so long. I was angry at Taylor for being dull and not giving me more information. I liked figuring out who was who and finding out so many memories and layers were all interconnected, but I wish the execution of the story was different and smoother.  I wish I could give Jellicoe Road more credit for being amazing, but I just couldn’t get over the way it was told. I am frustrated that it wasn’t better and more organized because I would have absolutely loved it. I am used to strange writing styles, being thrown into a story, and being told two different stories. I’m used to YA. I’m used to this kind of fiction. Unfortunately, this just didn’t work for me. I am giving it 3 stars because it was a good story, so I don't want to underrate it.Review Originally published at Love, Literature, Art, and Reason book Review Blog

This book... I liked this book but this was a hard book to like. Marchetta starts it out in a very confusing way that really turns the reader off to the book and it takes a little while to get into it.The book is WILDLY depressing. I mean, even the happier parts of it really aren't all that happy. Happy part: Jessa doesn't die. Happy part: Taylor finds out about her family and who they are. Happy Part: Taylor finds love. And, I guess that the teritory wars are kind of over by the time the book is over. They've all become friends.But the inbetween is so tragic. It's all steeped in loss; the Loss of Hannah's parents and then her brothers and, even at the end of the day, Tayor's mother. It's this group of kids who can never seem to catch a break. And then, just when Taylor figures it all out, figures her family all out, figures out that her House on Jellicoe Road has really been her family and home all along... it burns down. And she almost loses part of the family that she has.Also, Taylor starts out as this strong character and she gets... weepy a lot. I don't know. I get that the idea is that Marchetta wants her to learn to depend on the people around her, and I like that she learned to depend on the people in her house, like Raffy (I LOVED Raffy) but Griggs... I don't know. Her romance with Griggs just always kind of bothered me. They were so co-dependant and not in a healthy kind of way.I liked the character development of the Five. We got all this backstory about them even though a lot of them were dead. I loved hearing their story and hearing how they shaped Jellicoe road. They made a lot of the history of that place happen. I liked finally knowing what did happen to everyone and that you were kind of let to know along the way without being told. I DIDN'T like that you never really learned what happened to Webb. Yes, you learned that his brother Fitz shot him, but you never really figured that out until Taylor told you. And how did everyone else figure that out? I figured he'd been missing all these years but they all knew. I mean, for a story so centrally located around one boy, and what happened to him, I think we should have gotten a little more closure about his story.But I like that Hannah found family and I like that Taylor did too. I like that Jellicoe Road is this place of sadness and safety at the same time. I really liked Marchetta's writing. I'd be interested to read other things that she wrote. For this book, however, I was only midly impressed.
I had a very hard time getting into this book. It was a struggle for me to finish but it definitely had very interesting and thought provoking points.

I've just become that guy. I've just become that guy who strongly dislikes your favorite book. You know that big revelation-y movie moment where the hero turned villain looks in the mirror and thinks "Who have I become?" 

That's me. The guy who disliked it. I look down the Goodreads page and cannot find a single review that was not five stars. I feel evil. Why didn't I like the book? Well, let's just be clear on one thing: Melina Marchetta didn't do anything wrong. The book had narrative structure, character motivation, lyricism, and that ever important note of finality. But I just didn't believe it. I didn't feel emotionally involved in the story. I didn't find a connection with any of the characters, but to be fair Marchetta didn't give me any trails to hold onto. I felt like I was catapulted into the middle of the book; there was no build-up, no clarification, and no way to see insight into the protagonist's mind. I personally think this book would have benefited strongly from a first person narrative. I found Taylor's character to be interesting, but I just didn't feel connected to her. I felt like I was looking at the car crash, not like I was a part of it. But the ending was alright. Marchetta's strongest trait is her use of lyricism, and it's prominent towards the end. So, yeah. I did not like your favorite book and I feel like a terrible bastard for it (I wanted to like it). Just picture, if you will, that you never liked Harry Potter despite the popularity. Picture that despite the things you heard you heard about Pride and Prejudice, it was a letdown. My inability to like this book is my loss. It's as if I've forgotten how to feel emotion. 

Forgive me.

When Taylor Markham was 11, her mother abandoned her in the 7-11 on Jellicoe Road. Six years later, she find herself as the unwilling leader in her school's traditional battle with the Cadets and Townies. But Taylor has a history with the leader of the Cadets, and teen war games begin to take a back seat toward Taylor's journey to discover the truth about her family. I know I am in the minority rating this book so low compared to all the other glowing 5 star reviews. I didn't hate the book, but I didn't love it either. I liked it, but that's it. I wanted to love it. I’ve read so many great reviews about it that I was so sure it would be a beautiful, poignant story that I would love. And I tried to love it. I tried to care about the characters, to understand them, to love the writing and appreciate the story. I think it was the writing that stilted the story for me. I didn’t really care for it. It is unique and does have a certain charm to it. But it seemed a little weird and random at times. As a result, the characters never did reach into my heart. There were times when I felt for them, when I wanted them to find their story and unravel their past, but they didn’t cry out to me with heartfelt emotion.I found the names really confusing and gender-neutral. Narnie, Webb, Tate, Jude, Fitz, Raffy. I found the setting and groups of people - townies, cadets - confusing. And the whole territory wars didn't make a lot of sense to me. If the Cadets are only there for a short time, what is the big deal about having boundaries and claiming territory. It just seemed like a side story that wasn't really important. There was also a death that I felt wasn't explained well at all.I had a difficult time actually getting into the story. It took almost 3/4ths of the book before I become really intrigued and felt enough emotion from the characters to care about what happened to them. The beginning was confusing, but then it started making a little more sense, and I became intrigued. There are some beautiful, heartbreaking moments in it, sweet tender moments that made me smile. Maybe if I wasn't working so hard to piece the story together, I would have felt them more.

I finished this book, and then I looked at my friends' glowing reviews. Damn it. Not again. Anything but this again. Oh well.I didn't like it. It comes very simply to this. This book presents a mess of confusion that is a puzzle dumped out on a table. Taylor's story is the border pieces, Narnie's is the guess-where-to-even-start middle, and the manufacturer declined to put a picture on the box, so you just have to start putting together like colors and hope you can begin to see what they might comprise. I dutifully pulled out a piece of scrap paper, and started tracking the 5 characters of the second plot, while guessing how they connected to the first plot, because the point is they're connected, right? Or why else are we spending time on this, and I was, I have to admit, bored. The mystery wasn't keeping me engaged enough, and because I was working on the pieces, they weren't inspiring an emotional connection. How can you care about something if you can't even make out what it is?Then roughly halfway through, Marchetta is like, "Maybe this will help," and gives some better direction on what's supposed to go where, and I figured out what the puzzle was supposed to look like, except at that point I really didn't care. Let me say for the millionth time I had a shitty childhood pushed along by a crazy mother, and Taylor did not give me the feels about it (view spoiler)[and I'm annoyed by how nobly her mother is presented in the in end, because...bullshit. She damages Taylor at every turn and we're supposed to get the warm fuzzies because she was broken and she's dying.  (hide spoiler)]. I didn't care about her or Griggs, or how everything fit together.I didn't cry. I didn't feel a sweep of love and affection. I didn't feel catharsis. The only thing that I even mildly connected with was Narnie's act of sacrifice to protect her brother's spirit. I was dumbfounded. It was created drama. If Hannah had just been honest with Taylor instead of cloaking things in mystery, this wouldn't have even been a story.Emotionally this book was a giant miss for me, but I think it was technically well-written, if occasionally boring, thus the three stars.

I wasn't sure whether i should give this book three or four stars because i had a few issues with it.1. It took me really long to get into it, for the first 100-120 pages i didn't comprehend the sense of the story at all.2. Also, i found Taylor Markham a little hard to relate to, i'm quite different from her so she didn'T exactly give me wow moments (though i did mark some stuff)3. What exactly is the point of those territory wars? How are they held, i mean. I thought the procedure was weird. To me it seemed more like kids wanting to be rebellious.Now, one might think why i ended up giving 'Jellicoe Road' four stars, despite all the above.A lot of that faded after about a third of the book, when i started to see an actual storyline beginning to unfold. The characters, who i so far only knew from the surface, got a deeper personality. Though i have to admit, there was not one character who i felt like i knew. Perhaps there were just to many, from the past and from the present.I was a little overstrained at first, i mixed up the characters and now, after having finished, i still don't comprehend exactly what the point of the hermit was. I know it was Fitz, but through those short description of the many different deaths of the past and the present, i had trouble remembering who died which way.I suppose i should reread this book in a few months time.The writing was poetic, in my opinion. It intruiged me to read on, if only for the structure and the metaphors. That, i have to admit, is the beautiful side of this book.It's not the kind of writing that draws you in and doesn't let you put the book down, at least it wasn't for me, but it's raw and emotional in a way.It inspired me and it gives this book something special that i can't seem to fathom into words, but that's why i believe three stars would not be enough.I have hoped to enjoy this book more than i actually did, but still, it was a beautiful read in a way.3.5 stars :)Edit: I ended up changing it to three stars, because compared to other books this one just wasn't as good. Unpopular opinion but whatever..

This book has been on my to-read list for sometime now. It came up under suggested reads quite a few times and on more than a few must read lists. In addition, it's received many glowing reviews by people I follow right here on Goodreads. So imagine my disappointment when I was underwhelmed while reading On the Jellicoe Road. Wait, let me back up. Before I felt underwhelmed, I felt confused. Yes, I'd say I was mainly confused. See, in addition to reading the book itself, I also read ABOUT the book, so I know confusion was a common complaint. But no worries. This will remedy itself around 100 pages in. Yes, you read that right. 100. PAGES. IN. (Mind you, this book is only 290 pages).Color me dumb, but I read way past the 100 page mark and still felt that I wasn't smart enough for this book. Yes, things came together a bit at the end, but for at least half of the story, I found myself scratching my head in confusion. For example, I personally didn't see the need for the war between the Townies and Cadets where the characters and their complexities seemed to be story enough. I also didn't understand the tone of this war. In the beginning it sounded like serious, apocalyptic, impending doom. But before long the groups started hanging out together. Were they enemies? Was it all in fun? I still really have no idea.I think the war was just a way to place the main characters of Taylor and Jonah at odds. They have a history with each other, but it didn't end well. Now they are leading opposing teams in the seasonal fight. Oooh, how apropos. And Taylor's mentor Hannah's disappearance? A way for Taylor to rediscover her roots I suppose.So if I didn't really enjoy On the Jellicoe Road, then why the 3 star rating you might ask? Well that's because I have to give credit where credit is due. Author Melina Marchetta really does have a way with words, even if I didn't always get all the words once they were strung together to make a story. Jellicoe Road might be long and winding, but at least I enjoyed the scenery.

This book is really difficult to rate - it's a high 3 stars. For me, the first part of the book was chopped up too much, jumping between past and present, fact and fiction, leaving so many unexplained statements that it was a little frustrating. Once I understood enough of the story, it finally flowed.The story is doled out in bits and pieces to maintain suspense for the reader, but it doesn't really make sense. The main character knows a lot about the central events, but the information that she knows is provided piecemeal to the reader. Once I had enough of the information, I had to wonder why the main character had been so clueless. The main character has also forgotten a lot of information that she remembers at convenient points throughout the story. For example, she told a story about her childhood to a friend, but she has forgotten the story. It was often implausible that she would have forgotten important events or failed to make connections. It came across as a plot device.However, I really liked the interactions between the teenage leaders of different factions and their war. I liked the uniqueness of their world. The main device used to reveal the story was an interesting choice, even if I would have liked it to be a little more clear what was going on right from the beginning. I'm not sure if the things that I liked about this book (that were 4 stars) were enough to outweigh the things that felt inauthentic, like the adult characters' inconsistent personalities and actions or the main character's inability to remember things or make connections just five or seven years later. The material is definitely for an older teen, in my opinion. I'm not going to put it with the books for Caroline to read in high school, but I'm not going to get rid of it either. I'll put it in my box of material for her to look through after she's read all the good stuff.

This book was a complete surprise to me. It has been almost 20 years since I first read Looking for Alibrandi in high school, but for the last 6 months this book had been staring at me from my to-read pile and I finally gave in and read it.The reason why this book won't get a 5 star review from me is because I spent what felt like the first half of the book with giant question marks hovering above my head. What is going on here? What kind of a school is this? Who is in charge here? Why don't the kids seem to have any authority figures? For the longest time, no answers were given to any of these questions. What was offered instead was a dual perspective between the main character, Taylor, and the third person narrative of a group of kids called Narnie, Fitz, Jude, Tate and Web. We had no idea who these kids were or where they fit in.I made notes along the way as I was reading when things started to become clear to me, and even when I stopped thinking about putting this down and started to enjoy it. This would not have been a book I would have read all the way through had it not been for all the reviewers before me who had the same problem and promised that it got better after it go past halfway. For all that, once I started to enjoy the book, I really started to enjoy the book. Taylor's reading of the previous group of kids who had gone through a very similar situation to herself, Griggs, Santangelo and Raffy grew on me. Once the book became less The Hunger Games before The Hunger Games was written and more a kind of mystery pushing towards the end where we actually get the answers we've been craving, as well as gifting me with the gratification of characters who actually interact and actually contribute something to each others' lives, I found myself enjoying it a lot more.Melina Marchetta is obviously a very talented writer. On first read, this one was just a bit too much for me.

My ratings changed several times during the book. The Prologue was a 5, but with Chapter One it dropped to about a 1 1/2 to 2. The first 150 pages I spent mildly interested and very confused. I've read books that have gone back and forth between past and present and have been able to follow them, but the way this book was written was difficult to figure out in the beginning. The author knew all the characters and how they connected, but there's a lot of confusion until the reader (or maybe just me) is finally able to start piecing together where they each belong in the story. The other thing that made it a 2 was the "territory wars" between the teenagers in the book (all adults were oblivious). Was it really a war? Are there going to be casualties or are they just going to keep arguing with each other? Why does it matter who controls the club house or the prayer tree? At one point it seemed like little more than school rivalries, but ended with somewhat interesting insight on how the "war" began in the first place. I might not have been able to connect with that part of the story because it's been quite awhile since high school. The book is definitely geared towards teenagers (although, I won't be recommending it to any).The italicized glimpses into the past were always rated about a 4. The tragedy that brought together five friends and the mystery of what happened to each of them was what gave this book it's character and made it worth it to keep reading.As the story lines merged around page 250 or so, my rating went from about 2 stars to 4 stars, dropped briefly to a 1, and then rebounded to a 3. The heart of the story dealt with devastating tragedy and deep friendship that lasted even after death and the profound impact it had on the next generation. The ending truly came full-circle. I'm stuck between 2 1/2 to 3 stars for an overall rating.

In all, an intriguing story line. What unraveled it for me was my firsthand knowledge of asthma, post traumatic stress disorder, and the re-emergence of suppressed memories. When the heroine in the story, Hannah Markham, who suffered from all of those aforementioned qualities, would slip into an asthma attack, it was poorly described. She biked and ran seemingly great distances without any effects to her lungs. People talked her down from an asthma attack. I don't buy it. I feel like more time should have been spent developing how an asthma attack feels and should be taken care of if you're going to use it in a book, or not use it at all. For someone that has asthma it feels insulting, it just doesn't seem like it's a big deal, when it actually could kill you if not dealt with properly. The disregard in such a popular book is like "Oh, it's just asthma, you'll be fine." As far as the PTSD goes, the effects are glossed over, the recovery is quick. Again, not buying it. Some of the triggers for the suppressed memories feel more accurate however. The recovery rate is different with everyone that suffers through something traumatic. But Hannah Markham has an extraordinarily high amount of traumatic events throughout her life that have been suppressed. Does this make her tougher or more vulnerable to the most traumatic one? But again, it seems that in telling the story, the author had a chance to shed light on the effects of PTSD and did a shoddy job of it. All of this being said, the characters are well developed, the story itself is interesting and well enough told. There are some twists in it that are unexpected. I simply knew too much from a medical perspective about things that I care about on a personal level that have affected a loved one of roughly the same age as Hannah. I guess I just wanted this author who told a good story, to take up the mantle of a powerful pen as well, and make it the best story ever told. I didn't happen for me this time.

This is my first YA book for the year and I am glad I finally finished it. I had started this one in my classroom and was stymied a little bit because it is by an Australian author and it was a little confusing at first to figure out what was going on. For example, I wasn't too sure of the type of school that Taylor (the main character was in) and why there was this pseudo war going on between kids. I was also having a hard time determining the time periods since there is two narratives taking place but no clear dates associated with either. Once I got all of that sorted out, I really did enjoy the storyline and I felt like Marchetta's writing is really beautiful. The story centers around a young girl Taylor whose drug-addicted mother dropped her off on the Jellicoe Road when she was 11. She is taken to a boarding school and begins a close relationship with Hannah, a mysterious young woman who lives on the property. Taylor is also haunted by her past, a suicide that she witnessed when she was younger and a runaway attempt where she met a boy named Jonah, but who later betrayed her. Flash forward to present day Taylor who is engaged in a territory war with two other groups of kids (one led by Jonah), her feelings towards Jonah and the mystery surrounding Hannah's disappearance and finding her mother.The story also includes a flashback of the aftermath of a horrible car accident twenty years prior. You find out later that this story connects to Hannah's life. So overall, On the Jellicoe Road is confusing, but still sweet and I found myself rereading parts to make sure I didn't miss anything. Will definitely recommend to students in my class looking for a mystery & a good love story
Confusing narrative that picked up at the end. Wish there was more to everyone else's stories instead of focusing so much on the main character because they had more layers.

Sad to say this was another book I went into excited about but didn't get the hype over :/Took me a long, long time to get into. I'm talking 65% finished and then I'm just starting to actually like it. The whole first half of the book is just a turf war, basically. I thought it was going to be a mystery and it started off well, with that back story, which I was interested in but then we're in present time with the main character who I thought was a boy because I've always looked at the name Taylor as a boys name (I'm sorry!) and then they said she and I was like thank god they cleared that up because I was lost as hell. Speaking of names, they were all pretty atrocious. I look at Tate as a boys name too and every time I read it my mind automatically shifted it as a male and I was like "Shit! No that's a girl." So all the names kind of irked me (Jessa was nice, that was pretty. I don't know what the fuck Raffy was. That's not even a gender or suited for an animal. Poor girl, she was such a good character too. Unfortunate.)Anyway, after they finally stopped bullshitting about the turf war that I didn't care about at all and was spoon out my eyes annoying the story finally got interesting enough to carry on with. It was all really, really predictable though? I don't know. It was written well and it was darker than most YA so bravo for having balls since most authors lack that now but still, I guess with such a hype I just expected more.(it sounds like I hated it but I didn't, it just irked me a bit.)I think I'm just starting to fall out of YA and that pains me to say because I didn't think that day would come. Lately I've been finding it harder and harder to like these books. Still holding out hope, though !

This book left me with a whirlwind of mixed emotions. One can imagine my surprise because my emotions are never mixed and unknown to me!!! I read many reviews that said it's soooo emotional and I think I numbed myself out in order to secretly prove them wrong. I'm not going to lie it was hella confusing but it was also entrapping of my attention.I lived and breathed that book for the week it took me to read it and even though I wanted to give it up because it confused me so much I couldn't do it. I was very, very fucking angry by the time I finished reading it because it was unlike any other book I've ever read. Most stories are so cut in dry with the beginning, middle, and end and I began to discover why it was almost scattered so neatly. It was scattered in a way that made sense but still remained mysterious. It was a great paradox and I think it was this way because Taylor was a paradox herself. She was scattered but still somehow remained put together. She was emotional but still soo numb. She was confused but also so understandable of her life. And I think the thing I failed to realize while reading this book was the fact that I was Taylor, I was her emotions, I had become her through reading her story. I was no longer just a reader enjoying the words on a page but I was Taylor Markham. I was trying to hard to figure out the sequences to a story much like she tried to understand her life. I had become her when I numbed myself, unwilling to feel any emotion. So for that I give it a five stars because no book has ever forced me into the realization that I wasn't just the reader but I had become the character reliving the memories of her life for the very first time.
