I am in two minds about this book. I picked it up because I finally felt ready to commit to another book after The Hating Game, and I figured this would be a nice YA book to ease me back in. Except it's been too many years since I read my last Melina Marchetta book, and I forgot that she does not traffic in nice. Her books are grief and pain and emotional trauma.I am torn because, on the one hand, it's a Melina Marchetta book, which means it is well-written and feels very real. She throws you in the deep end to start with, and the book feels very mysterious as you are presented with two stories that seem unrelated, and you spend the first 100 or so pages trying to figure out who everyone is and what is going on. I actually really enjoyed how the two stories ended up interweaving, and how the mystery is slowly revealed.On the other hand, I found it really really really frustrating at how the adults in the story refused to tell the main character anything. So much would have been solved with just a little bit of frankness. Sure, I get that you don't tell children every horrible thing that happens, but there were some basic facts of the story that there was no reason to keep secret, even from a ten year old, let alone from a seventeen year old. It felt like secrets for the sake of the mystery, and the adults came off looking incredibly stupid and negligent because of it.Because of this, I have to knock it down to three stars, even though while reading it, I would probably have given it four. Be warned though, this is not the book to pick if you are looking to feel good. It is sad, and horrific, and only at the very end is it hopeful.

Summary: Taylor tries to piece together the mystery of why her mother abandoned her at a 7-11 years ago, what happened to Hannah, the woman who lives adjacent to her boarding school and is the closest thing to a parent she has, who a mysterious hermit really was, if there's a serial killer threatening her friends, and what, if anything, this all has to do with Hannah's manuscript about five kids who used to live on the Jellicoe Road where Taylor's school is, where her mother left her. On top of that, she has to deal with leading her boarding school houses in a territory war against the neighboring Townies and the military school Cadets, even though she has a crush on both leaders of the rival factions.Verdict: Confusing, drags in parts, but fun nonetheless.Positive: The mystery was well-crafted and took me a while to figure out. The book's message eventually is about love, friendship, and standing together instead of picking each other apart. The romance was also decent once it got off the ground.Negative: It took me over 150 pages to figure out what was going on. Territory wars? Cadets? There was exposition, but it didn't really clarify things for me. Marchetta isn't big on setting the scene, either. I couldn't for the life of me get a grasp of the big picture. The mystery took a while to get off the ground, too. Taylor worries because Hannah disappeared, but most of the first part of the book is about the three different groups of kids struggling to decide who gets to use the Club House, and I just didn't care.But the Printz committee seems to have liked it, so who am I to be a detractor.

Re-read in 2020: Taking away two starsI remember reading this way back when and loving it. In the five or so years since, I realized I forgot so much about this story that I had to revisit it and, well, here we are. One of the things that I forgot about this book was how confusing it is initially. I had read this, and I knew what the big reveals were going to be, and yet, I couldn't help but feel lost at times. I also forgot about the teen angst. I'm pretty sure I was a teenager myself when I read this book so maybe I understood Taylor better, but this time around, I was kind of over it. Don't get me wrong, I love me an angry, unlikable and bitter protagonist, but Taylor walks the thin line between unlikable and I'm-better-than-everyone-else. There are instances where the writing patronizes "other girls" - those who flirt and only care about boys and obviously can't be witty or smart. NO. We're not doing this anymore. Not in 2020, satan. There's also another aspect of this story that I never paid much attention to but I can't help focusing on it now: It's the casual physical violence? (view spoiler)[ Taylor slaps Jonah, Jonah beats up Ben, Jonah grabs Taylor by her neck and shoves her against the wall? (hide spoiler)] Why was that necessary? Especially since there was already so much tragedy in this story. All this being said, I still enjoyed this reading experience, hence the "problematic fave" shelf. I loved the banter between Taylor's unlikely squad and where this story ends.

One word I would use to describe this read would be "tranquil". Because Jellicoe Road is many things, many of which I didn't enjoy, yes, but most importantly, it was  tranquil, and for me, that was the novel's winning streak. Slow-paced and off to a sort of vapid start, I had trouble immersing myself into the story at first. There are present day chapters, and then we suddenly switch to another timeline where completely different characters are doing completely unrelated things, and to be honest, I think that could have been handled a little better, especially the introduction of all the characters to the reader. But what I did not expect was how beautifully Marchetta was able to weave both the past and the present together without me really noticing until it was right in front of my eyes. While I can't really say that I was attached to any of the characters in particular, I did care about them to some degree, enough for what happened to them to matter to me. And while the climax is heartbreaking and sorrowful, I still felt this weird sort of detachment, which I think I'll chalk up to Marchetta's writing style. Taylor was a great narrator, and so were Narnie and Jude. I do think this had more potential, or maybe just not the right kind of read for me at the moment. Either way, I would definitely recommend it to someone who's looking for something tranquil, calm, and nostalgic.

The novel starts off a little bit too confusing, a common observation from people who've read it. The shift in the two points of view could at first be really difficult to follow especially when you're still trying to get to know the characters. However, once you get accustomed to it, boy, will you appreciate the power of Melina Marchetta's writing ability. I'm glad I didn't put down this story (when I was getting frustrated by the first half, hehe) because the second half was such an experience. I have to admit, though, that I found the supporting characters more interesting than Taylor. I just didn't really care for her and the only reason why I finished the book was that I was really interested in Hannah's story. Also, I hoped that there would be more to the territory wars plot. It kind of disappeared in the second half of the book which is a bit disappointing after so much build-up in the first half. Jonah Griggs' story is also a fascinating one and I found myself wishing that his past would be explored more. His speech regarding his guilt over his father's death was my favorite in this story. I considered giving this two and a half stars because while I didn't hate it, I wouldn't say that I liked it that much that I'd use it to introduce Marchetta's works to my friends (I'd suggest the Lumatere Chronicles, by the way). In the end, I rounded up in salute to Ms. Marchetta's beautiful way with words.

I liked this book, but I didn't love it. There was a great story in there, but it was coated in layers and layers of over-the-top drama and unbelievable events. This book opens with Taylor, abandoned by her mother in a boarding school on Jellicoe Road, becoming the school leader in the war against the "cadets" and the "townies". This is a really cool idea, and it brings some playful fun to the novel. And true-to-form, Marchetta puts together an awesome cast of characters, that feel real and form such amazing connections with each other. Each feels unique without simply being "quirky". But throughout the book, Taylor also learns about a group of kids that used to go to live in Jellicoe before she was even born. Thus follows a series of revelations of unbelievable connections between Taylor & the group, which she takes forever to realise, but that's pretty obvious to the reader much sooner. This part kind of ruined the story a little for me, because it broke away from the "realism" that Marchetta usually brings to her novels, and felt out of place. I would have given this book 5 stars if it had slowed down a little, and cut out half of the drama/so-called "mystery".Nevertheless, I would still recommend that you read this book, because it has a lot to offer. Just be a little patient with it.

This book was an interesting read for me and. Read it purely because a friend said I should and stuck with it because everyone said I should even when I wanted to give up and I'm glad I did. I found that the first 150 pages were really really confusing. I literally didn't have a clue what was going on, who anyone was or why they were doing the things they were. The writing was really beautiful and strangely intense but I was just so confused and had I not been recommended the book by someone else I probably would have given up at this point. Suddenly after all the time of confusion things started to click into place and I started to get what was going on, who was who and how the whole narrative fit together which made it so much easier for me as a reader to connect to the book. Once I got to that part I was drawn in and completely fascinated by what was happening to the point where I needed to keep reading to find out more about the characters and how everything linked up which was done so cleverly. I realise this review actually tells you very little about the book itself. It's because I can't work out ow to put everything into words. All I'll leave you with is the idea that this definitely is a book worth reading and pushing through because by the end you'll be left needing more and wanting to read it again straight away.

This story is one that tells 2 stories into one. It slowly unravels the mystery of a group of 5 friends who come together after a terrible accident on Jellicoe Road.It tells a tragic story of love and loss. I loved how strong Taylor was while she was trying to dig into her mother and fathers past. Even Griggs, who is the leader of the Cadet with his drill sergeant attitude, has a compassionate side that he shares with Taylor. That compassion is what helps Taylor as she goes in search to find her mother. Slowly you see how their love grows even at times when you think their relationship is over!At times I felt very confused on which characters story I was reading about. I feel that if I were to read it a second time I would understand in better detail the past of the characters more.Overall I thought that it was a good story. I don’t think this would be a book I would buy from the book story though. I would have rather got it from the library or borrowed it from someone. I would still recommend this novel to anyone. It was a good story of friends, family, love, and loss.**Brief note: I read this book when I wasn't really into reading. To be fair, I've heard so, so many amazing reviews about this book and I want to read it again. I feel like I just didn't get it...and it's deserves another chance!

4,5 estrellasNo tengo palabras para describir lo que este libro me causó. Me rompió el corazón, me hizo llorar. pero es tan hermoso, y te hace sentir tantas emociones, que pienso que es un libro que todos deberían leer alguna vez en su vida. 
"-¿Qué quieres de mí?- pregunta.Lo que quiero de todas las personas de mi vida, quiero decirle.Más.Pero no digo nada y ninguno de los dos se mueve."
Es cierto que puede ser un poco difícil de entrar a la historia, sobre todo por la forma de escribir de Marchetta, (por lo menos eso me pasó a mí), y porque al principio todo lo que sucede no tiene sentido. Pero cuando lo tiene, y empiezas a entender todo lo que está pasando, merece la pena. Es imposible no enamorase de los personajes, sobre todo de Tate, Webb, Narnie, Fitz y Jude. Su historia de amistad es tan conmovedora que no. hay. palabras. suficientes. También está Taylor, la protagonista, que siempre está buscando a su madre aunque no lo quiera admitir, y Griggs, un chico que no sé como puedo empezar a describir . También están Santangelo y Raffy y Ben. Todos los personajes dentro de está historia, pero es que todos, son absolutamente memorables. Esta historia es de duelo, familia, amor y amistad y es una de las cosas más lindas que he leído en toda mi vida. 
"-Toma mi mano- le dijo, llorando contra su pecho-. Toma mi mano, porque podría desaparecer"

4.5 estrellasMe gustó muchísimo el libro, la historia que se cuenta es hermosa —del tipo de “un grupo de marginados que se reúnen y se vuelven inseparables” que me encantan— y los personajes son muy frescos y realistas.No quiero decir mucho, porque creo que es mejor que para este libro uno entre sin saber absolutamente nada, pero tengo que decir que de las dos historias que se cuentan la que más amé fue la del pasado. Amé a Narnie, a Jude, a Tate, a Fitz y a Webb; y siempre que tocaba leer un fragmento de su historia me emocionaba demasiado. Eso no quiere decir que no me gustara la historia de Taylor, pero es que simplemente la primera que mencioné es increíble.Y la manera en la que las dos historias se entrelazan... asombrosa. No quiero decir nada más, pero en serio que es genial.La única razón por la que no le doy las 5 estrellas es porque al principio es algo confusa, pero además de eso esta novela es perfecta.

Uma oportunidade de conhecer a literatura YA produzida na Austrália, "Na Estrada Jellicoe" é um livro tocante, estranho e difícil de largar. Tudo ao mesmo tempo. É o que costumo chamar de livro quebra-cabeça. A autora espalha as peças sobre a mesa e deixa que o leitor tente encaixá-las sozinho por um tempo antes de começar a jornada guiada.A história acompanha a vida de Taylor, menina de 17 anos que foi abandonada quando mais nova, e agora estuda em um internato. Há dois conflitos que movem Taylor:- O passado: Ela não sabe quem é seu pai e desconhece o paradeiro da mãe, e quer preencher essa lacuna da sua vida a todo custo, embora nenhum dos mais velhos a ajude com pistas ou informações.- O presente: Taylor está assumindo o "comando" de uma das casas do internato bem na época em que começa uma tradicional disputa territorial da região. As meninas do orfanato, os citadinos - moradores da cidade, e cadetes que acampam por ali nessa época se enfrentam em um jogo de regras definidas que coloca os 3 grupos sempre em situações delicadas.Além de se revezar entre esses dois conflitos, tentando nos ambientar com a brincadeira, a autora conta duas outras histórias, mais curtas porém importantes:- Sonhos: Taylor tem sempre um sonho estranho. Um garoto no alto de uma árvore que vem falar com ela. Os sonhos a deixam perturbada com alguma frequência.- Livro: A mulher que cuida de Taylor está escrevendo um livro, uma história com menos disputas territoriais e mais amizade. Sempre que Taylor pode, ela rouba algumas páginas para ler. Um livro quebra-cabeça, um livro de histórias dentro de histórias, exige mais do leitor. Não tem jeito. Você precisa ficar atento a tudo que é dito, mesmo quando nada parece fazer sentido, para conseguir juntar as peças. E se o livro parece confuso de início por conta disso, a sensação de recompensa é muito grande quando o quebra-cabeça começa a se formar. Lembra um pouco o "Conta Comigo" do Stephen King, só que muito menos didático. Como a escrita da Melina Marchetta é boa, dá pra encarar a parte confusa sem trauma. E do meio em diante, você vai notar que o ritmo de leitura aumentará consideravelmente. Saindo um pouco das tramas, vale dizer que o ponto forte são os personagens incrivelmente reais. Tanto os amigos de Taylor quanto os rivais parecem gente de verdade com quem conversamos no dia a dia. Se você gosta de YA, quer fugir do esquemão americano e não se incomoda com um pouco de desafio, fica de sugestão.

Where do I start? Do I start by saying this book was a gift that I thought would be decent, but fuck’d with my emotions the whole way through?The beginning was a little shaky for me at first but as it started building, I had so many questions running through my mind. The main character is a lost girl searching for a home, and her love interest is boy who made a decision that will forever stick with him. I don’t want to give away so much but the back story of the main character Taylor’s exsistance is tragic and beautiful at the same time. She was made from love but was not able to feel that love herself. The events that take place is this book will make you sad, but the way it plays out is fascinating. Her parents true story, the friendships she encounters, and her fight for meaning will truly grab you. My ultimate joy in the books comes from the line of communication. No phones really necessary. Communication is done by walking to each other or sending someone else to deliver a message. You had no choice but to understand each other or find ways to learn and accept. A great quick read with raw love that flows through the pages. P.S. I love Jonah Griggs!!

Melina Marchetta, again, never fails to amaze me with this spectacular book. It never occurred to me until now how I'm super impressed with her awesome choices of her book titles. (Saving Francesca. Finnikin of the Rock. On the Jellicoe Road.) They're perfect. Perfect titles on their own. Just by book's title and you'll feel in your gut instinct that something extraordinary is about to happen by just reading a certain Marchetta piece. Anyways, this book has gotten me to explore the wonders of the achingly sweet past that connects to how a certain present evokes how a person comes to know life, as unfair as it is, has also something good that's left in it for her. Don't be too easily swabbed out by the first few pages, because I tell you, I too was a bit "URGH!-I-couldn't-understand-a-thing!". Just continue to read on. You'll be surprised when you're finally enlightened. =)PS: There's one of the subplots here that reminds me of the "Book of Tomorrow by Cecelia Ahern". Just the part of uncovering the past and all. But they're still completely different from each other. Both actually entertained me and somehow evoked some same emotions out of me.

“Hold my hand, because I might disappear.”Jellicoe Road was an amazing read. I didn't know what the book was about but I've heard a lot of good things about it and surprisingly, the story and its writing is so gripping that I could not put the book down.I'm honestly overwhelmed I can't express the way I feel about the book as a whole - everything was so incredible and so gloomy, the story has this melancholic atmosphere and !!!!!!! I can't remember the last time a book made me feel like I'm in a trance.I love how the story was told between past and present, in the same chapters and the development throughout the story, characters and their friendship is sososo important. Even though I felt confused at times I enjoyed this book a lot more than I thought I would. This one definitely will stay with me for a while.(view spoiler)[Taylor and Jonah though. They're my dears, I love them and their relationship and their development together so much, oh my. I'm so happy they ended up together and ugh I already miss them. (hide spoiler)]

Okay. So, 4.5 stars.I can't lie, that last third really got me going. What an ending. Gutwrenching, amazing, just... love. I so wish that I was able to read this in one sitting. I think now that things are clearer, my initial thoughts, or doubts if you like, (as suspected) were unwarranted. I just wish that things weren't so hazy for so long.Ms Marchetta has this way, with each of her books, of crafting characters that you just adore. Characters with emotions so real that you read and are left feeling raw and cut open and wanting to hug them and let them know that it will get better.I loved Taylor. Truly, I did. She's probably one of my favourites. And little Jessa, god love her. Griggs, Griggs, Griggs. You're a tough one. I think you're a keeper, though. Pretty perfect for our girl.I'm just gonna say, pages 284 - 289 - WOW. Call me crybaby.Looking for Alibrandi will be my next read by this amazing Author I think. I just hope that she has something as special as this coming out soon (but if not, would begging, bribery or blackmail help?).

I had been wanting to read this book for some time now...finally got around to it and liked it very much! I particularly enjoyed the author's way of weaving the uncertain nature of memory within each description. The story is delightful, particularly for YAs, since it involves many teenage themes (separation, raging against perceived unfairness, separation from loved ones, coming of age, and peer pressure).

It's my first Melina Marchetta book, and sure, I've heard/read a lot of promising reviews about her works, but this was beyond what I expected. Intense. The author knows how to build suspense, and her words are so beautiful I could cry.

I just personally wanna thank everyone who has encouraged me to hang in there when im reading this book. Because boy it was worth the draggy and slow first half. I guess the only reason I didn't rated this book a full solid 5 stars is because of that. The first few chapters and 150+ pages were hell to say the least. IT WAS SUPER BORING I YAWNED. And nothing ever makes sense like????? I almost dnf'd it. BUT HOLY CRAP when I entered the second half, stuff starts to pick up and slowly making sense. All of the revelations slowly creeping up i was at the edge of my seatI love the friendship element the most in this story. I love the history. I love the romance too. It wasn't over the top, just sweet and nice it managed to make me squeal. I love how this book has a smidge of humour in it at times that I was laughing so hard.THE LAST FEW CHAPTERS HAD ME BAWLED LIKE A BABY IM NOT EVEN SORRYI personally wanna thank Suya for this. This post is dedicated to you <3333P/s: though I honestly think i might have to reread this bcs istg i think i missed out a lot of things the first few chapters

I need desperately to feel it all, so when something wonderful happens, the contrast will be so massive that I will bottle the impact and keep it for the rest of my life.Reading the first, say, 75% of Jellicoe Road was captivating at its best and perplexing and a bit tedious at its worst. But the way the last quarter or so tied everything up in a such a magnificent way shines an entirely new and brilliant light on the work as a whole. Finishing this book, it feels like it was created to be pondered and re-read. I guess you could say it's kind of like the difference between a trip and a journey, in that way.I also cherish the added value that I got out of this book due to its significance to Ameet, who's one of my very best friends. It's so rewarding to read something that is important to someone you love and find bits of them hidden in the book, it's one of my favourite kinds of book magic!

4.5 stars. It took me well over 100 pages to wrap my head around the story and connect with the characters. But once I was in I was completely and utterly hooked. The emotional pull of the characters crept up on me. I didn't think I was invested in their stories, and next minute I was crying on a tram!The story weaves together the stories of two generations of teens who lived 'on the Jellicoe Road' just outside a small country town somewhere in New South Wales, Australia.

“She died in a house on the Jellicoe Road. The prettiest road I’d ever seen, where trees made breezy canopies like a tunnel to Shangri-la.”***I’m compelled to rate this novel 5 stars (I'm really not stingy about giving books 5 stars), but for the wrong reason. The wrong reason being: peer pressure. All my GR friends gave this book a 5 star rating. It’s like a rite of passage, if you want to be taken as a ‘serious’ reader, you’d obviously have to be able to appreciate MM. And certainly, this book is an exemplary standard of what contemporary YA literature “should be,” instead of low-culture trash, like the Twilight series...And, while I admit my distaste for the Twilight series, I’d like to believe I’m not so snobby, or pretentious enough to look down on my fellow GR friends that actually enjoyed reading Twilight. However, it’d be a different story if they were claiming Twilight to be a masterful piece of literature, and that the film(s) blew their minds. Then, I might have to crawl under a rock. And weep, silently. However, here’s why I couldn’t rate this book a 5:First, I didn’t dislike the book. I did like it, and appreciated it so much more than Saving Francesca. But, like others have mentioned, the story started off a bit slow, and very confusing; and yet, I don’t think it HAD to be. So, if the confusion served no greater purpose in the story, why make it so difficult for the readers? Now, moving on to the romance...Why do authors feel the need to insert a love story in almost every single “young-adult” novel?! Don’t get me wrong, I’m all about the romance. But, what can I say about Griggs? He’s about as generic a character as Edward, from Twilight. What was so proprietary about his character that warrants praise from so many readers? He was a twisted, brooding soul, with a horrific, brutal past, and violent tendencies. Wow. That’s just so deep, right? Well, I guess I was expecting a bit more from his interactions with Taylor. There were glimpses of the moments Griggs & Taylor shared on that train when they were 14. And, they do spend quite some ‘interacting’ because of the territory wars. Yet, their romance was just a secondary story, in the overall plot, and it showed. This was my greatest let down (not that their romance was a secondary story, but that it felt like one). I would’ve liked to see more. Feel more. Not just told that Taylor’s love for him was so deep, and that no words could describe how she felt about him. Then, there’s Taylor. She’s the asthmatic girl that was left behind near a 7-eleven, abandoned by her druggie mother at the tender age of 7. That one line of description opens up so many possibilities. This character could’ve been so rich, and multifaceted. I could’ve been weeping, and hailing Taylor as one of my all-time favorite fictional heroines. And yet, there was such a deep bitterness to her that I couldn’t fully embrace. Also, I know this is totally messed up of me, and I’m likely to be accused of being some kind of masochist, but, I would’ve liked to see her knee-deep in trouble. She was obviously suffering, angry, and confused, yet she was picked to be the leader of her turf, and she seemed to be a good girl, for the most part. What happened to that girl that ran away? Where was all that anger, confusion, and desperation? OK, so she avoided her friends, treated them coldly, and didn’t want to form deep attachments. And, she had strange dreams… So what? I wanted to see, hear, taste, touch, and smell her pain. I didn’t. **However, despite my ‘issues’ with the book, I did find the writing to be particularly inspired. I especially loved the vivid, detailed imagery of Jellico Road. I also liked The Prayer Tree (what it symbolized), and all of the side stories, effortlessly woven together, to forge a harrowing coming of age story, dealing with loss, forgiveness, family, and love. “There is just something about that boy that makes me feel like I belong. Belong. Long to be. Weird word, but semantics aside, it is up there with solace.”

According to GR, I first read Jellicoe Road in February of 2010, about seven years ago now (hahaha I feel nauseated realizing seven.actual.years of life have passed). I just went looking for a review from 16 year old me to see what exactly I thought as a teen, but it seems like I never did get around to writing one, although I do remember loving the book and recommending it left and right with lots of exclamation marks.I'm trying to re-read favorites this year and take advantage of being home with physical books this week so that's why it's my first read of 2017.A lot of it was a pretty fresh reading experience, as I had forgotten lots of the revelations in  Jellicoe Road, and the extent of tragedies within.I'll freely admit I was crying towards the end. I'm pretty sure I didn't cry over it as a teenager (I've turned into a big old softie).I kept thinking while I was reading: "this is the quintessential contemporary YA book." Like it's as good as contemporary YA is ever going to get. For me, in 2010, it was exactly the kind of book I wanted to read or write myself. It's off the charts angsty (angst being something I was incapable of recognizing as a teen, mired in it). Basically every major character is messed up colossally. It can get a little melodramatic just from the sheer number of tragedies in less than 300 pages spread through relatively few characters; two moms dying from cancer, two manslaughters committed by teens, a suicide and attempted one, a fatal car crash, drug addiction, teen pregnancy, a serial killer...But melodrama actually isn't a crime in fiction as some might have you believe, and Marchetta's prose is lovely enough you know you're in good hands. I think Marchetta is so sincere and writes so well that she steers clear of seeming like she's emotionally manipulating you with all the tragedy, when in clumsier and more cynical hands, this same story would become graceless.I think it's quite lovely how everything comes together, though perhaps the strands are arranged a little too widely at the start which accounts for the confusion this book sometime causes readers at the beginning. Even though I cried this time around I'm somehow less touched by this book now then as a teen. I'm glad I read it at just the right time; the impact a book has on you is definitely based on when you read it in your life. Sometimes a book speaks to you more, depending on where you are in life. Jellicoe Road no longer speaks to me as deeply as it did when I was its target audience but I'm happy it once did.I think a lot of what separates me now from as a teenager is it's harder for me to unabashedly love things.I'm dropping the rating from 5 to 4 stars since it no longer qualifies as a favorite for me, even if it once was. It's still a good book.

On the Jellicoe Road was a departure for me from my normal reading habits. I usually read speculative fiction or historical, usually with a romantic twist or two, and normally with a happy ending. This book had some of those elements but what it mostly was, was a beautiful tale of friendship, love, hardship, grief, growth and death.Set in a small country town in rural Australia, Jellicoe Road begins somewhat confusingly with a first person narrative of a young girl watching her parents die in a car crash. I say confusing because although this narrative is first person, this is not the main protagonist of the book. The only way you figure this out is at the beginning it says it is set 22 years later, but the main protagonist, Taylor, is only 17.Nevertheless, once you sort out who's tale you are listening to, the initial dreamy sequences seguay into a lovely tale of three different groups of children fighting territory wars that the adults know nothing about. Don't get me wrong, there is nothing deadly about these wars, it is merely a way to make the life in the country a little more exciting, and you find out in a series of flashbacks (not really flashbacks but too complicated to explain in a review and I don't want to spoil the revelations) who created the territory wars.Taylor is a young girl without a mother. She was abandoned at age 11 at the Seven Eleven on the Jellicoe Rd. She was taken in by Hannah, who is also a kind of house mother to the girls in her boarding house at school. Taylor has several issues. She witnessed a hermit kill himself when she was 14. She cannot relate to any of the girls in her house and she has repressed most of her childhood memories.She has been voted in as head of the students at her school which means she is the one who must devise the strategies in the territory wars. In the beginning she is finding it hard to relate to her schoolmates and she has to ward off coup attempts as well as all the incessant questions from her Year 7s.The best thing about this book, I think, is the growth of Taylor as a person. She starts off the book as a loner who has weird dreams to someone with a large circle of friends and family.This book made me cry, it made me laugh, it has some of the best rounded out characters of any I've read, be it a small character or a main one. I heartily recommend this one to everyone.

Jellicoe Road is a beautiful example of an emotional coming-of-age story that focuses on loss, love, support, and all the things that can go wrong in life, and how one can overcome even the toughest of times. The story begins a bit confusing but begins to explain itself as the tale progresses, weaving an intricate narrative of past and present. The story is real and raw in its heart breaking emotions, and includes hints of the magic and the wonders of life that we can never fully understand but should always take time to appreciate.The cast of characters in Jellicoe Road is well-developed and filled with amazing and heart-wrenching backstories, though it almost seems ridiculous how much tragic background stories can exist in one book. Even so, the characters stir emotions as they come to terms with their personal histories and how that’s shaped them into who they are and who they want to become. Taylor, the main character, is stand-offish and resentful of the world around her, but as she begins to open up and regard each person around her with more understanding, the result is a beautiful story of growth and finding good in the world; no matter how bad things may or might have been. Adding in an interesting collection of friends, adults, and a wonderful love-interest, the characters move this story and provide a lot of its beauty.The writing is powerful and captures raw emotions and feelings not easily expressed with expert detail. Marchetta’s characters are believable if not a bit much, and the story progresses elegantly as Taylor and those around her change for the better. Jellicoe Road is a marvelous story that tells of life, loss, and the strength of human spirit, a must for any fan of contemporary or coming-of-age tales.

This is a wonderful, touching, enigmatic tale of 17 year old Taylor Markham, who is leader of the boarders at Jellicoe School. Of five friends many years ago, who also went to Jellicoe School. It also tells of how their lives intersect, of how Taylor has such an affinity to Hannah, who is hidden away in the old, unfinished house near the school. How Hannah disappeared suddenly, leaving Taylor mentally stranded, unable to cope with the 'wars' between the Cadets, who is lead by Jonah Griggs; Taylor has a past with him, and it's not good! the Townies and the School, which happens every year.Hannah left a manuscript of writings she had been doing over the years, and Taylor decided to work her way through it. She found things she wasn't sure she wanted to know...sometimes wondering if she should stop reading, as it was becoming more difficult to confront her own story, wondering about her mother, not knowing about her father. When we meet the characters in this book, from the Brigadier and Chaz Santangelo, to Raffy and Ben, we get to know them all, and feel their pain. We feel their despair, their sadness, but also their happiness, and the love they all feel for one another.I thoroughly enjoyed On the Jellicoe Road, and I would definitely recommend it to everyone!

At the start of this book, I thought that On the Jellicoe Road was just a YA book about groups of teens that play this war like game that would end up with romance, but this book was much more than that. It was full of mystery and about an intricate family of 5 friends and how their stories ended. It was fascinating; a serial killer, a lost, dead brother, two forgotten children and a war that was supposed to be a game. On the Jellicoe Road is from the POV of a girl who was abandoned by her mother and taken in by a helper at a juvi-like home. She becomes the leader of the kids at the home, and the home is at war with the Townies and the Cadets. Throughout the book, mysteries are revealed, romance is sparked and wars are resolved. I'm so glad I decided to pick up this book, Melina Marchetta has yet again managed to write one of the best realistic-fic books that I've ever read.

Read for the 2016 YA/MG Book Battle. Full review--and my ultimate decision--can be found here.[Also read: 10 March 2012]As much as I adored Taylor's journey and her evolution as she realizes her place in the world, the story of the original five and their relationship absolutely tore out my insides. Marchetta did an amazing job of capturing that sense of infinity that is just built into some friendships, and the yearning for that sense of simplicity was just ingrained everywhere. I love how this book is a twister story: it starts with all these loose threads and begins to wind them and twist them tighter, and tighter, until everything is just woven together. I wasn't completely taken with the original threads of Taylor's lift, but as things started falling into place I felt like I was holding my breath, waiting for the storm to break.

Genul YA deseori este despre cum doi adolescenți descoperă iubirea. În Șoseaua Jellicoe, protagonista este departe de a se interesa de tinerii din jur; tot ce își dorește este să fie lăsată în pace și să afle care este, de fapt, trecutul ei. Recenzia mea o găsiți pe canal.
If Kerrie is reading this: thank you for recommending me to read this in June; I had no idea what I was missing out on!

Molyról átmásolt értékelésAzon könyvek egyike, amit nem olvastam volna el, ha nincs hozzá molyos kihívás. Az egyik "kedvencajánlós" kihívás listáján láttam meg, és később szembejött velem a könyvtárban, én pedig úgy döntöttem, hogy túllépek a vöröspötty, meg a YA-okozta libabőrömön, és megnézem. Jól tettem.Ilyesmit írtam róla, hogy:---Nem kellett „végigrobogni” a könyvön, mint némely másik rövidebb olvasásomnál; bele lehetett gubózni, mint egy ismerős takaróba.Egyrészt *nagyon* YA: Mindenki összevissza érez benne hatalmasakat és szélsőségeseket, miközben önmaga előtt is játssza a coolt, és előbb vereti össze magát, minthogy bevalljon akár egy negyed érzelmet is. (Hatalmas jópont, hogy a könyv végén ezt így szóvá is teszik.) A felnőttek megközelíthetetlenek, értetlenek és haszontalanok. (view spoiler)[De aztán kiderül, hogy: Ó. Jaj. Nem. Bárcsak…  (hide spoiler)] Senki sem védett; mindenki csorba és szenvedett és megtépázták őket a menetrendszerű sorscsapások. Főhősünk hangja hiba nélkül illeszkedne vagy hat másik hasonló könyvbe. Satöbbi.Másrészt: egészen régimódian ifjúsági regény. A szerelem jelen van, de közel sem központi szerepben; a tényleges hangsúly azon van, ahogy egy kupac ember családdá épül. A könyv egyik legfontosabb mozgatórugója a barátság, a másik a rejtély. A kettős cselekmény rávilágít arra, hogy (view spoiler)[generációról-generációra a lényeg nem változik  (hide spoiler)]. Egy magára hagyott közösség szabályokat és hiedelemvilágot gyárt magának. „Számháború” és „nyári tábor”, melyek eseményei eleinte vérontásba… később pedig zenekarba fulladnak. :)Zsánerfüggetlen erénye és hibája a könyvnek a „másik” történet. Tényleg magával ragad, ahogy a részletekből kirajzolódik a teljes kép, de nem emiatt, hanem végül ennek ellenére kerekítettem felfelé a csillagozást.---A dolog azóta annyiban változott, hogy: - Elolvastam a "Love, Simon" (Simon és a Homo sapiens-lobbi) c. könyvet is, felidéztem A. M. Jenkins "Night Road – Éjjeli utazás" c. könyvét, és felállítottam egy magánelméletet a különbségről a YA, és a YA-nak álcázott ifjúsági regények között.- Illetve nagy nehezen sikerült beazonosítanom, hogy mire is emlékeztet a könyvben lassan összekovácsolódó kis közösség.Mindkét fejlemény csak még jobban megkedveltette velem a könyvet.

This book confused me. I spent the first several chapters feeling mostly disappointed, but also frustrated, because I really wanted to love it and I wasn't sure that I did...love it, that is.Taylor was such an unlikable character that was full of annoying teenage angst. She almost came off as spiteful and petulant. I couldn't understand her, or the strange world she lived in. At first, it didn't make much sense, and I was trying to grasp all the pieces of the puzzle that were being thrown at us, bit by bit. The townies and the cadets and all the houses and this battle that the three groups were caught up in, each led by one character. Taylor being one, Griggs, and Santiago.Then there's this whole other story being told about 5 friends, an accident that brought them together, and a life that they lived together. It takes a while to clarify that this back story is important and directly connected to current events. Then there are Taylor's dreams of a boy in a tree, which also don't make any sense. So that whole set up was quite confusing for me, and hard to follow. However, once the pieces started to come together, and I started to understand and see the bigger picture and connect all the dots...well, I found it to be heart wrenching and incredibly beautiful and amazing. I loved the relationship that blossomed between Griggs and Taylor. I loved the friendships that were created, the bonds that formed, the different set of characters and their quirks. Once the story was over, I felt it leaving a mark, and it stayed with me long after I had finished it. The only reason I wasn't able to give it 5 stars was Taylor. Even though I sympathized with her and rooted for her, I found her so annoying. Her sudden bouts of irritability and crabbiness and the way she'd sulk like a child were frustrating, and although I understood where she came from, it didn't mean I was OK with the way she treated her friends and loved ones.Otherwise, a wonderfully told story, with so much beauty and tragedy intertwined.

Finished reading: October 20th 2015


“It's funny how you can forget everything except people loving you. Maybe that's why humans find it so hard getting over love affairs. It's not the pain they're getting over, it's the love.”
(view spoiler)[On The Jellicoe Road has been on my radar for a while now and it actually has been recommended to me various times in the past. I ended up really enjoying this read, but I have to say the first part of the story is quite confusing. Luckily I was warned that the first part is exactly that and they told me to just keep reading and things would soon start to make sense. They were right. This novel by Melina Marchetta is without doubt very well written and the whole confusement in the beginning is actually part of the charm. Why haven't I given it an even higher rating? It may seem that I'm contradicting myself, but I don't think I would have continued reading without the warning that the beginning is hard to understand. The characters are very well developed though and once you get an idea of the whole situation the prose and plot just suck you right in. If you like realistic fiction and don't mind a confusing beginning, On The Jellicoe Road might just be the perfect read for you!Taylor was abandoned by her mother on the Jellicoe Road when she was eleven and ended up at a boarding school. When she was fourteen, she decided to run away and try to find her mom, but she was tracked down and brought back by a mysterious stranger. Now she is seventeen and the leader of the school's underground community, having to lead the annual territory war with the Townies and the visiting Cadets. This year the Cadets are led by Jonah Griggs, a guy she has some history with. When the only adult Taylor trusts, Hanna, disappears, things get even more complicated for Taylor... Now she not only has to make sure they don't lose any more territory, but she also wants to try and piece together the clues Hannah left behind. What is the real history of Jellicoe Road?The beginning of On The Jellicoe Road didn't completely convince me, but the rest of the story more than made up for it. The prose, the characters, the plot and plot twists... Melina Marchetta used those in a way that once you are past the confusing part, you just can't stop reading. I will probably try to do a reread at some point, since I will most likely enjoy this read even better the second time around. If you like the genre, I would definitely recommend this one; just remember that it may take a while before you can fully understand what the story is about. (hide spoiler)]P.S. Find more of my reviews here.

Taylor was abandoned by her mother at a young age and is now living at a boarding school. Hannah is her only real adult family member and as a result, she feels extremely close to her; however, Hannah up and leaves the boarding school without explanation. Taylor is beside herself with worry; plus, she is the leader of her dorm in the territory wars and is very reluctant about the whole thing. To make matters worse, Jonah, a boy she has history with, is back in town and is the leader of another group in the territory wars. While all this is going on in the back of her mind Taylor is still worried about Hannah and her whereabouts. Does it have anything to do with her mom? Melina Marchetta's puzzling and award winning novel, Jellicoe Road, took me on a wild roller coaster ride and didn't let me go until the story's final page.Ok. So. I am not going to lie. I pretty much loathed Jellicoe Road for the first one hundred or so pages. I wish you guys could have heard my inner monologue. I reminded myself of my students when they first encounter Shakespeare. I was saying things like, "Huh? Territory wars? Is this a dystopia? Am I in Maze Runner right now?"......."Wait. What's this part in italics?" ......."How did this win the Printz award? There's so story, really." ........"Am I even comprehending what is going on here? What the heck?" Needless to say, I was extremely confused. Since Marchetta is a new-to-me author, I had a hard time trusting her in that the story would make sense as I continued to read. Thanks to fellow bloggers, I was told to hold on and keep going. To me, it was like a bad workout. I didn't want to continue, because it was hard and I was tired, but afterwards, I was happy I ran that extra mile and felt pretty good about it.Taylor's story is interrupted several times with another story about five teens from the past. At first, readers will have no clue what is going on, but as you read further the teen's story is interwoven expertly into Taylor's. As a reader, you must have patience with this as you have NO prior knowledge concerning this what.so.ever. Don't get me wrong....I like a little mystery and confusion in my books, but this was more like 100 or so pages of not knowing anything.On a positive note, Marchetta is a brilliant writer. I was shocked by the second half of the book, because I didn't think she could really "fix" the mess of the first half. However, she proved me wrong. The puzzle came together and I definitely had that "A-HA!" moment when everything made sense. I can honestly say I've never read a story like Jellicoe Road. It is very unique as is Marchetta's writing style as well.But here is what is on my mind: Yes, Jellicoe Road is beautifully written, but I wonder how many teenagers will actually stick with the first half of the book? I know many of my 8th graders would probably give up and put it down, because most like to be sucked into a story from the start. In fact, many bloggers said that had to reread the book or pick it up again at a later date in order to get through it. Hmm.... To me, this aspect of Jellicoe Road takes away from the reader's overall enjoyment. So all in all, do I feel Jellicoe Road is well written? Yes. Do I feel that it's an interesting puzzle of a story? Yes. Is it life changing as many claim it to be? No, not for me, but that doesn't mean I won't be picking up her other novels in the future. I plan on checking out Saving Francesca and Finnikin of the Rock, because I can't deny that Marchetta is a talented writer

I'm giving "Jellicoe Road" 4 stars but I'm not recommending it. The opening is too confusing and the framing is badly done. I only kept with it because of all the glowing reviews. Still, there are things that should have been fixed before this went to publication.Follow this if you can..."Jellicoe Road" is about 17 year old Taylor Markham who lives at a boarding school yet spends her holidays with Hannah who Taylor thinks works for the school but really doesn't. If there's a connection between Hannah and Taylor in terms of blood or legal guardianship, Taylor doesn't seem to be aware of it. She only remembers her mother dumping her in town when she was 11 and has amnesia about most of the events of her childhood including that time when the local nut shot himself to death in her presence. Also, Taylor's never seen a therapist for any of this which seems incredibly neglectful on the part of both her school and Hannah.Got that?Okay, Taylor has just been elected as the leader of the School Kids who, every year, wage some kind of 3 way war with the Cadets and the Townies. They can do this because the teachers, who are occasionally referred to, never make an appearance. The boarding school kids also do all their own cooking which I found odd. Teenagers aren't known for making great dietary choices plus this seems an open invitation to give everyone food poisoning. Interspersed with all this are Hannah's stories about 5 kids from 22 years ago who were in a horrific car accident, became best friends and had a bunch of adventures but then one of them disappeared and another one got pregnant and two of them fell in love but couldn't be with each other and oh, once they built a tunnel but that might just be a myth and...You see the problem here? Also there's a serial killer running around but none of the adults thinks that's important. I'm glad I finished this book but I wouldn't recommend it to anyone else.

Jellicoe Road by Melina Marchetta was a mysterious and captivating read that follows a young girls journey to self discovery. Taylor our protagonist is appointed leader of her school's secret army and is abandoned by Hannah, one of the only people she trusts. She must fight for her territory against the Townies and Cadets while in emotional turmoil. Her peers question whether she is capable of leading them, especially because she clearly has a past with one of the opposing community leaders, Jonah Griggs. Taylor must uncover what has really happened to Hannah, find out whether she can ever trust Griggs again and piece together who she really is. Marchetta has a beautiful writing style that keeps you guessing to the very last chapter. She pieces together her story with fluid twists that are a pleasure to unfold. Her characters are believable and have distinct personalities which is suprising since this book has a massive cast. I loved the segments of manuscript that was written by Hannah woven into the story as it gave us a small yet insightful look into the past. Taylor was a good protagonist and I really feel like we went on a journey with her, at times she wasn't likable but I sympathized with her story. I didn't like the secrecy much and it fell flat at times especially because I don't think it was necessary for Taylor to go through what she did just to get answers about her family. The rivalry was a little silly too, it was obvious that these were just normal kids who wanted to get along deep down and it was bizarre to me that this tradition had gone on as long as it had. I really liked the ending but unlike others I didn't get that emotional, I think Taylor got all the answers she needed and I didn't think it was sad, to be honest I was quite happy for her. The story was wrapped up nicely and I liked that there was hope for Taylor, Hannah, Jude, Jonah, Raffy, Chaz and Jessa.

I should not have read this book at bedtime, because...clogged nose. Couldn't breathe. This is worth re-reading. More thoughts soon.***UPDATE***Full post at It's A Wonderful Bookworld.On The Jellicoe Road is one of those books that comes highly recommended by my friends at the book club. And I understand why. It talks about timeless themes of friendships, belongingness, and family, and of how relationships thrive despite having to go through grief and loss.This book was my first Melina Marchetta and I loved it. As what most reviews say, reading On The Jellicoe Road feels like being confronted with a puzzle with a hundred pieces to put together — you start excitedly but a few pieces in, you are tempted to ditch the project and just do something else, but then you still trudge on because you see a piece and you feel that this might be a part of a very pretty picture. Little by little, as you go along, the picture gets clearer and clearer until you are almost done, putting the very last few pieces, and you feel that the effort and the journey were all worth it. The final outcome takes your breath away, you sit back and gaze upon it a few moments, reliving the memory of how you finally got to the end.After I was done reading, I had to reread the first few chapters — the ones which made no sense the first time I read them — because I want to relive the moment and preserve the scenes in my mind. It is no surprise then that though it’s been more than a month since I finished reading, the emotions it evoked from me are still fresh in my memory. The wow moment at the end was absolutely mind-blowing and bittersweet.Continue reading here.

First of all I want to say that I've never read any novel like this earlier, because novels like this are unique. When I first started reading I felt confused and I didn't get what's the story about. But, after the first couple of chapters I started to get attracted to it. I really liked the story and the main character –Taylor- as well, of course there are many main characters not just her, But the story is from her POV .So to summarize the whole idea without spoilers –which is hard- we can say that it starts with Taylor, a teenager who's in Jellicoe school which consists of six houses. Taylor was left by her mother 7 years ago In this place and she's been taken care of by a woman called Hannah. But this place, where Taylor is, have its traditions. The traditions are that the school students, the Townies and the Cadets -who come to camp every year in this area- are to have wars. This is all according to an old purple book that no one knows who wrote it. This purple book includes all the rules about the war between the three factions. However, at the beginning of the book, Taylor gets chosen to be the leader of her school in this war and she's given the purple book. But as the war goes on and as the deals are being made….. everyone is finding out new and important information that are related to the past. And the info is very important to Taylor and others for a reason. So throughout the book there are so many secrets which are going to be known. So many mysteries that are going to be solved. And you really are not going to see it coming. I'm sure anyone who'll read it is going to enjoy it.

First off, here are some poppies.. A token for the characters in this book.On second thought, here's a field of poppies. Because one or two are just not enough...What do you do when what at first seemed to make no sense all at once starts to make perfect sense?Webb, Tate...Jude, Narnie...Fitz....Who are they? And what is it that links the past with the future? WHY NOT 5 STARS?The book is really amazing, especially when all the pieces start falling into place. But I had a hard time going through the beginning. You have to really really love reading -and have 100% trust in your friends who recommended the book- to survive it. Don't get me wrong, it was interesting from the very beginning, but it's not until things dawn on you that you start to love the book. And now I love it. Just its start was a little off for me.I LIKED how the author could bring us close to the characters' minds and make us feel what they feel, and see what they see. A FRIEND'S ADVICE AT THE ENDPlease don't give up on this book too soon. Just bear a little and it'll all get crystal clear. It was the first and the best piece of advice my friends gave me. And trust me it paid off.

By the time I finished this beautiful, entrancing novel, I was itching to shove it directly into someone else's hands. I loved how this book affected me, hours after I put it down each day. I was constantly dreaming up possible answers and connections to all the intertwining stories, or smiling to myself as I recalled the sweet romance developing alongside this mystery. While reading the book in class during SSR, I kept wanting to put the book down and say to someone beside me, "Whew! Can you believe it?!" (Don't worry. I resisted.)But the beginning. Dear GOD, the beginning is horribly confusing. Too many names, too many story lines, too many obscure references to odd inventions of weird kids. I'm quite grateful that I pushed through, but I've no idea why I did. When I gave it to a student today, I gave her the warning/encouragement: "The beginning is beyond confusing. I totally expect you to ask me some questions after the first few pages. Hopefully, it won't frustrate you the way it frustrated me. I promise, the rest of the book is worth it." With great trepidation, I watched her deeply furrowed brow as she dug through the first two chapters. I braced myself for a tantrum of helplessness. But finally, she looked up with a sigh and said with a smile, "Okay, I'm confused." I sat beside her, answered her excellent questions, and she dove back in for more. I'm crossing my fingers.

Un libro sencillo pero diferente...Debo decir que el libro me gusto, las primeras 100 paginas, aproximadamente, son muy confusas, no entendía bien de que iba, de que se hablaba, hacia donde iba y es uno de los puntos buenos del libro, que te deja con ese suspenso y esa intriga para continuar leyendo, el libro tiene dos historias parecidas que se van entrelazando conforme avanza el libro. Vas enterándote de cosas que al principio no entendías y poco a poco ibas descubriendolo todo junto con la protagonista y eso fue otra de las cosas que me gustaron, que lo ibas averiguando junto a ella.Me parece una historia sencilla a la cual la autora supo enredar muy bien todo para hacerlo confuso e intrigante, pero que al final todo es tan sencillo. Me gustaron los personajes los cuales son realmente muy reales, con problemas como todos y debo decir que Taylor es grandiosa, es tan cerrada pero a la vez valiente dispuesta a obtener lo que quiere. Creo que es de esos libros que entre menos sepas de que van, mejor. Es un buen libro y tiene momentos trágicos, romance, un poco de humor,intriga, todo en uno. Pero a mi parecer le falto algo más para acabar de convencerme.

Wow. This was so goodI don't even remember why or when I put this book on my TBR. It's been there for a while. Since I am trying to read more books that I already own, I came across this on my Kindle and decided to give it a shot. I didn't even read the synopsis, I just dove right in. The start of the book is extremely confusing. I got to the 6% mark and had to start over since I had no idea what was going on. I will be honest and say that I was not sure I was going to make it. I was frustrated. I thought the main character, Taylor, was a male for the entire first chapter! (It would have helped if I read the synopsis) I had no idea who anyone was or what was happening. If this happens to you; DO NOT GIVE UP!There is a beautiful story that unfolds on the pages of this novel. It has multiple layers and is revealed a piece at a time. Everything is important. Everything is relevant. It all makes sense in the end.And it is a really good story!

Jellicoe Road. En bok som blev så hyllad för något år sedan att det var i stort sett omöjligt att låta den passera. Jag har dragit mig för att läsa den. Mest för att det är otäckt att läsa en bok som i stort sett alla bara älskar, men också för att samma människor sagt att den är svår att komma in i. Jag vet inte vad jag förväntade mig, men det var fel. Läs mer på min blogg

It took me awhile to figure out what was going on in this book. There are related stories from the past and present being told at the same time. Also, the present has a lot of different aspects. It all connects and wraps up beautifully. Even though it wasn’t immediate love, since it took a bit for all the details to connect for me, I ending this story loving it.

“Someone asked us later, "Didn't you wonder why no one came across you sooner?"Did I wonder?When you see your parents zipped up in black body bags on the Jellicoe Road like they're some kind of garbage, don't you know?Wonder dies.”

the weirdest book that i have read but i like it!
the 2nd half was so much better than the first! By the time I finished, I really ended up enjoying it!
Woah, this was intense. Got me goosebumps a few times and tears in my eyes. But I found it a bit confusing at times, especially at the beginning.

Șoseaua Jellicoe, Melina MarchettaAceastă carte este exact genul care te poate bulversa. Cu o descriere mai degrabă interesantă, mi-am dorit să o citesc și să rezolv misterul. Până pe la jumătate, n-am înțeles absolut nimic, iar dacă eram întrebată despre cum este lectura, spuneam doar că nu știu. Pentru că nu știam. Pur și simplu nu empatizam cu personajul și nu îmi dădeam seama încotro duce acțiunea.Povestea este despre Taylor, care este părăsită de mama sa pe șoseaua Jellicoe pe când avea doar unsprezece ani. Acum, la șaptesprezece, ea este responsabilă cu căminele de la Școala Jellicoe. De când se știe, are aceste vise ciudate, cu un băiat trist care stă într-un copac și care îi vorbește. Dar Taylor este destul de pragmatică și nu își lasă sentimentele la vedere, căci pentru ea ar fi un punct vulnerabil. Printre atribuțiile sale se află și menținerea teritoriului comunității din care face parte. Dintotdeauna a existat un război între școală, Orășei și Cadeți, fiecare parte dorind să-și protejeze teritoriul și să nu-i lase pe ceilalți să depășească granițele. Practic, toată povestea se leagă de această luptă, ceea ce mi-a fost destul de neclar. De ce ar scrie cineva o carte doar cu scopul de a arăta cum se războiesc niște adolescenți pentru niște poteci, copaci, râuri și alte asemenea? Dar apoi mai e și Hannah, un fel de mentor al lui Taylor, care locuiește în afara limitelor școlii, și care dispare în mod misterios, lăsând în urma ei un manuscris format din pagini amestecate, fără început și fără sfârșit. Acolo, ea vorbește despre o tragedie care a adus împreună cinci tineri. Totul pare ireal, nelalocul lui, căci fiecare indiciu duce către niște vieți care au existat cândva. Și, cu toate că nu vrea să se arate atașată de femeie, Taylor se simte din nou părăsită și nu încetează din a crede că i s-a întâmplat ceva lui Hannah.Reîntâlnirea cu Jonah Griggs, conducătorul Cadeților, o trimite pe Taylor înapoi în trecut, când cei doi au avut ceva în comun. Cu toate luptele lor pentru putere, nu pot nega că între ei există o văpaie. Am crezut că nu voi regăsi deloc dragostea în această carte, dar a existat în fiecare filă, sub toate formele ei. Ascunsă, căci iubirea e exact ca o nestemată. Și abia atunci când răsare, poți să respiri ușurat .Povestea a fost amețitoare, m-a făcut să mă încrunt, dar mi-a smuls și zâmbete. Am decis să depunctez pentru faptul că nu m-a prins din prima. La final, totul s-a legat într-un mod precis și nimic (absolut nimic) nu a rămas nebifat. Ca un puzzle căruia îi lipsesc exact cele trei piese ce schimbă absolut complet imaginea. Și tare m-am mai bucurat de ea.

This is one of the weirdest books I’ve ever read, but it’s also absolutely beautiful. When I started reading, I had no idea about what I should expect. The story was really uninteresting for the first 150 pages, since it made zero sense to me, but then I started to piece it all together, and ...wow. This book is something extraordinary. Every word is carefully chosen and has a special purpose for the story. Melina Marchetta is a super talented storyteller, and I’m looking forward to reading more books by her. My main issue with Jellicoe Road is that you have to be extremely focused while reading, because every detail is important. It might not seem like a big deal while reading it, but then 150 pages later it’s suddenly of great significance for the story. (view spoiler)[Such as the postman being the serial killer. (hide spoiler)] This also makes me want to re-read this book, because I’m interested in discovering details I must’ve missed while reading it for the first time.  Overall, this is an amazing book (with a crazy but really impressing plot). If you start reading and nothing makes sense to you, don’t fret - just keep reading! Sadly, there are too many pages of plain confusion and boredom for me to give this novel five stars, although, in most ways, it’s a five-star book.I feel like I should write a longer review, but I don't know what else to say. Just read and let the story affect you. Embrace the emotions. Bye.

okay a thing about this. I think on reread of a physical copy this could really be a 5 star read for me but as the first 50% of the audio was super confusing I just wasn't that excited about it. I didn't even realise there were two time lines and what was happening. ONCE I did realise the two timelines and who was in them I really started to enjoy myself, there is so much grief and just pain in this book, in kids lives. There is also a lot of awesome friendships, of student relationships, and loves. Love is a big part of this book, holding back love, "forbidden" love, the family love your not sure you should feel, the love that you don't or can't let yourself feel.I really loved the relationship between Gregs and Taylor they felt real, they fought, they had real problems and it wasn't all star gazing and picnics. The one standout in the audio is the narrator being so aussie, the writing along is super aussie as is but she really brought the aussie to life for me. After becoming so used to american and english narrators it was really cool to be hearing someone who sounds like myself telling a story that I could imagine perfectly. There's drama, mystery, disaster, sadness, bad parents, dead parents, sad kids, angry kids, and a whole lot to love in this book.

Ok, so I did have some problems with this one- I saw the twists coming from the very beginning, it was extremely dramatic, and some parts haven’t aged well- but I absolutely inhaled this book! It was just compulsively readable. Melina Marchetta also wrote Looking for Alibrandi which was my favourite book during high school, so I’m surprised it took me this long to pick up another one of her books- I’m exited to read more! This book does deal with some pretty heavy topics, but if that doesn’t faze you I would totally recommend this.
La primera mitad del libro fue muy confusa y algo tediosa, tanto que casi abandono el libro.Pero la seguna parte...La historia de los cinco fue lo mejor, sin duda.Incluso llore un par de veces.

This is one of the most emotional shit i've ever read. My heart is forever attached to these characters and their paths. But i'm gonna have to point out why i took 1 star. First: the beginning of the book was a bit messy since i didn't understand what exactly was going on. And second: i wish the author wrote more about the characters from Hannah's novel. They were SO intriguing and i loved them but it would be better to see more of them.
– 4.5/ starswhile everyone was losing their minds about irma here in south florida, i was crying in my hotel room over this book. #shookreview to come
I liked the unknowing and the bit of confusion starting out and trying to work out what was happening.

This is how you write a book. Hands down. I feel overwhelmed. I’m sad and I’m happy. You know, after reading a book you sometimes wonder how it would’ve been different if something changed about it, or how you would have wanted it to be some other way. This is the story where I want nothing to change. I love it how it is. It’s a story I’ll never forget.When I started Jellicoe Road, it took me some time to get into the story. I was confused as to how the two stories were supposed to be related and it was mainly because I couldn’t read more than a few pages at a time. When I finally got into the story, I admit I had predicted some things but I don’t mind it at all because it felt like the author wanted me to know. Taylor had it figured out herself so it’s not as if she was some dumb, stubborn, moody protagonist. She did get on my nerves in the beginning. She pushed everyone away and had so many issues that I got angry on her at times but later, reading the story, I sat there feeling choked up with my eyes burning and trying to push back the tears because I was sitting around everyone reading the book and I didn’t want to draw attention to myself. Marchetta has such a beautiful way of writing a story. She is really a great author and I’m kinda shocked that it took me so long to discover her work. I felt everything that Taylor felt. It’s been sometime since I fell in love with the characters of a story. I adore everyone in this book. I love Webb, Narnie, Tate, Fitz, Jude, Taylor, Jonah, Raf, Chaz, Ben, and almost everyone else. Marchetta so beautifully manages to make every character she has mentioned in the story involved. Everyone is part of the story, unlike some authors who manage to bring up so many unimportant characters that are not even related to the story and are just made up and just as suddenly, simply gone. I can’t even imagine how it would’ve been for kids who became orphans in just a matter of minutes and how it became the turning event in all their lives. How that one accident took everything away from them and then gave them so much in return. To even imagine what Narnie, Webb or Tate had to go through, is like feeling someone crushing something inside me. I get very emotional when any character’s parent dies and in this story there is so much loss that I kept staring at a wall, blocking my thoughts listening to other’s talk around me, so that I don’t lose it infront of everyone. Every character in this story is significant and everyone is so different and each one of them has to face their own personal demons but when they are together, they simply enjoy each other’s company. And to have a relationship like those guys is something that can make anyone envious. Figuring out everything with Taylor and being with her on the roller-coaster ride of emotions was such a journey! I love her character. Truly. She had been through so much and she tried so hard to never get attached to anyone and tried so hard to hide emotions when she could hardly keep them in. She was so strong and even in her vulnerability, she did not fail to amaze me. She was broken but she held herself for everyone. I loved her relationship with Raf and Ben and Chaz and most importantly Jonah. Jonah and Taylor were perfect for each other and it’s been so long since I’ve loved two characters in a relationship together. Jonah knew how to act around her when she lost her temper. He didn’t sugar-coat anything and he was on her face and wasn’t scared of her like the others. He knew how to deal with her mood tantrums and in the same way Taylor was everything for him. She gave him a reason to survive and she understood him just as he understood her. *squeeeeeeeee* I feel giddy thinking about them together. Gee, I feel so girly. Anyways, if I start writing about the things that made me depressed or that I particularly liked, I would end up writing everything. So, I’m going to keep it short and say that it’s a story to know, a story to read, a story to remember, and a story that will make you cry with sadness as well as happiness. I loved the pacing, I loved how there were two stories and how those two stories were related together. I think I deserve a pat on the back for not bawling my eyes out and believe me there were moments when I would have just done that if not for the company. I have an urge to re-read it all over again and I will. Soon. The starting was shaky and the war seemed to be a frivolous issue but when I was in high school I remember having the same kind of rivalry with girls and guys of other schools for no reason..only cause it was. So, I guess I can see that. Also, Jesse knowing about where the tunnel was to save her life and Chloe's seemed unlikely. But overall, this book left an impression.

This took me about 3-to-4 hours to read in total. I started before falling asleep and then I picked it up the next morning and could not put it down until I was finished. Now, that may sound strange when I tell you that I almost didn't finish it after reading the first few chapters. I think I was just too tired to deal with the way it was written. It's sort of a puzzle at first, trying to decipher what was past, what was present, what was dream and what was reality because the author set it up in such a way that everything becomes a slow reveal. I love a good mystery and while this is not a mystery in the traditional sense of "whodunit", it is a very mysterious book, full of hints and teases. However, I found those hints to be very tiresome at first. So, I put the book down for the night and picked it up the next morning, thumbing through to see if I'd like what was to come, looking for answers to some of the questions that wouldn't leave me alone. I skimmed and found myself sucked into the story so that I would skim a little further still, before fully becoming invested. Finally, after much skimming, I went back and started over, reading passages that I'd missed through my first read, until finally I finished the entire book.I don't normally read books that way but I think the skimming really helped me stick with this book and I am so glad I did. I almost took it back to the library, unfinished! It's a very moving story, though like I said a little confusing at first. I couldn't figure out what this whole Townie vs Cadet vs "Us" thing was. Just stick with it, it'll all make sense as you go along. For better reviews of the actual book, read some others around here because this isn't so much as a review as a telling of how pulled in I was by the book once I gave it a chance. Let me leave you with the opener, though. One of the most tragic and sucked-me-right-in openers I've ever read."My father took one hundred and thirty two minutes to die.I counted.It happened on the Jellicoe Road. The prettiest road I’d ever seen, where trees made breezy canopies like a tunnel to Shangri-La. We were going to the ocean, hundreds of kilometres away, because I wanted to see the ocean and my father said that it was about time the four of us made that journey. I remember asking, “What’s the difference between a trip and a journey?” and my father said, “Narnie, my love, when we get there, you’ll understand,” and that was the last thing he ever said.We heard her almost straight away. In the other car, wedged into ours so deep that you couldn’t tell where one began and the other ended. She told us her name was Tate and then she squeezed through the glass and the steel and climbed over her own dead – just to be with Webb and me; to give us her hand so we could clutch it with all our might. And then a kid called Fitz came riding by on a stolen bike and saved our lives.Someone asked us later, “Didn’t you wonder why no one came across you sooner?”Did I wonder?When you see your parents zipped up in black body bags on the Jellicoe Road like they’re some kind of garbage, don’t you know?Wonder dies."

I am tempted to say that Tanja forced me to read Melina Marchetta's On the Jellicoe Road. I am also tempted to say that she bullied me into reading it. But I won't say it. Because after Tanja read a few books that I recommended her, it was about time that I gave Melina Marchetta, an author Tanja swears by, a try. And trust me, Tanja knows her stuff. Don't ever mess with her. Don't ever doubt her. Because one point that is absolutely clear to me now is that Tanja will recommend books that will make you cry and in the end, those are the best books. It wasn't easy for me to get into Jellicoe Road. The story is confusing as hell, and there were times when I had no idea what I was reading but I just kept reading because, 1) I had to do this for my girl who 2) kept motivating me to go on with it. But even if I didn't have reason number two, I would have still continued reading because Melina Marchetta created magic with her writing and just the flow of words had me wanting to turn the pages. The confusing shift between past and present was difficult to understand at first, but once I got the connection between the two, it became incredible. I guess with books like Jellicoe Road, it's not so much about understanding as it is about feeling. And I felt. I am unable to pinpoint exactly what I felt, but I felt that pull in my heart that made me want to hug the characters. It was towards the last 15% of the book that I really got into the story and started feeling, but that's okay, because those last few chapters were so damn stunning. So even though 85% is huge, I forgive it, because the last bit was where everything came together, all dots were connected and life went on. So to conclude, I will just say that Jellicoe Road is difficult to understand and confusing to read, but you don't you dare give up, because there are very few books that bring tears to your eyes, and this is one of those books. While I do not love this book as much as Tanja and Glass do, I still want to thank them both for making me read it. You girls owe me now. But first, thank you. Thank you for making me read this heart-breaking yet fulfilling story about what matters the most- family and roots. Don't forget to check out Tanja and Glass' reviews of the book. P.S: There is so much more I wanted to say, but for now, this should be enough.

Un lugar al que todos pertenecerían y anhelarían estar. Un lugar en el camino de Jellicoe

 Taylor Markham tenía once años de edad cuando fue abandonada por su madre en el camino de Jellicoe. Ahora, con diecisiete años de edad, Taylor no sólo es la nueva líder de su dormitorio del internado, sino que también va a descubrir muchos secretos sobre su vida antes de llegar a Jellicoe, sobre todo después de la persona que la cuidaba, Hannah, desaparece de repente de la escuela sin decirle nada a Taylor. En medio de todo eso Taylor se encuentra con su antiguo novio, Jonah Griggs y sospecha que Jonah sabe más acerca de ella de lo que ella misma sabe. Ahora, Taylor debe descubrir la verdad sobre el abandono de su madre y el paradero de Hannah. Y lo que va a descubrir sobre su verdadero pasado cambiará su vida para siempre.Melina Marchetta crea una historia misteriosa que rodea el pasado de Taylor y como afecta su estado actual. En realidad en el principio, hay muchas piezas de información que son como un rompecabezas que tienes que ir encajando mientras vas leyendo.
