Por cada capitulo que leía era como "¿y a donde se supone que me lleva esto? ¿que paso con Hannah? ¿y que hay de la mama de Taylor? ¿y quien se supone que ese niño?" Me gustó el personaje de Taylor Markham aunque hubo momentos en que su actitud agresiva hacia los demás me molestó, puedo identificarme con ella en la forma en que le resulta difícil confiar en las personas después de que su madre la abandonó y que Hannah, la persona más cercana que tenía a una familia, de pronto se fue. También me gustó mucho la relación de Taylor con Jonah Griggs, Raffaela, Ben, y Chaz Santagelo ya que fueron grandes amigos para ella, y sobre todo me encantó la forma en que estos personajes trataron de ayudar a Taylor con sus problemas de confianza y como le enseñaron el verdadero significado de la amistad. Ame la forma en que Melina Marchetta localizo esta historia en Australia. La manera en que describe los lugares, por ejemplo: el camino de Jellicoe y el Árbol de Las Plegarias. Los fragmentos del manuscrito de Hannah, donde se cuentan las historias de Webb, Narnie, Tate, Fitz y Jude fueron mis partes favoritas del libro. Eran desgarradoras y conmovedoras, aunque en el principio no las entendía. Cuando todo empezó a tener sentido descubrí lo muy importante que eran esos fragmentos en la historia. Melina Marchetta es definitivamente una de mis escritoras favoritas. Y espero con ansias leer otro de sus libros.

If I had been able to understand the story from page one I would be giving it five stars. I loved it from about page 175 or so on. I hadn't read any reviews or summaries before I started, I just bought it because it was on sale and had a pretty cover. Sometimes I do that. Sometimes I find treasure. Sometimes I find trash. I'm willing to take the risk. Having said that, I thought the book was set in the future and was somewhat dystopic when I first began. It wasn't.Taylor, our narrator attends a boarding school and her classmates, "Townies" and "Cadets" participate in some sort of war. I thought this was an actual war and that there would be dire, possibly even fatal, consequences to these skirmishes. When I finally realized the war was just a game these kids played for six weeks of the year the rest of the story fell into place. I was able to understand what was going on, get to know the characters and realize that the reason the story kept changing, and I often felt lost, was that sprinkled throughout Taylor's story is the story of five other kids in the past. Ah ha!Taylor was abandoned by her mother at the tender age of 11. She has always kept others at arm's length, been hesitant to show emotion and comes across as a bit of a bad ass. At 14 she attempts to run away from the school and find her mom. Her path and a young boy's, Jonah, meet up and their journey ends in what she feels is his betrayal. He calls home for someone to come and get them just before they reach where she thinks she needs to search. She doesn't know the true reasons he makes the call and when she and Jonah encounter each other three years later she has a hard time dealing with it. The story is about the loss of, and eventual reunion of, family. About establishing roots and knowing the history those that came before you. There's also romance, and praise the Lord, hallelujah, it's a healthy romance between teenagers. Marchetta writes these teens as difficult, angst-y, rude, snarky and touchy. In other words just like the teenagers I live with. They are not manipulative, overbearing, physically or mentally abusive and they allow each other to be who they are without attempts to change that or rule over each other's lives.I enjoyed the last part of the book so much(once I figured it out) that I may need to go back and reread. If I do I will probably end up giving it five stars.

Täna oli mul viimane eksam ja läbi sai ka viimati raamatukogust võetud seitsmest raamatust viimane. Kuigi see noortekas mulle väga meeldis, siis tahaksin nüüd veidi žanrist irduda. Lubasin ju aasta alguses, et loen rohkem erinevaid raamatuid!Melina Marchetta nimi on goodreads-is ja raamatuteemalistest tumblr-ites korduvalt silma jäänud, kuid eelmine tema paljukiidetud romaan "Saving Francesca" mulle nii väga ei meeldinudki. Seevastu "Jellicoe Road" jättis mulle üllatavalt sügava mulje.Ema hülgas Taylor Markhami, kui ta oli 11-aastane ning sellest ajast saadik on tüdruk õppinud internaatkoolis, kus ka paljud teised lapsed on probleemsed. Näiteks on seal mitu süütajat. Neiu üritas ühe korra ka minema joosta, kuid toodi tagasi. Igal aastal tulevad kooli lähistele telkima Kadetid ning toimuvad sõjamängud territooriumi üle. Taylor valitakse oma kooli esindama, kuid tal on ka teisi muresid. Üks vähestest täiskasvanutest, keda ta usaldab, on kadunud ning neiu ihkab teda iga hinna eest leida. Vastuseid otsides leiab tüdruk aga vihjeid oma enda mineviku kohta.Mulle meeldis raamatu müsteerium, mis küll poole pealt juba ilusti välja joonistus, kuigi Taylor ise oleks võinud ka asjast veidi varem aru saada. Selliseid saladusi ei oleks tohtinud tema eest õieti hoidagi. Samuti tundusid põnevad sõjamängud, mis küll veidi muu loo kõrval tahaplaanile jäid. Veidi nooremale lugejaskonnale saaks juba luuramiste ja vallutuste põhjal väga nauditava loo. Territooriumitest rääkimise juurde oleks muidugi ilusti passinud ka kaart. Ükskõik, kui probleemne ja murtud oli peategelane, siis tegelikult oli lugu positiivse alatooniga ning keskendus leinale, lootusele, sõprusele ning sihikindlusele. Raamatut lugedes tajusin, kuidas halvast saab sündida hea. Lõpu poole liikudes tuli küll rohkelt kurbust ja poetasin isegi paar pisarat, isegi mitte nukrusest, vaid lihtsalt olin Taylori loost liigutatud.

I want to read this for the first time, again. The first chunk of the book introduces Taylor. She pushes people away, is more interested in being alone than not and, in fact, rarely pays attention to anyone who happens to be around. Sound like it might be boring to read? It kinda was. It’s disjointed with little dialogue and the protagonist doesn’t go out of her way to endear herself to the reader. But it’s all in such a way that made me wonder why.And then it picks up. When a leadership position falls into her lap, Taylor takes it on grudgingly. She doesn’t rely on anyone and definitely doesn’t want to be relied upon, but the alternative means falling under someone else’s rule. The stories that she’s never understood from her past confront her more and more as she’s forced to work with others. It’s a little heartbreaking when Taylor doesn’t seem to notice that others need her as much as she needs them. During all the time that she’s thought she never had family, it’s revealed to have been quietly and steadily building itself up around her. It snuck up on me. Suddenly I was enmeshed in the lives of these characters and I was glad that they belonged to me for a little while. The story doesn’t rush in revealing itself and the confusion becomes alluring. It’s almost morbidly fascinating how one tragedy can snowball and affect so many lives. I love the idea that you create your own family, and that people can belong to each other in so many ways and for so many reasons. Like I said, I’m a little disappointed that I won’t get to experience reading this for the first time again.And, bonus, I have a new song to add to my musical rotation. I don’t know if I would have loved its ‘80s goodness without the book or if the book has imprinted itself onto the song in my head, but I’m digging The Whole Of The Moon by The Waterboys.

I think in order to fairly and accurately assess On Jellico Road, I'm going to have to read it again. First off, a large portion of the beginning I listened to the audio version. I wouldn't recommend this. The reason for that is definitely not because the reader was bad, as a matter of fact she was excellent but there are quite a few instances where Taylor is reading Hannah's novel and it's extremely hard to follow. In the book, these parts are indicated by italic print, making it obvious it is not Taylor's narration that is on center stage. In the audio version until you know there even IS a novel that Taylor is reading, it makes a confusing scenario even more so. So much happened, so much information was provided at the beginning of the book... but while I was reading those parts, I was too busy saying to myself; What the hell is going on here??? That maybe I could have paid much closer attention and gotten more out of it. There were so many "A Haaaa" and "Holy shit" moments later in the book that I felt like I robbed myself a little by not paying closer attention earlier on in my reading. I think as many "a haas" as I got out of it, I still missed quite a few of them. I rated this book 4 stars which to me is a good book. The only reason it didn't rate 5 stars or an "excellent" read was because it took so freaking long to get into it. I seriously was hanging on by my finger nails and the encouragement of my GR friends that the book was worth sticking out. It totally was. It's going to make me double think the next time I DNF a book. I will be rereading this soon, and I'm predicting when I experience Taylor and her friends the next time around I'll be bumping my rating up.

Melina Marchetta has this way of drawing a reader in and making them fall head over heels in love with her characters. I don't know how she does it! Her books always seem to start off confusing, this one wasn't any different, and before you know it you're sucked right into the story like nothing else in the real world matters. I was almost halfway through and was going to give up on this because it was just too confusing, but I went on because I have read so many good review, and oh my I'm am SO glad I kept going!Marchetta's characters feel so real, by the end of the book I feel like I know them and could text them to catch up and hang out. It's hard to tell you exactly what was going on in this book, so all I will say is read this NOW! Or you could wait until the movie is released, there's no knowing when it will come out so you should just read it. My only problem with books being adapted into a movie is that I hope they can capture the chemistry between all the characters.My only issue with this book (other than the confusing beginning, which made sense by the end) was the mystery behind Taylor's background and who her father was. I slowly guessed what was going on, which if you've read my reviews before you will know I hate when I guess things before they are revealed. But Marchetta was good at keeping little things secret and didn't reveal until later, so she kept me guessing a bit. Because of those small faults I give this 4 stars. I am now a huge fan of Melina Marcetta and I look forward to seeing what she comes up with next!Also on my blog

This book is one of those books that surprise you. Well, it surprised me anyway. I'd heard that it was good but that it wasn't everyone's favorite of books. But I LOVED this book. My one critique was that the beginning was hard to follow. Marchetta jumps right into the story without explaining much of the backstory or who the characters are. So it takes a few chapters to get into the groove of the story. But as you read, you learn not only how she has formatted the story, but begin to unravel the mystery that is the backstory of the characters. She drops you into the middle because she wants you to discover the beginning. The way she weaved the story together was, in my opinion, brilliant. It made a contemporary story into a mystery. And I really enjoyed how the once sworn enemies became best friends.I will say that I felt the Territory War was a bit underplayed. It was such a giant priority in the beginning of the novel, and just disintegrated. I expected to have more fights with her other leaders, more "battles" for territory, and more war games between the Townies and Cadets. I really loved that everyone became best friends, but the huge war that was so important at the start of the book just wasn't a big deal shortly after.All in all, a wonderful book. I'm glad I pushed past the first few chapters so I could really understand and love this book!

Rounded up from 4.5. I didn't realize I signed up for an emotional read until I reached two-thirds of the book. The premise tackles about territory wars between three factions: the Townies, the Cadets, and Jellicoe High School's underground community. But more than that, the novel explores the back stories of the factions' leaders and the adults around them, thus, unfolding two tragic stories about love, friendship and family. The fight for territories was intriguing, until that storyline got dumped midway (because it has, unfortunately, served its purpose) to focus on Taylor's quest of finding her mother and her guardian, Hannah. It took me a while to catch up with the characters, but it wasn't hard to fall in love with them as soon I got to know them. I love the sexual tension between Taylor and Jonah early in the story, but it fizzled out midway because it got a bit mushy for me at some parts. I also love the characterization, especially on Taylor and Jonah. They are two broken, vulnerable teenagers hiding behind their tough-looking persona, and I love how the author explored and explained their back stories. They are not your ordinary strong-willed characters. There were dull, predictable moments, particularly on the latter part of the story, but the epilogue stabbed me in the heart and left me aching for the characters involved.

I absolutely hated this book...and then I loved it. The first half was tedious, boring and very put-downable. I didn't like the author's writing style. It kept bouncing back and forth between the story of a girl living at a boarding school and a story of five friends. It was horribly confusing as it wasn't explained until later on that the story of the five friends happened in the past and was being read from a manuscript in the present. The worst part of the first half has to be the ongoing war between the kids in the boarding school, the kids from town and the cadet school. They fought over paths, fields, tree houses, etc., and these weren't arguments, they were beating each other up and taking hostages......and once you got into the second half it all started making sense. Every person mentioned in the first half became important in the second half. Everything and everyone was connected. I even cried at the end and that NEVER happens, well pretty much never.This is the story of family, and the lack of family, and the lengths people will go to for their family. It's about the beginnings of friendships that last a lifetime. It's about secrets. It's one of the best young-adult coming of age stories I have read.

I'm tempted to rate this book higher and maybe I will after a reread. I can see why it won all of the awards and is so well reviewed, but for the first half of the book I was very confused. There are two storylines (an italicized manuscript and the main character Taylor's POV), alternating between past and present, lots of characters and I got frustrated trying to piece it together. But then I read reviews and they all said the same thing about being lost for the first 150 pages so I kept going. I'm SO glad I did. Everything fit together beautifully in the end and all I could think was "wow." The story is well written, multi-layered and original. (I went into it only having read the blurb and knowing it was YA fiction, and I think that's the way to go). It's a mysterious story about friendship, abandonment, guilt, grief and forgiveness. I thought the love story with Jonah was very well done and the setting and characters were unique and well developed. I'll reread it now that I know how the pieces fit together and will check out more of this author's work. PS - My only other criticism is re: the territory wars (there seemed to be too much emphasis on them for the first half and I still have questions about them).

Taylor Markham lives in a boarding school though she spends quite a lot of time with Hannah, a woman who lives in a large house nearby. When she was seven, Taylor was abandoned by her mother, and four years ago, Taylor tried to head for Sydney to find her; but Jonah, who was accompanying her, caused their trip to be prematurely stopped when he made a phone call and the Brigadier came to collect them. Taylor has never forgiven him.During the unfolding of Taylor's story we are also given snippets of the story of 5 children who lived there 20 years ago, by way of a manuscript that Hannah is writing, and we are gradually given clues to help us see who they are now and what happened to them. Those snippets aren't written in chronological order, so the reader must be alert. Their story together began with a car crash that killed parents, so they also have abandonment and misery to contend with.The whole is told within an elaborate "war" that Taylor's school, and the Cadets and the Townies all follow for territory, and within a heart-warming (and sometimes heart-breaking) story about friendship and love. This is a book that will bear repeat reading!

Wow. Wowwwwwwwwwww. Had I known it was that good, I would've finished this in one sitting (not 3 months haha) Since I only read it whenever I have free time, like waiting in line or on my way home, it really took me months to finish this book. And I felt halfway through the book that meeeehhh the pacing is so slow I don't wanna finish this!!! Who are these characters??? Who is Tate??? Who's Narnie???? Is Taylor.... secretly Narnie? Are these characters based on the Taylor/Jonah thing? Idk anymore are they really just characters????? What is happening why do they have these factions??? Lol then one day I decided to just finish it. My friend read 4 books already and I'm still stuck with this one. Then wow wow wowwwwwww after everything has been cleared and I just wow all these feelings wow ???!?!?!?!!!!! I love you, Melina :( Thank you, really. It made me reflect on life tbh. I'm just.. speechless. (or not I just haven't really gathered my thoughts hehe) Now on to my next Marchetta book.....edit: took me 11 months (on and off tho, I had other books to read as well haha) so wow

I just closed the book. Wait, my eyes are still shedding tears.Ok.This is a story of intertwined lives from the past and present. A touching story about love, family and friendship. I have to admit that the story-telling was very confusing. It was about halfway through the book when pieces are starting to fall into place. I felt goosebumps whenever I read the italicized words. I craved for those stories; so I can fully understand the past that leads to the present. I didn't mind that I've already predicted who's who early on because the real story is how our main character, Taylor Markham, discovers it. Suddenly, she's unravelling events from the past that is connected to her present. Every bit of her journey is heart-warming and, at times, heart breaking. I cried while reading the 'other' story and much more towards the end, when everything is finally revealed, in place, and understood.I will recommend this book! You just need to get past the confusion and I'm sure you will then appreciate this book so much.Now, I'd love to discover other novels by Melina Marchetta!

Somehow I seem to be reading quite a bit of young adult fiction lately. Especially by Australian authors. Where were these kinds of stories when I was growing up? Maybe they were out there and I just didn't know where to look for them. Anyway, this is a really good story that is hard to put down once you get into it. It took me a little while to figure out who was who and what was going on but once I did I was hooked. The characters are complex and I actually cared about them, which is a rare thing with some of the books I've read lately. I would recommend this book to adults as well as teens. Older adults may find the School, Townie, Cadet war storyline a bit difficult to get into at first, but the story soon becomes more about complex relationships, harsh realities, identity, love and much more. Oh, and a highlight for me was reading that one of the characters wore a South Sydney football club t-shirt. Up the Rabbitohs!

I tried to start Jellicoe Road once before, and stopped about 50 pages in, because I couldn't get into it, and I didn't really understand anything that was going on. But I read a few different reviews, and most of them said not to get discouraged even if things didn't make sense for the first 100 pages or so. So, I picked it up again, determined to get all the way through. And I'm so glad I did. The writing is powerful and tender; the emotions are so raw and real. I loved each and every character. Their stories and backgrounds come together throughout the story, entwined in complex ways. I loved reading Taylor's POV, because I thought she was intelligent, strong and thoughtful - everything a good heroine should be. A beautiful, heart-wrenching novel that deserves a thousand awards.5 stars.

A mystery, a coming-of-age story, a puzzle—Jellicoe Road is all of these things wrapped up in one book. When I started, I was completely lost and didn’t think I’d ever make sense of what was going on (Townies? Cadets? Territories? What was with that car crash at the start of the book?). But my friend told me no one understands Jellicoe Road when they start out, so I continued on and was rewarded with a richly layered novel that fits all the pieces together in a way that felt both satisfying and inevitable. If you’re looking for a sophisticated but exciting YA novel that would appeal to your more mature reader, this would be a great choice. It has romance, intrigue, mystery and more, all wrapped up in a lovely cover and beautifully writing.

I wish I was a tenth as good at evoking emotion through words as Marchetta is. i got confused by this book so I skipped all the italicized bits and it still made me cry. I'm going to have to buy a hard copy so I can reread it properly. it's funny how for me, marchetta's books sneak up on you. they seem very ordinary at first but then there's parts that just punch you right in your feelings and leave you so unexpectedly emotional. they definitely work even better when you reread, because knowing where the emotional punch is coming from kind of helps you see all the intricate and subtle work Marchetta does in the build up and characterization. anyway. jealous of her talent and skill.

I gave it 4 stars because for me it was an inconsistent book. It started as a very young adult novel, 2 teens in love but they're in denial, blah blah blah. The same old story that didn't quite sit well with me. The story of Taylor and Jonah is also connected with the story of 5 friends. Now, the story of Webb, Narnie, Tate, Fitz and the Cadet guy (what's his name again) is something that really made me read the book. Their story made me cry. Its a book that does not end happily (depends on who is reading). Its a story of hope (as cliche as it may sound) and love. Its not the book I expected, it was a lot more.

Do you know how long it took me to finally read this book? FOREVER, OKAY? I had heard so many things and I'd basically convinced myself I was going to hate it, so I had zero motivation there. But something pushed me and I decided to give it a chance... and I'm glad I did. I can definitely see what the hype was all about. Though I'll admit it took me a bit to get into it because the beginning is REALLY FREAKING CONFUSING, I was glad I pushed through and got to the end, because when it all came together it was pretty powerful. Plus, I loved the characters. And I know everyone's all JONAH GRIGGS, and I can see why, but for some reason I'm still totally all about the Brigadier. ;)

Slow going at first, but when Taylor finally puts everything together, the reader is nearly as invested as she is. Part mystery, part boarding school tale, with a huge heaping of horrible things that can happen to kids. I understand why this won the Prinz, but I wouldn't recommend it to everyone. Sad and satisfying, it evoked tears, but didn't feel manipulative. And the references to To Kill a Mockingbird were appreciated.

I recommend reading it over the audio. Though the audio was mesmerizing, it got lost in the narrators voice and well got lost. I know that is kind of the method of the book, but not to the extent I felt I was just listening & not getting the unraveling. The fact that several of the characters go by different names also had me befuddled. But in the end it is a dark, sorrowful story wrapped in a lot of love.

BeautifulThis book is on our challenge list for this year and I gotta tell ya, I really didn't want to read it. But I did, and oh man did I love every second of this wild and confusing story! Amazing, the words are amazing, the feelings are amazing, the beauty of this story is amazing!

This book was kind of confusing for me in the beginning with the turf wars. I wasn't sure if there was killing involved or what. As I continued with the story I fell in love with the characters and didn't want to put the book down. It was a really good book with very well developed characters. I have to say that I love Jonah. :-)

I'm so glad I stuck with this book. I admit, I was a bit put off at the beginning by all the jumping around and the mix of mystical and real. But then, the bits and pieces started to make sense in my mind and I was on board. This book made me cry so much at the end and I wanted to run up and wake my little boy and just hold him. Excellent!

Dug a home in my heart. Here are some stars for the outpour of tears I got from it. I wasn't into it initially but I started appreciating it halfway through. Full of twists and very clever. Now I understand why people love this so much.

4.5 stars. Oh man, I really really loved this book. Such beautiful writing and amazing characters with mysterious and hazy histories. I think i figured out who was who much sooner than I was supposed to but I still really enjoyed it. Definitely reccommend.

This is a beautiful book. So much so that I finished it at 1 am on a week day.The beggining it's a little bit confusing but if you power through you won't regret it.Thank you for this story, Marchetta.

This book is very confusing at first, but stick with it, trust me, you will not be disappointed. This is a great book, very thought provoking. This story is filled with such heartache, but is so, so good.

At the beginning of this book, i was going to stop reading it , it was so confusing!! But then things started to clear out & i couldn't put it down. I really loved it, loved the characters, & how two stories are bonded together but at different time.
This book was... I can't even describe how fantastic and lovely and just amazing it's. Everyone should read it. Please, read it and be amazed.Jonah Griggs <3
4.5I didn't like the first third of the book, but the rest made up for all even though it was sometimes confusing.This is REAL YA, people should read more Melina Marchetta.Quite heartbreaking.
I needed to read this more quickly - I had it as my "bag book", which means I only read it when I had a few minutes somewhere. It needed to be given more careful thought - it needs a lot of it!
It took me over 2 years before I finally made it past the first chapter, but I'm glad I wanted until now. Listed under books that made me feel deeplyTruly incredible story
So sad and so beautiful. Loved it.
Buen libro, un tanto confuso al principio, pero me agradó

I can only think of three other books that have made me cry, and two of those involved the deaths of beloved pet dogs, which is the surest way to make me cry, hands down. This, though. This one is something else.I read this book in approximately four hours. How do I know? I started it on my lunch hour, and finished it at 8 pm, and I worked from 12:30-4:30. The four stars is deceptive; I loved the heart of this book. LOVED. This is a terribly sad book. And yet, it avoids Hopeless Town. That's a talented touch. LOVE. Let's get it out of the way now: I have no use at all for the territory wars plot. It seems more like a vehicle to make a book out of what might otherwise have been a short story, or perhaps an extremely clunky reverse parallel plot to the 80s territory wars starting? The main past characters get the brunt of the trauma. (view spoiler)[ Jude reads truest to me. He feels the outsider, and does what he is told regarding not telling Taylor or Jessa who they are or why he is around them because he's afraid Hannah and Tate will push him out otherwise. He handles Hannah with kid gloves because he can't bear to lose her. Hannah I can't quite figure. She is deeply, deeply messed up, and with good reason. To me, I can't see why she doesn't tell Taylor who they both are, but screwed up people do screwed up things, and her fear of losing both Taylor and Tate if she disobeys (how would Tate find out??) Tate's orders probably keeps her silent. And Taylor clearly describes how erratic Hannah's behavior can be with her--Hannah probably can't find her balance point in that relationship, thanks to...well,everything. Good lord, the trauma in the past of Hannah and Jude dwarfs the trauma in Taylor's past, and that takes some doing. (hide spoiler)]Though of course, there's plenty of sadness to go around! Having someone fall to pieces in your arms is a profound experience, and the recognition of that might be one of my favorite things in this book. (view spoiler)[ As Taylor rightly points out to Hannah, that's why things are so intense between Taylor and Jonah. It's also why things are so intense between Jude and Hannah, though they are adults and usually keep it under control--that breakdown after Webb's death happened longer ago, too. Having weirdly intense and fast-moving relationships is something of a thing in YA lit, but Taylor and Jonah have earned it, as far as I'm concerned. They did this thing when they were 14, and three years evidently elapse without them meeting again (still not clear on that; Taylor never mentions letters or phone calls once, which--editor's mistake? And for how easily Jonah appears outside her window, it's difficult to believe he stayed away the intervening two years he was in the vicinity.). Nevertheless, that connection you have with someone you saw emotionally stripped to bone never goes, and once that was out there there's no question of why this has to be so intense:  "How does Jonah Griggs get to be a ten? He sits on a train with me when we're fourteen and he weeps...self-hatred pouring out of him like blood from a gut wound in a war movie...I am the holder of the grief and pain and guilt and passion of Jonah Griggs and as we sit huddled on the floor of the carriage, he allows me to hold him...he takes hold of my hand and links my fingers with his and I feel someone else's pain for the first time that I can remember." Is that angst, or is that just another word for a way that emotional intelligence is born, how intuition can rise? The syntax in this scene (in the book in general, but this scene is the one I have to hand) is so fine: he allows me to hold him; he sits on a train with me. It would be easy to write this scene with slightly different words and lose the meaning of it altogether.  (hide spoiler)] Neither Taylor nor Jonah have connected with people much if at all until this moment, and that's what it's all about. That's the power of this novel. Connection. It's what they both want more of, and don't quite know how to get. There's a lot in this novel that I feel I can't criticize because I haven't lived it. Taylor calling her mother "Mummy" after all this. I've watched that parent-child bond go so many ways in my work-world, and it's one of the more mysterious things I've seen. Jonah being as functional as he seems to be, with his history behind him. I have a friend who shares some elements of that history, and he's shockingly functional too. People, we are strange and wondrous beings. And after all the horror that this novel bleeds, all the intensity alternating with the useless border wars non-plot, it still got me, with this: (view spoiler)[ "He takes her hand and draws her to his side. They don't say anything as they walk with me, but I've been here before, so I know that words aren't needed. I remember love. These two people taught it to me and when I see Hannah lean over and kiss Jessa's sleeping head, I know that for the rest of my life, no matter what, Hannah and Jude are going to be there. Like they always have been. And tomorrow I'll need them more than ever." That and when Taylor realizes that when she wants more, she needs to go and get it. Take that power, girl.  (hide spoiler)]On a lighter note, (view spoiler)[the whole exchange about the see-through nightie cracked me up. That was brilliant. Spot-on.  (hide spoiler)]And last but certainly not least, I loved how these characters saw each other through their eyes. That sounds obvious, but when Taylor looks at Griggs on the station platform she sees fear; when Jude looks at Narnie he sees her sorrow, and, later, her seeing everyone they've lost; when Taylor looks at Santangelo she sees his questions. I don't think we do this enough. I'm not talking about lovey-dovey gazing into each others' eyes; I'm talking about what amounts to using your limbic system, what some call intuition. It feels like magic and intuitive people are regarded as mystical, but as Benedict Cumberbatch's Sherlock Holmes so rightly states, "I didn't know; I saw.". This book deserved its Printz medal. Well done.*update 4/16/18 on reread*YOU GUYS! It's Ben the Violinist from The Piper's Son, plus bonus guitarists!!! I love it when authors weave characters in and out of books! Where oh where is my Jimmy Hailler book??? Step on it, Marchetta! (said lovingly yet impatiently)

I’m dreaming of the boy in the tree and at the exact moment I’m about to hear the answer that I’ve been waiting for, the flashlights yank me out of what could have been one of those perfect moments of clarity people talk about for the rest of their lives. If I were prone to dramatics, I could imagine my sighs would have been heard from the boundaries of the school to the town down below.The question begs to be asked, “Why the flashlights?” Turning on the light next to my bed would have been much less conspicuous and dramatic. But if there is something I have learned in the past five years, it’s that melodrama plays a special part in the lives of those at the Jellicoe School.So, JELLICOE ROAD. This story isn’t quite what I expected. For one thing, there’s a touch of magic in it, though it’s a contemporary YA, not a fantasy novel. For another, it reads very much indeed like a dystopian novel, although it’s not that either. Plus, there’s a definite mystery wrapped around the main story. Here's the back cover copy:Taylor is leader of the boarders at the Jellicoe School. She has to keep the upper hand in the territory wars and deal with Jonah Griggs - the enigmatic leader of the cadets, and someone she thought she would never see again.And now Hannah, the person Taylor had come to rely on, has disappeared. Taylor's only clue is a manuscript about five kids who lived in Jellicoe eighteen years ago. She needs to find out more, but this means confronting her own story, making sense of her strange, recurring dream, and finding her mother - who abandoned her on the Jellicoe Road.The moving, joyous and brilliantly compelling new novel from the best-selling, multi-award-winning author of Looking for Alibrandi and Saving Francesca.Which is all very well, but as you can see from the opening, the protagonist, Taylor, is dreaming about a boy when the story opens. This particular dream, and others, continues to be important through the story and particularly at the end. This is what I mean by a touch of magic.Also, Jellicoe School? The codified warfare between the students of the school, the townies, and the military cadets who spend a few weeks camping nearby in the summer . . . very dystopian feel to this element of the story. The adults don’t know what the heck is going on, even though the war gets pretty violent at times. No actual fatalities, but if the kids hadn’t gotten this all straightened out, I can hardly see how they would have avoided real trouble eventually.The story is not exactly about sorting out this war thing, though. It’s about Taylor getting her own life in order by working out her relationships to her friends at the school, to Chaz Santangelo (one of the Town kids) and most of all Jonah Griggs (leader of the Cadets). It’s also about Taylor sorting out her relationships with her mother, who abandoned her at the school years ago, and Hannah, who has been more or less acting as a mother to her since.So it’s a relationship story. Obviously. Except it’s really two stories braided together, because the story of what happened to Taylor’s mother and Hannah and their friends seventeen years ago is the frame story and also braided through the current-day story. Working out what happened to that earlier group of friends gives JELLICOE ROAD a definite mystery element as well. So it’s complicated.My overall reaction: It’s a pretty dark story. I, unlike whoever wrote the back cover copy, would not have picked the word "joyous" to describe it. What happened seventeen years ago is horrifically grim, and as we find out more about the aftermath, it just gets grimmer. There is a happy ending to that story . . . sort of . . . but the best thing you can say about the contemporary story line is: Taylor and her friends may go through some tough times, but it is *nothing* to what happened to the older generation. And everyone does wind up in a better place at the end than they were in at the beginning, but . . . moving, yes, but joyous?I actually disliked this story at first. I picked it up originally because of Chachic's recommendation, Brandy's comments, and Maureen's review and because the back cover copy sounded interesting. Two of the linked reviews (links now correct; sigh) refer to the confusing beginning. This is true, but it wasn't a problem for me. What was a problem for me is that at the beginning, Taylor is incredibly self-absorbed. I know she was going through a lot, but I really disliked her. Then a friend of hers at the school calls her on that and from that point on, she starts to grow into a much more likeable person. By the end, I liked her a lot. The bit where she tells off Sergeant Santangelo for being angry at his son, Chaz, is one of my favorite scenes. I really enjoyed seeing Taylor grow up and seeing the relationships between her and her friends deepen. Plus, Jonah Griggs! His backstory is *grim*. His background with Taylor is . . . also grim, in unexpected ways. But how he and Taylor figure out what happened in the past and work out their current relationship – all that is pretty much perfect.So, yeah, by the end, I loved this book. Since I was in the mood for emotionally intense contemporaries, I quickly picked up a couple more of Marchetta’s: SAVING FRANCESCA and THE PIPER’S SON.

Idk what to say about this book. It was strange. It was emotional. It was full of epiphanies. It was about belonging, about love, and about heart ache. It was about a girl looking for her mother. It was about depending on others. It was about depending on yourself. It was about Tate and Webb and Narnie and Jude and Fitz. It was about the past and the present and the future. It was about family. It's a very emotional story and at times painful to read because you see these characters that are good people make horrible decisions and become so lost that they don't even know who they are anymore. It's a story about loss, lonliness, death and guilt and all you wish for is that the characters get the happy ending they deserve.ps.: i cried. three times.

An entertaining read which had me totally engrossed or wondering why.Why was the war between the school, Townies and Cadets so violent? Why did the kids feel the need to participate in it every year? Why did Taylor seem to calmly accept the news of her relationship with her Aunt, mother and Webb? Why did everyone get so friendly so quickly?On the other hand this was a good mystery, lots of threads that came together, a bit of music, drug, domestic violence, paedophilia, young love, friendships, forgiveness and a happy ending. And topped off by a beautifully style of writing.

the beginning is confusing and it took me a while to figure out what was happening, so much so that I feel the need to re-read this soon to fully appreciate it. also, in usual melina marchetta fashion, there are a lot of tragic events in the book but thanks to her deft writing it never feels excessively melodramatic.P.S. jonah griggs is the best marchetta boy. period.

I definitely agree with reviewers who said the first 100 pages or so of this book are wildly confusing and I kind of felt like I was getting random names and plot points thrown at me. However, after a while things started to make sense AND THAT'S WHEN MELINA MARCHETTA DID TERRIBLE THINGS TO MY EMOTIONS.

4/5: While advertised as "teen fiction," the themes are very adult for the average teenager. This story was very raw and moving. It took a little bit to understand what was going on between the interwoven stories, but I got to a point where I could not put it down.

I'm sitting here with red puffy eyes and a headache, writing this. And it's all Melina Marchetta's fault...Taylor Markham lives at Jellicoe School. She's the head of the school boarders, leading them in a secret military-style battle for territory - in a teen war between the boarders' faction, the Townies and the Cadets that has been going on for generations. Ever since her drug addict mother abandoned her at a 7/11 store a few years back, Taylor has been happy to keep people at arms length. After all, by maintaining a tough exterior, it's easier to hide the hurt. And you can't be abandoned if you don't ever let anyone close enough to abandon you.Yet Taylor feels added responsibility pressing down on her. The disappearance of the closest person to a mother, Hannah, is a betrayal. Before long, however, Taylor moves past her fear of abandonment and worries instead that perhaps Hannah did not disappear of her own accord.Desperate to find her before its too late, Taylor's only clue is a manuscript of Hannah's, holding a story that feels less like fiction and more like a memory. And Taylor starts to wonder...what is it exactly that people are hiding from her? And will she live to find out?***If you can't already guess, this book is ENTIRELY mysterious. I guarantee that unless you have some crystal-ball-prophetic power you will be wondering what the hell is going on with anything for at LEAST the first third (it took me two-thirds, because I'm slower than most).The opening scene in Jellicoe is horribly shocking and angelically beautiful in equal doses. From there the reader is faced with a confusing jumble of people's names and places and actions, with no real way of being able to connect the dots. This is one of the few books where I feel the 100-page rule does not apply, make it 150 pages instead and you'll suddenly understand why I told you to hold on.This book has been called "distinguished" by other book bloggers and I would completely agree with the description. Marchetta has a crafty way of writing that is both mature and accessible.But what I feel this author truly excels at is her ability to create authentic teenage emotion. The relationships between these characters are so real - you feel the thrill of the first hand-touch of two (future) lovers, the fond feelings underlying an insult traded between friends, even the absolute desolation a teen feels when they realise their Innocence is being gobbled up by the Experience monster at an alarming rate. "No one understands us!", they cry.But you're wrong! Melina understands.I had only read Looking for Alibrandi by Marchetta before reading Jellicoe. I thought Alibrandi was a happy, bright little thing, until the book suddenly smacks you in the face with Death. In comparison, though, Jellicoe feels like a school excursion to the local haunted graveyard. Yep, On the Jellicoe Road is all about the ghosts, baby. Ghosts of the past, ghosts of the future, ghosts in dreams and ghosts in trees - pick your favourite flavour of ghost, they're all there. The book's also got this cool military thing going on - the school feels a bit like army barracks and when you pair this with the smalltown, isolated territory, well, you couldn't be blamed for thinking theres a bit of a dystopian thread running through the story.I could go on for a long time about lessons that can be learned here - the book is about journeys rather than destinations, and there are themes of abandonment, and freedom, and the blame game in abundance. Even better for the peeps out there who love a dash of symbolism - there's allusions to such classics as to Kill a Mockingbird and Maurice Sendak's Where the Wild Things Are, and it's totally open for reader's interpretation. I'm sorry I can't really give away more of the actual story, and I may have in fact confused you more, but believe me - it's all part of the master plan. And despite the hugely positive review I'm giving this book I have to come clean - I can't give this book five stars.Marchetta may be a whiz at writing, but she's a terrible surgeon. I feel like I've gone under the knife expecting to be dramatically altered yet healed - after all, my favourite authors have such precision! Instead I wake up to find that my brain thinks only of sad things. I want to curl up into the foetal position and never speak to the world again. This book deals with death, and then some. You can't say you haven't been warned!But hey, all in all, I am happy I read it *stifled sob* and I heartily recommend it *sniffle*. It's a fantastic offering from a fantastic writer and I know now that I'll just have to read Saving Francesca - I've heard brilliant things and it appears to be a lot of people's favourites of all of Marchetta's works... High Expectations, here I come!First though, I need a bit of time to get over this one. I'm exhausted. And I need to go wash my pillowcase.4 stars.A bit o' useless trivia: The original publication title On the Jellicoe Road was changed in the States to the simpler title of Jellicoe Road. Make of that what you will - I don't know what to think!

I will hand it to Melina Marchetta: she can write beautifully and she keeps you invested. At times Jellicoe Road felt tedious, mostly toward the beginning, and it was hard to see the end of the rainbow with this one. However, if you keep slogging through, it's a rather rewarding experience.
4.5 stars.
thought to come but !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
I was told this book gets better if you can survive the first few chapters, boy was she right!
IM NOT CRYING YOURE CRYINGJust, look at this beautiful, wonderful book. It's just raining on my face forever now

"I'm here because of you. You're my priority. Your happiness, in some fucked way, is tuned in to mine. Get that through your thick skull. Would I like it any other way? Hell yes, but I don't think that will be happening in my lifetime."

It breaks my heart (lol not like this book hasn't already broken it), but I cannot give this book five stars.First of all, PUT YOUR TORCHES AND SPEARS DOWN AND LET ME EXPLAIN.I'm going to try and begin justifying my decision by giving you a brief overview of the plot, but this is a hard book to sum up. Basically, there is a girl named Taylor whose prostitute mother abandoned her at a 7-Eleven outlet on Jellicoe Road when she was a child. She goes to Jellicoe School (a boarding school), where the students there are involved in an annual territory war with two other factions of teenagers: the Cadets and the Townies. Once, when she was fourteen, she escaped to try and find her mother, but was found and brought back. In this story, unwanted responsibility is thrust upon her, along with unexpected friendships and a revelation of the past that culminates in a huge storm of a headache and a heartache.Let's begin with the not-so-good so that we can end this on a pleasant note. I felt that the romantic aspects of the book, while portraying a realistic(ish) view of life, served very little purpose. The history that conspires prior to the present setting of this story opens up a world of possibilities that I felt had the capacity to be explored and intertwined with the main story arc, but instead seemed as if it was mostly just there to build sexual tension. Don't get me wrong, it was effective, but didn't contribute much value to the plot. Also, the romance didn't even develop in a very realistic way: in fact, the rate at which it progressed was almost alarming, and I felt that it was just riding on the reader's anticipation to move forward without very much logical flow and sequence (ie. it was pretty obvious from the start who it was always going to be). This, for me, is too great a flaw to ignore in my rating and because of that I've very, very reluctantly knocked it down a star.The good thing is, though, that there is something so magically enticing about this story. A quarter of the way in, I still had no idea what was going on. In the initial pages, the reader is just thrown into a seemingly random segment of Taylor's life with absolutely no introductions to who on earth she is and what kind of system the people there operate on. That's not even counting the bits and pieces of a completely different story chucked in at funny intervals to throw you off. Everything is a blur and it's a chore to piece everything together and get a clearer picture of the whole thing from any bit of contextual knowledge we can get our hands on.But therein lies the magic: the subtlety of the language and the way the plot opens up so gradually is kind of like unfolding a mystery I didn't even know was supposed to exist. It was here that I begun to suspect everything and everyone, and as a result, well... the supposed "plot twists" near the end were not very surprising for me. Rather, I thought it was better as a gradual thing, because while the revealing was taking its time, I was busy shivering with anticipation and oh my goodness is this it is that what you're saying no it can't be no it must be but no oh my goodness you can't do this to me noooo, and by the time everything finally converged, I didn't feel sucker-punched. I felt dead.(sorry, I couldn't resist being a little dramatic)Nah, I don't actually feel dead. It's amazing because there is so much hope in the tragedy that is presented. There are sad moments and parts of what is revealed in the end are undeniably tragic and horrible, but there is so much good that's been done and so many lives changed from all these supposed coincidences. In the end, what you get is the reality of mistakes, but at the same time also, the value of friendship and looking forward.------------------------Edit: Wow after reading so many reviews this sounds so shallow and unbelievably lame. BUT can I just cite this review? Because it is brilliant.

On the Jellicoe Road  is another great book that I could have only found through this site. For some reason, Goodreads-less me was unable to cross paths with it when I was closer in age to the protagonist. I had doubts when I first picked it up. It definitely took me at least six chapters or so to get into and want to know more, I'd read that this was the case for other readers so I just kept going with it. And it was worth it. It takes place mostly in small town present Australia, with briefer jumps back in time in the same location. It's as much about the place as it is the people, and the connections you build with both, especially through tragedy. I don't know why, but for a long time I had a strong opposition to reading YA fiction, even as a young(er) adult! When I was the same age as the protag (17) I tried my hardest to not wander into the teen section at Barnes and Noble because I thought I needed to read more serious works (I don't know where this idea came from...). I'm still fighting this weird book snobbery now but on a more subconscious level because I no longer care what people see me reading. (Well, I guess I have one little clue as to my nervousness. I went through a brief manga phase with my best friend in high school early on, and my Dad gave me the same talk his father had given him when he was still reading comics around that age- which is basically that you just can't anymore. To his credit, at the rate I was reading them and then buying more was probably becoming a little too expensive. But it definitely added to the anxiety of my book choices as it took some pushing on my BF's part to get me into manga in the first place! I've since come to realize that though my Dad is well read in his own exclusive non-fiction way, there are many things he won't experience from reading a little bit of everything. And it's taken me a while to see that not only is that okay, it's really good. Yesh, sorry about that extreme digression!) But because reading was usually a private pleasure for me, no one told me that not all YA is fluff. So, here I sit, once again amazed by another technically YA book, and ready for more. This review was more about me than the book I guess... sometimes that happens.  On the Jellicoe Road  has mystery, action and the perfect amount of romance. It made me laugh and cry (quite literally) and I stayed up until two in the morning to finish it. The reason I give it 4 stars instead of 5 is because I had an unusually hard time visualizing the world, which is critical for me as a reader. There were brief moments when I could see it perfectly, but Marchetta did not put much time into describing the characters beyond vague descriptions and adjectives. While I do sometimes like to alter the appearances of characters I'm reading about (as a kid Hermione had glasses and you couldn't tell me otherwise), I like a foundation to start with. This also applied to the world in general. She really just jumps right into it without much explanation which can be effective in many cases but I think with this story I would have preferred a little more background. All in all, this book opened my eyes a little wider to the power of YA fiction, and I'm ready for more that also set the bar. Teen aisle at Barnes and Noble, I'm ready for you! I can't wait to gift this to my cousins when they're old enough and make sure they never fret over what people see them read (if I can get them off their ipads, yikes). Yes, this review was coffee fueled.

As I rarely read Australian authors, I was expecting somewhat of a departure from the "stock" Young Adult lit books out there. It seems I got, in some ways, what I was expecting, but not in the manner in which I expected it. There were place-names that I didn't recognize (although Sydney was at least familiar-in-name); I had some trouble picturing the landscape not because of the lack of description, but rather because I assume it would be different than the stock landscapes in my head; and I kept wanting the characters to speak in an Australian accent, and I couldn't keep that up for long, as I was too "sucked in" to the characters and story. These things, however, were not the things that kept it from being a typical YA book. "I tell him stories. Lots of stories. About the Jellicoe School students and the Townies and the Cadets from a school in Sydney. I tell him about the war for territory."This book is characterized by two intertwining stories, both of which center on the same geographical location and interrelations among the three "factions" represented in the story (the school, the local "townies," and visiting "cadets"). While I had to go back a few times to re-read the sections of one of the stories as I began to feel my way through the book, some of the connections started to become clear as I continued. This discomfort with the divergent stories ultimately became satisfying, as they unraveled and converged slowly and naturally. Many iterations of YA literature focus on a single "misfit" who ends up saving the world or changing the community. The joy of this story springs from the self-discovery of a number of seemingly normal-and-troubled teenagers, all of whom struggle with reconciling their own identities. Still sounds like a trope, I know... But there's more to it than one might expect from this type of book.The interplay between self-and-origin and self-and-groups leads the main character, along with the people around her, to question where, when, and how identity really develops. Can we be complete if we do not understand where we come from? What are the turning points that make us who we are? Marchetta examines these questions from different viewpoints with a tapestry of answers, highlighting the complexity of being human. With the obvious question of finding out the truth of her parentage and a recently-disappeared parent-figure, the main character finds far more depth of understanding through reading the other story thread, which eventually converges with her own. Through dreams and flashback, this book makes the reader re-examine the glimpses of memory, which are contextualized and reinterpreted through different eyes over time, to seek the truth of SELF. Are we a product of our experiences or the interpretation of those experiences? Can we understand ourselves if we do not understand the motivations of those who have hurt or helped us? Complex but accessible, this book is appropriate for teenagers coming into a realization of identity. It is, however, just as poignant and engaging to a mature reader who may be tired of "typical" YA fiction. The author does not "dumb down" the concepts or complex relationships to cater to an I-want-it-now teenage culture looking forward to the upcoming movie-version. But these action-oriented folks will appreciate the building of suspense, multiple conflicts and layers, and engaging story-line. It's a quick and endearing read that isn't always easy to put down at bed-time.
Now that was a good cry.The book broke my heart multiple times but fixed it too. It was beautiful.

I love this book, I love love love love it. I'm not sure if I love the audiobook as much. (text itself, 5 stars, audio, perhaps 4.5?)Melina Marchetta is my favorite author, and this book is the one that really cemented her place as my favorite. To me it represents another level of writing for her. The audiobook in some places enhanced the story, but in others detracted. Mostly because of awkward, dated interstitial music that did not enhance the mood of the story at all, but also, ant this is so stupid of me to say, but because when I'm reading the book to myself I don't always think about how it's set in Australia, but when I'm listening to it being read I can never forget that and it was, it was honestly weird? IDK I'm probably a terrible reader for saying that.Beyond the audio presentation I've never properly written a review for this book, I think because I probably wasn't on Goodreads when I first read it and this is the first re-read I can remember doing.It's not surprising to me at all, having read all of Marchetta's contemporary work, that the theme of family, and especially found and created families, is prominent in this book. It's one of the things I like most about her work. It was also more evident to me on this read through that many of the unexplained pieces of the book would possibly be shuffled vaguely under magical realism by readers.This is not an easy book, and its not a breezy contemporary, but it is a deep look at the people we surround ourselves with, the love we find in this world, and the ways those things shape us.I also really really appreciate that the dangers of a very co-dependent relationship are on display here. It's refreshing to see a book that challenges its protagonist not to make a single person her entire world. It's also nice that the characters are flawed and make very real mistakes, and that their relationships with each other can survive those things.I don't know, maybe it's indulgent to see the self absorption of teens have few negative consequences on the ties binding them to friends, family, and loved ones here? I'm not sure.Also a note, I'm too blinded by my love for this book to genuinely critique it. There are probably problems of representation and plot here but I'm not going to be able to outline them for you, sorry.Edited to add: Re-reading this book was so odd, first, it's been, well I pre-ordered this book and read it immediately after the US release so it's been 7 or so years since I last read it. Many many things stuck with me and the anticipation of them was fascinating, but the how of things being revealed, and the when, that didn't really stick with me. Thus something I was convinced had happened about 3/5 of the way through actually came right at the end and I completely for got how we found out who one of the characters was. It was a completely different experience the second time through, but just as wonderful.

This review can also found here on my blog, PaperFantasies
If there’s a novel that is given more GoodReads love than this one, I have yet to hear of it. Browsing the reviews for Jellicoe Road, I was bombarded with 5-star rating after 5-star rating, glowing review after glowing review. I’ll be honest; after all that, the synopsis could have been about a dancing chicken and I would have rushed over to Amazon to order it. (It’s not, don’t worry.)Taylor Markham is a character taken straight out of a Lifetime movie; she doesn’t know her dad and her rarely-sober mother abandons her at a 7-Eleven, sentencing her to a life at a boarding school and guardianship from the one and only adult in her life to ever truly be there for her, Hannah…until she disappears, too. As if that’s not enough to ratchet the melodrama up to a 10, there’s a tragic story of 5 good friends being told simultaneously, one that happened in the past and slowly answers questions about Taylor’s history.The beginning of Jellicoe Road is very confusing, going back-and-forth between both stories with little to no segue, and no idea of how they match up in any way but location. It took me nearly half the book to really get into the story, and those pages were spent terrified I’d be the odd-man-out yet again, shrugging my shoulders at an enormously loved book and stamping my pessimistic, Debby Downer 2 –or –3-star rating on it. Thankfully, the second half delivered on all the promises the first half laughed at, and I found myself totally immersed in a heart-wrenching story full of lovable characters, many with huge, realistic flaws.What makes Jellicoe Road work is how it deals with the melodrama it contains. With so many tragic events making up the life of one seventeen year old girl, this could have gone terribly wrong in less capable hands. Marchetta manages to make it believable and relatable, never pushing it over-the-top, or cheapening the subject matter. There are no static characters, no Big Bad Guy or flawless hero. Everyone reacts to and is shaped by the events in their lives. This proves to me once again that the most important thing in a story is its characterization, especially in contemporary novels.This is hard for me to rate because of the completely different opinions I had about the first and second half. Ultimately, though you do realize that the beginning needed to be as slow and confusing as it was to make the rest so powerful, I can’t give this the full 5 stars when it took me so long to begin to enjoy it. I do, however, highly recommend it to readers who like a little more substance to their YA, and don’t mind having their emotions put on a rollercoaster of ups and downs.

If someone asked me to describe the plot of Jelico, I don't think I could. Finding family and love? Maybe? I was frustrated and confused through almost the entire first half. But then the pieces started to fall into place. With some serious orchestration and intricate plot weaving. Through to the end, which had tears rolling down my face while I sat in traffic listening to the audio. Characters - I don't really think I would have liked any of them in person. Except maybe the brigadier. He was the only character who seemed to have his act together. Everyone else was a mess. Narration was fine. Nothing to remark about. An overall frustrating read, that I ended up loving at the end. 4 1/2 stars. Lost a 1/2 star due to the confusion at the beginning.

Hmmm, I'm still a little bit on an emotional roller coaster with this book, but I'll try to write a review anyway.I did really like this book. It reminded me some of The Outsiders or Stand By Me, so if you've seen/read them, you may know what you are in for. It's written from Taylor's POV with some journal excerpts from Hannah. Taylor has had a rough life and knows very little about her dad and some of her past. I'm actually a little surprised at how little she remembers about her life before age 12, but since I had an ideal childhood compared to her, maybe that's the norm.Griggs is an interesting love interest, especially with what he had to deal with before even showing up at Jellicoe Road. At first he just seems like an intense guy with a bit of an attitude and a thing for Taylor. As you go along, especially near the end, you get to see more and more of the layers. I think I enjoyed his development more than even Taylor's.Chaz, Raffy and Ben are all great side characters. I actually like Ben the best and was a little sad that he's not involved as much as the story goes along. I do appreciate that there was not a love triangle, though.The journal entries by Hannah jump around a lot at first and it makes a lot of the story confusing. Add in Taylor's dreams, it can seem a bit crazy. If you stick with it, I hope you will think it is all worthwhile. You may have to reread the beginning again after you finish the book, though, to finish putting all of the pieces together. I loved Webb & Jude from the journal entries. Narnie, Fitz and Tate are OK, but I didn't really connect with them as much. (view spoiler)[ Though my heart really broke for Narnie a lot throughout the book.  (hide spoiler)](view spoiler)[ I was very glad at the end when Taylor said that she needed time away from Griggs so that she knew that she could live without him. I was glad that Taylor recognized how Tate's dependency for Webb was really unhealthy and ultimately her downfall.  (hide spoiler)]This book has a lot of swearing, though I thought it fit in well with the book. I usually am annoyed by swearing in books, but in this one I didn't mind so much. (view spoiler)[ There are also 2 brief sex scenes which you may not want younger YA readers to read.  (hide spoiler)] I did think it was strange how little adult supervision there was for the teens in this book. The adults are there at times, but not too often. I would recommend for 15 or 16 and up. It could be a good way to discuss death, sex, drugs, redemption and/or abuse with your teen. If you ever read it, I would love to discuss someday.  I forgot to mention it's also a great story about redemption. Not sure I can tell you more than that without ruining the book.

Taylor is leader of the boarders at the Jellicoe School. She has to keep the upper hand in the territory wars and deal with Jonah Griggs—the enigmatic leader of the cadets, and someone she thought she would never see again.And now Hannah, the person Taylor had come to rely on, has disappeared. Taylor's only clue is a manuscript about five kids who lived in Jellicoe eighteen years ago. She needs to find out more, but this means confronting her own story, making sense of her strange, recurring dream, and finding her mother—who abandoned her on the Jellicoe Road.So many people have been telling me that I have to read this book and now I finally have. I wasn't sure what to expect going in since I've seen such praise for it and I didn't want to be let down. It ended up being an entertaining read and I really liked the characters, but I wasn't as absorbed into the territory wars as I would have liked to have been.Taylor, newly appointed leader of the kids who attend Jellicoe school, was the main character and one that was both intriguing and frustrating. She was going through a lot and trying to deal with it on her own, which led her to passing her responsibilities as leader off on other people. It left a lot of room for growth and she did obviously care about the school and the kids under her care.At first, the plot was a little confusing. It took a few chapters to fully understand who was who and what was going on. Once that was dealt with, it made reading a lot easier. There was a lot of discussion about the territory wars, which was Taylor's boarders vs the townies vs the cadets and each group 'owned' part of the land. There were ways to get more land, to lose land, etc but it never felt like a huge plot detail to me, even though there was a lot about it in the book.What I was more excited about was to find out what had happened to Taylor's guardian, Hannah, who'd disappeared and why the story of five kids from eighteen years old was so important. It did take a few chapters to get used to the switching between the story of those kids and Taylor's group but once I did, it worked really well. The more that was revealed in the story, the more it connected to the present.The writing was absolutely beautiful. There were so many quotable passages. The interactions between characters were all over the place, in a good way. There was fighting and laughter and misery and support and love. It was great and they were my favourite part of the book.

I was surprised for this book. First because before start to read this book I saw a lot of 5 stars and this book is pretty book dut doesn´t deserve 5 stars for me. First I need comment that the first 80 pages are incredible boring and the story not make any progress. And that is important for me. I was so close to give 3 stars for so many elements.Taylor who is this girl hat was abadoned by her mom she finds to Hannah a wonderful person that rescue her and practically saves her life when she was only a child. And this time I am not going to publish spoilers because probably one the best elements is the suspense.But I must confess that this book has strong points. The romance was interesting and the mistery was pretty good. I am sorry but I didn´t feel magical the secundary story just really sad. Probably something i din´t enjoyed was the fact all these campament rules I was annoyed to one point.“Hold my hand because I might disappear.”Anyway was a good book I cried a lot to the end for several elements. And touched my heart. 4 STARS!

If there's a book in this world that I would have regretted putting down before finishing, it would be this one. Like many other reviewers here, I felt like I was dropped in the middle of a happening and had no choice but to find my own way by rereading some pages to try to figure out what was going on. But when the book finally started taking form, it became well worth the initial confusion. The novel follows two stories of two sets of teens from two different settings, but both are connected by tragedy. One is of the 17-year old heroine, Taylor Markham, who boards the Jellicoe School. Every fall, the “Boarders” fight the “Cadets”, military trainees who camp near the school for a few weeks, and the “Townies”, those who attend the school but live in town, participate in what is called the territory wars where they compete for various trails and buildings in town. In the beginning, she is elected as a leader of the “Borders”. She is highly respected in her faction, but is also known to be stubborn and hard to agree with. It is revealed in the beginning that she was abandoned at a 7-eleven bathroom at the age of 11 by her drug-dependent mother. She is picked up by her guardian, Hannah, who brought her to school on the Jellicoe Road where she works. The only memories she can recollect is sitting on a man’s shoulders, what her mom looked like, and a terrible shooting with the Hermit. The second story follows the tale of five teenagers whose friendship stemmed from a tragic accident. The novel continues as relations with the three factions develop, Taylor learns more about her past, and we out what happened with the five teenagers.The two storylines mixed with everyone seeming to have a “history” with each other was confusing at first, but to those who become stuck on unmotivated- don’t lose heart. Keep reading, because what awaits is nothing short of brilliant. I have to admit, Taylor was not a likeable character at first, but the story gives us insight on her past little by little, and the reader has no choice but to empathize with her. The story comes together in small but dramatic revelations that keep you on your toes. There is a lot about death, despair, anger, hurt, but also love, friendships, hope, and forgiveness. For a book that had so much emotion, Marchetta articulates it in a way that leaves you gutless. Other than the confusing beginning, this was a solid read that has a high recommendation from me.

A stunningly poignant novel. “I remember love. It's what I have to keep on reminding myself. It's funny how you can forget everything except people loving you. Maybe that's why humans find it so hard getting over love affairs. It's not the pain they're getting over, it's the love.”Marchetta weaves two stories decades apart together in such an impressive way! We have the story that Hannah has written about five teenagers who lived on the Jellicoe Road, they were each others family and all that mattered, and how they dreamed of getting out of Jellicoe Road. How fate had other plans. The main story is about Taylor, a seventeen year old who is now the leader of the Jellicoe kids in the territory wars. Taylor is just trying to survive. Abandoned at a 7/11 by her mother when she was 11, she doesn't have many aspirations for herself beyond surviving day to day. She's lost. And this is the complicated and beautifully wonderful story of how she finds herself. “As I walk back to the school on my own, I realise I'm crying. So I go back to the stories I've read about the five and I try to make sense of their lives because in making sense of theirs, I may understand mine.”“Is a person worth more because they have someone to grieve for them?”"Be careful what you wish for," he says with quiet menace, "because I'm about this close to telling you to get the fuck out of my life."I stare at him."What do you want from me?" he asks.What I want from every person in my life, I want to tell him.More.”As always, Marchetta has created an entire cast of characters that you will fall in love with. Her side characters are tenacious and crucial to the story, hardly feeling like side characters at all. And of course, the writing was gorgeous. Over all a really memorable story that I would recommend to anyone!I will definitely be reading it again, I think things will stand out even more then. “And then their voices stopped and their souls stood still and they ceased being who they had been. Because who they were had always been determined by him.”“And suddenly I know I have to go. But this time without being chased by the Brigadier, without experiencing the kindness of a postman from Yass, and without taking along a Cadet who will change the way I breath for the rest of my life.”

this book is pretty much perfect. i'm hesitant to give a 5 star review, but i just might switch it later...at least a 4.5. this is a book with important themes - abandonment, finding one's place in the world, guilt, defining one's self through one's relationships, love (not just romantic love, but love amongst friends). It delves deeply into relationships on all levels, with parental figures, siblings, friends, frenemies, acquaintances, mentors, the whole gamut. and in the end, it is about family, friendship, forgiveness, and the strength of human bonding. it also speaks of the influence that those around us have on the way we live our lives and view the world. in a way, this book gives me hope for humanity; yes, awful things happen, but people are resilient and can find strength in each other.there is so much heart and emotion locked into the pages of this book. (it's been a week or two since i finished reading, yet when i think back on it, all of the emotion comes flooding back). i can't count how many times my heart broke for taylor as she tries to navigate the world that surrounds her, but it's not just taylor for whom my heart breaks, it's narnie and jude, griggs; pretty much everyone has their demons that they carry.as for the plotline, there is slight confusion at the beginning as to what's going on with the different perspectives, but i picked it up rather easily. since the flashbacks/story are told out of sequence, i did end up going back and rereading those portions close to the end just to give myself a proper frame of reference (after everything was revealed of course). i figured out the connection between the stories earlier than i would have liked (and typically this knowledge will ruin a book for me because i prefer to be blind-sided) but found that it didn't bother me in the least. in fact, figuring this out made everything dearer to me, because i knew what some of the outcomes were going to be.characterization was really great. to begin with, there are a lot of characters, but none of them felt superfluous. each has their specific purpose and distinct, realistic personality; all are flawed, as they should be.really, really impressed with this book and hope to read more like it.

Ya'll, I wanted to love this one but I just couldn't. It's gotten amazing reviews, and it was certainly okay, but it just didn't do it for me.I thought the beginning was convoluted. We start with a story, it's going great, then bam! New story with new people and new places and no word on what happened to the old story. It takes a bit of reading to catch on, and you do, but I thought it was jarring to jump back and forth with no context.We immediately jump into the Townies/Cadets/House wars but we're not told why. Maybe I'm unusual here, but I wanted to know why these 3 groups were fighting over land and taking hostages and literally beating each other up. I may have been able to get into the story more if I had this background information.The plot in itself was quite good, unusual. It set up a lot of questions that I wanted to keep reading to find out the answers to. Like, where is Taylor's mom? Is she dead? If not, why hasn't she come for Taylor? What about her dad? Why are the land wars going on? What happened with Griggs years ago?There were a lot of characters and Marchetta did a decent job of giving them their own personalities. Some of them could have used a little more rounding out, but nothing was a deal breaker.The dialogue was good, quite realistic. There were a few terms or expressions that I had never heard of. I assume they are common in Australia. They were not bothersome and added to the feel of the story.There was no sexy hotness at all, which kind of surprised me, as there were a ton of teenagers living in a boarding school with little adult supervision. But maybe I have a skewed idea of what boarding school is like... There were a few nice kissing scenes, and 1 sex scene that was tentative and sincere.The Sum Up: It took a long time for me to finish reading this one.
