En lo que me basé para leer Jellicoe Road:① Es un YA. Y puedo confiar en un YA. (¡Queridos y alabados Young adult vengan a mí!)② Las reseñas que leí sobre esta historia, todas alabándola. (¡Gracias!)③ Que me fui 0 expectativas porque, primero: No tenía una p**a idea de la existencia de JR sino hasta hace unos 7 meses atrás, y yo me considero una amante y fiel seguidora del género, ja!. Segundo: es una historia que no fue spoileada ni nada. Lo que me hace pensar que quizás es porque no es tan popular, y si me estás leyendo justo ahora y no has leído Jellicoe road deberías corregir eso. YA.Lo que me encontré:① Lo que bautice el año pasado ―cuando leí Te daría el sol― como una joya: de los pocos pero buenos YA.② Una trama muy innovadora. En ningún momento sentí que fuese rebuscada, todo lo contrario, me resulto fresca y fácil de leer. Lo de Cadetes, paisanos y guerras territoriales. ③ La narración es ágil, sencilla y entendible. Puede que saltara de un momento a otro, pero eso sería en cuestión de escenas que hay algunas que me hubiese se alargaran más.④ Buenos personajes. Y no pensé que diría esto pero me termino cayendo bien Taylor, cuando deje de centrarme tanto en su hostilidad y la historia dejó de enfocarse (más allá de las 100 páginas, ugh) en los sueños y el llanto de Taylor, empecé realmente a disfrutarla. Y a los personajes dentro de la historia en esta historia son fabulosos. Me gusta que Melina Marchetta no se enfocó solo en Taylor y su vida sino que todos los demás tuvieron su participación y parte importante en la historia. Y eso es algo digno de alabar.Lo que me gusto:① La trama. ¿Ya les había dicho que me gusto la trama? Si te vas leyéndolo hazlo desde un primer momento por la trama. Es una delicia. Disfrútala, vívela, quiérela y súfrela como yo. Eso sí, que nunca se te olvide. Oh, la trama lo es todo. *suspira* ② Los personajes. Haría una lista bien grande porque en Jellicoe Road todos merecen ser amados. Solo personajes que crecen personalmente. En medio de tanto sufrimiento, devastación y despedidas se nota la manera en que Melina quiso reflejar el progreso de.cada.personaje.③ La historia dentro de la historia. La historia de Narnie, Webb, Tate, Jude y Fitz que me ha tocado el corazón. ④ Jonah Griggs. 😍🔥🔥⑤ El sarcasmo. Sarcasmo everywhere. #YayMis relaciones favoritas:① Está bien, se podría decir que debería empezar por la pareja protagonista, pero de primer lugar no debía dejar de lado a Hannah (Narnie) y Jude que, aunque casi nunca fueron una pareja al uso, para mí son la mejor no pareja que he leído. Jude, se mío. ♥①.② La relación colectiva. La de Jonah como cadete, Santangelo como paisano, y la de Taylor como jefe de las casas; con ambos. Cuando poco a poco se va acompasando el conflicto y las guerras territoriales para ser partícipe de fiestas, aventuras, pasado y amigos. Ben y los hermanos del flequillo a quien los une el gusto por la música. ② Taylor y Jonah, que a pesar de basarse en un inicio por un pasado en común y luego lo que vino después, para mí siempre será una de las relaciones más lindas que he leído. Fue pausada, dulce, a base de gestos y silencios compartidos que yo, literalmente, morí de amor.③ Webb y Tate. Porque sin Webb y Tate no habría Taylor, y sin Taylor no hay Jellicoe road, y sin JR; no hay Jonah. #JustSayin ④ Raffy y Santangelo. Que si tuviese la oportunidad de meterme a la historia para juntar sus caras de una vez por todas, la releería para cumplir mi sueño realidad.Mis escenas favoritas:① El día que Jude llega por primera vez a JR y ve a Narnie, luego vuelve al día siguiente a sembrar amapolas y conoce a Webb, Tate y Fitz. Los que luego serían sus mejores amigos. ② Fitz, ese niño que llegaría en una bici robada y les salvaría la vida. ESA ESCENA LO ES TODO. Me pone triste su destino y luego recuerdo quien es Jessa y parte de la tristeza se convierte en felicidad. ③ Nunca quise tanto un camisón (y no tenerlo precisamente), ni le di importancia. Nunca quise tanto (y agradecí) que una protagonista causara un motín usara un camisón como Taylor, hasta que causo esa reacción en Jonah; viniera él toda sensualidad y dijera una que otra frase listilla que me hiciera fundir en un charco. No valí nada. Y ya no tengo ovarios. 🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥④ En la inauguración cuando Ben dice las razones por las que Raffy y Santangelo deberían estar juntos fue reveladora. Y de las mejores, ¡Bravo!Todo lo demás es el resultado de una de las mejores lecturas del año. Porque Jellicoe Road 
me ha encantado
. Y ya estoy deseando leer más de MM.

Disclaimer: This review originally appeared on my blog, The Book Fairy's Haven.How do you rediscover your sense of wonder underneath all the layers of grief, forgotten memories and fragmented pieces of history when all you have is a script that tells a broken story and a girl who has forgotten her past?I first fell in love with Melina Marchetta’s writing a couple of months ago when I read Saving Francesca. This wonderful author has a way of making the lives of her characters seep into your veins, filling your soul with a bittersweet ache that refuses to go away long after you’ve turned the last page. And with On the Jellicoe Road, it proved to be no different.In fact, I’d go as far as to say that this book proved to be an even better reading experience - such is the exquisite power of her writing.Not only that, but the book wrecked me in a way that I never, ever expected it to, which is why the first thing you should probably know before I continue, is that Melina Marchetta is the queen of bittersweet reads.Her books aren’t the conventional kind of reads that always leave you with closure; they’re books that leave you with a lingering void in your soul; it’s one that you’re not sure how to refill and one that you’re not quite certain you want to. But, for all of their poignancy, they somehow, by their very nature, also leave you filled with a hope that speaks of new beginnings and all of the blossoming opportunities that go hand in hand with it. And On the Jellicoe Road, is definitely one such book.Yet, it doesn’t make for an easy read.It’s not because it’s heavy and dressed in intellectual snobbery ( quite the opposite, in fact) but it’s because the book is like a puzzle; the pieces all fractured and fragmented, and arranged in an order that at first appears to make no sense.I know many have abandoned this book for this very reason, but here’s my advice to you: Puzzle pieces always start out with no structure, but when it starts taking shape, it transforms into a completed masterpiece.Melina’s On the Jellicoe Road?It’s not only a phenomenal riddle-like novel waiting to be solved by the reader, but it’s a reading experience that transcends its very own essence when the pieces finally fit together. The book starts off at the scene of an accident, and hooks you in immediately:
“My father took one hundred and thirty-two minutes to die.I counted.It happened on the Jellicoe Road. The prettiest road I’d ever seen, where trees made breezy canopies like a tunnel to Shangri-La. We were going to the ocean, hundreds of miles away, because I wanted to see the ocean and my father said that it was about time the four of us made that journey.”
These opening lines not only set the scene for a journey that will span over the course of twenty years, but also asks the following question posed by an integral character in the book (I quote): 
“I remember asking, ‘What’s the difference between a trip and a journey?’ and my father said, ‘Narnie, my love, when we get there, you’ll understand. “
I didn’t think of it then, but only when I closed turned the second last page, did I realise just how important this question would be. I also never thought that this book would have such a wonderfully, hopeful and heartbreakingly beautiful response to the posed question, nor how it would fit in with the theme of the book, which is why the impact of this book was all the more powerful for it.Divided into past and present, present-day focuses on Taylor Markham, leader of the boarders at the Jellicoe School. With her trademark devil-may-care, rebellious and tough-as-nails attitude, she reluctantly finds herself having to deal with boarding house issues, trying to negotiate her way around territory wars, which includes dealing with Jonah Griggs – who is not only leader of the rival gang, The Cadets - but also someone she’s had an interesting history with.Having been abandoned by her mother at a young age, Taylor rarely lets anyone in, and when Hannah, the caretaker and only person Taylor has ever learned to rely on disappears, the only thing she’s left with is a strange and unfinished manuscript which chronicles the story of 5 people who resided in Jellicoe years ago.Taylor knows that in order to uncover Hannah’s whereabouts, she’ll need to try and make sense of the manuscript. But with so much of her own story missing and being plagued by strange dreams that may be connected to the manuscript, she’ll need to finally confront all the memories that she’s been repressing and try to find the mother who abandoned her On the Jellicoe Road so many years ago.The manuscript Taylor tries to make sense of focuses on 5 people Hannah wrote about: Tate, Webb, Fitz, Jude and Narnie.When we read this part of the story, we’re not quite sure why their story forms part of the overall arc and at first, one is almost tempted to skim through this part because you don’t really see a point to this segment (which, by the way, is told in the form of manuscript pieces intertwined throughout the novel).It turns out though, that these 5 people have more history with the Jellicoe Road than we could have imagined.Their story is one that is filled with laughter and happiness, devastating tragedy and bittersweet nostalgia. Narnie and her troop are all made so real to us, and even though a few of them are no longer around, you can’t help but feel as if their presence is deeply soaked into the story.I wish I could tell you how the story comes together, but that is an epiphany – an “oh, that’s why” moment that every person should have the privilege of experiencing on their own.On the Jellicoe is also a novel that deals with so many difficult topics.Tackling issues of abandonment, suicide and bereavement, it’s a no-holds barred look at how the devastating actions and bad decisions of the past, impact Taylor and the various characters in this novel, in the most haunting manner possible.The secondary characters are incredible in their own way, and only enhance the sheer beauty of this novel.From the budding friendship and romance between rival gangs and watching how beautifully it comes together, we get to see how each character, despite appearances have an underlying yearning for something so much more than the circumstances they find themselves in.The relationship between Taylor and Jonah is definitely one of my favourites in YA. Watching how mistrust slowly fades away and brings them to a point where they become each other’s support, is nothing short of spellbinding.What’s even better is that these two have a chemistry that’s not just based on physical attraction, but also on a heartfelt emotional connection.At the end of the day though, On the Jellicoe Road is not just a story about love, friendship and learning to discover who and what you are, it’s also a story of how the actions of one generation can have far-reaching consequences on the ones they’ve left behind.It’s a moving and beautiful read filled with love, loss, laughter, heartache and the power of friendship and forgiveness. Above all, it’s a book that will make your soul weep with ALL the feelings your heart can stand.Give this one a chance. It’s more than earned its place on my list of all-time favourite reads.

2 palabras: Brillante. Obra maestra. Literalmente no hay suficientes estrellas en esta galaxia para calificar este libro en cualquier tipo de escala de estrellas. En pocas palabras, le doy a esto una calificación infinita de estrellas.Si está buscando un libro que toque tu corazón, no busque más: Jellicoe Road, de Melina Marchetta, es un libro inquietantemente hermoso sobre el amor, la pérdida y la trágica ironía de la vida. Algunas revelaciones romperán tu corazón, pero siempre existe la promesa de esperanza, y eso es lo que hace que este libro sea tan poético. La historia comenzará confusa, pero no dejes que eso te desanime porque todas las partes se juntarán al final. Los personajes, especialmente los 5, se quedarán contigo mucho después de que hayas dejado el libro.TENÉIS QUE LEER ESTE LIBRO!!!!!!!!!
Simplemente, hermoso

"Some people say their prayers at night. I don't. What I say is always the same. My name is Taylor Markham. I live on the Jellicoe Road."
 I can honestly say I did not expect such an intricate and beautifully written story. I have book pals who've raved about this author and this book. Of course they recommended it to me and in typical reader fashion, I put it on the back burner with my Mt. TBR *smh*. I finally see why this book is often referenced and brought up again and again on my book feeds. There is a reason Jellicoe Road won an award, people!!Jellicoe Road tells the story about our heroine, Taylor Markham and essentially the significance of the book's title. [Side note: do you ever get happy chills when you come to understand why the title is what it is?? No? Just me?] I was SO confused as to what was going on in the first couple of chapters. I honestly didn't understand the hype. Once I hit chapter 16, my brain was on fire and it was non-stop MUST read each night! I continually spammed my friend Lisa at Romances Ever After with theories and all caps. I should really start keeping my chat receipts to show you my distress, theories and excitement while reading. There were a lot of emotions being thrown around in there. Anywho, back to the review~ There are a number of characters introduced that I found difficult to wrap my head around who was who all the time. The story weaves together the past and the present. The kicker was, the past was not Taylor's but of a different group of kids. I must admit that there came a point where I wrote down names and connection/relationship lines. The most obvious of these was the one between Taylor and Jonah Griggs. Jonah kind of grows on you. At least he did for me. At first, I just kept thinking "this guy is mean!", "whatchu doing Tay?", "the Ben guy is much nerdier and cuter, go for Ben!". Then Jonah starts dropping these smooth lines, being a caring individual and suddenly I'm a sucker for him. I came to care for many of the secondary characters as well: i.e. Santangelo. This precious pushover *sigh*. I wouldn't have mind learning more about him or even getting his own book because I felt vibes between him and another character! Also one for Hannah and the other person too please. Their backstory and history together hurt my heart so much.I think my favorite part of reading Jellicoe Road was trying to make connections to figure out what was happening. I was on detective mode, trying to solve the "mystery" of the story. There were some aspects that I was able to figure out with major determination and investigative skills. Other parts were very unexpected. My mind was blown on countless occasions! I highly recommend this book to all readers. I am officially a fan and happily riding this Marchetta train.

You know what? Amazing. That's my favorite adjective and I always use it to describe the books that I really love. But even that is such an understatement. This is so great, so wonderful that I can't even put it into words.Seriously. Like overflowing tears of happiness.
Plot
I'll go on without summarizing the plot. I'll tell you that even though the plot of On the Jellicoe Road may sound typical, it's the narration that changes it all. But really, I love everything about this book. I love the Houses all those rules in it and the Cadets and all that, it can very confusing at first but when you eventually understand it. I'll just warn you though that if you do read this book then great patience and understanding is required. Although the plot is pretty simple, it's the narration too that makes it all jumbled up. So you have to figure it out yourself to fully grasped everything. And I guess that's also one of the reasons I love this book, it makes the reader think. Really think. It's wonderful. It's amazing.
Characters
Taylor's character? I freaking love her. You know she's just a regular teenage girl. Yet, she's fierce. Tough. Not a perfect leader but a good now. She's what, seventeen? But acts like she's older than that. Her voice is so real, so alive that I feel like she's talking to me while I read this. I love everything about her. I love that she's responsible, I love that she gets annoyed, I love that she talks about her weakness and what she misses, I love how she puts on a brave face, I love how she handles situation, I just love her. Everything about her. She ain't no superwoman, but she's like a hero to me. I don't know why but it's like she inspires me.Jonah's character is wow. He looks dangerous in the outside but he's a total gentleman in the inside. Who would not melt reading about Jonah? Like so kilig!I love Jonah and Taylor interact. There's tension but there's also that sweetness. It's adorable and so so good to read. That bittersweet love!I love the other characters as well, even the characters in Hannah's story. They're all beautiful and so interesting to read.
Romance
I am a certified Taylor and Jonah fan! I mean, how can one not be? It's so fun to read about their conversations and their interactions. Their romance is not way over the top but the reader can really feel the connection.(view spoiler)[They didn't even said I love you to each other yet you can feel that they REALLY do love each other! (hide spoiler)]This romance that is that physically active but more emotionally active is a romance that I probably won't ever forget. It makes me think that you know words don't need to be said for you to understand, it's all about making the person feel it without saying it. And that I think is what makes Jonah and Taylor such a wonderful couple. Plus, this is also a mature couple. Yet there's also playfulness in them.
Narration and Writing
This two are probably the most amazing thing in this book. Taylor's narration is hands down, brilliant. It's alive, it's real. Her voice, it's like I can actually hear it. The way she narrates the book is so beautiful. I feel like I am part of the book and I'm in the book. And when I put down the book it's like waking up from a dream you know? Corny but true. It's complicated but when you finally get it, you'll be surprised how wonderful it is. I mean at first I was like "huh?" too but Marchetta's writing is so effective that well you'll be like "oh my gosh, this is awesome!" I enjoyed every part of this book, especially Taylor's voice. I feel like this by the overwhelming beauty of this book.The writing is also magnificent. It's detailed and it's confusing in such a good way that it will eventually make sense in the end. I love how she describes Taylor's emotions, her hardships, her happiness, her pain, her sorrow and just everything about it is so real. Like I can also actually feel it. I can connect so well with Taylor because of the writing and narration. And here I am again, frustrated that I can't express how wonderful it is. *sigh*I would really love to read more of Melina Marchetta's book, and really before reading this book I heard lots of good things already. I should've read it sooner! This is such a wonderful experience to be reading this book. Such a wonderful experience.

This book is brilliant. And I don't know how to give a teaser summary without spoiling anything but I'll try to base on the synopsis on Goodreads. To make it short and simple, this is a story of 
  Taylor Markham
, a 17-year old senior student in a boarding school near Jellicoe Road who was abandoned by her mother when she was 11. Another one-sentence summary: This is a story a girl so broken, that all she knows about herself is fragments. The pieces, some are not clear, some a little odd or unnatural that it seems that they're not connected at all.Also this one is told in two perspectives: present and past, making it even more confusing. At least at first. I'm not gonna even suggest that you guys read this. YOUR CHOICE. Why? because even I who loves mysteries ever since I was a young girl got confused and almost give this one up. The first half of the book seemed to be really confusing and boring, though I somehow figured it out even before I reached 50%. But if you ever pick this one up and find yourself bored and confused as hell, DON'T GIVE UP.It's amazing how the author successfully weaved all the pieces together until they become one. Taylor's mother dumping her, a woman named Hannah keeping her from then on and now left her too without even saying goodbye, the five mysterious teenagers who once lived on the Jellicoe Road even before Taylor was born, the boy who visits in her dream to listen to her stories, the Hermit who whispered something in her before killing himself, the Brigadier who everytime in town, some people are missing and even the territory wars between Taylor's school partakes in. The connection between all these is superb. It was so well-written that it's like every piece of the story is a puzzle piece and one you got the hints, and then solve them as a whole eventually, it was glorious. Also haunting and heartbreaking. And did I mention, it's brilliant?The author even handled the characters so well, the emotions this book left me are just TOO MUCH.And this is only possible if I get connected with the characters I feel them. Some might say that this story isn't just about Taylor and they're maybe right. You see there's Hannah and the Brigadier. There's the five teenagers who once lived on Jellicoe road years ago who call themselves the fucked-up Five. There's the townies and the Cadets who are the other participants in the aforementioned territory wars which seemed childish, by the way, but really it is a part of the mystery. Anyway, there's also Raffy and Chaz. There's Ben  and Jessa.And there's 
  Jonah Griggs
, the boy who Taylor knows as the one who betrayed her. But then she has no choice but to face him. I love the chemistry between all the characters but Jonah and Taylor's exceeds my love to other YA couples. And Jonah just added to my list of book boyfriends. And Taylor, my heart bled for her.Darn it, my heart bled even for those five mysterious teenagers. This is really such an emotional but satisfying story that I know will stay in my heart forever. This one actually just made it to the books I'll reread forever. No kidding. Because you see no matter how emotional I get by reading this, it's all in a good way. It's worth it. It didn't leave me unsatisfied, but actually hopeful.

    WARNING: 
  
  this book contains some issues that others may find as triggers, so beware. But hey, you guys know how I'm dealing with depression now, still I read this book, I handled it well and loved it. Like I said, it left me hopeful. So high-five to that.
Have a great day/night,

It happened of the Jellicoe Road. The prettiest road I'd ever seen, where trees made breezy canopies like a tunnel to Shangri-La. We were going to the ocean, hundreds of kilometres away, because I wanted to see the ocean and my father said that it was about the time the four of us made that journey. I remember asking, "What's the difference between a trip and a journey?" and my father said, "Narnie, my love, when we get there, you'll understand," and that was the last thing he ever said. 
I did a little bit of reminiscing last night, and picked this book up as it is one of my favourites. Melina Marchetta is hands down one of my favourite authors. I had first heard of her at school when we studied her book "Looking for Alibrandi" an easily relatable book that deals with a girl struggling to find her identity. My sister recommended this book of Marchetta's claiming that it was worth the read. She said not to be worried if you did not understand it at first, but to wait for it to all make sense because the wait was worth it.. and she was most definitely right. I will say the first time I read the book, I was not at all confused as to where it was going because my sister had given me an all-too-in-depth explanation of the entire book and what to look out for, and I'm glad she did. I can completely understand where people are coming from in finding the first part of the book a drag as the past and present stories seem to be utterly separate and the characters different. However, persevere is the word I would use for this book. The heartfelt content that will make your heart warm and break is worth your frustration. Some people do not like the way the book is worded, but I find that's what makes Marchetta in a league of her own. She does not give you a typical YA book that deals with "twilight" topics but instead brings you on a real, raw journey of families that were affected by their time "On the Jellicoe Road" and how all of their lives intertwined. It's not meant to be a book that should be easy to understand or read, it let's the reader make up their assumptions, and in a way it really gives reader credit in saying that they are not "dumb" but can figure it out on their own without constant help along the way. 
I feel arms around my chest, a mouth against my ear whispering . . . whispering . . . Jonah Griggs whispering . . . "Just breathe, just breathe, come on Taylor, just breathe . . . just breathe."
Reread this book is the advice I would give, I've reread it a million times, and am still finding parts of the story I did not find along the way.
"Forgive me, please. Please. Please. Please. Please." The words were pouring out of him, soaked with tears and phlegm and spit and blood, as she continued rocking him, while Jude held onto them both. And at that moment Jude thought something that he would never forgive himself for. He wished that he had never met any of them. 
This book is about identity, about belonging, about the bonds of friendship, the struggles and healing power of love, the way guilt can change a person's life, how hope is never lost and the importance of camaraderie. 
"What are you so sad about?" Santangelo says to me. "We're going to know him for the rest of our lives."
The interwoven stories from the past really add a depth to the book and allows comparisons between the friends of the past with the friends of the present. It shows the deterioration of one group and the coming together of another. Each character has their flaws, yet each character made me fall completely in love with them. I really love that this book showed that there is no clear distinction between a character that is bad or good, but that sometimes it is not their choice how they are perceived regardless of who they truly are. It shows how people who are lost, can be found.
 A home to come back to every day of their lives. Where they would all belong or long to be.A place on the Jellicoe Road.

Oh my god, this woman.I've been walking around like a zombie the entire day, trying to find the words that will do justice to how I feel about this book, and I'm still unable to wrap my head around what this book did to me. I want to gush and use words like beautiful and poignant and heart-wrenching, but they don't even come close to describing the depth of emotions I'm drowning in right now.You know how there are books you want to keep a closely guarded secret because you know - you just know - it would kill a part of you if somebody didn't appreciate it as much? And then there are those books that restore your faith in humanity and are so real and honest that you want to cry because such a thing exists and you're frustrated that it took you so long to find it and you're just downright giddy with happiness because reading them does something to you and you suddenly want to make changes in your life because you haven't been living the way you always dreamed you would and you want to share it with the world so that they can feel the same way?That's what Jellicoe Road is - a gift to the world. I'm not talking about its literary merit here, although Marchetta's writing by itself is astounding. I'm talking about it being a tiny voice contained in these 300 pages telling you to be the kind of person you've always wished you were. That little voice that gets lost in our constant rush to get somewhere. We have moments - I know I do - when we just take a step back from whatever we're "supposed" to be doing at the time and ask ourselves just where the hell we're going with our lives. And then it's gone. It's back to finishing assignments, studying for exams, working.Not living.You know what I want to do?I want to write this book on my walls. I want to stare at it everyday and remind myself of what is important to me. I want to wake up to Marchetta's unbelievable ability to say exactly what I wish I could say to myself sometimes, and to say it in a way that is just.. right. Wake up to her ability to create characters that make me howl with laughter and sob hysterically in equal measures. I want to read every book she's ever written and carry them with me everywhere I go, because just knowing they are there for me, should I need them, is comforting.I want to change the summary of this book on Goodreads, because it doesn't come close to even being in the same continent of what this book is about.I want to praise Melina Marchetta to the skies for creating secondary characters that aren't just accessories, but are as vividly alive as the main ones. I want to point at Taylor Markham and tell whoever is willing to listen, "THAT. That is how you create female YA characters." I desperately want to be able to stay separate from all the Jonah Griggs-love that is floating around on Tumblr (I'm failing miserably).I want to flood this review with quotes from the book, just to show you how lyrical and soul-shattering her writing is, but I really really think I'd be taking something away from you if I did. Her words deserve to be consumed with full knowledge of all that came before it because only then will it resonate as strongly as it should.I want to buy a thousand copies of this book and go up to every human being I know and thrust this at them with the hugest smile on my face and ask them to read it. And most importantly, I want to thank Raya with everything I've got for introducing me to such a wonderful author.
Quite possibly one of my favorite books I've read so far.It's beautiful, poignant, and shocking to the end.Absolutely worth the read.

Taylor Markham lives at the Jellicoe boarding school on the Jellicoe Road, where she ended up when her mother abandoned her at the 7-11 down the road six years ago when Taylor was 11. Taylor has suddenly found herself with a lot of responsibility, none of which she wants: she is head of her House at the school and is expected to pay attention to the younger girls, and she has been named leader of the school during their annual territory war with the local Townies and a group of prep school boys from Sydney called the Cadets, who come camp out on the Jellicoe Road every year for six weeks from September into October. Making life even more complicated, the leader of the Cadets this year is a boy named Jonah Griggs with whom Taylor has some "history." And Hannah, the only adult with whom Taylor has any real connection, suddenly disappears, leaving Taylor both grappling with her abandonment issues and filled with new questions about her mother. A parallel story is woven through the book, taken from a novel Hannah has been writing about 3 teenagers named Narnie, Webb, and Tate, who were brought together by a horrible car accident on the Jellicoe Road, which Taylor reads during Hannah's absence. This book opens with the words "My father took 132 minutes to die. I counted." So you might guess that it is not the most cheerful story around. Really terrible things have happened to the characters -- and yet, since they happened in the past, it didn't bother me as much as in other books I've read. Taylor, the 17-year-old narrator, is numb, but has a tough attitude that kept the story from feeling whiny or annoying. Plus, the way it's told is like a jigsaw puzzle. It's hard to tell what's going on for the first 100 pages or so, but hints and clues are tossed out in a way that kept me glued to the book -- I could hardly put it down. I did have to keep flipping back to double-check what I had already read, though, which was a little annoying. This is not an easy read, but it is completely absorbing. There's an intensity to the story that kept it living in my head every time I had to put it aside.I really enjoyed reading this book, and was completely blown away by it. The only minus I can call out is a bit of plot overkill at the very end, but the story nevertheless succeeded in ripping my heart out, stomping all over it, and putting it back together again. This is one of the very rare books where, after I finished it, I flipped straight back to the beginning and started it again. I think it's just an amazing achievement. This was the winner of the 2009 Printz Award, and totally deserved it.

“What do you want from me?” he asks.What I want from every person in my life, I want to tell him.More.This book deserves a lot more than a five star rating, but that’s all I have. I don’t know if my review will manage to contribute to the praise it had received from others, and I really want to, so here I go.Taylor - the lead character and the narrator of the present time story – is a 17 years old girl abandoned by her mother, six years ago, at a Seven-Eleven. Fearing being abandoned again, she tries to keep away from deeper relationships with people while craving such connection at the same time. One day, Hannah, her closest person disappears and Taylor has no choice but to ask for help so she can find her.There is a past time story going on parallel to Taylor’s and I think it’s best to go into this book without knowing anything about it because as it unfolds page by page is exactly how the magic of this book happens. It’s true that the first 100 pages or so of On the Jellicoe Road are not easy to get through but once I understood the two parallel stories and their connection, that didn’t matter at all, I was completely engrossed. Honestly, I don’t remember the last time I’ve read a book that made me care so much for every single character. The story is complex and multi-layered, with many characters, and I ended up loving all of it. Also, I ended up in tears more than once, and I have to say - the final chapters are devastating. Yes, it’s a heartbreaking and emotional book but in no way melodramatic. On the contrary, the characters are realistic and the emotions they go through are raw, and that only makes the book more powerful. And yes, I could feel the sadness and grief pouring from the pages but there is also so much love, forgiveness, humour and wit. And everything you could want from a book. So wonderful.I have read Saving Francesca and The Piper's Son and I loved them both, but On the Jellicoe Road is my favourite Melina Marchetta book so far. Read it, it’s an unforgettable experience.

5 stars? More like eleventy bajillion squillion stars. I love this book so much. Sosososo much.My review, originally posted here www.thetometravellers.wordpress.comI’m just going to come out and say that I have absolutely no idea how to put into words the complete and total love I have for this book. I think I’m just going to start typing and I’ll hopefully produce something meaningful.Firstly, I have to give a special shout-out to my dear friend Emily for bringing this book into my life. It was the second book of MM’s I read (in 2009) and the one that sold me on her so who knows if I would’ve ever read it, if not for her? Sometimes, when I’m a contemplative mood, I think about what my life would’ve been like had I not read it. Plodding along like I do, blissfully ignorant of this amazing book. So thank you, Emily.Secondly, I’m going to be honest and admit that it took me months to read it, because of the confusing start, and if not for Emily nagging me, I would’ve taken longer. I distinctly remember the day I made the decision to just finish it once and for all, because I was sick of having it on my bedside table. I picked it up again after firmly telling myself not to bitch out this time and that night, after passing the half way mark where things start making more sense, I finished it. And then I sat on my bed, thought about it for a while, flicked through it again and started bawling my eyes out. And so my love affair with On The Jellicoe Road began.Here’s some dot points on the things that I love about Jellicoe, because I can tell I’m going to start rambling soon if I don’t provide some sort of structure to this post:- It has one of the – actually no; probably THE most intriguing introductions I’ve ever read. Not that I can say this for myself, as I’ve already confessed it took me a while to read it originally, but from the numerous re-reads since then, it reels me in like no other introduction ever has, despite already being familiar with the story.- The plot: the intricacies of the two intertwining storylines, while initially confusing, is such a brilliant concept and it adds an air of mystery to the story, which I love.- The inclusion of lyrics from one of my favourite songs: Flame Trees by Cold Chisel.- The power of the feels: the way it makes my heart hurt, my eyes leak and my toes curl in a way few other books do.So there you go. I did try, but no words will ever be enough to accurately describe my feelings about this book. It is just… *sighs*

My cynicism towards books EVERYONE loves keeps getting proven wrong. Dang. Somehow I feel like I should be above the opinion of everyone else, and yet everyone else keeps being right. Now I sound like I think I'm superior. I don't think that. I just... Aw, heck. I don't know. I quit. I started Jellicoe Road being confused, which seems to be a common sentiment. I read the Prologue and was like, "Oh. Interesting." Then I started reading about these other people who had seemingly no connection to the prologue, other than the road name. Clue #1 that I was in for a confusing read.Clue #2 was that Taylor didn't know her dad/her mom abandoned her. I've come to learn that if any kind of deal is made out of this, we will be searching for them in some form, which leads to a confused Rachel. Clue #3 was this mysterious trip to Yass with a Cadet that kept being mentioned. Clue #4 was the war between the Jellicoe students, Cadets, and Townies. I don't get war. (This concludes my clue list, I promise.)It took me a good hundred pages to really get into Jellicoe Road, but when it happened, boy did it hook me. Once I had my bearings, Melina Marchetta certainly took me on a ride. She had me hooked, and I was her slave until I understood everything. Now, I don't give away storylines, because that would utterly ruin the book.Taylor is an utterly wonderful protagonist. She is exactly what I've come to expect from Melina Marchetta. She's strong-willed and tough, but hurting on the inside, just waiting for someone to unlock that part of her and be willing to listen. She's innately a good person, but rough around the edges and definitely has her flaws. And ohhhhhhhh Jonah. I really didn't think I was going to like him, until we met him. He's definitely my kind of lurveee interest. He's tough and manly, but protective and loving. :) :) :) :) :) He didn't fail to make me smile and/or swoon.As I've said before, I'm not really a big mystery fan, but this felt different. It didn't have the same danger, I guess, that most mysteries have. There was a distinct urgency to it, like if things weren't figured out quickly, there would be repercussions. This was quite true, but I didn't know it at the time.Most of what I can say is that Jellicoe Road is absolutely as good as everyone says it is and more. It's funny and poignant, joyful and tragic, magnificent and heart-breaking. If you're a fan of literally anything about books, it is absolutely worth your time.

Jellicoe Road by Melina Marchetta is one hard book to review, folks. I read it for the first time a couple of years ago and just recently read it again because I couldn’t quite help myself. I’m happy to say that absolutely nothing was lost in the reread. The emotional intensity and deeply felt sense of loss remained the same despite the fact that I know how the story weaves itself together.I know a lot of people who haven’t read the book get frustrated because all the reviews they read are so vague and mysterious. All I have to say to that is: Welcome to Jellicoe Road. The mystery that unfolds inside this story is incredibly deep and personal.I don’t really even know how to write a review without being ridiculously intense about the whole thing. I also feel like I should dig out a thesaurus so I don’t throw around the words “intense,” “powerful” and “emotional” too often. Because let me tell you, the book is all of those things.When you start reading the stories of the present day Taylor Markham along with the mysterious past narrations woven together by five friends – you’ll start out confused. Then, around half-way you’ll think “oh, I’ve got this figured out.” And sure, some of the pieces are easy to connect. But don’t think that doesn’t mean the story is without twists and turns – because you’re wrong. Also, don’t think that knowing how some of the pieces fit mean you won’t feel anything when the book finally brings them together. Because you’ll be wrong then too. No matter what you think you know, I can promise you at some point you will be affected. Heart broken. Mind blown.Also, no matter how many times it gets said, it deserves to be said again: Jonah Griggs is pretty much a god. He does have imperfections which are nicely highlighted, but it just makes him seem more real. Even though I normally scoff when high school aged relationships get too intense, I can say with no hesitation whatsoever that this is an exception.I would give a lot to see a sequel with these characters, but their story has been told. I don’t feel that there were any loose ends or pieces left unfinished. Darn shame. After creating these beautiful characters for us, the least Melina Marchetta could have done was give us a little more time with them.This book is definitely an experience y’all, and I could probably go on about it forever. If you haven’t read it – make time to do so. Feel free to thank me afterwards!

As I look at the books I have read in the last few months, I notice a common trait: an exclusive group of friends. The Secret History, The Likeness, rereading Harry Potter (oh the Marauders!), and now On the Jellicoe Road. There is something so captivating about being pulled into the nuanced balanced of a friendship. For we get to see the intimacy, the connections, the interests, the quirks, the loves…the secrets…the slight wobble to the balance….and the pressure pressing on the thin cracks. For just as I care deeply about Taylor Markham in Jellicoe Road, I also care deeply about Tate, Narnie, Jude, Fitz, and Webb, a group of friends who meet amidst a devastating accident and whose story is slowly revealed throughout the course of the novel. Marchetta deftly unravels the story for us and we are piecing together this history alongside Taylor. I kept reading to get to the next glimpse into their lives (just as I would anticipate the next time I could go inside the pensieve and see the Marauders in action.) Each moment that's revealed is a short, weighty jewel. For those who have read it, all I have to say is "Fitz and the tree" and you know how skilled Marchetta is with weaving emotion into moments without becoming sappy or obvious. There are so many hints throughout the entire book, so if the beginning is confusing, wait, patient reader! For Marchetta is just showing you all the threads before she weaves them deftly together. While I was entranced by the Five, I also loved getting to know Taylor Markham. Marchetta has the ability to create flawed and hurting characters who are strong and vulnerable, which allows for insights into brokenness and healing. Taylor is struggling to figure out why events have happened in her life and she is seeking answers, desperately, and we are invited in on this personal adventure. And Jonah Griggs. He compliments and encourages and builds a friendship with Taylor that strengthens them both. While their relationship slowly develops, it does not completely take over the story. Also, the author's depiction of Jellicoe Road and the Australian bush are gorgeous. I love when I feel like I get to travel to a place through the words an author skillfully paints. Poppies and canopy trees now flourish in my imagination.

Five star read. "On the Jellicoe Road" deserves every star and every accolade it's received in my opinion, and even as this is my first Marchetta read, I hope to read more of her works to come. This is a heart-wrenching novel; it's hard not to feel for each of the characters that are presented here. You feel every ounce of pain, relief, triumph and failure between each of the characters, and Marchetta captures emotion very well in the course of the story. I'm glad that I took the recommendation given to me to read it.Don't get me wrong, when I say that the first 100 or so pages are hard to get through - they are. There are many characters to keep track of, at least two storylines that seem to occur at once, and many threads strewn along each of those individual stories. I'll admit I actually stopped and started this novel a few times. For the patient reader, however, whether they're an elder teen or adult, the payoff is huge - it comes together beautifully. Ultimately the storylines merge in a potent display of emotion, history, and self-discovery. 17-year-old Taylor Markham is the center of it all. After her mother abandons her at a 7-11 when she's only 11, Taylor finds herself taken under the wing of Hannah, and attends the Jellicoe Road school nearby. But when Hannah disappears unexpectedly, leaving Taylor in charge of the younger students in her house and dealing with a turf war, she realizes that she must face aspects of her past as well as the story that Hannah has written and left behind in order to find the key to her future, and being able to move on from some tramuatizing events. I'll admit that I cried in a few places within the novel, because the pain Taylor feels with discovering the truths and unearthing things about her past that she would rather not think about are vivid and very real. Another thing I enjoyed about the novel was watching the steadily growing relationship between Taylor and Jonah Griggs - it feels vivid, realistic, and plausible, and I couldn't help but love the way their characters interacted, even through the moments where they clashed and took into account their difficult history with each other.Honestly one of the best novels I've read in recent years, not just in the young adult category, but among any genre. Overall score: 5/5

Two days later, and I can still get teary just thinking about it. I don't even know where to start in a review of this fabulous book. It was so emotionally potent; I can't even begin to describe the power it held over me, a power that I can only assume would be just as significant for any reader.Taylor Markham, like so many characters in literature, is trying so desperately to discover herself and her past. She is piecing together bits and pieces of past experiences of not only her own, but of the children who once lived at Jellicoe Road years before. She is trying to find out who she really is, what her purpose may be, and where her roots derive from. Her progress at first feels a little tedious, but by the end you are immersed and on board with every single decision and discovery she makes.Jonah, is without a doubt a truly swoonworthy character. On some level, I wish he was developed a bit more, or at least on a similar level to some of the side characters from Jellicoe's past, but that does not discount the development and value he did have. That is what is so amazing about Melina Marchetta. You may not get everything you want, but you can't help but feel so much confidence in her inherent skill as a writer that you know she wanted to you to think that extra step, wishing to know more about a character, and knowing that you know enough to make him or her truly remarkable. Melina Marchetta, once again weaves a fabulously enriched story that may start out a little slow, but builds so gradually and with such subtly that by the end, when it finally truly slams into you, you can't help but feel for every character involved. From Taylor, to Jonah, Narnie, Webb, Tate, Jude, and even Jessa, you feel each progressive emotional impact like a personal hit to the soul. Like I said it starts slowly, but once you meet a character revelation, I, at least, was overwhelmed with such deep seated feeling, and it didn't stop there. It continued and built until the very last word of the very last sentence of the very last page. I was almost inconsolable with tears that borderlined between absolute tragic desolation and uninhibited joy. I can't believe it took me so long to finally pick up this book, but I am so very happy I did.

I honestly don't know what to say about this book. My words lost along the pages. It messed my head and my heart. I don't think I need to describe how awesome this book is. You can read it from other reviews. This is mostly about my thought and feeling after I read it.It started with an unconvincing story, at least for me. The prologue was good. It has mystery vibe that made me wanted to enter chapter one immediately. But then I had trouble, big one, in first third chapters. I was overwhelmed with all those names and things that happened at the same time. And they felt like they didn't connect with each other, though I know that they must be connected. Long story short, I was frustrated and confused.As my friends said it is indeed confusing but it was worth it. So I reread first three chapters slowly and tried to absorb it. They were right, it got better for me and I can see the story clearer this time.The thing is there are three different stories in this book; the prologue story, about five students; the main character’s, Taylor Markhman, story and a story about her dream. So you see? Even her dream makes an interesting story.They intertwine each other. What seems didn't have connection in the beginning slowly make a dot along the way. It made me easier to connect those dots but when it truly happened I wished it happen differently, because it was so sad it broke my heart. It didn't mean that it's predictable, though. There are surprises that I think will leave you speechless.At the end of the page, I can assure you that it was so worth it. The confused, the anger, the sadness were worth it. And when you feel all those feeling, don't stop. Just hang in there like Taylor hangs in on her memory to reveal her true identity, because that way you'll find an amazing story that will linger, no matter how hurtful the story is.*picture from http://couldveshapedheartaches.tumblr.

It’s been a long time since a book has affected me so deeply, making my heart race, my tears flow, and my gut wrench.Clearly the plethora of awards for this book make a strong statement for the quality of Marchetta’s writing. Her ability to paint an emotional picture is what makes this book so remarkable. She doesn’t even describe what most of the characters look like; no “grey eyes and lush brown hair” like every other book I read because she doesn’t need those details. She paints her characters by who they are on the inside, who they are in their deepest sense. This book takes its readers on an emotional journey filled with great mystery, so much mystery that I really had no idea what was going on for the first 30% of the book. There are many characters and a slowly intricate weaving of their life stories, complete with tragedy, great love and laughter, desperation and self-discovery. Incredible. It was well worth the wait of slogging through the confusion in the beginning of the book.Despite all of the tragedy, this really is a story of hope. No matter what happens, there is always a way to pick up the pieces. The bonds of friendship and love are so powerful, even when one tries to run away from them."What are you so sad about?" Santangelo says to me. "We're going to know him for the rest of our lives."(view spoiler)[
  “What happens when she's not my memory anymore? What happens when she's not around to tell me about his belt leaving scars across my two-year-old brother's face or when he whacked her so hard that she lost her hearing for a week? Who'll be my memory?"Santangelo doesn't miss a beat. "I will. Ring me.""Same," Raffy says.I look at him. I can't even speak because if I do I know I'll cry but I smile and he knows what I'm thinking.”
(hide spoiler)]I haven’t cried slowly and steadily over a book in a long time, and am grateful to Melina Marchetta for reminding me of these most basic of raw emotions that live down in the deepest core of each and every one of us.

Five, five, five stars. I'd give this ten. I want to buy copies of this and give it to everyone I know. Be warned. This book will make you cry. I sat rocking back and forth sobbing as I reached the end. Melina Marchetta is simply one of the most gifted writers ever. She writes so wonderfully of things like grief and loss that it tears your heart out. Her characters are so well developed and real, you grow to care so much for them through the course of the novel and by the end you are a sobbing wreck of a human being...red-nosed and sniffling. Awesome.This book tells the story of Taylor Markham, aged seventeen. She was abandoned by her drug addicted mother at age eleven and rescued from the Seven-Eleven by Hannah. She attends the Jellicoe school, a boarding school where she is head of her house. She is in the middle of planning The War which is a yearly occurrence between kids at the Jellicoe School, the Townies and the Cadets, who come back year after year to camp in the woods near the school. Hannah has disappeared, the only adult Taylor trusts and she is desperate to find out what happened to her. I diddid find the first seventy or so pages a bit confusing as Taylor's story is mixed up with the story of five teenagers who lived on Jellicoe Road eighteen years ago, named Narnie, Tate, Webb, Fitz and Jude. Taylor also has dreams of a boy with no name up in a tree which adds a bit to the confusion. Now that I have finished the book and I know all I wonder why I was baffled by this. I actually started reading this in June. I put it down because I found it so confusing. I picked it up this morning determined to give it another go. I'm so glad I did. I finished it in a few short hours and cried my eyes out. It makes cranky that not everyone has read this book. Melina Marchetta should be a gazillionaire. And I'm eternally grateful to Goodreads as I never would have heard of this book or this wonderful author if I hadn't joined. Thank you Goodreads and thank you book reviewers for getting the word out.

another Marchetta book, another five stars. trying to be as unspoilery as possible!: Jellicoe was a little slower to get into for me, but you can see how this book starts out loose, with all these widely, thinly spread-out stories (part of the reason I think it took me a while to settle), and then how they start pulling in and twisting together and tightening in a way that tightens you, if that makes sense. it's compressing. I didn't cry but there were many points that I had to put the book down to process or work past something. I love getting to react like that.watching things start to fit is incredible. with any other writer this could feel contrived and way too much of a stretch, but there are very specific connecting points and so many things that happen that rely on these people being the people that they are, and it's fantastic. and as thick as this gets (especially compared to her other non-fantasy books) the core of it is (like, again, all of her other books), these kids and their relationships with each other. misc. things - because I don't want to say much more - I really loved the two main stories here, and I love that Marchetta tells stories about friendships and love that form foundations and homes, things that stick to you and can break you and fundamentally change you. there's a caring for these people from these people that I adore. and you can tell this story's written between Francesca and Finnikin, I think; she shifts away a lot from explicitly-said love, plainly-said feelings, and there's a lot of little things I loved catching on my own. the last line of the book (pre-epilogue) against the last line of the prologue made me put my book away so I could wail. also! it took me a while to understand what exactly the set-up of this story was, and I LOVE IT when authors let me fumble around for a while. she did the same with Finnikin, it makes me so happy.

Score: 4.5 starsThis book is simply fantastic. Well-written and heart-wrenching and honest and engaging, I can honestly see why so many people love it. The story was a bit confusing at the beginning, the pace sometimes slowed to a crawl and sometimes I got annoyed at how deliberately vague the author was, but I really, really liked it and strongly recommend it. I really look forward to reading more things by this author. At first, I had given this book 4 stars. Then I gave it 5. Then I went back and left it at 4 for a couple of days. And finally, after much debate, I decided to give it 5 stars based on one thing alone: I can't get it out of my head. I might just happen to catch a glance of it on my bookshelf as I leave my room or I might even be reading another book or browsing titles to buy next, but Jellicoe Road is lodged inside my head and, when it decides to let itself be known in there, it takes up all of my attention and I can't help thinking of it fondly. I loved the relationship between Taylor and Johna, their interactions and the chemistry between them. I loved Taylor's development and I absolutely adored the way the her story entwined with the other one been told. You might see the plot twits coming from a mile away, but it speaks very highly of a book and an author when seeing the twist from a mile away does not in any way ruin the reading experience, the quality of the story or your overall impression of it. This story is one of self-discovery and self-appreciation, of forgiveness and understanding and I truly believe the author did a marvelous job presenting them and making the reader live them through the characters. This is really a marvelous book and one I don't expect to forget about any time soon.

Bueno he leido este libro debido a Lucia Lorena, ella lo recomienda mucho en su canal y deben hacerle caso. Gracias por recomendarlo. Se que ella me ha dicho que no iba a entender nada al principio... efectivamente, no he entendido nada, pero igual al seguir leyendo uno va entendiendo. Al igual que lucia creo que este libro debe ser leído sin saber mucho de él por que no es lo que esperas. Realmente te deja marcada y esto e por todas las verdades impactantes que ocurren el libro, eso se debe tener muy claro, puesto que este libro no consiste en muchos plot twist, sino mas bien en unir que pasa en las historias que se cuentan y se van uniendo y las verdades impactantes que se dan en el libro.Mi puntuación le he dado un 5 de 5 como se ha visto, pero le daría en realidad un 4, 6 o 4.7 y esto es por que a pesar de lo mucho que me ha encantado lo últimos 5 o 6 caps se me hicieron muy novela de tv no se por que, pero podía escuchar una de esas canciones al final de una telenovela con satisfacción de que todo (como sea que haya salido) saldrá bien por el resto dela vida de los personajes.Ame a cada uno de los personajes,creo que cada uno tiene su esencia y no les cambiaría nada.Un consejo, si lo lees con atención te darás cuenta muy rápido de mas o menos todo aunque con algunas intrigas.Confieso que tuve mucho momento fangirl y que he tenido mini paros cardíacos por el libro. Definitivamente es un lectura que añadiré a los mejores libros que me he leído en la vida, lo he amado completamente y no se pero para releerlo. Considero una de esas lecturas indispensables y lo bueno es que te atrapa desde el inicio así no se entienda nada.

I can't believe it's taken me until now to read this. I've loved every Marchetta novel (I've read them all now, bar the last two in the Lumatere Chronicles, which I'm saving), and I can honestly say this is - hands down - my favourite.I was warned by my blogging buddies that On the Jellicoe Road would undo me, so I at least went in prepared. And it has undone me, completely. And not just because it is bittersweet and heartbreaking, but because it so life affirming. A beautiful story of family, friendship, redemption, forgiveness and hope.The characters...all of them compelling. Taylor and Jonah. What can I say: I could read their scenes for hours.There's beautiful writing, a breathtaking sense of place (in the bush and the city), sharp dialogue and a page-turning mystery about what's really going on.The story unfolds in rich layers - much like the characters. The reveals when they come are not so much bombshells as inevitable connections. And in the end, it's not the twists that are compelling, but the way the characters respond to them.Since finishing this book a few hours ago, I've read some stunning reviews here on Goodreads, so I know there's nothing I can add to describe the power and brilliance of this book.I borrowed my copy from the library. I'll be buying my own as this is one I'll definitely be reading again.

Here's the thing: Melina Marchetta is good. She's really good.This book takes a lot of getting used to. If you're having a hard time reading it, my advice is to just wait it out. Get past the first 100 pages, and I promise it'll all be worth it.This is the kind of book that keeps you up at five in the morning, just begging to be finished. It doesn't care that you need to get up early in the morning. It doesn't care that you need to entertain guests the next day and that, maybe, you don't want circles under your eyes that are darker than the inside of a Hollister. Absolutely no consideration from this book. Zero. Nada. Nill. Jellicoe Road is captivating, enigmatic, beautiful, and so very tragic. It's well-written and fascinating, with three-dimensional characters that will make you happy, sad, and everything else in between. I'm a little worried that it won't fly with its target audience since Melina Marchetta isn't exactly household name, but let it be known that this is probably the best YA contemporary I've ever read. There's also a 110% chances that I'm in love with Jonah Griggs, but I'm pretty sure Melina Marchetta can make me head over heels about a brick wall, so take that as you will.

This is the most impressive book I have read in 2013 so far, and it managed to get very high on my all-time favourites list. It also marked a first for me: I read it twice, back to back. It took me a couple of chapters to get into it and understand what's going on, but from that point on I was totally engrossed. I loved the story and the writing so much that I went back to the beginning and read it again, paying attention to every little detail and taking it all in. I had more tears in my eyes the second time around... It's a beautiful and heartbreaking tale of friendship and love, that's all I am going to say. I have a problem though with this book being labelled as young adult, which does it a disservice and limits its audience... It can certainly be read by older teens, but I would say adults would enjoy it more and understand it better. Same goes for Saving Francesca and The Piper's Son. Melina Marchetta is a fantastic author and her books deserve to be better known!

I'm usually very good about writing my reviews the day after I finish a book. I have been putting this review off for days! I just really don't know what to say about it but I'm going to try my best to write a decent review.Jellicoe Road starts of....I want to say slow but that's not true. It starts off very fast and doesn't wait for you to catch up. The first 100 pages or so I was like "Huh?" but then everything started coming together and I could not put it down after that.The book is about Taylor Markham. A girl in charge of her side of the territory wars and abandoned by her mother. She has to battle the Cadets and the Townies and take care of all the girls in her dorm. But who will take care of her?This book was like nothing I have ever read before. Marchetta's writing is incredible. The plot unfolds beautifully. Melina weaves the past into the story right along side Taylor's story. All the characters are expertly written. This book is intense, heartbreaking, beautiful and just.....wow! Those are the only words I have. Read this book!

Im afraid I can't give a proper review for this book because its been more than a week since i finished and I've forgotten some things. I was waiting for the perfect moment to write a great review because this book deserved it, so now i hate myself. But anyway here's what i remember;-I REALLY ENJOYED THIS BOOK! OMG 4.6 STARS!- definitely a unique and refreshing YA contemporary- the first few chapters were hell to get through because they were so confusing and didn't make sense, but the moment things start to place together i was addicted to know more- ALL THE TWISTS, LIKE WHAT. There's a whole past mystery trying to be solved throughout the book while a whole present plot is being told, and it's just pure Marchetta genius how she put it all together.- THE FRIENDSHIPS ARE ALL THE SQUAD GOALS!- definitely a book you HAVE to reread, because you probably missed the clues at the start. Im definitely planning to read it again soon.Highly recommended!

First Read Through- October 2011Second Read Through- July 2013Writing-5Storyline/Plot-5Characters-5Overall- 5-This book is...absolutely AMAZING! That is all I can say! You have to read it for yourself to understand why!So. First off, I love the idea for the territory wars. I love how the story explains how it started off, and what it really meant! I love the idea of a story in a story! The fact that we get to hear Taylor's story, but then also the story that Hannah is writing about her life!I loved all the characters and OMGSHH Taylor and Jonah!! I loved there growing relationship!You have the story told from Taylor's point, but it also switched to a story that is being written by Hannah. Her manuscript, and pieces of it are throughout the book. At first it's confusing but then as you progress it all comes together.So much to say about this book, but the final thing is...you NEED to read this book!Check it out- http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r69ozt...

Wow! Just wow. I'm not really sure what else to say. I had a really, really hard time getting into this book, and I'm glad for the reviews that warned readers to stick with it and get past the first 125 pages. I recently became a fan of Melina Marchetta after reading Finnikin of the Rock and was so excited to get a copy of Jellicoe Road. I was not disappointed! I now understand why Marchetta wrote the beginning the way she did, so readers, just go with it and keep reading! I promise it all comes together and everything get wrapped together in the end. I think it was around pg 200 that I didn't want to put this book down and stayed up to all hours of the night/morning reading. Loved it. Now I just want to reread it...

First five stars of the year and not a whole lot to say.What else can you say really, this book is simply incredible and I honestly can't find words that do justice to it.It was not an easy read, for the first 20-25% I had no clue what was going on, everything was so confusing and almost nonsense, that I was about to give up. I'm glad I didn't. I'm so, so glad. Marchetta has created a devastatingly beautiful story, one full of love and grief, friendship and family bonds, all together wrapped in an enthralling mystery revealed piece by piece.A story that made me laugh and cry, that leave me high and heartbroken and, by the end, it turned me into a bawling mess. Definitely this is one of the best book i've ever read (best YA for sure).I can not recommend it enough, just read it. It maybe a struggle to get into, but I assure you'll end up loving it.

I can't write a review for this book because I was left in tears and feeling emotionally raw. I just have to say: read it.(Update 9/21/14) I never thought that a second reading of a book would leave me more raw than the first time I finished it. Jellicoe Road, though, is a story that is told in layers and each layer is unfolded in a different, more beautiful way with each reading. Knowing how Narnie, Jude, Webb, Tate and Fitz story ends and how Taylor, Griggs, Raffy, Santangelo, and Ben grow into these wonderful people made my second reading that much more powerful. I still can't speak eloquently or wax poetic when I talk about Jellicoe Road, but it will forever be stitched into my heart and soul. It's a story that will break you into little pieces and leave you unsure if you want the pieces put back together. Again: READ. IT.

"I stand up and walk towards her, because my days of waiting for more are over. If I want more, I need to go and get it, demand it, take hold of it with all my might and do the best I can with it."I've just finished this book and I feel as if I have woken from a beautiful dream. I'm struggling to hold on to the memory of it. I'm refusing to re-enter the real world. I want to fall asleep and immerse myself back in this world. I miss it.This is a tender, tragic, heartbreaking, beautiful, wonderful story. It's about relationships, friendships, life and love. It will make you reminisce about your own past relationships, friendships and history. It will make you miss people and moments in your life you didn't realise you missed. It will make you appreciate how beautiful and precious life is. People are good. Life is good. It will leave you feeling wondrous and hopeful.

This book ripped me open inside. No, I’m not being dramatic. It is gut wrenchingly beautiful and heartbreaking, filled with hope, love, mystery, and incredible enduring. I’ve never read anything like this before and it is going front and centre on my “Favorites” shelf. If you decide to read Jellicoe Road and you find that the beginning is a little bit slow and lots of confusing...just do me a favor, please? Don’t quit. Just hang in there and keep reading. There will come a point where you’ll look back and realize that things are finally starting to make sense and you just can’t get yourself to put it down. By the time I was reading the epilogue, I was crying buckets of tears and my heart was shattered, but good heavens, I would read this work of genius again and again. What an indescribably unparalleled novel!

Este libro habla de muchas historias en una, y de muchas cosas a la vez. Su complejidad y su intensidad me abruma; tanto al punto que no sé cómo me siento al terminarlo... Estoy en shock. No sé cómo procesar toda esta información... Me siento feliz y a la vez triste. Tengo un sabor agridulce. Creo que más me siento triste... y a la vez siento que este es el mensaje que me dió: La vida es así. Altibajos. Siempre esperamos más... y no nos atrevemos a tomarlo. También creo que habla sobre el miedo, sobre el amor, la amistad, el miedo a desaparecer y consumirte por la tristeza... Por el temor a perder ese algo que te anclaba a la vida.El camino de Jellicoe une muchas cosas... el camino más bonito del que he leído...

Originally reviewed here.This book is such a mind-refresher. As the reader, you have to put together all of the pieces to get the whole story. We’re in Taylor’s mind, finding out the truth as she finds it. I love mysteries, so this is definitely an A+ book in my… book!I liked the idea of the territory wars, even though it was just a game. It forced these teenagers into adult/political roles. There were some scary things that happened with this subplot (can I call it that?), but all-in-all, it was interesting to see how these leaders interacted.I just really like this book! Melina Marchetta did an AMAZING job. I want to read more of her books!

I was very afraid that I wouldn't get this book, but I wasn't as confused as I expected to be. I like how Marchetta played with the intertwining story lines and sort of keeps you guessing all the way through. It's brilliant. Taylor is probably the most lost of all Melina Marchetta protagonist, though there's always Tom Mackee, so I feel like a reread of all the books is in order to make a sound judgement on that. The same goes for whether Jonah Griggs now takes top spot as favourite Marchetta boy (though again, there's always Tom and also Froi).Read the rest on The Random Transliterator

( 4.25 stars )I absolutely loved this book. The relationships were brilliant and the story was very engaging. It took me three sittings to finish this book and well, It was time well spent.However, the first 30-40 pages were very confusing and I am glad that I didn’t abandon the book then. (Yay!)The story very much resembles a jigsaw puzzle and the author doesn’t really wrap everything up in a neat bow at the end. It took me a lot of back and forth to fit all the pieces and answer all of the relevant questions and it was a complete treat.The serial killer arc was hilarious (only when it wasn’t - Jeez 😟🤯) And my favourite characters ? well of course Ben and Santangelo! X)

user_name: Tessamari ♥Many Waters...♥ ~ Sweet Spot Book Blog
text: Five Stars :)Thank you to my GR friends who recommended this book to me. It was a fantastic read. It took a little bit of time to get going and figure out what was going on, but once it got going, it really got going. I LOVED all the characters in this book, especially our H/h Taylor and Jonah. But then again, there are actually more heroes and heroines in this book. There's actually two stories going on, but they are all connected to each other. This story had me smiling, shocked, and on the verge of tears. Excellent, excellent read! Loved it :)

If I could give this book more than 5 stars, I would. It was absolutely brilliant, a remarkable story about loss, grief, redemption, and love. It is a beautifully told story, and is surprisingly funny at times given some of the darker subject matter. A couple of great love stories in here as well. I rarely get emotional when I read books, but I was crying like a baby at the end, it was so moving.I've seen several comments about it starting off slow, but I did not find that. Maybe compared to other YA it is not as action packed at first, not sure.

First Read: July 2, 2012Re-Read #1: June 26, 2015Re-Read #2: May 2, 2020For the first 80 or so pages, I was so confused. I’d heard about the amazingness that was Melina Marchetta, but I just wasn’t seeing it. What did everyone else see that I was missing?Read my full review at So Obsessed With!

Esto es lo más parecido a realismo mágico que he leído en un YA, y me encantó! La pregunta es: ¿en qué pensaba la gente de Hollywood cuando decidieron hacer la película de Looking for Alaska y no de esto? No me lo puedo explicar. Las escenas de "guerra", el suspenso, el romance, la amistad, los personajes, la escritura, ame todo! Este libro es como Jonah Grigg: un estado de ánimo. De los que quieres que te duren por siempre.

I laughed. I cried. And I fell a little (or a lot) in love with every single character. What an excellent book. (Although by the end I totally forgot this story started off being about territory wars). 4.5 stars.Let’s see how this holds up to my high praise 8 years later. (Spoiler alert: it totally will).Welp. Here I am, 4 am. Crying like a child because this book is even better than the first time around.

Brilliant. I don't have the words to do justice to this book. It was beautifully written with so much passion and feeling behind every word, each phrase and every telling of the various parts and pieces that make up this story. I don't know how to describe how it made me feel, other than to say this book was utterly, completely and totally brilliant.

ALL THE STARS.Seriously.ALL OF 'EM.Melina Marchetta, you are perfection. I want you to adopt me and...and...and we'll see the rest when we get there.This is me getting down on my knees and begging you to just adopt me god dammit. I clam up when I write reviews for you. What kinda powers do you possess? Do share.

All the hype for this book is on point and true. I love every single word of it. All the characters. All the stories. All the relationships and connections that were between everyone. And it all completely gutted me along the way. This is a book that I will want to pick up over and over again. Also.....GRIGGS <3

This is the kind of rare book that hits every note with without being self-conscious. It's easily one of the best books I've ever read. I'll still be thinking about it tomorrow, next month, probably a year from now.

fantastic.i finished this yesterday and my assessments on next week and usually i dont read for a month before my exams but what the hell THIS ONE. i WILL reread this and this is the highest praise i can give to a book. bravo, melina marchetta.

Eu não sei nem o que falar porque todas as palavras dentro de mim nunca serão o suficiente pra descrever a perfeição que é esse livro. Tão delicado, mas tão pesado. Tão puro. Tão bonito e tão triste.Sonhei com a estrada Jellicoe essa noite. Espero sonhar muitas outras vezes.
Aceasta e cea mai buna carte YA pe care am citit-o pana acum.
No words, just feelings... (●´□`)♡
THAT WAS SO SAD BUT I loved it
My first book by Melina Marchetta and loved loved loved it. I am now a big fan and will be reading all her books. This one pulled at my heartstrings. It's beautiful and amazing.
Wow. I feel gutted, in a wonderful, achy kind of way. I think I need to reread.

This was a great book! I loved the little things you don't pick up on a first. I think this was the saddest book I have ever read. But it was really good.
This is such an emotional roller coaster with an incredibly rich story. I need to read it again to fully appreciate the tale.

If I could give this book ten stars, I would. Absolutely LOVED this one!
